And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BOOK OF HAPPINESS, by Nina Berberova. (New Directions, $23.95.) Set in the years surrounding the Russian Revolution, this novel of passionate candor allows its characters to love without irony and to speak ingenuously about what they really want (including happiness).
 
THE BROKEN ESTATE: Essays on Literature and Belief, by James Wood. (Random House, $24.) A combative, polemical critic examines the transition from religious belief to literary belief in the 19th century and its sequels down to our time.
 
THE COLONY OF UNREQUITED DREAMS, by Wayne Johnston. (Doubleday, $24.95.) An eloquent biographical anti-epic novel whose protagonist, the nebbishy but effectual Joseph Smallwood, betrays its real hero, the great, mysterious island of Newfoundland, into incorporation with Canada.
 
THE DISTANCE TO THE MOON: A Road Trip Into the American Dream, by James Morgan. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The author sets out to see the U.S.A. in his Porsche in a cross-country travelogue that explores the enduring relationship between man and his real best friend, the automobile.
 
IN SEPTEMBER, THE LIGHT CHANGES: Stories, by Andrew Holleran. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Finely made stories, sharply awake to the idioms, cadences and concerns of gay life in the late 20th century, obsessionally aware of the passing of friends, health and youth.
 
JEM (AND SAM), by Ferdinand Mount. (Carroll & Graf, $25.95.) A rollicking novel of the Restoration, told from the viewpoint of one Jeremiah Mount (in real life a drinking buddy of Samuel Pepys and a possible progenitor of the author), who, though gripped by a professional envy that would stagger Salieri, comes at last to find saving grace in failure.
 
SAINT AUGUSTINE, by Garry Wills. (Lipper/ Viking, $19.95.) An informed rendering of the life and thought of the small-town African (A.D. 354-430) who became the most durable of theologians; usefully translated from the Churchly (for "Confessions," read "Testimony").
 
STILL WATERS IN NIGER, by Kathleen Hill. (Triquarterly/Northwestern University, $24.95.) Memory and anxiety are intertwined in a lyrical autobiographical novel, set in West Africa, that illuminates the losses and lapses of motherhood.
 
WALKER EVANS, by James R. Mellow. (Basic Books, $40.) An evocative biography, posthumously published, that captures in Evans a private heartlessness belying the humanity of his photographs.
 
WHO DO YOU LOVE: Stories, by Jean Thompson. (Harcourt Brace, $23.) Emotional needs are rarely stated and more rarely met (romance and family don't help) in these quiet, devastating, all-downhill-from-here short stories.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1387 words

HEADLINE: Where Are the Beret Factories of Yesteryear?

BYLINE: By Alan Riding; Alan Riding is the European cultural correspondent of The Times, based in Paris.

 BODY:

FRANCE ON THE BRINK
 By Jonathan Fenby.
 449 pp. New York:
 Arcade Publishing. $27.95. 
 It has become commonplace to say that France is in trouble. Indeed, the French are the first to say so. They complain about high unemployment, mounting insecurity, corruption in public life, a political elite that has lost touch with the people, a state that is no longer guide and protector. In brief, they complain that they were promised something better. But that is the French talking. When Britons and Americans point to their troubles, the French are convinced they hear the sound of gloating.
Well, yes. Tired of being lectured on France's intellectual, cultural and moral superiority to the "Anglo-Saxons," some officials in London and Washington may well be deriving pleasure from France's comeuppance. But, in truth, the Anglo-Saxon view of France is more complicated. France enjoys a privileged place in the imagination of educated Britons and Americans precisely because it is so stubbornly different. They may argue that France must modernize its economy and political system, but they also mourn the passing of the old France; they too fear that a new France will be less French.
Jonathan Fenby speaks for this point of view. A veteran British journalist who married into a French family and began reporting from France in the mid-1960's, he clearly loves France. But in "France on the Brink," a forceful piece of reporting sprinkled with personal memories, he also sounds an alarm bell. Over the past three decades, he has seen France change a great deal -- and mainly for the worse. He wants to be optimistic, but he perceives "a nation at risk." France can remain truly special, he believes, only if it shows daring.
One reason France is such an appealing target for snipers is, of course, the high standard by which it judges itself and asks to be judged. That its traditional self-esteem is partly a result of historical amnesia and political mythmaking does not detract from the fact that it has a blessed geography, a remarkable history, rich cultural monuments and an enviable art de vivre. After the humiliation of World War II, it also developed a prosperous economy, created a vast welfare state, asserted its independence from Washington and joined Germany in building a new Europe.
But, as Fenby points out in his first chapter, "Something Special," the French have become obsessed with l'exception francaise. "France occupies an exclusive place in the world, and could accept nothing less," he writes. "It is, its President declares, a beacon for the human race. The nation and its people may be loved or hated, but they can never be ignored." Among a veritable potpourri of facts, anecdotes and eccentricities that prove the point, Fenby offers one delightful illustration of French scorn for Anglo-Saxon pragmatism. "It will work in practice, yes," a French diplomat is said to have remarked. "But will it work
in theory?"
This is a chapter that any newcomer to France is well advised to memorize: it is food for many a lively dinner table conversation. Indeed, the entire book serves as a valuable introduction to contemporary France. Fenby stops and looks at every corner of French society, contrasting how it was with what it has become; with an occasional glance back, he also tracks the swings of French politics since Charles de Gaulle founded the Fifth Republic in 1959. One theme runs through his story: "The conservative strain in French life has always been far stronger than the revolutionary images suggest."
Change has come, but it has rarely been welcomed. In a chapter called "Vanishing Madeleines," Fenby notes that the classic images of France -- beret, baguette, dark cigarettes, corner cafe, the accordion, garlic and the like -- have all lost ground in daily life: only three beret factories survive, most baguettes are made with frozen preconstituted dough, foreign cigarette brands account for almost half of total sales, cafes are closing at an alarming rate, only Romanian Gypsies now seem to play accordions and even garlic consumption is falling.
Fast food is by now well entrenched and, worse, embraced by many French as a useful short cut in rushed urban schedules. Business lunches and summer vacations are shrinking. French men may still have wandering eyes, but they have less time for mistresses. The convenience -- and lower prices -- of supermarkets have put many shopkeepers out of business in cities and, even more alarmingly, in villages, which are dying across France (albeit occasionally revived in a different form as summer havens for Parisians and northern Europeans).
The countryside, after all, is the repository of French nostalgia. Until 1945, 40 percent of France's population was still rural. Thus, rare is the city dweller who does not have a parent or grandparent born in some distant pays. Even now, Fenby notes, "French townspeople have more country homes than any other Europeans." And it is the countryside that provides the food and wines that remain so central to France's image of itself. "Rural France," Fenby says, "is a state of mind." Yet the reality is painful. As agriculture has modernized, small farms have closed and villages have been abandoned. Returning one August to a village that had known better times, Fenby recalls: "That used to be the busiest time of the year. But now all was silence. The square was deserted."
The pace quickens, though, when the author turns to the grim suburbs, or banlieues, of major cities, suburbs that have been transformed over the past 25 years by Arab and African immigration. The first generation of immigrants consisted in the main of solitary men with jobs. But by the time their wives and families joined them, jobs were harder to find. And now their children are rapidly forming an underclass living in project housing, unemployed, surrounded by drugs and violence. Fenby recounts familiar stories of gang warfare, race riots and ritual car burnings, but he also visits several banlieues and is left alarmed by the anger and despair he encounters. And, he notes, "Each banlieue riot involving young immigrants sends more votes to the far right."
When it comes to pointing fingers, however, Fenby does not hesitate. Whether it is France's failure to integrate immigrants and the commensurate rise of Jean-Marie Le Pen's far-right National Front, whether it is the growth of unemployment to a constant 11 percent of the work force, whether it is the spate of corruption scandals in public life, he sees the country's political elite as ultimately responsible. Today a few thousand politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen, many of them graduates of the exclusive ecole Nationale d'Administration, run France and, in Fenby's view, all too often they run it for themselves. And the French are beginning to notice.
NARROWING his target, Fenby then looks at how three men exercised the monarchical powers of the French presidency over the past 25 years. He is not impressed. But if he portrays Valery Giscard d'Estaing (1974-81) as a vainglorious snob and Jacques Chirac (1995 to the present) as something of a buffoon, he believes Fran-->ois Mitterrand (1981-95) was positively dangerous -- devious and unprincipled. "In opposition, his amorality could be excused as necessary in the pursuit of power," Fenby writes. "But once he had reached his summit, it got even worse. He simply did not seem to care about any real values."
Given what the future keeps bringing them, the French are understandably fearful of still more future. However, given their continued expectation that the state solve their problems, Fenby sees no alternative to looking again to the elite to find answers. He points the way: it must lead a nonviolent revolution, "which embraces the modern world while preserving the best of the past." He even harbors some hope that the current "cohabitation" between the conservative Chirac and his Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, will produce "a different kind of politics, which would be much less ideological, less a prisoner of the state, more open-minded -- and, dare one hope, less personalized." Yet he does not sound too sure. He demonstrates that he cares passionately for France, but he ends his book with France still "on the brink."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3531 words

HEADLINE: Who's Afraid of China?

BYLINE: By Patrick E. Tyler; Patrick E. Tyler, former Beijing bureau chief for The Times, is the author of "A Great Wall: Six Presidents and China," to be published in September.

 BODY:
On the night of Feb. 19, 1997, I was detained by a squad of Chinese policemen in a small town on China's border with Kazakhstan, which is about as far away as you can get from Beijing and still be in the country. The region is hauntingly beautiful, framed on the north and south by the snowy Mountains of Heaven, which overlook the arid plain where Chinese and Russian forces clashed so ferociously in 1969 that President Nixon thought nuclear war was going to break out between the two Communist giants.
I had flown to Kazakhstan in order to cross over the border into China and to return to Beijing via a long overland route that would take me through Yining, a remote city where Chinese Muslims had rioted during the holy month of Ramadan. Unfortunately, the Chinese had other plans for my trip. When the creaky bus I was in rolled across the no-man's land and up to the checkpoint on the Chinese side, I was asked to step out and show my papers. As soon as the guards saw my passport they set up a commotion, calling out, "Jizhe!" ("journalist"), as if I were an invader. They conducted a four-hour search of my luggage and, by the time the evening was over, I was shown to a hotel room whose door was then secured with a tractor chain and padlock. 
 Thus ensconced as a guest of the local Public Security Bureau, I dozed off, only to be awakened by the phone sometime after midnight. In a feat bordering on the miraculous, a colleague had managed to get a circuit through to tell me that China's state news agency had just reported the death of Deng Xiaoping.
In a panic at being so far away from the story I had been waiting to cover for five years, I persuaded a guard to open the door a crack. When he did, I pushed by him and ran into the night. Huffing along the Chinese highway under the weight of my bags, I gestured wildly at each set of headlights that pierced the blackness until I finally hitched a ride to Urumqi -- eight hours across the desert -- and caught the last plane heading east that afternoon.
Flying over the whole of China on the day that the Deng era ended, I was overcome with curiosity about the Chinese with whom I was traveling, and so I walked the aisles for the next two hours, introducing myself in imperfect Chinese and asking my fellow passengers their thoughts about the future. The answers I received reinforced for me not only how profoundly pragmatic the Chinese are, but also how misguided American perceptions about China have traditionally been -- and continue to be.
The Chinese on board -- merchants, traders and some Communist Party members -- were not seething with animosity toward the United States; they weren't even particularly suspicious of America. Instead, they were worried that Deng's death would weaken the Communist Party's commitment to a "socialist market economy," that it would undermine the successful economic revolution that the Chinese leader had begun nearly two decades earlier. These people were fearful that Deng's dictum, "To get rich is glorious," might be upended and that China would lapse back into the chaotic politics that characterized the Mao era.
How different these sentiments were from American perceptions at the time. For Americans, Deng was connected with the bloodshed at Tiananmen Square. Though the Chinese leader had charmed Americans during his 1979 state visit -- wearing a 10-gallon hat at a Texas rodeo and coming across as an impish Yoda -- that image was erased in a single bloody night. The June 1989 massacre, in which unarmed students were gunned down by Chinese troops, instantly created a new and seemingly indelible picture of China in the United States -- that of the repressive state.
The summer of 1999 seems in many ways to be a repeat of the summer of Deng's death, when American perceptions of China and Chinese perceptions of their own predicament were two huge Titanics passing in the night. In May Americans were swamped by images of riotous Chinese youths, their faces contorted by anger, throwing rocks and other projectiles at the American Embassy in Beijing in retaliation for NATO's mistaken bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
Then, a few weeks ago, Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, reopened the dangerous question of Taiwanese sovereignty -- is Taiwan part of China or not? In an interview, the Taiwanese leader appeared to proclaim that the doctrine of "One China" was dead as far as he was concerned. Beijing then answered with harsh language, giving rise to fears that the Chinese might be on the verge of engaging in the kind of ballistic-missile diplomacy that prompted President Clinton to dispatch two aircraft carriers to the region in 1996.
This was also the summer of the Cox committee report, the hasty product of an ideologically supercharged select committee of the House of Representatives led by Christopher Cox, Republican of California. The committee concluded that over a 20-year period, Chinese spies had stolen secrets for missiles, military weaponry and nuclear warheads from American weapons labs. The Chinese bounty included design elements for the neutron bomb and the W-88, a hydrogen bomb so compact that eight of them can be loaded into the nose cone of a submarine-launched Trident II missile.
The 700-page Cox committee report portrayed the People's Republic of China as nothing less than a voracious, dangerous and fully equipped military rival of the United States. "The P. R.C. will exploit elements of the stolen design information" to build strategic weapons that "will be able to strike the United States," the report stated. The report also asserted that "a modernized P. R.C. strategic nuclear-ballistic-missile force would pose a credible, direct threat against the United States."
That these fears are aroused so effortlessly is not surprising. Ever since the cry of "Who lost China?" ricocheted across our political landscape in 1949, a number of Americans have remained deeply suspicious of the People's Republic. Throughout the Korean War, the cold war and Vietnam, politicians turned this fear to their strategic advantage whenever they could. Even Richard Nixon, who staged the opening to China in 1972, made it an issue in the 1968 Presidential campaign, comparing China's revolutionaries to the "more explosive ghetto elements in our country."
Playing the China card has worked in our time too. Bill Clinton scored points in 1992 when he accused George Bush of "coddling dictators from Baghdad to Beijing." And China shows every sign of figuring prominently in the 2000 campaign. Armed with the Cox report, Republicans have already begun to chastise Democrats for courting Communist fund-raisers and indulging Chinese espionage at the nation's weapons labs.
There's just one problem: 1.3 billion Chinese have no interest in threatening America or in kicking U.S. forces out of Asia or in becoming an imperial power to dominate the region. Certainly, the Chinese are fiercely patriotic. Every time a foreigner says that Tibet ought to be an independent nation, or Taiwan should be allowed to declare a separate state, it incites an energetic response, for the Chinese see themselves as victims of ceaseless foreign invasion since the Opium Wars 150 years ago.
Nevertheless, if any generalization is to be made about 1.3 billion people, it would be that the Chinese want nothing more than to have a long period of peace and stability in which to develop their economy. The people I flew with that day in 1997, those I met and worked with during my five years in China, just want to get rich, as Deng exhorted them to do. That is why they are hustling, saving their money and investing as never before. And that is why it would be unthinkable for China's leaders to embark on an arms race with the United States. Prosperity at home and military expansionism abroad are fundamentally incompatible in China today.
Nowhere is this clearer than in the Yangtze River Valley, where the Chinese are building the largest hydroelectric structure in the world: the Three Gorges Dam. When completed, the controversial dam will provide nearly 10 percent of China's electrical output. Unfortunately, no one seems to know where China will get the financing to finish the project, and this is a source of great unease for the country's leaders.
China's growth depends on power -- power to run the factories that are booming in southern China, power to build new factories there and across the country. Indeed, just to keep pace with growth, China must construct approximately a dozen 1,000-megawatt power stations every year. (In America, one or two of these large stations is added a year -- at the most.)
The need for energy is not just economic -- it's demographic. In the next 30 years China's population is expected to grow by 400 million, bringing the total to 1.6 billion. In short, the Chinese need the dam and other infrastructure investments simply to stay afloat. Mindful of their Soviet counterparts, whose system collapsed because its leaders chose to invest in swords rather than plowshares, China's leaders understand that to embark on a military build-up would be nothing short of folly.
Economic imperatives are not the only reason China poses a limited threat to the United States. Strong language aside, attacking America has never been a centerpiece of Chinese doctrine.
I learned this firsthand from Hua Di, a Chinese rocket scientist who worked on the current generation of Chinese ICBM's. Hua Di came to the United States in 1989 for a conference and after the Tiananmen massacre decided to stay, because he had previously spoken out in favor of the pro-democracy movement. He is now in detention in China, accused of sharing information with Americans about China's weapons programs.
I first met Hua Di at Stanford in 1994. Back then, we would spend hours over bowls of rice in Bay Area Chinese restaurants, talking about politics, science and China's strategic objectives. Words burst out of Hua Di's mouth at great speed, and he once startled me by saying that Mao and his successors never gave much thought to selecting targets for China's nuclear missiles. The reason, he said, was that the missiles were purely retaliatory. According to Hua Di, all Mao cared about was that no nuclear strike on China would go unanswered. Whether the strike came from Russia, the United States or France, all Mao wanted was to be able to send a messenger by car, bicycle or horse to one of the caves or silos where China's ICBM's were hidden and to have that messenger whisper a single phrase to the missile commander -- The Chairman orders you to launch." The most China could hope for, Mao realized, would be one stinging shot back at its foe.
China's nuclear doctrine has certainly advanced since then, but with a no-first-use policy and adherence to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, China is not (nor has it ever been) the nuclear rogue that Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon once feared. China has never resorted to nuclear blackmail in its international relations; nor has it activated its nuclear forces in any military crisis.
Every year, a large gathering of specialists on the chinese military meets at a leafy resort to debate the intentions and capabilities of the Chinese military. Last year, the conclave took place at a venue more closely associated with the Middle East than with China: the Wye Plantation in Maryland. Gathered on the shores of the Chesapeake were experts from the intelligence, defense, diplomatic and academic communities, including John Culver, the C.I.A.'s top student of the People's Liberation Army, Michael D. Swaine of the Rand Corporation, Paul Godwin of the National Defense University and James R. Lilley, a former Ambassador to China.
The debate in Wye's plush conference rooms was contentious, but the consensus was clear: China is a backward military power that is gradually modernizing the portion of its military responsible for safeguarding its own backyard, including Tibet, Taiwan and whatever dominion China eventually negotiates for itself in the South China Sea.
Looking out over the next two decades, experts like Culver concede that China could seek to leapfrog its antiquated military technologies and develop modern weapons that would be more threatening to American interests and to U.S. forces in the Pacific. But today the evidence suggests that while China is working to master state-of-the-art technologies in its laboratories, it has little expertise and few resources to build the industrial base necessary to become a modern military power.
The Chinese Air Force is a case in point, with neither the factories nor the skilled work force to develop modern warplanes or keep them flying. For example, it was long rumored that China was on the verge of deploying a supersonic fighter: the F-10. But Chinese engineers could never get one to fly out of the barn. Eventually, in 1992, the air force gave up and purchased a few squadrons of Russian SU-27's at bargain-basement prices. In short, the B-2 Stealth bomber is not in China's future.
The Chinese Navy is in similar shape, hampered by an aging fleet and outmoded shipbuilding technology. After more than a decade of design and construction work, China did manage to send a prototype of its first strategic-ballistic-missile submarine to sea in the 1988. The project, however, has been a bust. Only one Xia-class "boomer" has been built, and the boat rarely leaves its pier -- and then only to venture into coastal waters, where its medium-range nuclear missiles could not come close to the United States (or even Guam). To make matters worse, the boat leaks radiation, further limiting the time its crew can be aboard.
John Culver, in remarks at the National Defense University, stressed that the Chinese Army still relies on an inventory of weapons "that, in most cases, has been deployed with the same units for up to 30 years." Most analysts believe it would take hundreds of billions of dollars over decades to modernize China's military. As Paul Godwin points out, "If you don't get on the technology train, it gets harder and harder to catch up."
To understand better the limits of the Chinese threat, I paid a visit to those whose voices have been largely drowned out by the Cox committee's thunderbolts and their reverberations in the news media: American weapons scientists and nuclear experts.
Over the course of the summer, nuclear laboratories at Los Alamos and Livermore have been portrayed as undisciplined nests of nave technicians whose pockets were not so much being picked as looted by clever Chinese spies posing as scholars and distinguished visitors. And so, in July, I ventured to Stanford to hear from a group organized by Wolfgang Panofsky of Stanford and Iain Johnston of Harvard.
I arrived a little late at Encina Hall, which flanks the bell tower at the center of campus. The room was packed, with people spilling into the hallway. Panofsky, a physicist and the former director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator, took his place at the front of the room. As a young man, Panofsky was in the B-29 that flew over the Trinity Test Site at 10,000 feet when the United States detonated its first atomic bomb. Though he advised Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy and Carter on nuclear weapons policy, Pief, as he is known, could be almost invisible in a crowded room -- but for his prominent scientific brow which juts like a promontory over his small frame. In a voice accented by his native German, Panofsky explained how he had read the entire Cox report and found it so full of false assumptions, unsubstantiated claims and errors that it could not be a useful reference for anyone studying the Chinese military, as he has been doing for decades.
Flipping through slide transparencies to illustrate his point, Panofsky described China as a small nuclear power, with fewer than 30 intercontinental ballistic missiles capable of reaching the United States. In contrast, the President of the United States has at any time about 10,000 nuclear weapons under his command, about 6,000 of which could be programmed to strike China. Where the U.S. intelligence community has attributed gradual improvements in China's nuclear arsenal to the skill of Chinese physicists and to design information gleaned from open sources, European countries and espionage, including espionage in America, the Cox committee rounded all the corners to conclude that whatever China took, it took from us.
Even if that were the case, Panofsky said, it wouldn't matter. China, he argued, has not built or deployed many of the weapons it is accused of having stolen. Moreover, and perhaps most important, there is no silver bullet in the American arsenal that could be stolen by the Chinese that would ameliorate the chronic and fundamental weaknesses in its conventional and nuclear forces.
The greatest threat China poses to the United States has always been a distant one: an attack or naval blockade on Taiwan that would destabilize Asia and pull America into war. The threat is real, but it, too, has been exaggerated and misunderstood.
From 1945 to 1949, China fought a civil war that pitted Mao's peasant revolution against Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government, which was America's ally against Japan in World War II. When the generalissimo fled to Taiwan to avoid defeat, he took the Republic of China with him into exile, arrogating to himself -- with America's backing -- the role of legitimate ruler of all China. The key to stability in the region has been to sustain the illusion that all Chinese believe there is one China, but to take the definition no further. That was President Nixon's goal when he went to China in 1972, withdrew American forces from Taiwan and drafted the Shanghai Communique, which artfully managed to defer the unresolved Chinese civil war into the indefinite future.
The delicate balance in the region was preserved until 1995, when the Clinton Administration managed to call Taiwan's status into question. The flash point was the Administration's decision to allow Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, to visit the United States. Granting the Taiwanese leader a visa, especially before China's new President, Jiang Zemin, had visited the United States, surprised Beijing and triggered fears there that Washington was siding with Taiwan's independence movement. As a result, Chinese missiles began to fly across the Taiwan Strait. In response, the United States dispatched two aircraft carriers to the waters off Taiwan -- the first such display of American military power directed at deterring mainland China from invading the island in 40 years. Though the crisis quickly cooled down, the issue threatens to flare again.
Last month, Lee Teng-hui proclaimed that Taiwan was abandoning the one-China doctrine -- thus throwing down the gauntlet of Taiwanese separatism once again. To counterattack, China's leaders loosed a barrage of vilification against the Taiwanese leader; so far, they have not resorted to military demonstrations.
Americans should remember that neither Washington nor Beijing can predict or control the political changes on Taiwan, which now has a population of 21 million. China and the United States could stumble into a military conflict over the island if Taiwan declares its independence. Barring that unlikely situation, however, it is essential that the United States hang back in the region, especially if it wants to avoid repeating the mistakes of 1995. Mainland and Taiwan leaders are constantly talking to one another in private channels, channels from which the United States is excluded. Therefore, the public campaigns mounted by Beijing or Taipei often are attempts to gain leverage within these private negotiations.
As with the Arab-Israeli dispute, China and Taiwan both seek to manipulate American public opinion and Congressional action to their advantage. Americans should be aware of this ideological battleground -- and that it might be a mistake to take too seriously the strong words from both sides.
These are the real issues in U.S.-China relations. Conjuring nuclear threats where none really exist is a diversion from the more urgent American task of accommodating China's rise as a power in Asia, one that will have its own national interests, many of them congruent with the American interest in a stable and prosperous Asia.
In 1998, Bill Clinton told President Jiang Zemin that China's leaders were on the wrong side of history. President Clinton was right -- but it is also true that China itself, even with woefully imperfect leaders, is on an irreversible upswing. The sum of China's negatives in the last 20 years has never surpassed the positives that have taken place post-Mao: economic freedoms have expanded, but so, too, have personal and democratic ones. A hostile American policy toward China would surely undermine the constructive forces now at work in the People's Republic. That would be tragic. That such a policy would be based on faulty and perhaps politically motivated assumptions would be a travesty.

HEADLINE: Land of the Free Market

 BODY:
The conservative dictum that urban sprawl is but the collective expression of the free market is more fiction than fact (Michael Pollan, July 11). Let us not forget that it was the Government, in an attempt to resuscitate a crippled economy in the 1930's, that deliberately jump-started America's taste for suburbia. The Government has historically promoted suburbia and its attendant necessities through programs that provide guaranteed loans and mortgages to home builders and home buyers and financing for highway construction over public transportation. It also provides public infrastructure to residential developments in ever more remote exurbias. In a "free market," equally informed consumers make choices among a number of options. But it is nonetheless clear that Government has always played a role in limiting or opening up certain of these options.
 
Marijke A. Smit
New York

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 8-1-99: On Language;
Bill-o' Rights

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
Sir William Blackstone, working away at his "Commentaries on the Laws of England" in 1765, had to deal with a list of stated rights passed by Parliament in 1689 in "An Act Declaring the Rights and Liberties of the Subject and Settling the Succession of the Crown." Just as Parliament settled on William and Mary of Orange as King and Queen, Blackstone settled on the list of powers to which their subjects were entitled as "the bill of rights."
Like most members of America's Continental Congress in 1774, Edward Rutledge, a delegate from South Carolina, read Blackstone. According to notes taken by John Adams, Rutledge rose in Carpenters' Hall in Philadelphia on Sept. 28 to say, "I came with an Idea of getting a Bill of Rights." He didn't get one. However, 14 years and one revolution later, Alexander Hamilton wrote in Federalist Paper No. 84, "The most considerable remaining objections to the Constitution is that the plan of the Convention contains no bill of rights." Hamilton thought it was unnecessary, but James Madison disagreed, and Thomas Jefferson wrote that he favored "the annexation of a bill of rights to the Constitution." Madison offered a dozen amendments; the states brushed aside 2 dealing with apportionment and Congressional pay and ratified 10; though the list never had a formal title, the United States had what became known as "the Bill of Rights," capitalized. 
 Cut to two centuries later. I invited Judge Samuel I. Rosenman, one of F.D.R.'s great speech writers, to visit the Nixon speech writers at the White House. He told us how Roosevelt's writers had enlivened his 1944 State of the Union Message by inserting an Economic Bill of Rights (to a job, to a decent home, to a good education, "to adequate protection from the economic fears of old age"). Sometime later, when I noticed one of the newer speech writers, Lee Huebner, slaving over the world's dullest economic message, I passed along the Rosenman tip: do a preamble called an economic bill of rights. He did, and our turbid message with a ringing label got pretty good coverage.
The day before F.D.R.'s 1944 use of the Economic Bill of Rights, Senator Joel Bennett Clark of Missouri introduced legislation drafted by Harry Colmery of the American Legion, who called it a Bill of Rights for G.I. Joe and G.I. Jane. "The House sent the G.I. Bill of Rights to the White House," reported The Times on June 14, 1944, as millions became entitled to guarantees on home mortgages and support for college education. Crime came next. In 1983, according to the National Center for Victims of Crime, in Virginia, the International Association of Chiefs of Police adopted a Crime Victims' Bill of Rights. Voters were victims, too, in the eyes of Max Macauley of Sacramento in 1988, and he proposed a Voters' Bill of Rights. Six years later, this label was picked up by a group of Chicago professors who plumped for "truthful, understandable messages," and no last-minute tricks. The millionaire Ron Unz now has that phrase going in California, where it means spending limits, partial public financing, a ban on corporate gifts and fast Web-site disclosure of fund-raising.
Which brings us to the Patients' Bill of Rights, now the subject of lively debate and very likely to be a battleground in the campaign of 2000.
As 1973 began, the American Hospital Association, in Chicago, packaged a policy statement in the catchy phrase. Lawrence K. Altman, the doctor reporting on medicine for The New York Times, put it in his lead, which earned it a front-page headline: "Hospital Patients' 'Bill of Rights' Backed." Dr. Altman explained, "What the hospital association has done is to collect the most commonly questioned situations and put them in one document." Included were the right to respectful care, confidentiality of records, a primary physician and notification of experimentation.
Twenty-six years later, Senators Tom Daschle and Ted Kennedy went to the White House to announce that "by passing a Patients' Bill of Rights -- national standards -- we can make sure that all Americans have the same right to health care."
The other day, I hopped in a cab, read the Taxi Passengers' Bill of Rights (to a clean cab and a respectful driver) and went to the supermarket, where I was reassured by a Consumers' Bill of Rights (to fresh produce and no hassling over returns). I am now at work on a Bill-of-Rights Writers' Bill of Rights. These include "the right to full coverage" and "entitlement to public attention."
 
Clara Bow Lives
In the Roaring Twenties, after her smash performance on the silent screen in the movie "It," she was called "the 'It' Girl." Clara Bow had it, and every flapper wanted it.
In Bob Woodward's book about Presidential hubris, "Shadow," the reporter writes about the thoughts of Sydney Hoffmann, a lawyer for Monica Lewinsky: "She concluded it was highly possible that Lewinsky had a form of Clara Bow syndrome, named after the famous silent-film actress who couldn't say no."
This is a classic example of a mondegreen -- a mishearing, or passed-along garble, of another's spoken communication. An example is a child's rendition of the opening of the Pledge of Allegiance as "I led the pigeons to the flag."
In 1922 (the year Clara was starring in "Down to the Sea in Ships"), an eminent French psychiatrist observed and reported a syndrome in which a woman has a delusional belief that an older, powerful, often celebrated man is in love with her. He called it psychose passionelle, which translates roughly as "erotomanic passion psychosis."
It is listed in Longman's Dictionary of Psychology and Psychiatry, however, under the name of the French doctor who identified the syndrome. His name was Clerambault.

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
In Providence, Spring Rolls to Pizza

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER, a former restaurant critic for The Times, is co-author with Pierre Franey of the forthcoming "Cooking With the 60-Minute Gourmet" (Times Books).

 BODY:
TEN years ago Providence was known for three things: highly regarded colleges, an unmatched trove of Colonial and Federal architecture and Al Forno restaurant. But in recent years this historic port city has been on a tear, restoring the downtown riverfront, erecting shiny new office towers and, most notably for travelers, sprouting a crop of appealing new dining spots.
After years of decline, Providence is again becoming an economic and cultural force in New England, yet it is still small enough (population about 160,000) to have a cozy, convivial feeling. Following is a partial rundown of notable restaurants around town, some old, some new -- all of which you can walk to from bed-and-breakfasts on the collegiate East Side or from downtown hotels. 

Capriccio
At first glance, Capriccio looks like one of those turgid, Naugahyde-swaddled eateries that you find in most American cities. Owing to lack of research on my part, I strolled in for lunch one day dressed as if I were going to a tennis match. The owner for 23 years, Vincenzo Iemma, graciously ushered me to a table in the dim, grottolike dining room, complete with a waterfall, stone walls and pinpoint lighting.
The oversized, leather-bound menu illustrated with drawings of the chef and other key staff members was hardly encouraging. So what a delightful surprise it was to sample the light, herbaceous and boldly flavored food. I started with octopus, which may have been the best I have ever had: perfectly grilled, buttery tender and impeccably fresh, set over a nest of frisee.
One can't judge a kitchen's range with my limited sampling, but if the pasta special is any indication, there are plenty of winners. Farfalle cooked al dente comes tossed in a sprightly sauce of balsamic vinegar, olive oil, chopped tomatoes, arugula and baby shrimp. Other appealing selections include the pasta ribbons with sun-dried tomatoes, asparagus tips, mascarpone and chicken broth, and risotto cooked in champagne and chicken broth, studded with shrimp and asparagus tips.
Not surprisingly, the wine list is formidable, heavy on big-ticket Bordeaux and Tuscan selections. I had a fresh and pleasing 1996 Gavi "Le Lune" from Marchesi di Barolo ($33.50).
Among main courses, a Gibraltar of tuna steak did not fare as well; it was nicely cross-hatched and seasoned but, because of its size, still raw in the center.
The friendly and highly professional captain, packing a big battery-powered pepper mill, offered to wrap the remaining fish for me. I told him that I didn't think I could carry it too far.
For dessert, there was a nondescript tiramisu, all fluff and no coffee flavor, and a good pyrotechnical rendition of crepes suzette.
 
Neath's
The Providence food scene took a giant leap eastward with the opening last November of Neath's, a contemporary Cambodian restaurant with French touches in a restored warehouse along the Providence River. The chef and owner, Neath Pal, trained in some of Paris's better restaurants, including the Gaston-style Sousceyrac, before coming to Providence, where he put in a year at Al Forno.
The airy dining room is done in a winsome raspberry tone, with tall wooden columns and an open kitchen. From the window tables there is a view of the river and, in the distance, the eerily illuminated Narragansett Electric plant.
Typical of Mr. Pal's variegated cooking style is the buttery duck confit paired with star anise and a blend of five Chinese spices, along with a wonderfully mellow sweet-potato gratin with a port and fresh ginger reduction. Steamed and seared dumplings filled with Napa cabbage, shrimp, shiitake and ginger are light and well seasoned, too.
Another titillating starter is the Cambodian spring rolls, crunchy skeins of bean sprouts, Thai basil and grilled shrimp, served with a peanut dipping sauce, or the wood-grilled baguette served with a coconut and scallion dipping sauce. Local oysters are roasted well (not dried out as is so often the case) and flavored with a sweet-salty Japanese lime vinaigrette. The friendly service staff is helpful when it comes to describing these exotic dishes.
Desserts are fun and invigorating. Sweet and sticky rice with cubed mango and coconut milk is a house favorite. Smooth, intense fruit sorbets in lovely, perfumed broths are fresh and cleansing; also recommended are the fried chocolate wontons with ginger ice cream.
What Neath's wine list lacks in breadth it makes up for in intelligence. Among whites there are some well-chosen, crisp sauvignon blancs, pinot blancs and gewurztraminers -- all of which stand up nicely to these sharp-edged dishes. I sampled two bargains -- the 1996 Columbia Crest sauvignon blanc ($18) and the 1997 Hugel Gentil, from Alsace ($22). Reds are equally well matched, and prices across the board are very reasonable.
 
Cafe Nuovo
 Perched on the downtown riverbank, with panoramic views and an outdoor terrace, is Cafe Nuovo (under the same ownership as Capriccio). A popular spot for lunch, now five years old, it is sleek and modern, with slate-gray-and-rust banquettes, modern art and an open kitchen.
The chef, Timothy Kelly -- formerly of Canal Bar and 150 Wooster Street, both now defunct, in New York -- serves a bright palette of contemporary American fare with a few colorful dabs from Asia. His seafood chowder is a lusty and well-seasoned creation, replete with shrimp, salmon, scallops, butternut squash, corn and sweet peppers. A hillock of tuna tartar holding a flagpole of rolled seaweed, accompanied by a lime-juice-and-ginger-oil sauce, was pleasing, as were the grilled oysters with wasabi sauce.
One dish that just missed the mark was a special -- skewered shrimp and sweet bell peppers with a cloyingly sweet sauce. Lunch salads are a good bet, especially the "exotique," combining grilled shrimp, avocado, artichoke, and hearts of palm in a Middle Eastern-style yogurt dressing. Among the seafood options, deftly cooked salmon moistened with a tomato-balsamic dressing came with grilled zucchini and sun-dried tomato-tinged mashed potatoes.
The varied wine list is generally fairly priced, although a few more selections under $25 would be welcome. I had an excellent Markham sauvignon blanc from the Napa Valley ($26).
Emily Pascal, the young pastry chef, is making waves around town with her stellar desserts, including a black and white chocolate mousse with cappuccino tartufo, and a chocolate and vanilla tasting plate.
Several times a month, on the river outside the restaurant, the city puts on a spectacular show called Water Fire, in which giant torches perched over the water are ignited. Cafe Nuovo is an ideal viewing spot. The next displays are on Aug. 21 and 28 and Oct. 9 (others may be added, so check with the restaurant).
 
Empire
Empire is a sassy new kid on the block, a stylish, breezy cafe directly across from the city's highly regarded Trinity Repertory Company. The owners, Eric Moshier and Loren Falsone, earned their culinary stripes, as so many local chefs have, at Al Forno (whose owners are also part-owners of Empire).
Opened last March in a former Packard automobile showroom, the long, L-shaped space has been spiffed up in pale gray tones with a granite bar and tall windows facing the theater. It attracts a vivacious young crowd, especially after the theater.
When the kitchen revs up its engine the results can be rousing. Among the better starters is a crispy tempura of sugar snap peas served in a paper cone, with a hot anchovy and garlic dip. Brittle, thin-crusted pizzas are good to share, either the Margarita with mozzarella and lots of fresh basil, or another with spinach, sausages and three cheeses. While stuffed artichoke is humdrum, you can get a nice individual antipasto plate with four kinds of ham and salami.
The chef takes a straightforward entree, like roasted pork tenderloin, and imparts brio by glazing it with rhubarb; the pork comes with a beguiling fennel-onion puree. The best dish I sampled was the roasted rack of lamb with a bright Vidalia-onion-and-mint chutney and potato dumplings. And you can't go wrong with a simple lemony chicken breast with asparagus and fried onion rings.
Empire's small wine list is full of bargains under $25, especially from Italy. One worth trying is the ripe, light-bodied 1995 Gigondas from E. Guigal, in the Rhone Valley ($26).
The enthusiastic service staff will get you out of the dining room in time for a performance across the street. But if you are not scurrying off to the Trinity Rep, you might make your third act either the feathery lavender panna cotta with caramelized apples, or the pear and rhubarb crumble with mascarpone.
 
Al Forno
Al Forno is so hot that the Providence River emits steam as it flows by. This 20-year-old Northern Italian grill-style restaurant gets away with a no-reservation policy and, judging from the nightly lines, hoards of gastronomic pilgrims find the trek worthwhile. The owners, George Germon and Johanne Killeen, have been lionized in the national press for years, but based on my most recent dinner there, they are showing some human frailties.
The clamorous two-level restaurant is all white and cheerful, while the brick and slate upstairs room is comfortable and convivial -- except for hard, cushionless wooden banquettes for the tables along the wall that would make a Puritan wince. The young, informed servers do the best they can under trying circumstances.
Al Forno is famous for its toasty wood-grilled pizzas; try the Margarita, which inspired the clone at Empire. The clam roast platter is briny and fresh, although the sausage was so hot I could barely taste anything else (in fairness, the menu warns you that it is spicy). A soft-shell crab sandwich, on garlicky bread with bean sprouts and tomatoes, was fun, and it came with excellent shoestring potatoes.
Two big letdowns were the dried-out and bland pepper-grilled chicken and the unseasoned grilled squid along with flavorless rice. Wonderfully fresh sea bass is grilled to perfection, but the accompanying tomato-scallion sauce puts the canned versions in a favorable light.
The restaurant's international wine list seems to have improved since my last visit, especially in whites, with good selections under $30. Two wines that complement this smoky food are the full-bodied and savory Monsanto Chianti Classico Reserva, 1995 ($35), and from the esteemed house of Mastroberardino, the white 1996 Lacryma Christi ($29).
Among the desserts to try are the ripe blueberry gratin, the homemade ice creams and the sharp-sweet gooseberry tart.
 
Bill of fare
These restaurants accept major credit cards, have a smoking section and have valet parking, except where noted. All but Capriccio are wheelchair accessible. Prices are for a three-course dinner for one with a glass of wine.

Cafe Nuovo, One Citizens Plaza; (401) 421-2525. Lunch, from 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner, 5 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Thursday; until 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. About $40 to $45.
Empire, 123 Empire Street, corner of Washington Street; (401) 621-7911. Lunch, 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner, 5 to 11 P.M. Monday to Thursday, to midnight Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. About $30 to $35. Valet parking Thursday, Friday and Saturday night. Smoking at outdoor tables.
Al Forno, 577 South Main Street; (401) 273-9760. Dinner only; open 5 to 10 P.M. Tuesday to Friday; 4 to 10 P.M. Saturday. Closed Sunday and Monday. No reservations. About $40 to $45. Free parking. No smoking.

HEADLINE: Completing an Incomplete

BYLINE: By Ron Dicker; Ron Dicker is a frequent contributor to the Sports section of The Times.

 BODY:
Every morning before leaving the house, Reggie Barlow, a wide receiver for the Jacksonville Jaguars, says he kisses his college diploma. "It's my greatest achievement."
 Lem Burnham, the vice president of player and employee development for the National Football League, is hoping more players will show the same ardor. In 1992, Mr. Burnham initiated the N.F.L.'s continuing education program to nudge players back into the classroom. Every summer, before training camp, he and his staff are host to a symposium urging rookies to finish what they started. Unlike Major League Baseball and the National Basketball Association, the N.F.L. requires all players to have some college before joining a team. But only 30 percent of all first-year players, and about 35 percent of all league players, have a degree. 
 The program helps players apply for and schedule classes around training, provides counseling and skill-assessment testing, and arranges internships, often working in conjunction with universities near the players' home teams.
 This year, 30 players graduated, the most since the program began, and more than 400 attended classes -- usually off-season in the late winter and spring. (Training camp precludes summer school.) Since the continuing education program began, 100 players have graduated.
 The athletes seem to be making the most of their second chance.
 According to Mr. Burnham, players entering the N.F.L. without a degree had a mean grade point average of 1.9 in college, but those who resume their studies achieve a 3.2.
 For players, motivations vary. Donnie Edwards, a linebacker with the Kansas City Chiefs who recently polished off his master's in education administration at the University of California at Los Angeles, cites a boyhood visit to the home of a well-to-do family where he was told that a college degree was the way to a big house and a white picket fence. Others see it as key to their stature as role models, or as a fallback for their life after football -- no small consideration, given that the average duration of a pro football career is three and a half years, to say nothing of the hazards of a profession where one injury can lead to abrupt career displacement.
 "Football is a small window in your life," said the Tampa Bay Buccaneers coach Tony Dungy, who encourages bench warmers and high-profile athletes alike to finish college. A few Buccaneers have even taken classes in-season, which is fine with Mr. Dungy. "As long as it didn't jeopardize what he had to do on the field, I wouldn't be against it."
 Here are five players who went the whole nine yards.
 
KEN NORTON JR.
 Between them, Ken Norton Jr. and his father have won three Super Bowls and boxing's heavyweight championship of the world. But no man in the Norton family could call himself a college graduate until this past June, when the younger Norton, 12 years removed from his starring days at U.C.L.A., returned to the university and received his diploma as his father, wife and three children watched.
 Mr. Norton, 32, a gifted linebacker for the San Francisco 49ers who holds the team record for the most tackles in a single season (165), said a feeling gnawed at him as he raised his children.
 "I'm really pushy when it comes to education with my children," he said. "And I thought, 'How can I be preaching all this mess when I haven't done it myself?' I felt like the biggest hypocrite in the world."
 Mr. Norton, who normally spends the off-season in Dallas, moved with his family into an apartment near the U.C.L.A. campus last winter, and he took on a full load to finish his sociology degree. His wife, Angela, and 13-year-old daughter, Brittney, helped type his papers.
 The 49ers coach, Steve Mariucci, excused his defensive standout from a minicamp so he could write his last five papers and take three final exams. It was a rare gesture in a sport consumed with winning.
 "If it was important to him, it was important to me," Mr. Mariucci said.
 
DERRICK BROOKS
 Even before becoming a Pro Bowl linebacker for two years running for the Buccaneers, Derrick Brooks thought about expanding his options for the day his football career would end.
 Mr. Brooks, 26, had always been a diligent student. He graduated with a communications degree from Florida State University in three and a half years, nearly unheard of for a player at the football-obsessed school. Yet he felt he had not done enough in the classroom to insure a future in the media.
 In April, Mr. Brooks completed his master's in communications after taking classes for four years at his alma mater in the off-season. He bolstered his resume by appearing on a weekly highlights program on local television called "The Derrick Brooks Locker Room Show" and attended a broadcasting seminar.
 "It takes commitment," said Mr. Brooks, a 6-foot 235-pounder who has averaged more than 130 tackles over the last three seasons. "There's a lot of things you can't do. No vacation. But at the same time, I'm having fun."
 
REGGIE BARLOW
 Reggie Barlow may have caught 11 passes for 168 yards last season for the Jaguars and returned a punt and a kick for a touchdown, but the statistic he is most proud of is the 3.0 grade point average he earned while working toward an education degree from the University of North Florida.
 Mr. Barlow, 26, a former player at Alabama State, has been a student teacher at both an elementary and a high school, and plans to focus on high school. Not that teaching physical education gives him a break from competition: At First Coast High School in Jacksonville, his charges, who were well aware of his exploits as a wide receiver and kick returner, constantly tested him. "If they could beat me in horseshoes," he said, "it was a good day for them."
 
ROMAN OBEN
 "How many cruises can you go on before you get bored?" asked Roman Oben, a 6-foot-4, 310-pound offensive tackle for the New York Giants and a fourth-year pro.
 There was never a question what he was going to do in the off-season. Mr. Oben, 27, who came to the United States from Cameroon with his mother when he was 4 and graduated from the University of Louisville with a degree in economics, enrolled at Fairleigh Dickinson University, in Teaneck, N.J., after his rookie year. He expects to get his master's degree in public administration in the spring of 2001.
 Last spring Mr. Oben served an internship with the Archdiocese of Newark, helping to organize retreats for high school students. He hopes to work for a major city government next year and follow that with a stint in the private sector.
 "In five years," he said, "I'll have enough experiences to know what I want to focus on."
 
TOBY MYLES
 An offensive tackle for the Giants, and now a bachelor's degree candidate in business administration, Toby Myles, 25, has been competing for a starting job as Mr. Oben's backup for two years. While he is determined to have a productive professional football career, the possibility that it might
 not work out has been in the back of his mind.
 "I got out in the real world and realized how important it was to be competitive as a citizen when my playing days are over," he said.
 Mr. Myles, who lost credits when he transferred to Jackson State from Mississippi State, pulled a heavy load in the spring. From 8 A.M. until noon he trained with the Giants at the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford, N.J. Then he ate a quick lunch, studied for a few hours and drove to Fairleigh Dickinson for classes from 5 to 8:30 P.M. He received B's in accounting, statistics, business as a global society and business law. Mr. Myles plans on being a college graduate by this time next year.
 "It will make one phase of my life complete," said Mr. Myles, who hopes to own a business when he retires from football. "I want to say I'm an educated man."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 17; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 2684 words

HEADLINE: Student Life;
Betwixt and Between

BYLINE: By James Sterngold; James Sterngold is a correspondent for The Times based in Los Angeles.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
It was mid-June, and so Virginia Parks, a teaching assistant in the geography department at the University of California at Los Angeles, was singing the usual end-of-semester blues. She had to grade roughly 80 final exams, each of them 8 to 10 pages, for a course on race and employment in cities.
 To earn extra money, she was also helping with a biogeography class, and had to grade final exams for some of its 100 undergraduates, as well as a handful of their final presentations. 
 For both courses, Ms. Parks is paid about $1,700 a month.
 It was a heavy burden, but those were just half of her responsibilities; in addition, Ms. Parks is working on her Ph.D. The day before administering the first of the undergraduate exams, she had to take her own final in statistics. And days after grading the last of the undergraduate exams, she would have to sit for a grueling week of what are known as qualifying exams, the last step before beginning a thesis. She had four hours of written exams on a Monday, eight hours on Tuesday, four more on Wednesday, and then a 48-hour endurance test of an exam in which she had to research and write a 30-page paper outlining a thesis plan for a hypothetical topic that would be given to her.
 "I'm a little bit freaked," said Ms. Parks, 28, sounding surprisingly cheerful nonetheless.
 Graduate student life has always been, to put it mildly, a time of sacrifice. But that is part of the strategy: students are regarded as apprentices, both scholars and educators in the making, with tenured faculty wielding considerable power over their futures. Teaching is seen as part of the training for a life in the Academy. The modest wages are considered almost a bonus.
 But Ms. Parks and her fellow teaching assistants, or T.A.'s, have rejected this traditional academic model.
 In a shift that could have subtle yet far-reaching implications, the teaching assistants at the University of California -- one of the largest state university complexes in the country, with 170,000 graduate and undergraduate students on nine campuses -- elected this spring to form unions to demand better conditions.
 "For these students, teaching is a job," said Elizabeth Bunn, a vice president of the United Automobile Workers in Detroit who has been overseeing T.A. unionization efforts. "We've never accepted the argument that there is a difference between the university and other kinds of workplaces when the issue is work. The workers are not asking to be paid for their work as students. They are asking to be paid fairly when they work as employees of the universities."
 The California campuses are by far the biggest prize in a movement that has been slowly gaining momentum around the country for years. Twelve campuses, including three at the State University of New York, had T.A. unions three years ago, according to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Today, there are 23 unionized campuses, with serious movements under way at institutions like Yale, Temple, Oregon State and New York University.
 So far, only students at public universities, which are governed by state labor laws rather than Federal law, have succeeded in forming unions, after being recognized as public employees.
 Unions hope the next breakthrough will be at a private university. The National Labor Relations Board is considering a case filed on behalf of N.Y.U. graduate students. If the board decides that, under Federal law, the T.A.'s are employees rather than students, it would open the way for a union vote in the next academic year at N.Y.U. It would also reverse a 25-year-old interpretation of the law and enable union elections at other private institutions.
 This historic shift is part of a broader change in university instruction. Over the last several decades, tenured or tenure-track faculty members have been teaching an ever-shrinking proportion of undergraduate classes. The number of part-time faculty and teaching assistants has increased to 47 percent in 1995 from 22 percent in the mid-1970's, according to the Department of Education. The change was motivated largely by the need to reduce costs, said Cary Nelson, a professor at the University of Illinois who has written extensively on this shift.
 Now, of course, most universities are prospering in a robust economy, but the trend of relying on low-paid part-timers and T.A.'s is still growing, surprising researchers.
 "We expected that when the financial situation improved it would go away," said Jay Chronister, a professor of education at the University of Virginia and co-author of a recent study on this trend in teaching responsibilities. "That has not been the case at most institutions."
 One reason, Dr. Chronister said, is fear that graduate enrollment would drop if T.A. positions were cut back. Also, some universities want full professors focusing on scholarship and research. "We assess the quality of a faculty member, correctly or incorrectly, through the quality of publications and grants they can bring in," said Dr. Chronister. "We don't build our national reputation on teaching."
M s. Parks met with her six biogeography students in a classroom off a palm-shaded courtyard. One by one they stood and, somewhat nervously, gave presentations they had been assigned weeks earlier. Each had been asked to critique an academic article assessing the effects of development on various environments, from a national park in Africa to a reef off South America.
 Ms. Parks -- slight, energetic, with a droll sense of humor -- stretched out in a chair, a battered pair of eyeglasses sliding down her nose. She listened patiently and asked questions to stimulate discussion and draw out the students. After class, with union organizing posters as backdrop and a bare table as a desk, she spent an hour in the office she shares with other T.A.'s, making herself available to any student who strolled in, as she is obliged to do.
 The biogeography class had been particularly time consuming, she said, because it was outside her area of concentration, economic geography. For instance, she needed to study the six articles she had assigned the students, and regularly put in far more than the 20 hours a week the university sets as a guideline for T.A. work.
 Her real interest is economic development in the inner city -- social justice, as she puts it -- which is why she got a master's degree in urban planning before embarking on a Ph.D. With tenure-track positions much sought after and in short supply, she said she is leaving open the possibility that she might end up working for a think tank or nonprofit foundation after completing her studies.
 She is convinced that one of the greatest obstacles to achieving her goals is the teaching. But it is essential because she needs the income. "What's falling behind is my own research," Ms. Parks said. She has had to delay for more than a year a paper on changing patterns of immigrant labor within cities because she cannot find the time. "I would catch up over the summer, but I have to find a job and work over the summer."
 Even some students who oppose the aggressive unionization efforts agree that teaching can prolong graduate studies and make it a more trying experience.
 Amy Young, a graduate student in geology, said she had lost about a year in her studies because of her teaching load. But she worries that undergraduates will suffer if T.A.'s limit their work hours, one of the union's main goals. "It wouldn't be possible to do a good job on just 20 hours a week," Ms. Young said. "I would feel like I was gypping the students if I didn't put more time into it."
 For their part, tenured professors say they do not monitor the hours T.A.'s put in, but do expect competent and full work in the classroom.
 "I guess it's sort of 'Don't ask, don't tell,' " said Mark Ellis, Ms. Parks's adviser in the geography department and a supporter of the union cause.
 Melissa Savage, the professor with overall responsibility for the biogeography course Ms. Parks was helping with, calls the system archaic. "At one time graduate students were really captives of the faculty," she said. "They had to do a great many things for nothing. That sort of thing is frowned on now.
 "Universities are increasingly like the corporate world," Professor Savage added. "The perception of the university as a protected place, as a place set aside from the hurly-burly of life, is no longer true."
 Not surprisingly, university administrators disagree. They say their greatest concern is that unionization would upset the traditional, informal relationship between student and professor on which graduate education has long depended.
 "Really, the concern for me is the possible establishment of an adversarial relationship of two groups who should be involved in nurturing and mentoring relationships," said Dr. Claudia Mitchell-Kernan, U.C.L.A.'s dean of graduate studies. "We have felt that the teaching experience was part of the education, and we continue to feel that the educational component of the T.A.-ship is primary, particularly for those preparing to go on to academic careers.
 "That's really the question," she said. "Where the balance lies."
 Robert Berne, N.Y.U.'s vice president for academic development, who has been the point man in the battle against unionization on that campus, said the university's resistance has little to do with finances. Instead, he said, the issue is flexibility and the role of the professor as mentor, guide and sometimes colleague.
 "These are students and the activities associated with a union would harm that," Mr. Berne said. "The fundamental academic enterprise would be negatively affected in a number of different ways. The work in graduate school is really individual and it depends on a relationship with professors that the union would homogenize."
 Ms. Young, the geology student, believes unionization would be a violation of a code of honor. "By joining the union," she said, "I feel like I'd be slapping the department in the face."
Last December, the organization behind the union drive at U.C.L.A., the Student Association of Graduate Employees, or SAGE, called a strike for semester's end, the busiest time. Some T.A.'s broke ranks and taught their courses anyway. Some held classes off campus.
 Ms. Parks chose not to go to class or grade any papers. She described it as a difficult but necessary step.
 "You heard a lot of people saying, 'Oh, we're so dedicated. This isn't really work. It's this higher calling,' " she said. "I am totally committed to it, but it's a job. I just felt we really had to stick with it. I believed the action meant totally withholding our labor."
 The action lasted four days, with the State Legislature stepping in and calling for a cooling-off period. The university docked the strikers' pay for the days missed, including Ms. Parks's wages. Ms. Parks objected, because the work she would have done was merely put aside for her to do when she returned. With the support of her department, she was ultimately given full pay.
 The strike, though short-lived, underscored for many people how strong the movement had become. It had taken 15 years to get that far.
 The unionization drive in California began in 1983 at Berkeley. Four years later it became affiliated with the U.A.W., which had been trying to organize white-collar workers.
 After a two-day strike in 1989, the organization began collective bargaining with the administration. It won two benefits for teaching assistants: a partial remission of graduate student fees and paid health care, excluding eye and dental care.
 The biggest break came last December, after years of litigation, when U.C.L.A.'s SAGE chapter won a ruling by California's Public Employment Relations Board that declared teaching assistants were state employees, not just students.
 A vote was ordered to determine if the T.A.'s wanted to be represented by the union. The union won the vote at U.C.L.A. in March, followed a month later by Berkeley and then the remaining campuses. A total of 68 percent who voted were in favor.
 Among the priorities are limiting work hours to 20 hours a week (an unlikely prospect, all agree) or getting paid for time put in; extending health insurance to include dental care and eyewear; seeking a full remission of fees (they currently get 60 percent of about $5,000 a year) and improving the grievance process so that graduate students do not find their academic standing jeopardized if they complain about abusive conditions or harassment on the job.
 "What we are doing is not going to make graduate student life idyllic," said Ricardo Ochoa, a law student and president of the Association of Graduate Student Employees at Berkeley. "But it has the potential for easing some of the pressures."
 Students expect their lives to remain a constant balancing act. Ms. Parks receives no financial assistance from her family. She and her boyfriend, also a graduate student in geography, share the $550 rent on a small one-bedroom apartment in Venice. It is about seven and a half miles from the U.C.L.A. campus, and Ms. Parks, a former bicycle racer on the U.C.L.A. team, pedals her old bike to school most days.
 Existence is Spartan, with a meal out a rarity. She and her boyfriend go to movie matinees because they are a few dollars cheaper, and they rarely socialize in bars or other venues that cost money.
 "I can tell you where all the free things are in L.A.," Ms. Parks said.
 She is relatively sanguine about her financial restrictions, but the issue is a sore one for many students tired of the economic sacrifices. "I feel like I should be a grown-up by now, with a car that doesn't always break down," said Elizabeth Schirmer, 28, who is working on her Ph.D. in English at Berkeley. "It gets old."
Teaching assistants are buffeted by several high-pressure cross-currents.
 Grievances against professors, for instance, have the potential for wrecking academic careers, graduate students say. As it stands, complaints must be taken to the chairman of the department involved. There is no neutral third party to hear them.
 It is a little discussed subject, but anecdotes circulate about graduate students who have faced some form of retribution after complaining about a professor -- a poor letter of recommendation or a refusal to transfer a graduate student to a different adviser.
"This could damage the position of a student and employment prospects," Ms. Parks said.
 Rhoda Janzen, a poet who is getting her Ph.D. in English at U.C.L.A., agrees. "The tenured professor has an unusual and even a dangerous amount of power," she said. "It's awesome."
 Teaching assistants also face pressure in grading undergraduates. On the one hand, if the grading is not tough, it can harm the T.A.'s reputation as well as the professor's, Ms. Parks said. Yet tough grading can be even more hazardous. Undergraduates, increasingly worried about getting into professional schools, have grown more aggressive in challenging teachers about grades.
 "To be a tough grader you have to be willing to put in more time explaining better what you did, giving students more time to do their work," Ms. Parks said. "You're sort of betwixt and between."
 The pressure "isn't subtle, it's overt," Ms. Janzen said. She was once threatened with a lawsuit by a student to whom she had given a B. In general, professors back them up in disputes, Ms. Janzen said, but it's important to be careful not to embarrass them.
 "You have to tiptoe around the tenured professors as well as the students," Ms. Janzen said.
 But undergraduate students face a similar situation with their teaching assistants. Ms. Parks recently wrote a recommendation for a student who was seeking to transfer to Stanford. The letter made her realize the responsibility and power she had.
 "In the end, I'm the one who knows the student," Ms. Parks said. "I'm the one writing the letter of recommendation, and there's no recognition in the system for the role we play."
