LENGTH: 3599 words

HEADLINE: Making the Ask

BYLINE: By Michael Winerip; Michael Winerip is a senior staff writer for The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
If ever there were a man placed on this earth for the purpose of being president of the University of Virginia, it is Dr. John Casteen 3d. Born and raised near Portsmouth, Va., he entered the state's elite public university in 1961 after turning down offers from Harvard and Princeton, and was immediately smitten by the beauty and grace of this campus that Thomas Jefferson designed. Dr. Casteen earned a bachelor's degree with high honors, then a master's and a Ph.D. in English, with a specialty in Beowulf. Along the way he learned 12 languages, won a literary award for a collection of short stories and built a reputation as a dedicated teacher.
 When still in his 20's, he told one of the deans, Ernest Ern, "I'm going to be president of this university," and to this day, at the age of 55, when asked to name his heroes, Dr. Casteen ticks off a list dominated by past University of Virginia presidents. One of his formative moments as a young man came in the spring of 1970, when he watched the University of Virginia president at the time, Edgar Shannon -- an English scholar, a former Harvard professor and a World War II hero -- win over a crowd of 4,000 angry antiwar protesters gathered at the heart of the campus on the lawn near the Rotunda. "For the first time," said Dr. Casteen, "I heard a lengthy, serious debate about the moral basis of intellectual life and national policy." 
 In 1990, it was Dr. Casteen's turn. A methodical, driven man with a love of the classics, he set out to create a blueprint for his university presidency that was finely balanced and quite traditional. He would spend three days a week on campus guiding his professors and deans. He would teach a literature course each semester, to keep in touch with students and carry on the role of the scholar president. And the remaining time he would devote to travel, to spread word of the university's good deeds, to partake in academic associations and to help with fund-raising.
 But after three years, the university's board of trustees had no patience for a traditional president. Dr. Casteen was in trouble with the board. "We didn't know if he'd be able to continue," says a top university official.
 Dr. Casteen wasn't bringing in the bucks! During the recession of the early 90's, politicians in Richmond had taken a cleaver to Virginia's higher education budget, in a few years' time reducing annual state funding to the university from $178 million to $122 million.
 By 1993, the University of Virginia -- one of the most respected public universities in the country -- was receiving just 13 percent of its operating budget from the state.
 By 1993, the board wanted one thing beyond all others from President Casteen: money. University trustees feared that without a major fund-raising drive, the school's quality and reputation would suffer.
 The board's new marching orders were quite specific: Four out of every five days Dr. Casteen was to be on the road fund-raising. And no more teaching; that was a relic of the past. "They wanted me outside selling," Dr. Casteen recalls. "They were upset I was spending three days a week on campus."
 As Joshua Darden, a former university board chairman, says: "The seven-figure donors, they want to see the president, it makes them feel important. John had to be out there."
 What Dr. Casteen has accomplished in the six years since has been impressive. He has raised $884 million on his way to a goal of $1 billion by the end of the year 2000, one of the largest fund-raising efforts by a public university. The drive has endowed 514 new scholarships and 135 professorships, greatly expanded the library collection and raised salaries, helping the university hold on to its talented faculty.
 Such financial strength has played a role in keeping Virginia the top-rated public university for five years in a row on the influential U.S. News & World Report college survey. By fattening the endowment to $1.2 billion during this era of shrinking government support, Dr. Casteen has also helped insulate his university from some of the political whims emanating from Richmond.
 But all this has come at both a professional and a personal cost. He was criticized last year as an absentee leader in an editorial in the student newspaper, which nicknamed him Capital Campaigner Casteen. And while Dr. Casteen is a private man who rarely discusses his personal life even with those closest to him, friends say the fund-raising roadshow contributed to the breakup of his second marriage.
 If the enduring image of President Shannon was that of a man talking reason to 4,000 protesters, the enduring image of President Casteen on campus may well be of a man schmoozing up alumni at the president's residence; last year he opened Carr's Hill, the president's home, for more than 150 fund-raising events.
 Nor is this considered extreme these days, even for a public university. In fact, it is rapidly becoming the norm. At one meeting of Dr. Casteen's cabinet, nobody blinked when he explained what he would be doing in the next months. "I plan to get pretty deeply into people's pockets," said the Beowulf scholar.
It is remarkable how fund-raising has come to preoccupy top people at even public universities. This is not something a president is allowed to delegate anymore. As one Casteen aide, Gordon Burris, says, "We need the president making the ask." And as another aide, Robert Sweeney, says, "They want to see the president when it's time for the closer." And in between, says Dr. Casteen, "you really have to work on cultivation." Otherwise, the president's time is his own.
 In recent years, in the face of lagging state support, several public universities, including Berkeley, the University of California at Los Angeles and the University of Michigan, have undertaken billion-dollar fund-raising drives, according to the latest report from the Council for Advancement and Support of Education in Washington.
 While at first blush this would sound like good news for America's public universities -- how can you argue with more money? -- free money often has its price. At the University of Virginia, for example, major donors tend to be out-of-state businessmen, alumni who have gone off into the larger world and made their fortune. They complain about the need to have more out-of-state students accepted to give the university a more global perspective (the current ratio among the 18,500 students is one-third out of state, two-thirds in state). And they'd like to see less state interference, perhaps even ending the university's public status altogether. "This is an opportunity to wean ourselves off state support," Everette Doffermyre, an Atlanta lawyer and donor, said at an alumni fund-raising gathering in Tucson last year. "This is our chance to get control of U-Va.'s destiny."
 Professors also worry that donors will pressure universities on policy as well as admission preference for their children.
 University officials say such concerns are exaggerated, and the benefits outweigh the potential conflicts. One reason Dr. Casteen has come to embrace his fund-raising role was his experience in the 1970's as a professor at another great public university, the University of California at Berkeley. There he saw firsthand how the school suffered when its leadership got locked in funding battles with Gov. Ronald Reagan. "It made me realize public institutions are fragile," he says, "and the need for some degree of financial autonomy."
 Among presidents, Dr. Casteen is considered a master of the soft sell. He was guest speaker last year at a meeting of Maryland's 13 public university presidents, who sat around a horseshoe-shaped table at their headquarters in Adelphi taking notes on Dr. Casteen's sure-fire fund-raising tips.
 "To conceive of fund-raising as making a pitch is missing the point," began Dr. Casteen, explaining that the real way to win over alumni is to get them enmeshed with the university's future. "Money's only one part of what you need to ask for," he said. "I ask for their vision of the university, I ask for their political support, I ask for their membership on committees, I ask for their children."
 The president must make the ask, he said, because the president embodies the university, and "people donate to a person, not a committee." He told the university presidents how he'd tried to set a tone, including making his own pledge ($50,000, simply listed alphabetically in the alumni donation publication); giving up teaching ("If I was going to be on campus three days a week, I wasn't going to be in Chicago in front of a guy at the Commodities Exchange"); and using his house for events whenever he's on campus ("There is a serious relationship between people coming into my house for a reception before ball games and being a large donor").
 He talked about how he used surveys and national rankings to put goals into focus for donors. "We did some research and discovered we're the largest university left without a concert hall," he said, a fact he constantly drops at alumni functions. He personally rewrites fund-raising letters. ("They have to inspire," said the former short story writer.) And he spent a half-hour going over his appointment book. ("This man likes to take a walk around campus -- he wants to walk, we walk. . . . This event, I'm not the center, I'm there to add a little weight to the party.")
 After an hour and a half, the presidents gave him a rousing hand. Dr. Hoke L. Smith, Towson University president, said that these fund-raising seminars usually focus on the technical, like the ratio of initial contacts to closures. "This was spiritual," Dr. Smith said.
 And this is precisely how Dr. Casteen landed $1.2 million for a new media center. In 1996, Dr. Casteen and one of his fund-raisers visited a wealthy alumnus, Tim Robertson (U-Va. '77, son of the evangelist Pat and president at the time of the Family Channel cable network). "John always brings somebody for support," Mr. Robertson says. "It's a lot more pressure when they bring two or three guys."
 Dr. Casteen asked what Mr. Robertson felt the university was lacking, and the TV executive suggested that the English department needed a media center to tap into the talent and wealth of the television world. "They thought that was a great idea," recalls Mr. Robertson. "They said they'd get back to me. I was amazed at how fast they did." In a few weeks, Dr. Casteen was visiting again, this time with his arts and sciences dean. "They had a whole curriculum laid out -- so fast!" says Mr. Robertson. "John said we'll need x amount to endow a professorship, x to set aside this floor at the library."
 After the deal was clinched, the university announced it -- several times. "They milked it for all its press value," Mr. Robertson says.
How does a man like Dr. Casteen, with so many intellectual gifts, have the patience and will to spend so much time on the road begging for money, alumni dinner after alumni dinner, cocktail party after cocktail party, the same speeches, the same conversations? A student reporter once asked how he did it, and Dr. Casteen's answer was fascinating for how little insight it provided. "To maintain the necessary pace," Dr. Casteen said, "you don't do anything magic, you keep your head clear, you exercise, you sleep, you follow rules of moderation." Rather than a peek into Dr. Casteen's psyche, this was his fitness regimen for ultra-marathon fund-raising.
 Indeed, today's university president often resembles the national television-age politician -- public figures who don't have an internal world or the ability to convey it, even though they are quite intelligent. That lack of introspection can be precisely what enables them to operate so effectively in the public arenas where they dwell.
 Dr. Casteen himself was briefly in politics, serving in the 1980's as state secretary of education to Gov. Charles S. Robb, a Democrat. He is shrewd politically, which has enabled him to continue as university president under both Democrat and Republican governors. When he speaks, he has a way of looking at you and raising an eyebrow, of starting an idea and not quite finishing it, often seeming to say more than his words while never really answering that controversial question.
 At the same time, as his vice president for development, Mr. Sweeney, points out, "he can deliver an impressive 40-minute speech on anything with no notes."
 Though he's constantly under pressure, rarely is there a crack in his game face. "I've seen him at a million tough moments when I know his stomach had to be churning," says Mr. Ern, the dean, who has worked with Dr. Casteen 30 years, "but John never lets on, that's part of the mystique. He doesn't let you see inside."
 As to what really is going on inside, even those closest to Dr. Casteen say it's hard to know. "I've never engaged an individual who can talk in such detail of hiking Dismal Swamp and say so little about himself," says Mr. Ern, referring to Dr. Casteen's passion for the outdoors. Even Dr. Casteen's brother Tim says, "I don't know how much I can help, he doesn't open up much."
 Dr. Casteen will not discuss how the demands of fund-raising affected his marriage or his relationship with his three grown children (nor would he permit interviews with them). But as one friend says, if you spend 80 percent of your work time on the road and when you are on campus you open your house for more than 150 fund-raising events a year, there is little time for a personal life.
 "If the spouse doesn't thrive in the fishbowl business," another friend says, "it's a problem." Dr. Casteen's former wife, Lotta, an English professor at the university, declined to be interviewed.
 To meet John Casteen 3d you would assume he was born to this elite world, but that is not so. His father and grandfather were shipyard workers in Portsmouth, and his parents still live in the same house where Dr. Casteen and his two brothers grew up. To this day, the brothers -- Dennis, a quality control worker at Norfolk Naval Base, and Tim, a fourth-grade public schoolteacher -- live on the same block as their mom and dad.
 The very things that have led Dr. Casteen to take a different route from the rest of his family also help make him the perfect fund-raiser for the University of Virginia. For his own worldly success illustrates the possibilities that a great public university can open up for a boy or girl of modest means.
 As a senior at Cradock High School in Portsmouth in 1961, he was accepted to Harvard and Princeton but could not afford either of those private universities. He chose Virginia after the dean of admissions, Marvin Perry, made a visit to the Casteen home to recruit this bright student and, sitting at the kitchen table, showed the family how it could afford the state school with its lower tuition.
 John 3d was the first Casteen to attend college. From the time he entered, he always worked to help pay his way, in the dining hall, at the library, unloading trucks at Morton Frozen Foods.
 He had trouble adjusting at first, didn't have the sureness of students from the elite private schools; as a freshman, he struggled to post a B-/C+ average. But during his sophomore year, he developed more confidence that this was a place he belonged, and he rarely got anything less than A's. From then on, the university felt almost magical. It was there that he met professors like William Faulkner and John Dos Passos, who turned him toward literature.
 After five years away, as a professor at Berkeley, Dr. Casteen returned to Charlottesville to be the University of Virginia's dean of admissions from 1975 to 1982. It was during this time that he began to return the favor that the university had done for him. Under Dr. Casteen, black student enrollment jumped from 2 percent to 11 percent, the current level. Nor was this a token effort. The four-year graduation rate of black students at Virginia -- 84 percent -- has long been the highest of any public university in the country.
 Back in the 1970's, when Dr. Casteen was laying that groundwork, he would spend his Sundays driving the state, visiting black churches, trying to convince parents that this university, which had been segregated into the 1960's, would now welcome their sons and daughters, that their children belonged at the state's elite public college.
 Dr. Casteen was doing for those families what Marvin Perry had done for him two decades before, sitting in the kitchen on Wildwood Road, explaining that a family could manage to send a child to a great university on a shipyard worker's salary.
 The university has undertaken only one other capital campaign since it was chartered in 1819. In the early 1980's, it set a goal of $90 million, raised $137 million in three years and promptly dismantled its development office, which is how things stood until Dr. Casteen took over. "We could never let that happen again," Mr. Sweeney says. "We can't afford to lose momentum."
 And so while there is still more than a year left in the current billion-dollar drive, the Capital Campaigner is already laying the groundwork for the next one. During the last year, he has been holding weekend retreats at resorts around the country -- in Tucson, Martha's Vineyard and Kiawah Island, S.C. -- with small groups of rich, hand-selected alumni in their 30's and 40's who Dr. Casteen hopes will run the next campaign.
 At the Tucson retreat, held at the Westin Paloma resort, where rooms go for $350 a night, all costs for the weekend for the dozen alumni and their spouses were picked up by the university. They flew in from all over the country, some in private planes, and one, Louis Elson, whose family made its fortune in airport stores, arrived from London. All were long-term donors. A few had already given more than $1 million; half had given more than $100,000.
 Dr. Casteen, who makes $360,643 a year, didn't just drop in, make a speech and leave. He spent the entire weekend, joining the alumni for seminars, meals, drinks, brainstorming sessions and lectures.
 After a Friday-evening cocktail hour on the patio, with the sun setting behind the desert mountains, the president delivered a speech at dinner on the decline of state aid to the university. This is why, he said, he was assembling a group of 100 families "to take the leadership for the next drive. You are about to take ownership of this thing."
 Before saying good night, Dr. Casteen told them, "I'll see you in the morning. We go to work at the godawful hour of 7:30." And sure enough, these bankers and venture capitalists, corporate lawyers and computer software entrepreneurs, were all there at that godawful hour, dressed in their khakis and polo shirts, shaved, showered and ready for a seminar on how the university will need to change by 2020.
 During the entire weekend, no one asked for money. The word was rarely spoken. "At U-Va.," said John L. Lewis 4th, an investment manager and six-figure donor, "gentlemen don't discuss their money or their grades."
 "This is about strengthening their bonds to the university," Dr. Casteen said. "These people understand why they're here."
 Indeed, Bert Ellis -- who a few years ago sold his chain of 13 television stations for $745 million -- had a keen grasp of why. "After I sold my company I gave a half million to the university and allocated stock, so I guess that's when I jumped up to this level," he said. "My wife and I can't spend the money we have. We love this university. Being a giver here is fun. I'm not anonymous. I want recognition. I want some tickets to the ball games."
 In recent years Virginia's governors, Democrat or Republican, have not been kind to higher education. During the early 1990's, it was Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat, who cut state aid to the public universities. And now that Dr. Casteen has overcome those cuts through aggressive fund-raising, a new governor, James S. Gilmore 3d, a Republican, has formed a 39-member commission to study whether the state should have more control over how those private donations are being used.
 But if Governor Gilmore thought he was going to make political hay on this one, he gauged wrong. Editorial writers, business people and student leaders have blasted him for being hypocritical -- on one hand the state has cut its support, on the other the state wants control of private money the university raised to fill the state budget gap. In a vote of confidence for Dr. Casteen and the other state university presidents, a bipartisan legislative committee this year asked the Governor and his commission to "cease and desist." While the commission continued to hold hearings, says Mr. Darden, the former trustee, "they've been a real snore." Governor Gilmore is seeing firsthand, free money has its price.
 There is nothing like an outside enemy to unite a community; the Governor and his commission have succeeded in making Dr. Casteen a popular man in Charlottesville. In an editorial this past school year, the student newspaper apologized for its earlier criticisms, citing the "tremendous success of the campaign," and acknowledging that "Casteen's leadership has even humbled the editorial powers that be of this newspaper."
 It is not often that students admit to error -- certainly not in print -- and it must have given Dr. Casteen a great sense of vindication.
 "Yeah," he says. There is a pause, he lifts an eyebrow, but says no more.

HEADLINE: Is It Only a Game?

BYLINE: By George Vecsey; George Vecsey is a sports columnist with The Times.

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
Right in the middle of a game, Brian Bell realized he had lost his motivation to play football.
 "Never had I felt so helpless, where your actions don't make a difference," Mr. Bell said, recalling his disillusionment with the administration at Swarthmore College. "If they are not committed, then what's the point?" 
 If a highly motivated student and athlete like Brian Bell was unhappy, then football was in big trouble at Swarthmore, which first fielded a team in 1878.
 By that 1997 season, Swarthmore was unable to compete even on a modest scale. It was losing badly, its little stadium was practically empty, recruiting had fallen off, and players were quitting in the middle of the season, if not actually in the middle of games.
 "I felt the school could do away with football and it probably wouldn't make the front page of the school newspaper," said J. P. Harris, the quarterback.
 There were, perhaps, enough reasons for Swarthmore to end football, as other schools have done. But the college, invoking its Quaker tradition of talking things over, began an internal debate about whether football had any educational and communal value to one of the more distinguished private colleges in America.
 The response was an open-ended commitment to upgrade the program, using more aggressive recruiting and more money, in particular an anonymous $100,000 gift from an alumnus to underwrite some of the major costs like feeding and transporting these large-sized undergraduates.
 Success has not been immediate for the Garnet Tide. In the first year, the team still lost every game, and its losing streak has now reached 28 straight games -- the longest in the country.
 When they talk about football, Swarthmore administrators sound a little like bemused relatives who inherit a clunky heirloom from honored ancestors. They try to respect it, to maintain it, but this is not exactly a place where people go around chanting, "Goin' to Pasadena! In a Winnebago!" as they might at a Big 10 mega-campus on its way to the Rose Bowl. (At Notre Dame, in the fall, one could attend the most serious convocation on liberation theology and soon be aware of whom the Fighting Irish were playing next Saturday.)
 The costs and demands have begun to impress themselves on the leaders of Swarthmore. The reality is, football is more high maintenance than any other activity on campus. It involves coaches, equipment, food, travel, open fields, hard afternoons of practice, recruiting trips and -- perhaps most important -- an admissions department that sees something positive in young male applicants with broad shoulders and a certain inclination to whack other people around on autumn afternoons.
 Must there be a place for this sport at a small, elite college like Swarthmore? Just exactly where is the law that says higher education needs a football team to, pardon the expression, kick off the academic year? Some Swatties, as they are known, ask that question.
 "For me the choice was either go to the library to study or go to a football game -- so I chose the library," said Ethan Devine, who graduated in the spring and works as a Latin American equities research analyst for Goldman Sachs in New York City. "I remember a lot of people saying they were happy they graduated and the football team hadn't won a game," he said. "They think the whole thing should be abandoned, and they're pretty bitter that that much energy is put into it." Mr. Devine has never attended a game.
 Jeff Wu, president of the campus Asian Society, also thinks funds could be better utilized. He suggests new faculty members and a student center. "It's an academically focused institution," he said. "Focusing our money on sports is not beneficial for most of the people at Swarthmore."
Swarthmore's tiny and peaceful campus, in a leafy suburb of Philadelphia, has a decidedly 19th-century feel. The old main building, Parrish Hall, looms at the top of a long, graceful hill. By contrast, the athletic department is at the bottom of the hill, separated from the main campus by a railroad line.
 The 1,300 eclectic students have things to do other than watch football. A school brochure includes a sampling of campus activities: several a cappella groups, the Civil Liberties Society, Conscious Consumers, Earthlust (an environmental group), Firefighters, Martial Arts, Mad Wriggles (madrigal singers) and Swarming Earthworms (Men's Ultimate), a highly physical version of Frisbee. The campus is a registered arboretum, and every April Fools' Day -- how typically Swarthmore -- students change the names of the plants and trees with fake placards, sometimes using arcane Latin puns.
 The Princeton Review's "Best Colleges" 1999 edition says of Swarthmore: "What's Hot: Campus is beautiful, honesty, school runs like butter, left-wing politics, dorms. What's Not Hot: religion, hard liquor, drugs, beer, Greeks."
 "Anywhere else it would be a Ph.D." is the semiofficial slogan of the bachelor program at Swarthmore, which U.S. News & World Report ranks just behind Amherst as the country's top liberal arts college. Grading is so tough some students complain they are hindered in acceptance to graduate schools.
 Football has somehow managed to survive here. Early in the century, Swarthmore competed with many major Eastern schools, but as the sport became a powerhouse at some of them, the college settled for the modest Division III, with its lack of athletic scholarships.
 Dick Hall played football here in the early 50's and later pitched 14 seasons in the major leagues, mostly with the Baltimore Orioles. Now a semiretired accountant in Timonium, Md., the lanky Mr. Hall recalls with amusement a later period when Swarthmore "hired a good coach, and there was a question of whether they were winning too much."
 This ambivalence seems a recurrent theme. Neil Austrian, the president of the National Football League, was Swarthmore's captain and quarterback in 1960. "If I followed everybody else on a Saturday afternoon, I would have wound up in the library," he said recently. In Mr. Austrian's day, one of the big rivals was Haverford, on the Main Line of Philadelphia, but that school gave up the game in 1971.
 "Football consumes a disproportionate amount of resources, certainly the financial resources, time and the energy to do it right," said Greg Kannerstein, the athletic director at Haverford College. Mr. Kannerstein admitted he missed football as a community event but said it was too difficult to recruit 60 to 80 men out of a male enrollment of 550.
 At least 22 colleges or universities have dropped football in the 90's, mostly for economic reasons. Officials at Boston University emphasize that Title IX, the Federal law mandating gender equity in school sports, was not behind its decision to close its program in 1997, as was frequently reported. It folded football because of lack of interest. In the final season, an average of 2,500 fans attended home games in the 13,000-seat Nickerson Field. Boston University, which played Division 1-AA, a higher level than Swarthmore, had just two winning seasons from 1985 to 1997, not enough for it to justify spending $3 million a year in scholarships and operational costs.
 Asked whether he missed football, Boston's athletic director, Gary Strickler, said, "Yes, I do personally, but I don't know that it's been a great void in our program, to be honest." There was a fervent and angry and small group of football supporters, but administrators say it has not remained a presence. The sport will not be back, or certainly not anytime soon.
 The trend is downward. According to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, its membership and the number of football teams is growing. But the rate of participation is declining. In 1956, 80 percent of member schools fielded a team. That percentage dipped to 70 percent by 1971, 63.1 percent by 1981 and 58.6 percent by 1997.
 Nonetheless, football has a huge psychic hold on America. Many campuses embrace it with zeal, and the resources of a Fortune 500 company. There is the old story about the college president who wants to have an institution the football team can be proud of.
 The University of Chicago, Fordham and Villanova gave up football and then started it anew. They decided something had been lost in campus life. And after 135 years of existence, little Bryant College, a business school in Rhode Island, decided to field its first team last year, hoping it might draw people onto campus in the fall and attract students.
Brian Bell, a wiry 6-foot-1, 190-pounder from Laurel, Del., had played in two state championship games in high school. He was recruited by the University of Delaware but worried that he might not have been first string until his senior year. He met a Swarthmore alumnus through an enrichment program in his hometown and is sure he chose the right college, but his love of football was sorely tested by the lack of success.
 In fall 1997, Swarthmore lost its first five games by margins of 56, 73, 49, 31 and 46 points, and Mr. Bell fought the urge to walk off the field. Then the Tide went to California to play Pomona-Pitzer, the team representing two of the prestigious Claremont colleges, and was beaten by 64 points.
 "People were making light of it, and that really hurt," said J. P. Harris, the quarterback. "We felt we were on our own. The school spits out a lot of rhetoric on excellence, but we didn't feel they were doing that on athletics.
 "Ultimately, losing was our fault. I'm never going to blame anybody else. If you look at it, playing ball is a full-time job, 30 hours a week. Nobody is holding a gun to your head, but we didn't feel that the effort was being reciprocated."
 There were just not enough football players coming in, and some already there were defecting. Feeling overmatched, at least seven quit. "Guys were doing a cost-benefit analysis about playing football," recalled Mr. Bell, now beginning a career with Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm. "I had to make a decision myself."
He added, "One thing I learned from football was commitment. These are the moments that define you. You started something. What are the messages you are sending to younger guys if you quit?"
 As the 1997 season ended with four more lopsided losses, the college's president, Alfred H. Bloom, considered ending the program. "If I had felt it was necessary, I could have recommended it," said Dr. Bloom, who said he had extremely limited experience with football.
 "The students came to me, disheartened," he said. "Football was not living up to their expectations. I spoke to several alums. It was clear to me that we would be in a better position to attract people if we had football, but Swarthmore was letting them down by not having an exciting program."
 The school acknowledged a general malaise among students, and found critics on the faculty.
 Barry Schwartz, a psychology professor and onetime associate provost, is knowledgeable about sports but skeptical about football's value.
 "The students are worried that the need for bodies on the team will skew the admissions process," he said, adding: "Diversity is a good thing. It's hard to sustain it if you need 75 people on the football team."
 One of the most eloquent defenders of the sport turned out to be Jennie Keith, the provost, a Quaker, an anthropologist and decidedly not a football fan. "We are an extraordinarily cerebral place, but there is a pitfall in going beyond cerebral to disdaining what is not of the brain," she said. "It is against the Quaker tradition to stereotype people. When people talk about football, I stop to remember that my brother played center in high school.
 "Football brings us some kids who would not have us on their radar screen," Dr. Keith added. "We do intellectual work, trying to understand life, but we need to combine this with some action in the more messy world."
 The players, quite naturally, felt threatened by even a debate. "They throw around the word 'diversity' and that applies to everybody but athletes," said Mr. Harris, a political science major from Derry, N.H., who will attend Catholic University Law School this fall. "Athletes are a minority here. You hear about 20 athletes being admitted, 10 percent, isn't that high? The implication is, Are you really worthy?"
 Mr. Harris rallied his teammates. He and several other players sought out Mr. Austrian, a member of the board. He reassured the players that trustees still wanted football. There was a consensus that the sport needed affirmation if it was to continue.
 After much discussion, the hierarchy did exactly the same thing big-time foundries do -- it removed the coach, Karl Miran, whose record was 25 victories, 51 losses and 1 tie.
 "This was very uncharacteristic of Swarthmore College," said Robert E. Williams, the athletic director. "We agonized over the decision, but if we were going to continue, we were going to have to bring in new leadership."
 The new coach was Peter Alvanos, 33, who had been an assistant at the University of Chicago. Impressing people with his energy, Mr. Alvanos, young, fiery and ambitious, was able to gain some perks Mr. Miran surely would have loved.
 Instead of two and a half coaching positions, Mr. Alvanos now has four (two of them doubling as track and field assistants), plus several part-timers. According to Mr. Williams, coaching costs are about $150,000 a year, close to double what they were two years ago.
 "Football is somewhat more expensive than other intercollegiate athletic programs at Swarthmore," said Dr. Keith. "That greater cost is one of the challenges in maintaining a football program here."
 For the 1997-98 school year, Swarthmore spent $47,116 for travel, equipment and to hire game officials -- roughly one-quarter the cost of all 12 men's teams. An undisclosed portion of $10.9 million in financial aid goes to players. There is no tangible revenue, as there is at universities that charge admission to games or have television income.
 Mr. Williams expects the upgraded program to become more expensive in the near future. The school has allocated $20,000 for a new look in uniforms and equipment -- a sore point to other campus teams. (Xiang Lan Zhou, 21, an engineering major who plays on the badminton team, complains about the struggle to get money for birdies.)
 "We've been playing football with under 40 student athletes," Mr. Williams said. "If this is successful, we'll have 65 to 70 athletes. That will mean more equipment, more beds, more food. Instead of one bus, we'll need a bus and a van. It doesn't just stop."
 Money, however, is only one factor in football success. The other is recruiting. At most colleges and universities, coaches shake their fists at the sacrosanct admissions office, telling horror stories of the brilliant blue-chip recruit who got away. Before Swarthmore's new coach was hired, the athletic director read him the facts of life: the only legitimate recruiting agent on campus is the admissions office.
 At Swarthmore, the new dean of admissions is Robin G. Mamlet, who worked at Occidental College, Pomona and Sarah Lawrence without gaining much feel for football. "You listen to the voices of the institution, and they come from different places," Ms. Mamlet said. "We've always been proud of an engineering degree at a liberal arts college. That's a voice. The football voice? That is nebulous."
 When they began talking about the future of football, Ms. Mamlet said, "we asked, 'What is our responsibility?' " The answer was: "At least make it moderately safe" -- meaning enough bodies so the players would not be overwhelmed and exhausted.
 The goal was to start each season with 65 to 75 players, to account for practice, backup for injuries and attrition. The hope was that there would be 20 bona fide players among the 180 young men accepted each year, about 10 percent.
 "That is significant," Ms. Mamlet said. "That gets your attention."
 Before the school year ended in 1998, Mr. Alvanos assembled the players who would be returning in the fall.
 "I will never forget his first words," said Mr. Harris, then going into his senior year. "He said, 'Take off your hats and sit up straight!' The room fell dead silent, and that's when I knew things were going to be different." (As it happens, those were pretty much the first words of Lou Holtz when he began his epic regime at Notre Dame.)
 "I've never seen guys work out so hard," the quarterback said. "I didn't think we were any more gifted, but the improvement was attitude."
 Mr. Alvanos began involving the community, asking a marching band from a local high school to play, and invited faculty members to be his assistant for a game. Ms. Mamlet was on the sideline for a wrenching 21-13 loss to Ursinus.
 "These are kids I know," Ms. Mamlet said. "I admitted them. I was watching them do something that turned out unsuccessfully, but there was so much drama when the coach sent them out there. It made me realize even more that athletics have their place, to watch our kids having fun, pouring their hearts into something physical."
 When a dubious pass interference call set up a last-minute winning touchdown by Franklin and Marshall College, they railed against the officials with uncharacteristic volume and language that would have been appropriate at a Philadelphia Eagles game.
 Mr. Alvanos's final 1998 record was eight straight losses, but Mr. Bell called the season "awesome."
 At football powerhouses, on the morning after the last game, coaches fan out all over the continent in search of new behemoths, trying to charm the mothers and fathers of prospective recruits. Mr. Williams, who began his coaching career at Rutgers University, said with a chuckle: "You can't really call what we do recruiting." Mr. Alvanos and his assistants tend to travel by car three to four hours from campus. For the rest of the country, they rely on recommendations, with candidates visiting campus on their own.
 Mr. Alvanos said he does not even begin to recruit a player unless he has an SAT score of 1250. Ms. Mamlet said 1300 sounds a bit more like it. She said the median SAT score at Swarthmore is 1440, and though there is slight leeway for students with special skills or gifts, football players fall within the norm, in potential as well as in performance.
 "The final call is hers, and we respect that," Mr. Alvanos said. "If she says, 'Coach, you're wasting your time,' we're going to cut him loose. If she says, 'Coach, this one looks good,' we go after him."
 Mr. Alvanos is delighted to have recruited, by long distance, a couple of backs who were sought by rival schools, as well as two offensive linemen from the South, both around 6 feet 3, 265 pounds.
 "Harvard has proven to me, personally, that football can be played at every top-notch institution in America, if they do it within the philosophy of that college," Mr. Alvanos said. "We didn't come here to make football bigger than the college. It's an outlet for the kids, a way to let their hair down, let their minds be at peace for two hours at practice, get rid of frustration or anxiety. Some people go for walks, some people read books to relax, these kids come here to play football."
 If there is value to the participants, what is the value to the campus?
 Community building is the rationale for football at many colleges. You hear it everywhere, including here. "Look at it this way," Mr. Alvanos said. "The only sport I know that has homecoming is football, and that happens in the fall. It sets the tone for the academic year. It brings people together. A Saturday afternoon of enjoyment -- if you win, anyway."
 Dr. Bloom was asked whether he could see himself pulling the plug on football somewhere down the line.
 "This is not yet the time to talk about it," he said. "This is still an experiment. I have full confidence it will succeed."
 Swarthmore's new season begins Sept. 4, when it matches its 28-game winless streak against Oberlin of Ohio. Oberlin has not won in 19 straight games (following a previous 40-game streak). Something has to give.
 The classic definition of football comes from Vince Lombardi of Green Bay Packer fame: "Winning isn't everything, it's the only thing."
Swarthmore's version comes from Dr. Keith (who has indeed heard of Vince Lombardi): Winning isn't everything -- but it is certainly something."

HEADLINE: Blackboard: Curricula Esoterica;
Doctors, Soldiers, Serial Killers

BYLINE: By Abby Ellin 

 BODY:
How do you get students excited about potential snoozers like the politics of war, the American judicial system or myocardial infarctions? Traditional lectures and textbooks don't seem to cut it anymore. Today's teaching approach is pedagogically offbeat. As they say on "ER," intubate, Brutus.
 
"The Biology of 'ER' "
Purdue University,
West Lafayette, Ind. 
 Prof. Edward Simon believes that television shows come in two categories: those that make you smart and those that make you dumb. "ER," he believes, holds rank among the smart set. Students enrolled in "The Biology of 'ER,' " most of whom are premed, watch a different episode each class and talk about the medical and biological aspects of the series. "The program raises questions of safe sex, AIDS in the workplace, cancer treatments versus death with dignity, the ethics of drug trials, euthanasia and medical economics," said Dr. Simon, a biologist. "It also depicts the trials and tribulations of medical education. Students learn so much from it."
 
"The Politics and History
of the Vietnam War"
Barat College, Lake Forest, Ill.
 Students liken Robert P. Arnoldt, an adjunct professor in the history department, and James J. Brask, chairman of the political science department, to Siskel and Ebert. The men, both Vietnam veterans who team-teach the course, argue with each other in class and present their very different experiences of the war. "He was drafted and went in when the war had become a political football game, whereas I volunteered to go in and kill Communists," said Professor Arnoldt. "When we teach we teach from these kinds of views." Students, mostly upperclassmen, also get to handle "props" like defused hand grenades. "This year they took what they learned in class and applied it to the situation in Serbia," he said. "They started questioning whether we should send in ground troops, examining the mistakes in Vietnam and applying them. That's what history and political science are supposed to be."
 
"The American Jury"
Newman University, Wichita, Kan.
 O. J. Simpson and Jesus Christ have both been tried in this undergraduate class, which examines the decision-making skills and critical thinking required of jury service. Taught by Robert Beattie, a lawyer, the class reviews prosecution and defense records of notorious cases and stages mock trials. This fall, Lee Harvey Oswald and Charles Manson will be tried. Mr. Beattie wrote to Mr. Manson, who is serving a life sentence for the slaying of the actress Sharon Tate and six others in 1969. Mr. Manson called Mr. Beattie from prison, and agreed to hours of taped interviews. Mr. Manson was eager to defend himself, Mr. Beattie said. Mr. Simpson, who also got a letter, didn't respond.
 
"Introduction to Business"
Lehigh University,
Bethlehem, Pa.
 As a dry run-through in product conception and development, student teams in the College of Business and Economics devise ideas for new lines of Nike products. Past highlights: Nike lingerie, Swoosh magazine, Smart sock (a sock with a pocket), Player's Club (a theme-cafe franchise), the Tracker (an electric odometer attached to an athlete's shoe) and Nike Fuel, a sports drink. "Nike is a company students can identify with," said Prof. Karen Collins. "It's a brand name they like." Winners of the competition for the best business plan earn a trip to Nike in New York. Abby Ellin

HEADLINE: Blackboard: Finance;
How to Be a Millionaire

BYLINE: By Abby Ellin 

 BODY:
A penny saved is a penny earned, but a penny invested could mean the difference between early retirement and hard labor. The sooner a child learns this, the better.
 So believes Bruce M. Levine, a lawyer who teaches investment strategies to fifth graders at the Donna Klein Academy, a private school in Boca Raton, Fla. "A kid who invests $50 a month in an equity mutual fund and throws in some of his birthday and holiday money and then funds $2,000 a year into an IRA, invested the same way, is likely to have over $2.4 million by age 65," said Mr. Levine. "My kids understand the power of compounding over the long haul, the long-term benefits of diversifying and the stupidity of buying and selling frequently because of the risks and costs." 
 His students also learn how time, money and rate of interest affect financial goals; the advantages and disadvantages of mutual funds, and the relationship between risk and reward. They study words most adults don't even comprehend: net asset value, dividends, capital gains and losses, dollar-cost averaging. And since they're still fifth graders, they get to write songs, stories and cartoons about the concepts.
 The curriculum is based on one developed by the National Endowment for Financial Education in Denver, now being taught in some 11,000 schools nationwide.
 But only 14 states require personal finance at some grade level. Last year, the Jumpstart Coalition, a group of nonprofit organizations concerned with financial literacy, tested 1,500 high-school students. The average score was a dismal 57 percent. Most students didn't know what the stock market was -- which explains why Mr. Levine thinks 8- and 9-year-olds should start preparing for the future. "It's criminal," he said, "to deny our youth road maps to financial security." ABBY ELLIN
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Mystic

BYLINE: By ERIK SANDBERG-DIMENT; ERIK SANDBERG-DIMENT lives in eastern Connecticut.

 BODY:
Mystic is a village divided, many times a day, by a bridge. When the bell rings, its staccato clapper often accompanied by a toot or two from approaching boats, the classic bascule bridge across the Mystic River rises to let boats through and traffic on Main Street, vehicular and pedestrian, comes to a stop.
Conveniently in summer, if you're on the western shore of the river when the bridge lifts, there's Mystic Drawbridge Ice Cream and, down the other side of the street, Mystic Ice Cream and Sweets Shoppe. The surrounding coast is the historic heartland of nautical Connecticut, the ports of New London, Mystic and Stonington. All three were major forces in the whaling, sealing, shipping and privateering industries of the 1800's and together formed the economic mainspring of the region. 
 The nautical theme carries on. Whales, this time belugas -- agile, gray 2,700-to-3,500-pound living torpedoes -- cavort at Mystic Aquarium's new Alaskan Coast exhibit. Home for these belugas is an 800,000-gallon rock-furnished tank, with below-water viewing. Also new is the Institute for Exploration's interactive oceanographic exhibition, Challenge of the Deep, assembled by Robert D. Ballard, discoverer of the Titanic's wreck.
Mystic Seaport -- the splendid 17-acre re-creation of the 19th-century harborside village -- remains a living time capsule that carries the visitor back more than a century in maritime history. Many of its nearly 500 vessels are on display, as is a reproduction in the making of the Amistad, the 19th-century slave ship.
On a different -- though still historical -- note, the Mashantucket Pequot Museum, outside Ledyard, is completing a showcase for the history of the Connecticut tribe whose Foxwoods casino has made millionaires of its 550 members.
 
Events
The Mystic Outdoor Art Festival, in its 42d year, more or less takes over the town on Aug. 14 and 15. More than 300 artists are scheduled to display their talents from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., mostly on Main Street (Route 1). There will also be live music in the Mystic River Park. For information, call the Chamber of Commerce, (860) 572-5098.
Think Mystic Seaport, and tall ships with billowing sails come to mind. Yet marine engines are not without charm. At the Seaport's eighth-annual Antique Marine Engine Exposition, Aug. 21 and 22, collectors from across North America will demonstrate about 200 pre-1950's engines; there will be boat parades at 2 P.M. on both days on the river; (888) 973-2767.
Also on Aug. 21 and 22, Adam's Garlic Fest will feature garlic lectures, lore and fare, a farmers' market and live music. It takes place at Adam's Garden of Eden, 360 North Anguilla Road, Pawcatuck, a 10-minute drive from Mystic, (860) 599-4241. Hours: 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Free.
At the Denison Pequotsepos Nature Center in Stonington, the hike of the month starts at 6 P.M. on Aug. 25. It is a four-mile walk at Barn Island preserve in Pawcatuck to explore rolling terrain, birds and other wildlife at dusk. Free; call (860) 536-1216 to register.
Restaurants from across the state come to downtown Mystic Sept. 10 to 12 for the Taste of Connecticut Food Festival. Thirty restaurants will offer international cuisine for sale. There also will be music and other entertainment, along with local beer and wine. The fair runs from 5 to 10 P.M. Sept. 10, 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. Sept. 11 and 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sept. 12. Information: (860) 536-3575.
 
Sightseeing
When friends from Europe visit, we usually end up taking at least an evening stroll through one of the area's casinos built on Indian reservations -- Foxwoods, off Route 2 between Interstate 95 and Route 2A, (800) 752-9244, or the Mohegan Sun, off I-395, Exit 79A, (888) 226-7711.
Next to Foxwoods is the Mashantucket Pequot Museum, 110 Pequot Trail, (800) 411-9671. The museum's main draw is a reproduction of a 16th-century Pequot village, complete with surprisingly realistic life-size figures. Sound stations throughout the village provide concise, informative tales of life in the community.
Admission is $10, $8 for ages 55 and up, and $6 for children 6 to 15. Open daily 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. through Labor Day, then 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., except Tuesday, the rest of the year.
The museum also offers free garden tours on weekends through August and a tour of five archeological sites on the reservation every Tuesday in August and on Thursday and Saturday in September. These last two hours and start at 10 A.M. or 4 P.M., depending on the day. The cost is $6, and reservations are required from (860) 396-6981.
In Mystic itself, the Seaport, on Route 27, (888) 973-2767, has an unsurpassed collection of vessels from the 1840's to the 1930's. Most are smaller wooden sailing, paddling and rowing craft but there are also ships like the the L. A. Dunton, a 123-foot Gloucester fishing schooner. The full-size reproduction of the 129-foot schooner Amistad under construction in the museum shipyard is expected to be launched next year. She is to make her maiden voyage in a tall ships parade in New York Harbor next July 4. Mystic Seaport is open daily 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $16, $15 for 62 and older, and $8 ages 6 to 12.
At the Mystic Aquarium, 55 Coogan Boulevard, Exit 90 of I-95, (860) 572-5955, you'll find Steller sea lions -- the largest of these mammals -- in the Alaskan Coast exhibit, as well as the beluga whales. Also this summer, naturalists wend their way around the re-created Alaskan coast with red-tailed hawks, screech owls and other species on their arms.
The Challenge of the Deep exhibit follows a trend toward interactive multimedia display. Most of the displays take the form of robotic exploration. One is the R.O.V. Manipulation Arm, a remote-controlled device used to pick up and move undersea objects, like artifacts, seen on a video screen. The aquarium is open daily 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $15, $14 for age 59 and up, and $10 ages 3 to 12.
Among the historic houses in the area are Palmer House and the Old Lighthouse Museum in Stonington, both run by the Stonington Historical Society. Admission to each is $4, children 6 to 12, $2; a ticket to both museums is $6 or $3 for children.
The lighthouse, at the tip of the Stonington peninsula, (860) 535-1440, is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily in July and August, closed Monday other months. The museum in the granite tower is not so much about lighthouses as about whaling, sealing, farming and general life in Stonington in centuries past. And, yes, you can climb up into the tower.
The Capt. Nathaniel Brown Palmer House, on Route 1A in Stonington, (860) 535-8445, also provides a good climbing experience. During the house tour, visitors take a winding staircase to the octagonal widow's walk atop the building. Palmer, an early Antarctic explorer and the original inhabitant of this 16-room Victorian mansion, built the house with his brother Alexander, also a ship captain. Inside are family memorabilia and nautical artifacts. Open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Closed Monday.
 
Where to Stay
It can be difficult to find a place to stay on summer weekends, and a two-night minimum stay is often required then.
Among the many B &B's in the area is Brigadoon, 180 Cow Hill Road, a little over a mile from the Mystic village center, (860) 536-3033, www.brigadoonofmystic.com. It has eight rooms, all with private bath, in a cozy 250-year-old farmhouse. Besides a country breakfast, tea and pastries are served in the afternoon, wine in the evening. A double room is $105 to $115 weekdays, $125 to $150 Friday through Sunday, the higher rate for the Rose Cottage.
Harbour Inne and Cottage, on the river at 15 Edgemont Street, (860) 572-9253, www.harbourinne-cottage .com, has six rooms plus a cottage with outdoor hot tub, and accepts pets. A double is $95 to $135, the cottage $175 to $250.
In Old Mystic, the village north of Mystic itself, the Old Mystic Inn, 52 Main Street, (860) 572-9422, www .visitmystic.com/oldmysticinn, offers eight rooms in an old carriage house as well as the main building. There are peaceful gardens and the various rooms have canopy beds, fireplaces or whirlpool tubs. A double is $125 to $155.
Budget: Old Mystic Motor Lodge, just off Exit 90 of I-95, (860) 536-9666, www.visitmystic.com/omml, has 56 rooms, all with a microwave and a small refrigerator. Doubles are $109 to $159.
Luxury: It doesn't get any more nautical than the Steamboat Inn, 73 Steamboat Wharf, next to the drawbridge, (860) 536-8300, on the Web at www.visitmystic.com/steamboat. The 10 elegant rooms of the Steamboat Inn, four with wet bars, and all with whirlpool bath, overlook the river. Doubles are $180 to $265.
Adding a new meaning to B & B, there's the Kittiwake, a 57-foot 1966 Chris-Craft that is a boat-and-breakfast, (203) 686-1616. Moored upriver from the bridge in Mystic, this air-conditioned vessel has two staterooms, $150 and $165; no credit cards. Breakfast on deck, anyone?
 
Where to Eat
The quarter-millennium-old Capt. Daniel Packer Inne, 32 Water Street, Mystic, (860) 536-3555, is still in the hands of the Packer family and their descendants. Completely restored, with the old fireplaces and many of the exposed wooden structural details preserved, the restaurant features a lively tap room downstairs and memorable dining upstairs. The blackened colossal sea scallops and Thai lemongrass sea scallops with vegetable dumplings (both $7.50) are tasty appetizers. Entrees range from Maryland soft-shell crab ($17.95) to stuffed lobster ($22) to porterhouse steak with fresh oyster mushrooms and Bermuda onion ($22).
What makes Abbott's, 117 Pearl Street, Noank, (860) 536-7719, so appealing is its setting -- picnic tables set among lobster traps with a view of the island-dotted bay and moored sailboats. The whole deal -- chowder, shrimp in the shell, steamed clams and mussels with melted butter and a 1 1/8-pound lobster with coleslaw and chips -- runs $21.95. The signs -- "Beware! Seagulls Steal Meals. Do Not Leave Table Unattended" -- mean what they say. No alcohol served, but you can bring your own.
For lighter fare and smaller crowds, try Kitchen Little, overlooking the river on Route 27 just north of Mystic Seaport, (860) 536-2122. In addition to seafood lunches, it offers 45 different breakfasts. Typical are the Portuguese Fisherman (scrambled eggs, chourica and linguica sausage, peppers, onions and a zesty sauce) and the Mystic Melt (scrambled eggs with crabmeat and cream cheese), each under $6. Open 6:30 A.M. to 2 P.M., till 1 on weekends.
The Olympia Tea Room, about 20 minutes (or more, depending on summer traffic) from Mystic at 74 Bay Street, Watch Hill, R.I., (401) 348-8211, still has the casual atmosphere of its former ice-cream-parlor days. Favorites are fish and chips ($9.95) and littlenecks and sausage over linguini ($15.95). Dinners there often end with the Avondale swan, an ice-cream-filled cream puff ($5).
For a more formal meal, Three Fish, 37 Main Street (Route 1), Westerly, R.I., (401) 348-9700, offers such appetizers as yellowfin tuna sashimi spring rolls with wasabi cream ($12) and entrees like pan-seared Stonington sea scallops ($18). Even the butter comes in a fish shape.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Glorifying Governments Is Also an Art

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALL governments engage in, even require, propaganda to reinforce their authority and disseminate their policies. Made by human beings, governments naturally like to look good. They show distinct preferences for glory, no matter what their actual circumstances. So the powers that be build monuments, put victory and liberty on coins, establish patriotic celebrations, fabricate myths.
The word propaganda comes from the Latin phrase for propagating the Christian faith; it acquired a generally pejorative sense only in World War I, when governments took strict control of war information that could be used in the mass media. Long before, every medium that could spread ideologies or enhance renown and power had been called upon to do so. Popes and kings and dictators commissioned architecture, sculpture and painting, enlisted playwrights and speakers, and hired designers to shape the ruler's image and fashion the servants' livery as well as the military's uniforms. When photography came along, it, too, was soon pressed into service. French and British royalty in the mid-19th century started by posing with their families so that their subjects might feel a certain warmth of kinship with their emperors and queens. 
 During the technical peace of the 1930's, Germany, the Soviet Union and the United States took the uses of propaganda, beneficent or otherwise, to new levels. Two major -- one might even say resounding -- governmental photographic programs in that decade are explored and compared in "Propaganda and Dreams: Photographing the 1930's in the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.," at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington through Oct. 3. Here, even the dreams look like propaganda.
This enormous and instructive show of 232 images, including a few posters and photographically illustrated books and magazines, is accompanied by a catalogue written by the curator, Leah Bendavid-Val. The exhibition offers some previously unknown photographs from both countries as well as such revealing items as a second version of Alexander Rodchenko's well-known "Pioneer Girl" and a variant of Dorothea Lange's picture of a migrant worker's wife with her hand to her head, apparently more posed than candid. These reminders of photographers' ways of working hint at how artfully constructed and determinedly willed was the persuasiveness of their images.
Lenin, who regarded art as an educational tool, called for central Government oversight of all kinds of information. The Soviet system aimed not only at educating the illiterate masses but also at reconstituting humanity by creating a new and more harmonious individual, a project that could be furthered by keeping examples before the public's eyes. All published and professional photography was essentially Soviet Government photography, as the Government controlled all publications. At one point, photographers were ordered to hand over their negatives so they could not be used commercially. Nonetheless, Ms. Bendavid-Val says, many images and even negatives were returned to their makers, and what the Government did keep was neither organized nor well cared for.
The United States had plenty of non-Governmental photographers, but the Farm Security Administration, one of the most prominent, discerning and important photographic employers of the 1930's, was of, by and for the Government. The F.S.A. was established to rally support for New Deal programs to help farmers. Roy Stryker, the head of the agency, ordered photographers to hand over their negatives, and did not return them. (Walker Evans, unhappy with the arrangement, took two pictures of everything and sent in only one.) Stryker took complete charge of the photographs he received, even punching holes in negatives he did not like. He made great efforts to get these free-of-charge pictures published and displayed, and he preserved the archive, which is now in the Library of Congress and making its way onto the Web.
So both Governments were engaged in large-scale photographic projects meant to promote their ideas and programs. The subjects were sometimes similar -- farmers, children, interiors, daily life, some industry, some urban environments -- but the press releases for "Propaganda and Dreams" -- and on a couple of occasions the show itself -- mistake this for stylistic similarity. Both subjects and styles reflect the different histories of the two nations, something about their different goals, a lot about their different circumstances in the 1930's.
The Soviet work owes a great deal to Rodchenko's experiments in the creation of a new vision by means of vertiginous views, close-ups and dislocations. By the 1930's, after Russia and the Communists had revolutionized art as well as government, the Soviets forced the art genie back into the bottle, but they never quite convinced photographers to abandon their discoveries. Many photographers made straightforward documentary pictures of the approved type, but the esthetically daring, disjunctive style, replete with bold diagonals and sudden changes of scale, never died out altogether. Rodchenko was accused of excessive foreign influence and discredited. Men like Boris Ignatovich, who continued along related formalist paths, were not persecuted, merely ignored. Despite the utopianism of believing that they could change the very way people saw, despite images that today look very strong, Ignatovich and others like him seldom got published, yet they did not renounce their vision.
Modernism in American photography had a wholly different tone and derivation from most European and Russian modernism: it tended to be flat, planar, tangentially cubist and constructivist. And though it was the Soviet administration that decreed an end to extravagant modernist experiments and a return to a simpler, less stylized presentation, it was America that accepted the directive without even being aware of it. The plainspoken approach was valued here as a token of honesty. American documentary remained stylistically restrained, partly to distinguish itself from the crowd-pleasing blandishments of commercial work.
Walker Evans was not alone in the 1930's in centering his subjects in the middle distance and keeping them strictly parallel to the picture plane, nor are there many flourishes in the work of Lange, Russell Lee or Arthur Rothstein. The photographers' very styles were meant to say: "We are compassionate but neutral. What we show you is the unvarnished truth, uncontaminated by the prejudices of art and personality that creep into magazines like Life and Look." If the Soviet belief in the new man and woman was strengthened by radical ways of seeing, the American documentary style was a kind of visual equivalent to the homely, log-cabin character of Honest Abe.
WHEN the photographs are visually similar, the similarities are often superficial. Even though the two countries shared a faith in the potential of government to improve the lot of the citizenry, even though both believed in the redemptive power of machinery, even though the photographers were equally convinced that their imagery could influence social change, the historical differences were overwhelming.
The U.S.S.R. was at last barreling into the 20th century in the 1930's on tractors and electric lines; the United States had been industrialized for nearly a century. The Soviet Union was supposedly at the beginning of a glorious future; the economic problems of the United States struck many as the end to an entire system. The Soviets were fashioning a collective society; Americans pinned their hopes on the individual. The Soviet pictures are robust, full of hope, dynamic. The American pictures, supposedly about the will to overcome, are frequently sad, forlorn, empty and arid: the image of people who know they are in trouble, as opposed to the Soviet image of people who are determined to believe they are not.
Art journals in recent years have repeatedly criticized the Farm Security Administration and its photographers for being agents of Federal Government propaganda, a criticism that ironically recaps political complaints about the program by President Franklin D. Roosevelt's opponents in the 1930's. Critics today also accuse the photographers of exploiting their indigent subjects, an objection that goes to the heart of recent doubts about documentary practice.
MS. BENDAVID-VAL repeatedly and properly points out that photographers, editors and publishers in both America and the Soviet Union believed in the rightness of their cause and the usefulness and appropriateness of what they were doing. By definition agents of Government propaganda, they were also acting on their own beliefs, for they shared the political faith in reform and progress.
Besides, the Soviets approved of propaganda as education and understood that the greatest persuasive enterprise in America was not the Farm Security Administration but advertising, from which they hoped to learn some valuable lessons. American critics have further objected to the F.S.A.'s project as a kind of Government advertising, which it was, and it may not seem as benevolent today as it did to photographers then. But unlike most advertising, it did include critiques of the American system, particularly of racial segregation.
Even in the 1930's, some American photographers had doubts about taking advantage of disadvantaged subjects (or at least about other photographers' doing so), but times were different, and both photographers and subjects expected that the subjects would benefit from these pictures. And sometimes they did.
What is astonishing is that Soviet photographers, and Soviet citizens generally, apparently continued to believe in their cause in the face of mounting hunger, executions and brutal repression. Ms. Bendavid-Val writes: "In the U.S.S.R., citizens went hungry and endured slave labor to build Soviet industry, witnessed purges and terror in the name of it, and still they believed they were better off than the rest of the world, that they belonged to the world's most prosperous, free and classless society. These attitudes, bringing into question the very notion of belief, influenced the course of history." This is, of course, one of the great tragedies of this century, that so many people have suffered in the name of the betterment of humankind.
The bizarre disconnects of the Soviet photo enterprise take on a different coloration when seen in the light of such beliefs. Photographers praised collective farming long after Stalin engineered a famine to kill off thousands upon thousands of farmers who resisted collectivization. Rodchenko's first-rate picture essay on the building of the White Sea Canal, part of which is on view at the Corcoran, in the pages of that remarkable magazine "U.S.S.R. in Construction," is a dynamic view of an industrial triumph that cost more than 250,000 lives, a fact that Rodchenko could not have missed. Evidently, he rationalized conscripted labor and death as the necessary costs of progress, to which his best efforts of description could also make a contribution. The road to hell is paved with good intentions, and sometimes with good photographs.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Hotel Developers Cut Expansion Plans, Shift Focus

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
PINCHED by tighter financing and a modest decline in occupancy rates hotel developers and operators are trimming their visions of building new lodgings in New Jersey.
But since the economy is strong and room rates continue to inch up they are peeling back, not eliminating, construction plans. While the focus in the recent past was on building extended-stay and limited-service hotels, attention is now shifting to full-service lodgings. 
 Developers have completed, begun, or will soon begin work on 18 hotel projects, both new construction and expansions of existing hotels. In all, 2,400 rooms will be produced in the next 18 months, nearly half the number of rooms that were planned last year, according to CB Richard Ellis, the national commercial brokerage, which tracks the hotel industry.
In the nation, as in New Jersey, the industry "is still healthy, but it is a quieter time" for development, said Patrick Ford Sr., president of Lodging Econometrics, a division of National Hotel Realty, in Portsmouth, N.H., which specializes in development trends. Mr. Ford traces the slowdown to last fall's temporary tightening of credit, which resulted from the financial turmoil in South America, East Asia and Russia.
Financing has since become more available, "but it's nowhere near the levels it had been," he said, adding that underwriting requirements "are more stringent and lenders are more selective."
Gregg Delany, vice president of the Lodging and Hospitality Services Group at CB Richard Ellis's Manhattan office, said because of the proliferation of limited-service and extended-stay hotels lenders are "unwilling to aggressively finance such projects." He said they favor full-service hotels, for which "there is a shortage of supply and an increase in demand."
Eight of the hotels involved in this round of development in the state are full-service hotels and 10 are limited- or extended-stay lodgings. The latter, said Mr.Delany, would have been higher "if the more conservative capital market did not curtail their production."
John A. Fox, senior vice president at PKF, a hotel and real estate consulting firm in Manhattan, considers the construction slowdown good news. "It will," he said, "prevent the industry from entering an overbuilding situation."
Other factors that will keep the industry on a even keel, analysts said, are the influx of firms expanding within or relocating to New Jersey, where a spate of office buildings have been or are being built. Business travel, they added, remains relatively steady.
Over the last 12 months ending in May the occupancy rate in New Jersey hotels was 68.7 percent, down 2 percent from the previous like period, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. Nationally, the rate was 63.7 percent, relatively unchanged from the year before. At the same time the average daily room rate in New Jersey hotels increased by 4.5 percent to $91.70; in the nation it rose by 3.8 percent to $79.15.
Robert Bowers, vice president at Smith Travel Research, said if the supply continues to tighten and the economy remains favorable, "occupancy rates should firm again or inch up in the year 2000." Room rates will continue to rise, but not as fast as they have in the last 24 months, Mr. Delany added.
MEANWHILE, construction continues, only now "where and what kind of hotel is being built" takes on added significance, Mr. Fox said.
Among the hot markets in New Jersey is the Hudson River waterfront, particularly in Jersey City, where one hotel is under way and two more are planned. Work began in May on 187-room Marriott Courtyard Hotel, the first hostelry at the 600-acre Newport mixed-use center at the northern end of the city's riverfront. The $25 million hotel is being done by the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park Queens, Newport's developer. Melvin Simon Associates, a shopping center developer in Indianapolis, is an equity partner.
"Hotels were always part of the Newport master plan," said Richard LeFrak, president of the company bearing his name. "But there needed to be a critical mass to support one and now it has been reached." He was referring to the millions of square feet of occupied offices and thousands of housing units on the city's riverfront (there are two million square feet of office space and 4,000 residences in Newport alone). And more than two million additional square feet of offices are expected to be built on the riverfront in the next two years.
When completed next spring, the hotel will join the 199-suite Club Hotel & Suites by Doubletree that opened last year at the corner of Washington Boulevard and Sixth Street. Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus and Garden State Development of Jersey City, which developed the hotel, say it is performing well, but decline to release occupancy figures. . Daily room rates start at $169.
"Its performance is indicative of the waterfront's latent potential," said Robert S. Deeley, regional vice president of lodging and development at Marriott. And given the Newport hotel's location, across the street from a PATH station with access to Manhattan, he said, and Mr. LeFrak agreed, it will benefit from a spillover of demand from firms across the river looking for a less expensive alternative. Daily room rates have yet to be set.
Mr. LeFrak said his company had plans for a full-service hotel, with up to 400 rooms, and was in discussions with Marriott to operate it.
At its Harborside office complex at the waterfront's southern end, Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Cranford, has begun site work to develop, in a joint venture with Hyatt Hotels Corporation, a 350-room hotel on a pier. "There are now no full-service hotels, and it would be hard to replicate one like this," said Mitchell E. Hersh, chief executive at Mack-Cali. He said the $90 million hotel would "be reinforced" by his company's construction of a 185,000-square-foot office building at Harborside for Waterhouse Securities, the discount brokerage.
And on the waterfront in Weehawken, Hartz expanded by 108 rooms the 262-room former Ramada Inn Suites hotel at its Lincoln-Harbor mixed-used complex and opened it last month as a Sheraton, with daily room rates starting at $169.
Mr. Ford of Lodging Econometrics said there was also more attention these days on urban downtown hotels, some of which are being built with public funds.
That is the case in downtown Trenton, where the city plans to build a 200-room hotel and conference center with a 600-car garage at Lafayette and Warren Streets. The hotel will be connected to the Trenton War Memorial, a historic landmark.
The $50-million project will be financed mostly by the sale of bonds. James Harveson, acting director of the state's Department of Housing and Development, said the bonds would be sold this fall; construction of the hotel, which Marriott will operate, will follow.
Suburban markets with large pools of corporate tenants are also attracting development. One is Woodbridge in Middlesex County, where Inn Hospitality of Iselin, for example, has recently expanded and is now renovating the 300-room Sheraton it owns at Route 1 and Gill Lane, which is linked to a 100,000-square-foot office building.
With the 100-room addition to open this week, work is to begin on refurbishing the hotel's facade and common areas, said Dorothy Zarnik, a partner at Aztec Architects, of Iselin, which is designing the renovation. After completion of that work, which is to cost between $2 million and $3 million, the existing rooms will be redone, she said, noting that the renovation is needed "to remain competitive." Daily room rates are $160
Prime Hospitality Corporation of Fairfield, which last year announced it was slowing down construction, has resumed its activity on a limited basis with a focus on AmeriSuites hotels, its short-stay concept. The company opened one with 126 rooms on Route 4 in Fair Lawn in January and is not now planning any new ones in the state, said Terry O'Leary, vice president of franchise sales and development. But, he said, franchisees are planning to build three in Parsippany, Fort Lee and New Brunswick.
By October, he said, his company will invest $2 million to renovate and convert a 149-room Howard Johnson on Route 23 and Ratzer Road in Wayne to a Wellesley Inns and Suites. "We're not adding new rooms, just better ones," he said, noting that daily room rates range from $85 to $125.
Mr. Deeley of Marriott said his company had 12 limited-service hotels planned in the state, including one each in Parsippany and Bernards Township. Those hotels, which include its moderately priced Courtyard and Residence Inn concepts, will have 120 to 200 rooms each.
"We still see opportunities in locations where a new supply of rooms is warranted," Mr. Deeley said.
