HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Court Rulings Trouble Housing Advocates

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THREE recent court decisions upholding rejections of moderate-income housing projects have rattled supporters of Connecticut's Affordable Housing Law.
They fear that the 10-year-old law, which has prevailed in the majority of court challenges until now, is vulnerable in cases based on concerns for potable water sources, open space and septic systems, which were not as intense a decade ago. 
 Now towns where resistance to moderate-income housing is pervasive have a new catalogue of reasons to oppose the law.
Decisions handed down by the Connecticut Supreme Court in July, and by the Superior Courts of New Britain and Bridgeport in March and June, ruled in favor of Glastonbury, Newtown and Bridgewater, respectively. The decisions involved three projects with a total of 159 single-family homes and apartments, 37 of which were to be offered at below-market rates.
Under the affordable-housing law, developers of market-rate projects receive negotiable density bonuses if 25 percent of their units are priced for tenants or purchasers whose incomes do not exceed 80 percent of the area or state median income, whichever is lower. The state's goal is to raise the proportion of housing for lower income tenants or owners to 10 percent in each of its 169 municipalities.
Last month only Justice Robert I. Berdon dissented when the Connecticut Supreme Court ruled 6 to 1 against the Christian Activities Council of Hartford, a century-old inner-city mission society with about 30 member churches. It wanted to build a total of 28 affordable single-family homes on 33 acres of unused water company land in Glastonbury. The watershed tract of forests, brooks and ravines -- for sale by the Metropolitan District Commission, a Hartford-based public water agency -- once served several towns in the area.
The court made its decision on the issue of open space. Justice David M. Borden wrote in his opinion that the public interest in the protection of open space, conservation and recreation clearly outweighed the need for affordable housing in the town.
Justice Berdon wrote in his dissenting opinion: "This case calls upon us to resolve the issue that lies at the heart of affordable housing in this state: What burden is a municipality required to satisfy before it may reject an affordable housing proposal? According to the majority, this burden is extremely deferential to the local zoning authorities whom the law was designed to keep in check."
Glastonbury's lawyer, William S. Rogers, said: "I think the Supreme Court was correct in saying that you can reject simply by saying you are preserving open space. The town set policy 20 or 30 years ago for a 600-acre tract to be to be preserved," including the parcel in question. And, he added, "the local real estate people counted at least 100 units in the affordable range around town when this application was heard."
ACCORDING to the state's Department of Economic and Community Development, 7.13 percent of the housing for the 29,000 residents of the 52-square-mile Town of Glastonbury is affordable. "We feel we have been quite successful," said Ken Leslie, Glastonbury's community development director. "We've had an affordable-housing program for 20 years."
Douglas Wootten, president of the Christian Activities Council, said that he was "extremely disappointed in the Supreme Court ruling."
"It undermines the statute," he said, "and opens the way for towns to be even less responsive to affordable housing using this decision as a precedent."
His council was supported by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and the Connecticut branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, both of which filed friend of the court briefs.
"Connecticut has one of the most restrictive zoning systems in the country, one that we believe has resulted in a pattern of housing discrimination in town after town," said Joseph Grabarz, director of the Civil Liberties Union's Connecticut office. He called local zoning "a political fiefdom."
The Civil Liberties Union's legal director, Philip Tegeler, added that the affordable-housing appeals procedure, which allows a developer to take a town to court when it believes that its project has been unfairly treated, is fundamentally a civil rights statute. "This decision," he said, "weakens all our other efforts to open up housing for people all over the state."
In the Newtown case, a proposal by D & H Homes was rejected by Judge William A. Mottolese because the property and septic system were in an aquifer protection zone, creating a substantial impact on public health. John Horton, a principal in D & H Homes, and his partners own 31 acres on which they planned to build 96 single-family homes using the 25 percent below-market component. "We believe that the issues Judge Mottolese ruled on are correctable," said Mr. Horton, "and we plan to proceed with some kind of development. We believe there is a need for affordable housing in Newtown." Affordable dwellings amount to 2.01 percent of all housing in Newtown, according to the state's Department of Economic and Community Development.
Judge Sidney Axelrod, in Superior Court, turned down John F. Carr Jr.'s proposal in Bridgewater, saying that there was no potable water supply for the subdivision, nor had the required municipal or State Department of Utility Control approvals been obtained. The proposal had called for a mix of 35 single-family homes and apartments on 24 acres, with an affordable component.
Over the summer Mr. Carr said he would attempt to meet the town's and Judge Axelrod's requirements by drilling a well and performing tests to determine whether he has sufficient volume of potable water, plus providing engineering drawings of the septic system. He said he would then apply for the required approvals and, upon receiving them, submit a new application to the town.
"It's an expensive procedure," said Neil R. Marcus, his lawyer. "The town is upping the cost to discourage affordable housing by holding it to a higher standard than market-rate housing." A market-rate condominium complex nearby with the same density of one unit per half-acre was not required to perform such tests in advance, he said.
Bridgewater has a population of 1,800 in 20 square miles, with homes priced from $250,000 up, including summer and weekend retreats owned by Mia Farrow and other celebrities. Its affordable-housing figure is .25 percent, state figures show.
"I think it's fair to say" said Michael A. Ziska, Bridgewater's attorney, "that although the town is not averse to affordable housing, the density proposed for this site was three to seven times higher than the current two-acre zone." He was referring to varying calculations for the single-family homes and apartments in the Carr proposal.
Timothy Hollister, a Hartford lawyer who represents many developers in dozens of such cases around the state, said he was discouraged by the recent turn of events. But, he said, "these three cases are coincidental in timing. Applicants have prevailed in two-thirds of the cases this year, but that's down from three-quarters a year or so ago." He has compiled informal statistics on the development of more than 1,500 affordable units built since the law went into effect, predominantly single family, but with a large rental contingent.
Shrinking amounts of available land and public concern for basic infrastructure issues, he said, "have made developers more aggressive, proposing affordable housing in areas where water and sewer are not readily available. To get the density for affordable housing you need those two things."
As the lawyer for Avalon Bay Communities, he has been involved in the company's seemingly endless string of lawsuits against towns that initially reject its proposals for luxury rental apartment complexes with the 25 percent affordable component.
But Avalon Bay has so far managed to prevail in court, using the law to its advantage in shoehorning its way into Wilton, Trumbull, New Canaan and other upscale towns that routinely resist affordable housing, albeit at the cost of lengthy legal battles.
While the suburban and rural towns resist affordable housing, Connecticut's major cities of Stamford, Bridgeport, New Haven and Hartford exceed the prescribed 10 percent, but need more, officials of those cities say.
The Stamford Zoning Board is considering a measure that would bring the state's affordable-housing law onto the city level. New housing developments in certain zones would be required to rent or sell 20 percent of their units below market rate. Because of the area's high income level, earnings of no more than 80 percent of the state's median income of around $54,000 would be the criterion for eligibility.
That would please Eileen Buchheit, a Bridgewater resident.
"The intent of the legislation was not for small villages like Bridgewater," she said at a public hearing on the Carr project, "but rather for large cities like Bridgeport."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In /Munsey Park, N.Y.;
High Standards, Eye to Tradition

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
HOMEOWNERS in less exalted parts of Long Island haul their trash to the curb, mindful of collection schedules that must be met.
The chore would be unthinkable -- in fact, it would be contrary to village regulations -- in Munsey Park, a sedate, high-income village of 835 homes on the North Shore of Nassau County where all the niceties of suburban living are scrupulously observed. 
 Here three times a week the garbage man walks up the drive to retrieve cans behind houses and then dutifully returns them.
And when snow falls overnight on the village's 10 miles of undulating roads, "before you open your eyes in the morning the roads are plowed," said Mary Ann Horne, assistant manager of Daniel Gale MacCrate Real Estate, who moved here from Boston eight years ago with her husband, Frederick Horne, a banker, and their two children.
These amenities and special qualities like the stately sycamore trees and slate-roofed, two-story, sturdy and well-kept, center-hall colonials along Park Avenue give Munsey Park its decidedly upper-crust North Shore character. It is a place where tradition reigns, and where the Island's signature ranches and split-levels would look jarringly out of place.
But for many prospective buyers, the crown jewels are a public-school system with a reputation for excellence and an express-train commute of less than half an hour to Manhattan.
Munsey Park, a residential community almost exclusively made up of detached colonial, Tudor and Norman-style homes on lots typically of a third to half an acre is one of several high-income villages that are considered part of Manhasset, an area defined by the district boundaries of the highly rated Manhasset public schools.
In addition to Munsey Park, Manhasset includes the villages of Plandome, Plandome Manor, Plandome Heights and Flower Hill, as well as unincorporated Strathmore-Vanderbilt and Manhasset proper.
Munsey Park upholds high architectural standards, with permit requirements not only for all structural work but even for esthetic changes such as door or window replacements.
Most dwellings range in age from about 70 years old, reflecting village beginnings in the 1920's, to about 40.
Though newer homes are found here and there, the village is not the kind of place where new buyers are allowed to raze existing houses and replace them with ones more to their taste. Residents maintain older homes much as boat owners at certain yacht clubs keep aging racing fleets in ship-shape condition.
Despite housing prices that exclude most potential buyers, the market in Munsey Park is vigorous and inventory is low, Mrs. Horne of Daniel Gale MacCrate said. "People are getting their asking prices, and in some instances more," she said.
Diane Harragan, the president of Blaich House & Home Realty in Manhasset, described a three-bedroom colonial with two-and-a-half baths currently for sale for $650,000 as "probably the least expensive house in Munsey Park at the present time."
But in a market with "a tighter range" than in some other well-to-do areas, the highest price for a house currently on the market was $949,000 for a three-bedroom colonial, also with two-and-a-half baths on "a beautiful piece of property" she said.
As in other parts of Manhasset, property taxes in Munsey Park appear low when compared with high home values. Indeed, the village is among those areas that benefit from often criticized assessment practices in Nassau County that exact relatively higher taxes from residents in lower-income areas.
IN June the Federal Government sued Nassau, charging that its assessment practices imposed unfairly high taxes on minority homeowners in less prosperous areas. A court order or a voluntary decision to overhaul the current system could raise property taxes in Munsey Park and elsewhere in Manhasset.
But real estate agents said higher taxes would be unlikely to quell buyer interest in a village where houses tend to appreciate like blue-chip stocks in a steady market.
And it's friendly, said Susan Fickinger, who was at first put off by "houses that seemed very close together where you are literally next to your neighbor's driveway" when she and her husband, Thomas, moved to Munsey Park from Short Hills, N.J., four years ago. "From day one we always felt a strong sense of community and family," she said. "It was almost a Midwestern welcome. Neighbors were bringing apple pie to the door. We've been tremendously happy here."
Lacking shorefront or a golf course of its own, Munsey Park is nonetheless near Long Island Sound and private golf and swimming clubs including the Plandome Country Club, the North Hempstead Country Club and the Strathmore Vanderbilt Country Club, which has no golf.
The village has a small, architecturally correct shopping plaza on Route 25A, also called Northern Boulevard. But major shopping is found outside the village on the Miracle Mile along Northern Boulevard, with the tony Americana as its eastern anchor.
St. Francis Hospital, a 279-bed Roman Catholic institution specializing in the treatment of heart disease and the second largest cardiac treatment provider in the United States, is just beyond the village's northeast boundary. Two churches, the Congregational Church of Manhasset and the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour, are within the village.
For Munsey Park residents, an added advantage is the proximity of the k-6 Munsey Park Elementary School, where proceeds from a $21.5 million bond issue voters approved in 1996 paid for 16 new classrooms and a new auditorium built to conform with the stonework of the existing school.
The grade school, one of two in the district, is within walking distance for Munsey Park children. District students attend the Manhasset middle school, for grades 7 and 8, and the high school, where more than 95 percent of graduates go on to higher education.
THE Munsey Park school principal, Dr. Jean Kendall, said enrollment was expected to grow from about 560 to 650 students over the next several years, growth real estate agents said reflected more young families moving into the district.
The school has two computer labs and computers in every classroom. Fourth-grade students finished close to the top for Long Island public schools in statewide English language arts tests this year, Dr. Kendall said.
A comprehensive math program places early emphasis on problems and problem-solving. There are extended learning and mentor programs for students with special needs, and an arts program that includes dance and drama clubs.
At the Manhasset High School, attended by 730 of the district's 2,400 students, median S.A.T. scores last year were 544 in verbal and 592 in math. Both scores are far above average state scores of 495 in verbal and 503 in math. Two students were National Merit finalists this year.
Dr. Peter A. Pantina, associate principal for grades 7 through 12, said more than 70 percent of the 160 graduates in the high school class of 1999 earned Regents diplomas.
HONORS classes are offered in math, English, social studies, chemistry and biology. Networked computers with Internet access are available in several computer labs and every classroom. More than 80 percent of students take part in extracurricular programs. The middle school, where antidiscrimination programs are emphasized, is part of the high school campus.
In pre-Colonial times the Manhasset area was inhabited by the Matinecocks. They called it Sink Sink, or "place of many stones." By the 17th century disputes over ownership raged between the Dutch and English settlers. The area remained rural and lightly settled through the next two centuries.
A trestle built in 1897 near the mucky southern end of Manhasset Bay brought the Long Island Rail Road, and by the 1930's the Manhasset area was a haven for commuters. In the early 20th century the Munsey Park area was still a rolling expanse of estate farmlands and woods. In 1922, Frank A. Munsey, a newspaper-chain owner, purchased the 300-acre estate of Louis Sherry, the confectioner, moving into and remodeling the Sherry home, which survives today as the Strathmore-Vanderbilt Country Club.
By his death in 1925, Munsey had more than doubled the size of his land holdings. Without heirs, he left all of his assets to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. The museum engaged land developers to build a high-quality residential community with strict architectural and land-use controls on part of the land, and sold the balance. The section developed by the museum was named for Munsey. Roads followed natural land contours and were named for artists. Over 2,000 people attended the opening of the first model home, on Park Avenue, in 1928.
The village's Copley Pond, near the Congregational Church of Manhasset, was once a water hazard near a now-vanished golf course's 14th hole. The course opened in 1932 but closed just five years later because of an operating deficit.
Now the pond attracts skaters when it freezes and provides open space in a village that has little despite its affluence. A large playing field at the Munsey Park school and Waldmann Memorial Park, a passive park on the village's northern boundary, also fill the gap.

DEPRESSION AID: During the Depression residents of Munsey Park held onto their homes tenaciously despite adverse economic conditions. A local realtor, Ernest G. Blaich, said in a May 1933 letter to The Manhasset Mail that while many of the homes were for sale at distress prices few or none of the owners had suffered foreclosure. Not until 1951 did the existence of an emergency committee village officials formed in 1933 to avert foreclosures come to light. The committee, whose members included the village's then Mayor, Harold B. Callis, and five others, collected money from residents and secretly lent it to homeowners at risk of mortgage foreclosures. In 1951, $268 remaining in the fund was transferred for other uses, and the rescue effort was disclosed.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: New Construction in Rockaways;
2-Family Houses In Arverne

 BODY:
The Briarwood Organization of Queens has begun selling new houses on a handful of sites in the Arverne section of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, the first phase of new construction on urban renewal land that has seen no development activity for about 40 years.
There are to be 40 two-family houses in all, in scattered locations south of Rockaway Beach Boulevard between Beach 59th Street and Beach 61st Street, in an area where existing houses still stand. Meanwhile, plannning proceeds for broader economic development ventures on the 260 acres of vacant urban renewal land. 
 Briarwood's project is called Waters Edge. Prices range from $227,000 to $260,000, with first occupancy planned for next spring. Eligible buyers must have incomes no lower than $40,000 a year and no higher than $133,500, said Vincent L. Riso, president of Briarwood. "The first six buyers were chosen just last weekend," Mr. Riso said. "We expect to sell out by September."
The houses, designed by Fakler/Eliason of Fresh Meadows, Queens, are all brick, with shingled mansard roofs and a one-car garage. No model homes were built, but at a sales trailer between Beach 59th and Beach 60th Streets on Rockaway Beach Boulevard Briarwood has built a scale model of the homes.
"People who are now paying $600 a month or more to rent an apartment in the area can live in a new house for the same amount of money, as long as they have good credit and a 5 percent down payment," Mr. Riso said. "We're having no trouble finding buyers."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
In the Internet Gold Rush, Fund Customers Find a Research Treasure

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ

 BODY:
CLICK on "buy." Click on "sell." Click on "payoff."
The mutual fund industry has joined the rush to the Internet over the last two years -- and the move seems to be benefiting both the fund companies and many of their customers. 
 Investors can buy funds on the sites of many no-load fund companies or through the sites of one of several brokerage firms that offer fund supermarkets. To avoid losing customers to on-line firms, many no-load fund groups, including the Vanguard Group, American Century Investments and T. Rowe Price Associates, have opened their own on-line brokerage firms, trading individual stocks and sometimes offering thousands of funds beyond their own.
Such supermarkets will be the conduits for the bulk of all fund purchases by 2003, with most investors relying on fund company sites for information only, according to James Punishill, author of a report on Internet investing for Forrester Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. By 2003, Forrester predicts, investors will hold $1.2 trillion in mutual fund assets in Internet-based accounts, up from an estimated $128 billion by the end of this year.
The most noticeable change brought by the Internet, however, has been its capacity to deliver detailed research to virtually all investors, no matter how much they have to invest. Using that information -- which is often free -- investors can compare funds before making choices. Dozens of Web sites offer performance figures as well as portfolio tracking, so investors can monitor their holdings and the shifts in their asset mix of stocks, bonds and cash.
"The self-directed investor has at their disposal what five years ago professional investors didn't even have at their disposal," said Cebra Graves, Internet strategist at Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago.
Morningstar's Web site lets investors compare funds and portfolio holdings at no charge (www.morningstar.net). For varying fees, investors can gain access to more detailed screens and data. Morningstar also supplies data to other companies like E*Trade, whose site provides free access to research and sorting tools using end-of-quarter data. The Mutual Fund Education Alliance, an association of no-load funds, offers a site at www.mfea.com with fund industry news, investment planning tools and links to fund company sites. Investors can register on the site to gain access to a personal portfolio tracker.
In other words, the Internet lets investors get the information they need when they want it. "Inevitably, you didn't get the brochure at the right time and, inevitably, the information you need isn't in there," said Shelton S. Unger, head of on-line services at Vanguard. With the Internet, a great deal of information is available immediately, she added, and you "sort of find your own path." Vanguard recently updated an investment planning service to allow investors to prepare on line for retirement, college or other investment objectives. The service considers the user's risk tolerance and time horizon, among other factors.
One bonus for the fund industry is that many investors who know the Internet are willing to receive routine information, like shareholder reports, on line instead of in the mail. That can help keep down a fund's expenses. When an investor requests a prospectus over the phone, for example, Vanguard spends $10 to $12 to respond -- in labor costs for the phone representative and for printing and mailing.
Internet use is climbing at Vanguard: 37 percent of all shareholders used the Web to get information or to make a transaction in the first quarter of 1999, up from 20 percent a year earlier, Ms. Unger said.
The trend is evident elsewhere. At Charles Schwab & Company, 45 percent of all mutual fund transactions were on the Internet in mid-June, up from 25 percent a year ago and 16 percent at the beginning of 1998.
"What we see is that the process of investing is easier, richer than it's ever been before," said Jeffrey M. Lyons, senior vice president for mutual funds marketing at Schwab. Instead of searching through magazine and newspaper articles for information and advice, investors can go on line to sort through thousands of funds and run through detailed asset allocation scenarios for growth or value investing as well as domestic or international choices. "Then, immediately, they click a button and invest in the fund," Mr. Lyons said.
Schwab and other companies say the ease of Internet trading has not caused investors to flip rapidly in and out of funds. Schwab customers are charged a redemption fee if they sell shares within six months of purchase.
Brian C. Murray, general manager for E*Trade's mutual fund group, which reserves the right to charge a fee for sales made within three months, said, "There appears to be an even stronger buy-and-hold ethic than I expected."
The fund industry has also found the Internet to be useful for reaching retirement investors. The 401(k) Forum is an Internet-based retirement investment adviser hired by companies to offer personal 401(k) advice to their employees. Fidelity Investments, which already offers extensive Web-based services to its retirement plan participants, is now offering a service aimed at small businesses, "e401k," that is a 401(k) plan sold and maintained entirely over the Internet.
Despite the success of the Internet as a means for research, the average investor remains a little reluctant to click and invest. That largely reflects how many people began using the Internet just last year, Forrester's Mr. Punishill said. In fact, most fund investors with Internet access visit fund company sites only for tasks like checking on a portfolio balance or downloading a prospectus, according to a survey taken last fall and published by American Century.
Although 46 percent of Internet users with funds visited fund Web sites in 1998 -- up from 28 percent in 1996 -- only 9 percent bought or sold shares, up from 3 percent in 1996 but down from 11 percent in 1997, according to the survey. The main reason for their reluctance is the fear that the Internet is not a secure place to conduct business. Some 52 percent expressed concerns about making Internet fund transactions, though that share was down from 68 percent in 1996.
PEOPLE who buy funds on the Internet are more likely to use fund supermarkets, where they can get consolidated statements and gain access to funds from other companies, Mr. Punishill said. Although fund companies have been forming their own brokerage firms, virtually none of them -- with the exception of Fidelity and Vanguard -- will be able to compete effectively with the big discounters, he asserted. "Very few fund companies will have the resources or know-how to turn themselves from a mutual fund company into a brokerage firm," Mr. Punishill said. "They are different business models altogether."
Some experts say the majority of investors are unlikely to ever use the Internet to buy or sell funds. Eli E. Neusner, a senior consultant at Spectrem Group, a financial services consulting firm, argues that as a percentage of mutual fund investors, those investing on line will peak in just a few years.
Investors can be overwhelmed by the amount of information on a Web site, Mr. Neusner said, and often prefer to speak with an adviser for guidance, particularly when dealing with complicated issues like estate planning or saving for a child's college education.
On the Internet, he said, "no one has found a thoroughly efficient way of walking an uncomfortable investor or even a moderately experienced investor through a financial strategy."
But Mr. Graves at Morningstar predicted that on-line technology would evolve to the point that any client could use the Internet to talk with a financial adviser on line. Once that happens, he said, "the Internet is no longer a technology that favors one demographic over another."

HEADLINE: In Washington, a Tax Break for Homebuyers

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Debbie Chewning started searching for her first home last year, she often drove from her rental apartment here to the bucolic streets of Takoma Park in Maryland, just across the border from northwest Washington, where she hoped to live. "I really liked it there," said Ms. Chewning, who has lived in the Washington area since 1981. "It was one of the first places I looked when I decided I needed to stop renting."
But when Ms. Chewning heard that the Federal Government would pay her to buy a residence in the nation's capital, she turned her back on Takoma Park. The incentive: a one-time $5,000 credit against her Federal income tax. "I started concentrating on the areas of the District where I could get more space and a yard that were in my price range," said Ms. Chewning, an office manager for a consulting company that specializes in environmental issues. 
 In March, she moved into a two-bedroom, Victorian-style home in the Capitol Hill area of Washington. Her $170,000 home includes a dining room, full basement and garden.
Ms. Chewning's gift from the Government is an unusual income-tax credit, available to income-eligible people who buy a primary residence in the nation's capital. It was designed to increase homeownership in a city that has not only seen a steep decline in population in the last few years but also holds the dubious record of having the lowest rate of homeownership in the country.
In the mid-90's, when the District's debt climbed to more than $700 million, residents could not always count on basic services like garbage collection and street cleaning. In 1995, Congress put the District's financial management in the hands of a financial control board. The city's health has steadily improved since then.
Eligibility for the short-term tax credit, which is available only in Washington, is limited to single buyers whose income is no more than $90,000 and married couples who together earn no more than $130,000. Buyers coming from outside the District may have owned homes immediately before moving there, but for District residents to qualify for the tax credit they may not have owned homes there for one year before they buy. Buyers must close on principal residences between Aug. 5, 1997, and Dec. 31, 2000.
What distinguishes this tax-credit program from other homeownership incentives is that it provides relief on income tax rather than property tax, which is a common provision of government programs.
A spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service said the agency had not tracked the number of taxpayers who received the credit. But a survey by the not-for-profit Greater Washington Research Center said its research suggested that up to 3,495 buyers claimed all or part of the credit.
(For single people with incomes of $70,000 to $90,000, the credit is reduced by 25 cents for each dollar of income that exceeds $70,000, and for couples the same phase-out in value applies for joint incomes over $110,000. For taxpayers who owe less than $5,000, the remaining credit can be applied in following years until used up.)
The center's figures were based on a sample survey mailed to about one-third of residential properties that had transferred ownership in the District last year.
Using the results of the survey, the center concluded that 62 percent of those claiming the credit already lived in the District, about 18 percent had previous addresses outside the District and the rest said they previously lived outside the Washington metropolitan area.
Real estate professionals, housing experts and local officials say the tax credit has contributed to the best housing market in the District that they have ever seen. A strong economy, lower interest rates and an apparent renewed faith in the District as a place to live have also encouraged people to buy homes.
According to the National Association of Realtors, sales of existing homes and apartments in the District jumped by 50 percent last year, the second-biggest increase in the country after Kentucky.
In 1998, 13,000 homes and apartments were sold in Washington, according to the organization. Sales totaled 8,700 in 1997 and 6,700 in 1996. The N.A.R. figures are rounded off to the nearest 100 and do not include new homes.
James Assey, a lawyer who returned to Washington after working in South Carolina for nearly two years, said the tax credit helped him make his decision to buy a home rather than rent again.
"I came back fully expecting to rent a place," said Mr. Assey, who started his rental search in the District as well as in Alexandria and Arlington in Virginia. "But I discovered that when I crunched the numbers and took into consideration the tax credit and the cost of renting, it made no sense to rent." Late last year, Mr. Assey paid $250,000 for a town house on Capitol Hill that includes his two-bedroom residence and a small rental unit.
JEFF CITRIN, who bought a $110,000, one-bedroom condominium in a prewar building in the Adams Morgan neighborhood, said that the tax credit made it possible for him to buy the apartment he wanted.
"I started looking in 1997 and then stopped to save money and pay off bills," Mr. Citrin said. "When I came back to the market about Christmas late last year, prices were higher and there were not as many apartments in my price range. The tax credit definitely helped."
Tucker and Susan Greer said the $5,000 tax credit helped them justify making a commitment to the District.
"We are both Government workers and we love being in Washington," said Mr. Greer, who works for the Government Printing Office. "When it was time for us to buy, I was really open to any option. When they dangled the $5,000 in front of us, it made the decision to stay in Washington easier." The Greers, who rented an apartment in Dupont Circle, paid $230,000 for their three-bedroom, 1890 row house in a nearby neighborhood, Logan Circle.
The tax credit was the idea of Eleanor Holmes Norton, who represents the District in the House of Representatives, as she searched for ways to use tax policy to revive the city. The program was part of the Federal Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997.
"We have already lost three times the population in this decade as we lost in the last," said Ms. Norton, who expects the tax credit to increase the base of taxpayers, stabilize neighborhoods and stem population loss. "This tax credit was the fastest way to stimulate homeownership."
ACCORDING to the Census Bureau's estimated population statistics, the District has had a 13 percent drop in population since 1990. The census put the estimated population at 606,900 in 1990 and 523,100 as of July 1, 1998. According to the census, in 1998 the rate of homeownership across the country was 66.3 percent, while in the District about 40 percent of residents owned their homes.
"Washington is a city of homes," said Ms. Norton, a native Washingtonian, "but the majority of residents are tenants. We need more homeowners. When you own your own home, you are less likely to flee."
Eligible buyers claim the credit when they file Federal income tax returns for the year they bought their homes. Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of home mortgage funds, which is based in Washington, and the District's Housing Finance Agency are working on a strategy to allow buyers to use the money up front for down payments or closing costs. The most likely plan will be loans from employers.
Patrick Lavigne, who with his wife, Lari, bought a three-bedroom house in the Capitol Hill area, said they were motivated as much by the city's atmosphere of rejuvenation as by the tax credit.
"Did the $5,000 make us decide to buy in the city; probably not," Mr. Lavigne said. "It certainly didn't hurt."
"Given the political situation in the past, living in the District has been trying," Mr. Lavigne said. "This was a community that for a time was not able to sweep the streets. But recently some of our concerns have been offset by improvements. We are more comfortable with our investment now."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2725 words

HEADLINE: E-Mail, E-Commerce And Now E-Buildings

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE 

 BODY:
IT hasn't become as routine as electricity, water and heat, but quietly and at an impressive pace information technologies -- especially new modes of electronic data transmission -- are joining established utilities as services that Manhattan apartment dwellers have come to expect.
"We already take cable television, local telephone connections and long distance for granted," said Jonathan Rudes, the senior managing director of Newmark and Company Real Estate Inc., and a member of the Real Estate Technology Forum, which is helping the industry match information technologies and market demands. "We generally expect that we'll walk into our houses or apartments and, like lights and heat, those two services will be there on demand." 
 Familiarity with other information-entertainment technologies, Mr. Rudes said, should breed expectations regarding their availability. He cited "smart" appliances operated by remote control and card- or thumb-reading security systems as future examples. With more people communicating by E-mail and shopping by computer, he said, high-speed Internet access in Manhattan apartments is already starting to become commonplace.
"Until you have high-speed Internet access at home, you don't realize how much you need it," said Ari Rubenstein, a commodities trader and adviser who, with his wife, Atoosa, rents a $3,300-a-month, 1,000-square-foot apartment in 180 Riverside Boulevard, a new Trump Place luxury building overlooking the Hudson at 68th Street. "Now, I wouldn't move into a building without it."
Mrs. Rubenstein, the editor of CosmoGIRL!, a new magazine and web site for teen-agers, is equally enthusiastic about high-speed Internet access, and her cell phone -- both "time savers," she said, "when time is a precious commodity."
Neither considered the building's offer of satellite or cable television (they opted for cable) an attraction, since they "don't watch and don't particularly care." But Mr. Rubenstein, in particular, was intrigued with the promise of the building's internal computerized information system, through which the concierge can track packages, make travel, restaurant or theater reservations and provide a range of interactive services, including teleconferencing, in which tenants are able to see and speak via computer with visitors at the front desk. The system also coordinates residents' maintenance and security/access requests.
Colin Abernethy and his wife, Alexis, didn't concertedly search for a high-tech residence either. But after finding the new space they wanted at their price and location -- 1,700 square feet for under $700,000 in the Ice House at 27 North Moore Street in TriBeCa -- they discovered that they needed all the information services their condominium can provide: digital satellite television; cable, if they desired; a responsive local telephone service, including the possibility of telephoning internally -- and free of charge -- with other residents and building staff; a reliable and economic long-distance carrier of their choosing, and, yes, high-speed Internet access.
"They may have started as amenities, but now they're necessities," said Mr. Abernethy, a former managing director at Bear Sterns who helped found Flextrader.com, a web site for retail investors, and plans to open a computer-equipped home office. Mrs. Abernethy, he explained, is the director of sales for Material Connexion, a materials resource library. She works at home, on her laptop, up to four hours a day. "I'm on line seven or eight hours," he said. "When it comes to processing information, wherever I am I need speed and choice."
So does Simone Procas, a litigation associate at the law firm of Gibson Dunn & Crutcher L.L.P., who with Edward Ferguson, the head of New York City's Trade Waste Commission, will be moving next year into a $635,000, 1,300 square foot condominium being built at 53 North Moore Street. "At work I go on line for legal information -- past cases, recent court decisions, The New York Law Journal," Ms. Procas said. "If I can get that at home, great; it means I can come in less often on weekends."
WAS it requisite to their apartment search? Not really, said Ms. Procas, whose priorities were location, space and price. "But it's nice to have the potential for several phone lines, cable television, the Internet, where I also shop for books, read breaking news and plan our vacations," she said. She could get used to these at-home services "very quickly," she said.
That's what building owners and managers are banking on as they install the infrastructure for information technologies, particularly high-speed Internet access, in new construction as well as renovations.
"They want to take advantage of having a captive consumer audience -- residents who will be in their buildings 12 to 24 hours a day and who will need services," said Christopher H. Martorella, the managing director of Boston Financial, a real estate investment firm. "Now, their audience is more technologically savvy; they probably use more technology on a daily basis, and feel more at ease. Owners and managers want to capture revenues from that."
And they don't mind benefiting from the desire of service providers to get access to those tenants. The competition can be so intense that vendors will offer to discount or bundle services, waive installation charges and wire the building virtually free of charge. Some developers may arrange to collect a small fee for every resident who signs up for a particular service.
Nancy Packes, the president of Feathered Nest, a Manhattan real estate brokerage, said that developers are giving increasing attention to the electronic sinews of their buildings, especially when their target groups of residents come from certain industries or professions. "Attracting these market segments," Ms. Packes said, "has made high-speed Internet access standard in the last year and a half. No new building has gone up without it."
Pamela Liebman, the president of Corcoran Group Marketing, said developers are also recognizing that many residents today want to work out of their apartments. "And a number of those residents were spoiled in school and at the office, where they had available to them fast and sophisticated technologies," Ms. Liebman said. "No wonder they have certain expectations regarding services that should be available to them at home."
Owners and developers of residential buildings, said Mr. Rudes of Newmark, are beginning to see information services as a point of competition. "It's starting with the technologies -- who can offer better reception or faster, cheaper speeds," he said. "Later, the competition may focus on content" -- who can provide better-quality, lower-cost information; who has the smarter, more thoroughly wired "information concierge."
Landlords are also retrofitting older buildings with the new technologies. Herb Hauser, president and chief executive officer of Barnes Wentworth, a technology engineering company, said there are about 50 major retrofit projects around the city right now.
"The whole retrofit market, and service industry, is likely to pick up," Mr. Hauser said, "once landlords and co-op boards discover how simple and inexpensive it can be -- $75,000 to $125,000 to bring fiber optics and broadband conductivity to a 110 to 125 unit apartment building. And you don't have to have a mess of wires or drill lots of holes in people's walls."
Developers and owners of residential properties understand that these new technologies are like apartment balconies, Mr. Martorella said, noting, "Residents may not use them, but they like to know that they can walk outside if they want."
Laughing ruefully at the analogy, Waiman Leung, a resident of the Ice House, agreed. Mr. Leung, an options trader, paid $550,000 for his 1,700-square-foot condominium. He loved the high, domed ceilings, the TriBeCa neighborhood, the space and the price, which he said was a lot less than what he had seen in SoHo.
As for the building's high-tech options, he said, "The D.S.S, or direct satellite service television, was a big draw, because I love watching football, along with Bloomberg financial news and CNN. And the satellite dish on the building's roof means that I get games from across the country and great reception."
Mr. Leung's home entertainment system attests to his infatuation. He hooked up the satellite video output connection in his bedroom to a Macintosh flat-panel monitor for what he considers to be "the best picture on the market," and the satellite audio output connection to a Bose system "to boost audio quality." He has a wide-screen, high-definition television in his living room, connected to six speakers for a surround-sound effect.
WHAT of high-speed Internet access, which he relies on in the office and has yet to use at home? Mr. Leung said that neither he nor his friends have found the proffered combinations of price and speed -- that is, the money they must pay for the higher speeds they like -- to be irresistibly attractive. "So," he said, "we haven't signed up yet."
But as with balconies, so with technology; Mr. Leung and his friends say they like the very notion of choice.
"Developers, owners and managers may not fully understand the technologies," Mr. Hauser said, "but they know that they are important to residents and that residents want options. That gives the developers enormous power. In effect, the spaces in which people live may determine the shape of the information industry."
The problems arise in the choices available. "It's as if it's 1900 and building owners wanted to install elevators," Mr. Hauser said. "If they went to Otis, they would get an elevator with an electric motor. If they went to another company, they'd get one driven by hydraulics. A third company sold steam-piston-driven products. There are many ways, technologically, to provide any one service, like television or high-speed Internet access, and every technology provider has a product and an agenda."
And every product has its merits, drawbacks and risks, as members of the co-op board at 133 West 17th Street are discovering. Jack Piry, the co-op's vice president, described the situation this way:
The turn-of-the-century building has 24 apartments ranging in size from about 1,300 square feet to more than 3,200 square feet. Maintenance starts at $869 and runs up to $1,575 a month. He said that one of the last apartments sold, a 2,000 square foot penthouse, went for approximately $700,000.
The only electronic services this co-op has are telephones, from Bell Atlantic, and cable television, from Time Warner. "We don't have even the option of getting on line fast, if we wanted it in the future," said Mr. Piry, who works with computerized patient data for New York Hospital. "The phone jacks are not always conveniently placed" (his is above the washer-dryer) "and as for cable television, the reception has not always been great, in part because of the wires."
VISITORS to 133 West 17th Street cannot miss the wires -- like two giant vines dangling along either side of the building, with a loose-hanging high wire in between. In most New York City buildings, cable television service comes in from the street to the basement, then courses up through the service hallways or stairwells, branching off on each floor to deliver the service to each apartment.
In 133 West 17th Street, however, cable television is supplied through cables that run outside the building from a box on the roof, and then into the individual apartments. The cables are unsightly, and, exposed to the weather, they have been damaged periodically, producing "ghosts" of broadcast images on residents' television screens.
"Many of us would like better-quality, cheaper cable," Mr. Piry said. "We'd like the opportunity for higher-speed computer use, and we'd certainly like fewer wires that are no longer exposed. Oh, and customer service for both telephone and cable has been an issue."
Don Judd, a member of the building's co-op board, suggested alternatives: For the television service alone, they could try a satellite dish, assuming, that is, that a dish placed on the building's roof would be in the satellite's line of sight. Or they could try a fiber optics-based system, especially since, according to a company spokesman, RCN Corporation has been "building out" in New York -- that is, installing and extending the reach of its own fiber-optics lines beneath the streets.
"The good thing about using an RCN" or similar company, Mr. Judd said, "is that the cable service is cheaper and the one company could handle telephone local service, cable TV and, through a cable-modem arrangement, Internet access for each apartment -- and with minimal wires."
But there are drawbacks, said Mr. Judd, who is responsible for the relationship between Lucent Technologies and Sun Microsystems worldwide.
These include the lack of competition, which he believes generates more and better services at an improved price; the limitations of any cable-based technology -- that the more people using it simultaneously, the slower the operating speed, and the issue of what happens if someone wants to go back to Time Warner: Would they be charged an installation fee?
"The bottom line for users," Mr. Hauser said, "is that they're at a stage when they can order 17 different kinds of spaghetti, but it's still spaghetti sitting there on their plate. Somebody has to take the bowl, untangle the mess and figure out which of the spaghetti is really gourmet pasta."
 
A Glossary of High-Tech Terms
 
Bandwidth: A measurement indicating the volume of information that can be transmitted over a network, usually expressed in megabits per second. The higher the bandwidth, the wider the information pipeline, the greater the flow of data. Even using the fastest modems currently available with phone lines, users can access the Internet over regular telephone wires at only 56 kilobits per second (that's 56,000 bits per second). By contrast, T-1 speeds can reach 1.544 megabits (1.544 million bits) per second, while digital subscriber lines (D.S.L.) can approach T-1 speeds.
Bit: The smallest unit of computerized data. The word comes from collapsing binary digit.
Bps: How fast data are being moved, expressed in bits per second.
Byte: -- There are usually 8 bits to a byte, or a single character.
Cable modem: A technology that uses a modem and coaxial cable to give computers speedy access to the Internet. The same coax may deliver your cable television service.
Coaxial cable: Cable configured with an inner conductor and an outer shield positioned around a common axis.
Dial-up connection: Accessing the Internet using a telephone and modem.
Direct connection: High-speed access to the Internet; just turn on your computer (if it is suitably hooked up to a T-1, cable-modem or digital subscriber line) and you're in.
D.S.L.: Digital subscriber line, a way of using electronics to move data at high speeds (at close to 1.54 megabits per second) over regular twisted-pair, copper phone wires.
Fiber optics: A form of communications using light transmission through optical (glass) fibers.
Intranet: The computer communications network internal to a building, company or organization.
I.S.D.N.: Integrated Services Digital Network, a network of all-digital, high-bandwidth telephone lines that can simultaneously deliver audio signals, video signals and data. In other words, it's a way of moving more and different data over regular twisted-pair, copper phone lines at a brisk 128,000 bits -- that's 128 K -- per second. Very popular in the late 1980's and early 90's, it is much less popular now.
L.A.N.: A system of connected computers within a building, an apartment, a house or other small area.
Leased line: A telephone line rented for someone's use 24 hours a day, seven days a week. A T-1 is an example. Think of it as a private line.
Modem: A device connected to the computer and to a telephone line or cable through which one computer can talk to other computers.
T-1: The name given to a bandwidth or category of leased telephone lines that allow very rapid movement of data (1.544 megabits or 1,544,000 bits per second) over the Internet.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Emily Epstein, Paul Landau

 BODY:
Emily Sarah Epstein and Paul Stuart Landau are to be married today at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Judge David G. Trager of Federal District Court in Brooklyn is to officiate.
Mrs. Landau, 30, graduated with honors from the University of Chicago and is a candidate for a Ph.D. in American history at Yale University. She is the daughter of Rachel and Melvin Epstein of Brooklyn. Her father is a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. Her mother is a freelance writer and the author of "Anne Frank" (Franklin Watts, 1997), a biography for children. 
 The bride's maternal grandfather, Herbert Stein of Washington, was a chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon and Ford Administrations.
Mr. Landau, 36, is an associate professor of African history at Yale. He is to become an associate professor of history at the University of Maryland at College Park in September. He is the author of "The Realm of the Word: Language, Gender and Christianity in a Southern African Kingdom" (Heinemann, 1995). He graduated from Wesleyan University and received a master's degree in history and African studies and a Ph.D. in history from the University of Wisconsin at Madison.
He is the son of Sarah Bradford Landau and Sidney I. Landau of Manhattan. His mother, an architectural historian, is a professor of art history at New York University. His father, a lexicographer, retired from the Cambridge University Press in Manhattan, where he was the editorial director and the editor in chief of the Cambridge Dictionary of American English, which is to be published in September.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
When It Comes to Tax Cuts, Torricelli Thinks of Elections

BYLINE: By James Dao; James Dao reports from Washington for The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The current debate on Capitol Hill over tax cuts is one of those grand hand-wringing spectacles that Congress does best. Return the surplus to hard-working taxpayers, or shore up Social Security and Medicare? Target cuts to the middle class, or scatter them about everywhere? Protect against future deficits, or stimulate the economy?
In reality, the choices are not so stark. And most people in Washington believe that ultimately, Congress will pass a Republican bill, President Clinton will veto it and the two sides will negotiate a compromise that more or less satisfies both. 
 Which makes much of this dust-up a form of political foreplay, noisy posturing aimed at the masses in preparation for the 2000 elections, when Republicans will run as the tax-cut kids, and Democrats as their fiscally responsible parents.
Leave it, then, to Senator Robert G. Torricelli, New Jersey's junior Democratic senator and senior political operative, to explain the raw partisan politics of it for us.
To Mr. Torricelli, the tax-cut fight is about policy, yes, but perhaps more important, about remaking the image of the Democratic Party. As he sees it, his party should not be on the defensive about cutting taxes. Instead, it should be seizing the issue, pushing for big tax breaks and forcing the 2000 electoral fight onto Democratic turf, meaning issues like health care, Social Security and gun control.
So Mr. Torricelli has been out front of many of his Democratic colleagues in pushing for major tax reductions. Earlier this year, he angered some Democrats by co-sponsoring legislation with Senator Paul Coverdell, a Republican from Georgia, that would greatly reduce the number of Americans paying taxes in the highest bracket.
And last week, he joined a group of centrist Democrats and moderate Republicans in advocating legislation that would cut taxes by $500 billion over 10 years -- a measure that falls neatly between the main Republican bill, which would reduce taxes by $792 billion over 10 years, and the principal Democratic bill, which would reduce them by $290 billion over the same period.
As Mr. Torricelli sees it, he is helping stake out a place where his fellow Democrats can eventually land. And then, with the right spin, the party can try to claim that it was there all along.
"This is an important moment for the Democratic Party," Mr. Torricelli said last week. "The traditional perception problems of the Democratic Party have largely evaporated. The Democratic Party is now given a fair share of responsibility for eliminating the deficit and creating annual surpluses. The extraordinary economic growth during the Clinton years has convinced many people of the credibility of the party in managing the national economy.
"The single obstacle left is to convince people of our commitment to lowering tax rates and keeping taxes as low as possible while still maintaining our obligations. It's the third leg of the stool."
As usual, Mr. Torricelli is operating on several levels here. On one, he is chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, in charge of the party's long-shot efforts to regain control of the Senate next year.
But he is also the putative leader of New Jersey Democratic Party, with a vested interest in seeing that a Democrat wins next year's Senate race against Governor Whitman, whose own tax-cutting credentials are well established.
The two major Democratic candidates, former Gov. Jim Florio and Jon S. Corzine, the former chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, have said they support President Clinton's plan, which calls for a smaller tax cut than Mr. Torricelli is proposing, to leave more money for Social Security and other domestic programs.
"The President's approach is more sensible, in that it targets tax decreases for laudable purposes and for the people who need those benefits most," Mr. Florio said. "The Republican approach is income redistribution the wrong way.
Finally, Mr. Torricelli must look to his own re-election in 2002. And in a state that he says is one of the most tax-sensitive in the country, pushing for deeper cuts can't hurt.
"I think people understand my role in this," he said. "While taxes are important to the country in general, they are are a particularly acute problem in New Jersey. With property and state and Federal taxes, we are perhaps the most taxed state in the nation."
The Senator's advocacy of a tax cut has annoyed some Democrats, who think he has gone too far in advancing a core Republican plank. It has also drawn hisses from liberal groups, who assert that his proposal to shrink the top bracket mainly helps the wealthy.
Mr. Torricelli says that is not so, that middle-class families earning $50,000 a year are being taxed at the highest rate. And he makes no bones about the fact that this is about helping middle-income people, and not the poor.
"These are incomes where people struggle," he said. "And the Federal Government has no business taxing them at that rate."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
All He Wanted Was a Little Respect

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
MAYOR Milton Milan was on vacation last week, having wrapped up a stressful game of chicken with the state of New Jersey. He went to the office anyway and, shirtsleeves rolled up, was able to reflect on why he had filed for his city's bankruptcy and challenged its overseers in Trenton to take over his operation.
The Mayor wondered aloud how he could have done anything else. Since he had refused the state's demands for stricter monitoring of its finances, and since the state in turn had cut off its regular infusion of funds, Camden was running out of money. 
 "When you push a city that has nowhere else to go, you can only expect the actions that were taken," Mr. Milan said. "When you have nothing and you are asked to give something, you're going to do what I did."
The weeklong flare-up ended July 22 in an agreement that left Camden without the new state payments it had sought but with an assurance that the State Financial Review Board, which has looked over his shoulder for a year, would be reviewed annually.
Many described the Mayor's gestures as more theatrical than fiscal. That is of no apparent concern to Mr. Milan, who calls his performance "the shot heard round the state."
"I think the City of Camden, being the poorest city in New Jersey, will get a little more attention," he said. "Wall Street called. CNN called. It was newsworthy."
Then he said, "I think at the end, the state of New Jersey and the people at the bureaucracy level have a better perspective on who I am and on the city of Camden."
Milton Milan was born 36 years ago on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and moved to Camden at age 9. He grew up on public assistance, according to a script that plays out across the city: "The story doesn't change: a poor Latino kid raised in urban area with abandoned buildings and nets with no rims, playing handball, playing in front of fire hydrants in the summer. Fights on the streets, brushes with the law, the friends who died or were arrested, or AIDS touched their lives one way or another."
As for the city, the Mayor puts a diplomatic gloss on Camden's dependency, while taking the honor-of-the-streets view that Camden is owed a little respect.
"What last week was about was making that recommitment," he said, recalling that Governor Whitman came to Camden to congratulate him when he was elected in 1997. "Partners look out for each other. Partners talk. They communicate. We don't want a handout."
Actually, the city does want a handout. Last summer, Mrs. Whitman pledged $15 million to close Camden's budget gap but installed the review board to supervise the city's finances.
Camden's tax base has been depleted by what Mr. Milan described as "people leaving their keys in the front door and walking away and the big businesses walking out of the city." Half the city's property is tax-exempt, and Camden gets no sales tax from its waterfront attractions, the New Jersey State Aquarium and the Sony E-Center Amphitheater. The city's unemployment rate is 13 percent and the per-capita income is $7,276, as against neighboring Cherry Hill, where the per-capita income is $24,458. In Newark, the per-capita income is $9,424.
State aid to Camden, including school aid, amounts to more than $3,000 a year for each resident. The state has taken over the police force. Services have been stripped. And still the city has a deficit of $24 million in its $111 million budget.
During the week of crisis, while Mr. Milan warned of police cars without gasoline and employees without paychecks, City Council members generally supported him. The day after the bankruptcy filing, the Council approved his request to petition the Superior Court for a state takeover of day-to-day operations.
But Councilman Gilbert Wilson said in an interview that "the method could have been different," adding that Council members had suffered the embarrassment of learning about the bankruptcy petition from reporters hours after the Mayor filed it.
State officials maintained that the city had no authority to file for bankruptcy in Federal Court and could not be declared insolvent because the money was in the offing as soon as the Mayor accepted its terms.
Mr. Milan declared that he was willing to step aside, letting state officials decide how to collect garbage and maintain playgrounds. In the interview last week, he insisted that he did believe that that could happen. "Not only did it cross my mind," he said, "but I found peace with myself in being able to live with that decision.
"I already knew in my mind at the end of this battle if it meant giving up my position as Mayor, at whatever level, I was prepared to do that," he said, "because this activist who crossed the line and became a political official, knowing what being poor and not having anything meant, knew that the bottom line was getting the service delivered. So whether I deliver it my style, or the state delivers it their style, the residents were going to get the services."
Being poor is a theme with Mr. Milan.
"I didn't have the luxury of going to college and getting out of an urban area and my life changes," he said. "My savior and support has been my mother and a four-year tour in the United States Marine Corps."
A few years later, having become a carpenter, he returned to Camden and started his own construction company. He was not yet 30.
Mr. Milan was elected to City Council in 1995, running outside the regular Democratic slate. By the time he ran for mayor, the Camden County Democratic Party had befriended him and provided formidable support. Mr. Milan won a five-way race with 40 percent of the vote.
The election of Camden's first Hispanic mayor reflected its demographic shifts. Latinos make up 32 percent of Camden's 84,000 residents, up from 19 percent in 1980; African-Americans make up about 58 percent.
Despite his comfortable position in the county party organization, the Mayor still styles himself as an insurgent. And in discussing the powers in Trenton -- especially the review board -- he grew irritated, leaning his jumbo frame across his desk and extending his arms for emphasis.
"Don't let me be answering to a group of people who have their own political aspirations, who come down here once a month and try to figure out the problems of the city in three hours," he said. "I'm here every day, 65 hours a week, and they're going to tell me whether or not I need sweepers, or whether we should afford to buy four or five police cars?"
He was careful to give Mrs. Whitman the benefit of the doubt, saying that the review board "hasn't allowed the voice of people of Camden to reach the ears of the Governor," but he returned to the notion of a state-city partnership with some resentment.
"They called it a partnership, but this partner had barbed wire around his ankles," he said. "There was only so much of that that the city would take."
The Mayor allows that Camden's prime problem is not the state but the earlier devastation of its tax base. "That has been the crisis in the city of Camden," he said, "along with lack of vision, a lack of leadership."
Councilman Wilson, often mentioned as a possible opponent in the mayor's race of 2001, agreed that Mr. Milan had been saddled with the city's mess. "He's doing the best he could be doing," Mr. Wilson said.
Mr. Milan does have some vocal enemies. One is Councilman Ali Sloan El, who quarrels openly with the Mayor and often points out financial irregularities to the review board. Frank J. Fulbrook, a civic activist allied with Mr. Sloan El, said the Mayor was effective when he wanted to be, citing his promising efforts to bring the battleship New Jersey to Camden. But Mr. Fulbrook called the Mayor "a disappointment" and his bankruptcy maneuver "a hollow victory."
"Were not going to be any more viable a year from now than we are today," Mr. Fulbrook said.
Mr. Milan said he had not decided whether to run for re-election. He sold his interest in his contracting company when he became a councilman, and he said his only construction activity was the constant renovation of the big house in East Camden where he lives with his wife, Kathy, and their three children, ages 13, 10 and 10 months.
He seemed pleased to point out that neighbors find him mowing the lawn.
"My kids," he added, "are out there picking up trash."

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB;
Unauthorized Days to Remember

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
People may use terms like truancy and playing hooky. But as the mail indicates, sometimes a little unauthorized time off from work can lift the spirit and refresh the soul -- if you don't get caught.
One summer Friday, when he was Philadelphia bureau chief for The Associated Press, George Zucker decided to spend a day at the race track. "If there's any emergency, call the clubhouse," he told his deputy. "The maitre d' has a telephone." 
 Sure enough, writes Mr. Zucker, who is now retired and lives in Haverford, Pa., "just as I was getting down to some serious losing, the maitre d' came to the table and said my office was on the phone."
The caller was the deputy. "New York needs to talk to you right away," he said. "I told them you were on the road, and I would try to track you down."
Mr. Zucker writes: "Public phones weren't available during racing hours, so the track's public relations guy said I could use the one in his office. He showed me to his desk and closed the door.
"Just as my boss came on the line, the stentorian voice of the track announcer boomed from an office speaker: 'The horses for the fifth race are now entering the track!' "
"Having found our dream house in another state, my wife and I considered ourselves fortunate to find jobs in the same company," writes Will Hall, a scientist who is now retired and living in Springvale, Me. She was a secretary to a vice president; he was a research supervisor.
But they soon found their workplace unfriendly. "Driving to work one morning, we joked about playing truant until we thought of a way we could work it," Mr. Hall writes.
"We found a phone, and I called my office to say that we were terribly ill, perhaps from the slightly odd-tasting fried shrimp we'd had for dinner. Then we drove to Atlantic City, where we saw a couple of shows, enjoyed some good food and drinks and very carefully avoided getting too much sun.
"Several days later, as we were driving to work, we were struck by the idea of trying it again; but we thought better of it and determined that we had better find new jobs. Still, it would have been fun to call in sick again and tell them we had finished the fried shrimp."
One day, Kathy Gambrell of Washington decided to award herself a day off from her job as an office manager for a doctor and to pay a visit to Baltimore's Inner Harbor. So she called her boss and said she was caring for a sick relative.
The boss said that since she had to go to an all-day meeting anyhow, it was O.K. for Ms. Gambrell to miss work.
So Ms. Gambrell wasted no time boarding an Amtrak train for Baltimore. "And who should get on the same train, sitting two seats in front of me on the Metroliner?" Ms. Gambrell writes. "My boss, headed to an all-day conference in Baltimore.
"She never said whether she saw me or not, though I assume she did. I was wearing shorts, a T-shirt and sandals and did not exactly have an elderly relative in tow.
The lesson: "Always find out where your boss is going to be and be somewhere else."
In the summer of 1969, Martin Wakesberg, now of Burnt Hills, N.Y., was 20 years old and working at his first full-time summer job, as a file clerk for a scrap metal company in Manhattan.
"I was scheduled to work July and August with no time off, as my raison d'etre was to fill in for the regular employees who would take vacation," he said. "But of course, as everyone knows, this was the summer of Woodstock, and all my friends were going. What to do?"
He called in sick and went.
"The following Monday I went to work as scheduled. Later that morning, I was filing papers and daydreaming about the past weekend when my supervisor came up behind me and said quite matter of factly, 'So, how was Woodstock?' Without missing a beat, I turned and replied, 'Great!'
"He just smiled and walked away."
Mr. Wakesberg's epilogue: "To this day, I have used my sick days honestly."
"Use truancy as a tool," is the advice to managers from Audri J. Carr, the manager of new product sourcing and a project team leader at Lucas Aerospace, a division of TRW in Aurora, Ohio. "Use it as a reward. Be understanding. Promote it quietly and within reason."
Ms. Carr, who believes that more time off than a standard two weeks a year fosters creativity, loyalty and productivity, cites the example of a manager in her group who runs three times a week.
"He has now been joined by several other engineers who run with him," she writes from Shaker Heights, Ohio. "Lunch is supposed to be 30 minutes. What with the four-mile run itself, changing clothes, then showering and changing back, that time pushes one and one-quarter hours at least. At first it bothered me. Was he abusing the time out for lunch? Then I decided the real question was: Did he perform on the job? Were his assignments completed well and on time? The answer was yes. So let them run. Running is a great stress reliever."
Ms. Carr writes that she would rather manage "a motivated, productive employee than one with perfect attendance."
