HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen Jetta;
A Workhorse Adds Punch And Curves

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR 

 BODY:
HE sassy New Beetle has become a highly recognizable symbol of Volkswagen's resurgence in the United States, but the real workhorse in the showroom has been the company's best seller -- the less retro, more roomy Jetta sedan.
The American small-car market has been dominated by Japanese auto makers who have churned out sturdy, sporty models year after year. Volkswagen, after a decade of dwindling sales and quality problems, has undergone something of a renaissance lately by re-energizing its styling with fresh, curvaceous lines, refocusing its advertisements to attract young buyers and recalculating how it dresses up its cars. 
 The Jetta had pretty much been an also-ran to the coolly efficient Honda Civic, one of the best-selling small cars, and other foreign entries. VW was also hurt by a reputation for slipshod quality, though it seems to have made some solid gains on that score lately.
This year, on the heels of New Beetlemania and a midsized Passat that got plenty of praise from most car critics, VW is offering a restyled Jetta, the four-door-with-a-trunk based on its hatchback sibling, the Golf. With the Jetta, VW is trying to take on the pint-sized competition by offering a more spirited car under the hood with a lot of standard features and people-pleasing details inside. Starting at $17,325, compared with $13,200 for the lowest-priced Civic DX sedan or $15,245 for the best-selling Civic LX version, VW is boldly suggesting that although these cars are about the same size, more money buys a lot more car.
This was no small gamble for VW, because so many buyers in this market make up their minds based on reputation and value, two categories in which the Japanese, especially Honda, have excelled. But so far, the strategy is paying off: sales of the new Jetta are up 26 percent over last year while sales of Civic sedans are off a bit this year.
In a test of both the Jetta GL, the least-costly version, and a Honda Civic sedan, I found that while you quickly sense the Jetta's power and acceleration, its handling was not as proficient as the Honda's. The Jetta leaned slightly but noticeably in turns, and the engine and suspension produced a tad more road noise and a harsher ride than that of the smoothly competent Civic.
But the Jetta stood out in two aspects. One is its delightful styling. Big, bold wheel openings play off a smooth, arcing roof that provides a styling touchstone for all VW models and echoes through to the arched eyebrow over the instrument cluster. I loved the way the top half of the adjustable steering wheel, like the bigger Passat's, lined up neatly with the curve of the dash in front of me. And the gauges, backlit with neon blue and highlighted with bright red needles, finished off an eye-catching, sporty cockpit.
The other plus is that the product planners have done their homework. They have studied the Civic and other popular small cars feature by feature and either matched the competition or gone them one better. The stripped-down Jetta GL comes with many touches that other auto makers put only on higher-line models. It has air-conditioning, power locks, a compact disk player and a keyless locking system. Honda Civics offer these features, but only on the more expensive LX and EX versions.
In the safety area, VW has two front air bags and two side air bags in both front seats. The Civic has two front bags, none on the side. On the Jetta, anti-lock brakes are standard; the Civic includes this crucial safety feature only on its top-of-the-line EX, which starts at $17,145 with a manual transmission.
Also, the Jetta has three adjustable head restraints in its rear seat, with lap-and-shoulder belts for three passengers, too. The Civic has two built-in headrests and lap-and-shoulder belts; there is only a lap belt for the center passenger.
The Civic is a larger car, with a wheelbase four inches longer and an overall length three inches beyond the Jetta's. The difference is seen in the Civic's leg room, which is slightly better, both front and rear, though VW improved the Jetta's leg space this year by an inch over the previous model.
The Jetta has the larger trunk -- though neither could swallow my bag of golf clubs. For that, I used the folding rear seat to stow them lengthwise. Both the Civic and the Jetta have lockable, folding, two-piece rear seat backs in 60/40 splits. Smartly, though, VW has placed the locks for the seat backs near the passenger doors on both sides of the seat; Honda's one lock is in the center, requiring you to get in the seat and turn around to unlock it.
Up front, the Jetta is powered by a 2-liter four-cylinder engine with a cast-iron block and two valves in each cylinder. Its 115 horsepower is plentiful, but what is truly impressive is its considerable torque at modest speeds. It does not do much for fuel economy, however. With a five-speed manual gearbox, the Jetta registers a so-so mileage rating of 24 city and 31 highway; the rating is 22/28 with a four-speed automatic.
Earlier this year, VW added a turbo-charged, direct-injection diesel to its Jetta line. The 2-liter engine gets a whopping 42/ 49 miles a gallon; prices start at $18,520.
By contrast, the Civic's leanly efficient base engine -- a 1.6-liter, aluminum-block four-cylinder -- produces 106 horses and manages a thrifty 32/37 miles a gallon with a five-speed manual (28/35 with a four-speed automatic). This is the first gasoline engine to meet California's tough low-emission standard.
Both the Jetta and the Civic offer bigger engines on more expensive versions. VW has a top-of-the-line GLX with a 2.8-liter, 174 horsepower V6. The Honda Civic EX uses Honda's variable-valve-timing technology for a more efficient, cleaner engine that produces 127 horsepower from a 1.6-liter, four-cylinder power plant. The V6 Jettas begin at more than $20,000; fully loaded, they exceed -- gulp -- $24,000.
While the Jetta struck me as a very well conceived car, I did catch a few goofs. One was that the neatly adjustable cup holders that pop out of the dash obstruct access to a storage bin and the driver's view of the top of the stereo. And while the sun visors include lighted vanity mirrors for both front occupants, the mirrors are covered by lids that, when you flip them up, block the light embedded in the ceiling.
And one final annoyance. The windshield wipers kept noisily slapping the body of the car. Was this bad adjustment or a Janis Joplin retro touch?
 
INSIDE TRACK -- A small car with some big-car touches but a not-so-trim price.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Japanese Nuptials in Exotic New York

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY STEVENS

 BODY:
THE wedding was scheduled to begin promptly at 11 A.M. The Rev. Richard Leonard paced back and forth in front of All Souls Unitarian Church at Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. Mr. Leonard, 71 and semiretired, has officiated at nearly 10,000 weddings.
Yet something was odd. Mr. Leonard said he had not met the young couple he was about to marry. "I rarely know their names until we meet out here at the curb," he said. "And then we continue inside to the parlor for a quick interview to acquaint ourselves before the ceremony begins." 
 The reason the minister had never seen the bride and groom is that they were recently arrived from Japan, part of a growing group of Japanese who go to New York to be married by Mr. Leonard or other ministers.
"These couples want every detail of a Western wedding," said Mr. Leonard, who added that most of the couples he marries these days are Japanese. They want that ceremonial walk down the aisle to "Here Comes the Bride," he said, "and even if they don't speak a word of English, they want to say their vows in English."
That was the case with Kyoko Hakamata, 25, and Makoto Yonekura, 29, the couple for whom Mr. Leonard was waiting. "We met at a dinner party in Tokyo and soon after decided to get married," Ms. Hakamata said through a translator after the wedding. "We both knew we wanted it to be in New York. We are getting our picture taken on the Brooklyn Bridge with all the skyscrapers in the background to show everyone we're on top of the world."
Mr. Leonard estimated that he had married more than 600 Japanese couples in the last 10 years, with the number of weddings increasing significantly in the last three years.
"This summer I'll average about three Japanese couples a week," he said. "And that's pretty good considering the economy over there." Most of the couples are married by Unitarian ministers, sometimes in a church, sometimes at famous places in New York.
The ceremonies are just part of the deal. Typically, Japanese couples sign up for wedding packages. The deals offered by Japanese travel agencies in New York often include limousines, flowers, tuxedo and gown rental, hotel accommodations and, most important, photographs and videotapes to record every step.
Mr. Leonard deals regularly with three agencies -- one is Aysulu New York, which arranged the wedding of Ms. Hakamata and Mr. Yonekura -- and he knows of five others.
Geoffrey Tudor, a spokesman for Japan Air Lines, said the Japanese first became interested in overseas marriage about 30 years ago, with the release of "Blue Hawaii," a 1961 Elvis Presley movie that featured a wedding in that state.
At the beginning, "The overseas wedding trend was something for the wealthy to indulge in," Mr. Tudor said. But prices have fallen, he said, and last year 49,000 Japanese couples traveled on Japan Air Lines to the United States to be married, up from 11,000 in 1989.
Noriko Tomaru, a wedding coordinator and photographer who started Aysulu three years ago, said wedding packages now constitute more than half her business. And New York, she said, is on the rise as a destination.
"For a while, Hawaii and California were the hot spots," said Ms. Tomaru, who advertises in several bridal magazines in Japan as well as three Japanese newspapers in New York. "But since New York has become so safe and clean, it's become the trendiest among young Japanese couples."
Many Japanese are fascinated by New York; there is a weekly television show in Japan that does nothing but profile ordinary New Yorkers.
"They want everything in their albums from the Empire State Building to the World Trade Center to Times Square," Ms. Tomaru said of her marriage-bound clients.
Ms. Tomaru's packages cost $5,000 to $25,000, exclusive of hotel costs and plane tickets. The basic package includes the wedding ceremony, limousine rental and flowers, and a videotape and a photograph album as keepsakes.
"We spend most of our time making a beautiful video and album, because most of the couples return to Japan and throw a large reception and show the video on a wide screen," Ms. Tomaru said.
Couples vary widely in their budgets. "Many of the brides and grooms rent their attire down in Chinatown," Ms. Tomaru said. "But I have the girls that want to buy from Vera Wang, too."
And while some couples head back to Japan the day after the wedding, many stay for a week to soak up the sights. Some fly to Disney World, a popular honeymoon spot for the Japanese.
Enchantment with New York is not the only reason Japanese people flock here to tie the knot. A traditional wedding in Japan can cost $50,000 to $150,000. The reasons: Everyone from both extended families must be invited and receive a gift, and kimonos, wigs and other customary accouterments are expensive. The only alternative is a plain civil ceremony.
One side effect of the marriage migration to New York, Mr. Leonard said, is his own fame of sorts overseas. "It's funny to think about how many wedding videos I've been in," he said, showing a picture of himself in a Japanese bridal magazine. "Many of the couples who come to get married recognize me."
Back at All Souls, Mr. Leonard paced a few more moments and then caught sight of a white stretch limousine desperately trying to switch lanes to pull up in front of the church. Ms. Hakamata giggled nervously as she got out of the limousine, a trail of fluffy taffeta floating behind. Mr. Yonekura circled her nervously as he checked his spiky hairdo in the side mirror. Her parents sheepishly got out after them. "Welcome to New York," Mr. Leonard said loudly, shaking their hands at curbside.
A Toyota Corolla, which had screeched to a halt in front of the church just moments before, looked like a clown car as a surprising number of people piled out: a photographer and his assistant, a videographer, a stylist, a translator and a driver. They hauled out a bundle of equipment and jumped into action to make sure they got pictures of the minister greeting the wedding party.
A half-hour later, after the couple rehearsed their vows in English and were coached about the kiss -- not a tradition in Japan -- the organist began a passionate rendition of "Here Comes the Bride." The couple entered the empty, guestless church, which can seat 550. The bride's mother was led down the aisle by the limousine driver.
After the short ceremony, the couple sat on the steps in front of the altar and spoke about their lives and how they met as the videographer taped and the photographer snapped away. They nodded to Mr. Leonard. Ms. Hakamata smiled and said in uncertain English, "We wanted to get married in New York because it's the best city in the world."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Media Companies Adding Web Cachet

BYLINE: By ERIC QUINONES

 BODY:
INVESTORS in search of long-term growth in Internet companies may want to heed this adage: Brands rule.
In some ways, that may seem a subversive notion these days. After all, scores of freshly minted dot-com stocks have climbed to dizzying valuations, and many Web-focused investors have bypassed the old-line media companies that control brand-name magazines, music, movies and other so-called content with Internet potential. 
 But Wall Street is betting that the situation is about to change, as traditional media companies accelerate their efforts to gain on-line advertisers and audiences.
Three companies leading the charge are Time Warner, Walt Disney and CBS. "We know the products that they offer, and we've come to expect a certain level of quality from them versus some newbie who comes out of nowhere and claims that on the Web they're the hottest thing," said Mark Hardie, a senior analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
And these companies can cross-promote their efforts, giving them a leg up on independent content providers.
All three companies have announced deals in recent weeks that add to their Internet assets, but the moves have caused little stir in their stock prices. "I'd say that value is not being recognized in the marketplace right now." said Tom Barrett, an analyst with MFS Investment Management, a money manager in Boston.
So investors who hope to gain from such stocks may have to think long-term. Tom Wolzein, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein in New York, expects the percentage of cash flow that these companies derive from the Web, an amount now negligible, to climb into the double digits over the next four to five years as they expand their on-line businesses. Cash flow is a good benchmark for media company profitability.
The on-line build-up is under way. Time Warner, for example, said on July 13 that it would merge Columbia House, the record club it owns with Sony, with the on-line music store CDnow. Time Warner will own 37 percent of the new company, which by the end of the year will offer music that can be downloaded directly from the Internet -- the hot new market for music.
After the CDnow deal was announced, Mr. Wolzein raised his 12-month price target for Time Warner stock by 28 percent, to nearly $91 a share, citing the company's overall Internet profit potential. The shares closed Friday at $72.
Assuming that the overall on-line advertising market continues to flourish, Mr. Wolzien projected that in 2001, Time Warner would have cash flow of $8.7 billion, of which 3 percent would be from Internet businesses. By 2004, he said, cash flow would reach $12 billion, with the Internet portion climbing to 11 percent of the total.
Time Warner has also moved to correct one misstep. It is phasing out its Pathfinder site -- a platform for magazines including Time and Money. Users tended to skip its home page and go directly to the magazine Web sites.
Instead, the company will focus on hub sites for target audiences, combining related magazines with links to the Web sites of other Time Warner properties, including WarnerBros.com and CNN.com.
Disney's Internet business took a big leap last year, when the company bought about 42 percent of Infoseek, an on-line search service, and then created its own portal, the Go Network. Together, the destinations are the fifth-most-popular Web property, according to Media Metrix, an Internet research company in New York.
On July 12, the company announced plans to buy the rest of Infoseek and merge all of Disney's Internet holdings into a new company that it will control, Go.com. Shares in the new company will be offered publicly through a tracking stock -- meaning that the assets continue to be owned by Disney but that the share price effectively tracks the performance of those assets. Disney can use the tracking stock for acquisitions.
Disney's stock has been struggling this year, in part because of falling merchandise sales. But Jill S. Krutick, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, expects the shares to rise from their current $27.4375 to the mid-$30's in the next year, partly because of Disney's Internet investments.
Mr. Wolzien expects Disney's on-line business to account for 4 percent of $5.8 billion in cash flow in 2001, rising to 14 percent of $8.6 billion in cash flow in 2004.
AT CBS, the strategy has been to tap into existing Web-based businesses. The company bought positions in several specialized Internet companies -- including Marketwatch.com, Sportsline USA, Medscape and Rx.com -- in exchange for millions of dollars' worth of promotion across its TV and radio properties. CBS is also reportedly developing a portal similar to the Go Network.
Mr. Wolzien projected that CBS would report cash flow of $2.5 billion in 2001, 5 percent of which would be from on-line holdings, with cash flow rising to $4.1 billion in 2004, 10 percent of it from the Internet. James Marsh, an analyst at Prudential Securities, expects CBS shares to hit $51 in 12 months, up from $43.9375 on Friday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Counting Coinages In Jargon

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
IF terms like "administrivia" and "elephant hunt" make you scratch your head, you are not alone. It sometimes seems that American businesses coin new jargon faster than anyone can keep up with. For evidence, look no further than the E-mail in-box of W. Davis Folsom.
Dr. Folsom, a business professor at the University of South Carolina-Aiken, makes a study of business jargon, which he said appears to be becoming both more prevalent and more confusing. He recently updated a jargon dictionary he compiled just two years ago and found himself adding more than 500 terms. 
 He also maintains a modest jargon Web site, www.duesouth.net/dfolsom, and receives many E-mail queries from visitors to the site.
Lately, as the stock market has alternately roared and coasted, Dr. Folsom says he has received more queries that go beyond simple market terms like "Big Board" and "basis point" to arcane expressions like "dead cat bounce" (a derisive term for a sudden rise in a downtrodden stock, from the adage "even a dead cat will bounce").
Most of the mystifying jargon Dr. Folsom is asked to explain is technological, not financial, in origin -- like "chip jewelry" (an out-of-date computer) or a "plug-and-play employee" (someone with the skills and knowledge to walk into a job and be productive immediately).
He is still pondering the full meaning of the computer-industry term "V.A.R.," for value-added reseller -- a dealer who does something to make the merchandise she handles more valuable -- which now seems to be stretching to take in some categories of computer consultants.
And he sees daily evidence of how American jargon can confuse foreigners, from the Israeli college student who couldn't imagine what a "cash cow" might be to the woman in Brazil who was stumped by the phrase "take no prisoners" in a business context.
Still trying to decode "administrivia"? Dr. Folsom defines it as trivial reports and bureaucratic busywork. "Elephant hunt"? Enticing a major corporation to move into a community, stimulating economic development.
When it comes to being understood, American business lingo, it seems, isn't plug and play.

HEADLINE: Dollar Makes Canada a Land Ofthe Spree

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario

 BODY:
LOVE brought them here, but the cheap Canadian dollar kept them from leaving.
Joseph Carte and Annette Lovejoy drove for two days from their home in Cottageville, W. Va., to Niagara Falls, N.Y., to get married, but the prices they found on a brief tour on the Canadian side of the Niagara River persuaded them to tie the knot here. The clincher was the exchange rate they received for their American dollars at a local bank. "We gave them $300," the new bride exulted, "and they gave us $432 back." 
 The Canadian dollar, nicknamed the loonie (for the bird on the back of the dollar coin), has been on a two-year descent that some people say is a little bit crazy. Although it perked up a bit in the first half of this year, gaining more than 3 American cents, to 68.9 cents on May 4, it has since turned down again, closing on Friday at 66.4 cents.
The longer-term decline, which economists attribute to the continuing fallout from the 1997 world financial crisis, has prompted a bargain-hunting boom by Americans. They are saving money by boarding flights to the Caribbean from Canada, placing mail orders in Canada, buying vacation homes in Canada and even sending their children to college in Canada.
Homeless Americans, too, are discovering the Canadian advantage. Sheridan Lee Taylor, 25, headed for Vancouver nine months ago from Utah with $600 in his pocket and never looked back. "It lasted me quite some time," he said. "Six hundred dollars American turned into $1,000 here, easy."
Of course, not all things Canadian are bargains. Certain products -- notably gasoline and alcohol -- remain far cheaper in the United States because of higher Canadian taxes. And other goods are routinely priced to reflect currency values; a book, for example, might be stamped "US $27.50/$45.00 CAN."
But whenever a currency is strong, there are good prices to be had in markets away from home, and the United States dollar is king around the world these days. Despite a recent surge, the euro has fallen 8.2 percent against the greenback in 7 months, and countries from Colombia to Thailand have found their currencies losing value against the dollar. The hegemony is making it cheaper for Americans to honeymoon in Paris or to vacation in Brazil. But Canada is closer to home, so it gets more than its share of American visitors out to get the biggest bang for their bucks.
Americans made a record 43.9 million visits to Canada last year, up 8.4 percent from the previous record of 40.5 million in 1997, when the Canadian dollar began its dive, according to the Canadian Governent. The American visitors threw their money around, too, spending a record $8.6 billion in 1998, up 24 percent from $6.9 billion in 1997, in United States dollars. And travel industry executives say the numbers have almost certainly risen this year.
American companies are also getting in on the action, spending $12.7 billion (United States) on acquisitions in Canada last year, up 70 percent from $7.5 billion in 1997 and nearly three times the $4.4 billion in 1994, according to KPMG Corporate Finance of Toronto.
"In a way, we're kind of another Mexico," said Ross H. Chafe, the president of Flags Unlimited in Barrie, Ontario. Last year, Aberdeen Fabrics of Aberdeen, N.C., bought a controlling stake in the company, which makes a half-million Canadian flags a year. "It was relatively cheap for them to invest in Canada," Mr. Chafe said, "and the dollar allows us to compete very well in the American market."
BUT this is also a game for weekend warriors, not just big players. Last year, about 20,000 Americans who live near the Canadian border drove to Canadian airports to fly to places like Jamaica, Cancun and Las Vegas on package tours sold by Signature Vacations of Toronto, according to Chris C. Robinson, the company's national marketing director. That's twice as many as in 1996.
"What we're seeing is a very significant increase over the last two years," Mr. Robinson said. He has been advertising in Rochester and Buffalo newspapers to draw attention to the bargains. "We've really stepped that up over the last couple of years to ride the wave," he said.
Americans don't even have to leave home to take advantage of the favorable exchange rate. Motorcycle riders, for example, can log onto the Internet to order oil filters, luggage and other accessories sent by mail from Wolf BMW in Alisa Craig, Ontario, halfway between Detroit and Toronto.
"The mail-order business is something we got going about a year and a half ago in response to the Canadian dollar being so weak," said Christine C. McQueen, a co-owner of Wolf BMW. "We sell quite a bit of stuff across the border."
American students are flocking to college in Canada, also because the price is right. There were 2,917 Americans studying in Canada during the 1997-98 academic year, according to the latest available figures from the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada. That is up from about 2,400 a year in the early to mid-90's.
Michael Reed, 18, of New Haven, N.Y., plans to attend the University of Toronto, a prestigious Canadian school where a partial scholarship will winnow down the costs to $8,000 a year.
"He'd been to Toronto and seen the school, but it wasn't really playing into his thoughts much -- or ours," said his father, William J. Reed. "But in looking at the money and how far our dollars would go, it made tremendous sense."
Americans are also buying vacation retreats in Canada. Keith D. Hodson of Stevensville, Mont., a manager for Para-Chem, an adhesives maker, just bought a third home, a two-bedroom condominium 16 floors above downtown Vancouver in a building called the Venice. The price was 280,000 loonies -- only $188,000 in American money. The exchange rate "just makes it a much better buy," Mr. Hodson said.
Matthew Brubeck, 38, of Berkeley, Calif., said he and his wife were also considering buying a place in Canada. A cellist in the band of the rock singer Sheryl Crow, Mr. Brubeck recently visited Vancouver on the Lilith Fair concert tour.
"If we came up to Vancouver and bought property, we could get an apartment in the city and a ranch 30 miles outside of the city," Mr. Brubeck said. "The American dollar being so strong would definitely affect a decision to buy property in Canada."
As American tourists throw money around across the border, the ever-polite Canadians are holding their noses as they pocket the cash.
Robin N. Rootes, 23, a waitress in Vancouver, says the big tips she receives from American customers more than make up for their sometimes arrogant attitudes. "They come over and spend and say they can spend as much as they want," Ms. Rootes said. "Yes, they are demanding, and yes, they are high-maintenance." But, compared with the natives, they tend to leave more loonies and toonies (the nickname for Canada's $2 coins) on the table.
"Quite honestly, we're going to make money off of them," she said.
Ben C. Giles, 18, a recent high school graduate, is making his money by handing out coupons for Circus World, a shop on the tourist drag here on the Canadian side of the falls, working from a post between the roaring water and an oversized Frankenstein holding a hamburger.
"So many people are coming over, so a lot of the students get jobs," said Mr. Giles, resplendent in white makeup, a clown suit and a fuzzy wig with red, yellow, green, blue and purple stripes. Still, he shakes his head in annoyance at the Americans who ask him what time Niagara Falls is turned off.
The weak dollar is good news for Canadian exporters, too, because their goods cost less in American dollars. As a result, Canada's trade surplus with the United States widened by 7.7 percent last year, to $16.65 billion. By the end of May this year -- the most recent figures available -- it had more than doubled, to $11.2 billion from $5.3 billion in the comparable period last year.
THE losers, of course, are Canadian consumers, who have to pay more for American imports and can only dream about the bargain-hunting trips they once made south of the border. Maxinne Cheng, who manages a store in Vancouver's tourist district, said she missed her trips to Seattle, three hours away by car, where she used to shop.
"There has been an exact switch," Ms. Cheng said. "Five years ago, we would go down to Seattle to get good deals. Now the Americans come here for shopping."
The latest figures from the Canadian Government show that day trips by Canadians to the United States dropped 11 percent last year, to 31.9 million, the lowest level in more than a decade and about half the 60 million in 1991.
As the effects of the powerful American dollar reverberate across Canada, Canadian nationalists are fuming about economic imperialism. "There has been a fire sale of Canadian assets and an influx of foreign capital," said Peter S. Bleyer, executive director of the Council of Canadians, a nonprofit advocacy group in Ottawa. "It is about taking existing economic assets out of the hands of Canadians."
He fears that in times of trouble, American companies will let their hearts overrule their wallets and close factories in Canada before laying off employees at home.
But these are good times for Americans, and for now, many of them are gambling on the cheap Canadian dollar -- sometimes literally, in the casinos in several high-traffic spots along the border. Even those who win, though, may wonder if their returns are all that great.
Ike Baker, 56, recently made the one-hour drive from his home in Depew, N.Y., to show Niagara Falls to visiting relatives, and he tried his luck at craps at a casino here. "I started with 40 Canadian dollars," Mr. Baker said. "I won $150; I lost $50 back."
Then he cashed in his $100 winnings, received just $60 in American currency, and asked himself this: "Where's all the money?"

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Propelling Exchanges Into the Era Of the Chip

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
AMERICA'S biggest securities exchanges are under attack for the way they do business. The day of the buttonwood tree, under which the New York Stock Exchange was founded in 1792, are long gone, and the days of the specialist seem to be fading. The era of the button -- otherwise known as electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s -- seems to be moving in fast.
The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market, the big boys on the block, are feeling the heat. Last week, Nasdaq's board authorized stepped-up preparations for converting the exchange into a publicly traded company. The Big Board is considering a similar move. 
 Nasdaq's action came a day after Archipelago, an upstart E.C.N. that accounts for about 2 percent of Nasdaq's daily volume, said it intends to become a stock exchange.
Harold S. Bradley, a senior vice president at American Century Investments, has had it with the status quo. He took some time last week to speak his mind and to say why investors should care about the exchanges. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
 
Q. This whole push for change at the stock exchanges seems to have come suddenly. But you don't agree with that, do you?
 
A. Well, we started using Instinet, the first E.C.N., for our customers in 1989. And in 1992, the Securities and Exchange Commission put out its Market 2000 report, which contained a section on changing technology and its impact on markets.
At the time, Congress was worried that E.C.N.'s like Instinet might fragment, balkanize and segment the markets and asked for comment.
We filed a 24- to 25-page response relating to our needs and those of our investors. But we were one of only four investment firms that responded to that report.
So this has not happened overnight. The New York Stock Exchange has been so immune to technology that people were saying they didn't need to change. But the partners in Archipelago, and we are one of them, are saying there is a need for new mechanisms.
 
Q. Why should John Q. Investor give a hoot? Why change?
 
A. John Q. Investor should care because if he wants to save and get good returns on his investments, he wants to get maximum return on his invested dollar and not pay anyone any more than he has to. Currently, intermediaries take an awful lot of money away from those maximum returns.
If someone is adding value to generate returns, I am happy to pay them for it. But let me pay 2 people instead of 10.
 
Q. Could you amplify on that? What kind of manpower is involved in a Big Board trade?
 
A. If you want to buy a stock, you call a broker, and you do that on your own or through a mutual fund.
My trading desk then calls a sales trader, who calls the position trader who calls the floor broker, and then the floor broker goes to the specialist.
That is 6 people, which means 11 folks are involved once all is said and done. I find that completely absurd in today's world, and I have to pay each one of those people in that chain. A computer chip can get me on the floor in a nanosecond.
The New York exchange has spent a lot of money on technology, and they can process trades extremely efficiently. But the way stocks trade is still the same. They need to spend a lot on point-of-sale technology.
 
Q. Do you think the New York and Nasdaq markets would function better as for-profit organizations?
 
A. I think they would become more efficient if they went public. The only way to be successful in a public company is to align the interests of your customers with your business model. Nasdaq and the New York have some of the smartest people in the business. As I said before, these problems are not new and not unstudied.
But the staff at both is completely bridled and throttled by their own members, who hamstring any innovation that might impede their own economic self-interest.
 
Q. Some have raised concerns about conflicts of interest if the exchanges were for-profit entities. Do you share those worries?
 
A. I see far fewer conflicts of interest in a for-profit exchange than under the current system. You would have public owners and accountability.
 
Q. A month or so ago, Merrill Lynch upset its brokers when it decided to offer its clients access to low-cost on-line trading. Isn't this the other side of the same coin?
 
A. The Internet disintermediates. It takes out the middlemen who are not creating value. Now, there is a lot of value added in the process. But right now it is hard to figure out just what it costs and where it resides.
When you take intermediation out, it will wipe out those who are adding marginal or no value. Archipelago is the functional equivalent of Amazon.com for selling stocks. The New York Stock Exchange has to figure out a way to be Barnes & Noble.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The American Middle, Just Getting By

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
TWO stately oaks on the front lawn grace the home of Tracey and Carrie Jones, and the front door opens onto a long, carpeted living room with a large fireplace at the far end. The Joneses linger in their living room, pointing out the view from a picture window, before showing a visitor two cramped bedrooms and a kitchen too small for a breakfast table.
The Joneses' single-story ranch house is definitely on the modest side in Madeira, a prosperous Cincinnati suburb. They bought it in 1995 for $132,000 -- the upper end of what they could afford. Their family income of $49,700 puts them, statistically, in the heart of the American middle class. But while Madeira would be an ideal setting for a movie about a middle-class family, the Joneses struggle to feel that they belong. 
 The robust economy of the last three years has lifted their family fortunes. Mr. Jones, 42, who designs machines that label plastic containers, has watched his salary rise 9 percent since 1996, to $43,500. Still, to make ends meet, he mows lawns in his off hours, making an additional $1,700. And Mrs. Jones, 37 and raising two children, provides a crucial extra by earning $4,500 as a part-time bookkeeper for her dentist.
"There are times when I feel comfortable about our lives," she said, "and there are times when I am with my friends -- most of whom are not working because their husbands make more than enough money -- and I wonder, 'What are Tracey and I doing wrong?' "
That a family taking in nearly $50,000 annually does not feel securely in the middle class may be understandable in expensive cities like New York or Los Angeles. But such sentiments are evident here in Cincinnati, too, where the cost of living is roughly equal to the national average and the median family income mirrors the nation's. Four middle-income families interviewed at length for this article say they do not think of themselves as middle-income. What looks good on paper does not, for them, translate into an easy life.
"Most people do not have any idea how the median family lives," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "The biggest news is how budget-constrained these people really are."
In fact, middle-income families have been stuck in place for a decade, their incomes even losing ground to inflation through part of the 1990's, according to data from the Census Bureau. Only last year did the middle-income family finally make significant progress; the median income rose by more in 1998 than in any year since 1986. Yet, in contrast to earlier generations, these families don't see themselves as sharing in the national bounty. Instead, they wonder why they have to struggle so hard just to pay the bills.
"We have the impression from television and the media that our prosperity is huge, but that is not the middle-class experience," said Marc Miringoff, a Fordham University expert on social indicators and co-author of a new book, "The Social Health of the Nation" (Oxford University Press). "These families have had to work hard for their modest gains."
The median family income is somewhere between $46,500 and $50,000 a year, according to estimates by Census Bureau officials and private economists. (The Census Bureau will publish the exact 1998 figure next month and the 1999 median in September of next year.)
That means that half the nation's 71 million families earn more and can afford more than Tracey and Carrie Jones, and half earn less and must get by on less money.
Clearly, middle-income families in America have acquired more possessions than their parents and grandparents had. But the middle-class comforts of an earlier day were accessible to families with just one earner; today, middle-income families find that they must combine at least two incomes, and often three, in pursuit of a life style that seems always out of reach.
And they work harder each year to earn that income. A married couple with one or two children, for example, worked an average of 3,860 hours -- more than two full-time jobs -- in 1997, up from 3,236 hours in 1979, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data by the Economic Policy Institute. Only 28 percent of the nation's middle-income families scrape by with just one earner, the Census Bureau says, and that is usually because there is only one parent.
What worked for the last generation no longer works for this one. But ask the Cincinnati couples, who range in age from 25 to 65, to compare their lives with those of their parents, and they say that the exercise would not be relevant. Mr. Jones's father, for example, made lots of money in a machinery sales business he started at age 55, after struggling most of his adult life as a machinery salesman for others. "I won't accelerate as fast as he finally did," Mr. Jones said, "but I'll get there in time."
During the 1980's and early 1990's, when middle-income breadwinners were losing jobs right and left and incomes were stagnating, public opinion polls suggested that for the first time in generations, American families believed that their children would not do as well economically as their parents had. For now, that doubt has faded. While their lives are a constant, precarious struggle, with periodic setbacks, the four families here say they are making progress nevertheless.
"We are in a different time," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "We do measure progress against our parents, but not that 'I will be better off at age 30 or 40.' It is, 'Am I going to end up being better off?' "
There are guideposts in this ill-defined journey, the most important being home ownership. All four families own modest homes that were bought for less than $140,000, the average price here. Three are on their second or third homes, having traded up each time. All the houses are air-conditioned, with showcase living rooms, and all are comfortably furnished, however small and cluttered the bedrooms and bathrooms.
Multiple car ownership is another common characteristic, though most of the vehicles were bought secondhand and some now have more than 100,000 miles on them. The families also have small stock portfolios, which have risen in value as the market has climbed, but in their eyes, the holdings are too small to spur spending. They view them instead as savings for retirement or a rainy day.
They all struggle to keep their spending in line with their earnings, showing an aversion to debt that Government statisticians say is characteristic of families at the middle of the income spectrum. In sharp contrast, lower-income families spend far beyond their incomes, according to surveys of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Not that families in the middle are averse to spending: The four in Cincinnati are steady shoppers, acquiring, among other things, big double-door refrigerators, radiant-heat stoves, expensive stereo equipment, cherry dining room sets, big-screen TV's, boxes of toys, computers and elaborate outdoor grills. One home even has an in-ground backyard swimming pool with a diving board.
"I think middle-income people have acquired a lot in this recovery," said Douglas Haskell, associate director of the Center for Economic Education at the University of Cincinnati. "But that only seems to accelerate their desire for more."
 
The Starters
Home Improvement: Paying the Price
The unlikely owners of the backyard pool are Sean Brandyberry, 25, a data manager, and his wife, Tulena, 24. As evangelical Christians, hoping to spend at least some of their time in missionary work, the couple shun material trappings. For them, a rising income is the road to financial independence, not to a home with a backyard pool.
"That is how a lot of people define their lives, by how much they have," Mr. Brandyberry said. "I am not saying we are above that thinking. We clearly aren't. But we try not to let it be a conscious force driving our lives."
The pool came with the 30-year-old, two-story, four-bedroom home in Springfield Township that they acquired last year for $65,000 in an estate sale. The pool was filled with weeds and dirt, the house rundown. "I thought I would fix it up and sell it at a profit," Mr. Brandyberry said. But with two infants, and three more children planned, his wife wanted bigger quarters than the two-family duplex in which they had lived the previous 18 months, occupying one apartment and renting out the other. So they moved into the new house themselves.
A few months later, this past June, the Brandyberrys became a middle-income family, when Mr. Brandyberry asked for a raise and got a big one -- to $34,600 from $29,200. He works for Kendle International Inc., a rapidly growing company based here that specializes in auditing doctors who test new drugs for pharmaceutical companies. His college degree was in religion; he even spent his junior year analyzing the Bible at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. But he had done well in math and science, and, having married before graduation, he tapped those skills to make a living, joining Kendle in late 1996 as a data processor.
While Mr. Brandyberry's salary alone is well below the median family income, he and his wife have kept their duplex and rent the apartments, adding $2,400 to their net income. Mrs. Brandyberry, trained in accounting, gets the family the rest of the way, earning $12,000 by auditing Kendle expense accounts at home.
Their total income, then, is $49,000. Their mortgage debt is $131,000, at 7 percent, and they owe $3,000 on a school loan. "What we have in income is what God intended us to have," Mr. Brandyberry said, "and we have a responsibility to be good stewards of what he has given us."
That means saving. But for all of their effort to do so, much of the young couple's cash reserve has gone into fixing up the house with touches like a new sliding glass door from the kitchen to the backyard and, most expensive of all, a new pump and other equipment for the pool.
In his day, Mr. Brandyberry's father had a similar fast start after college, joining the booming retail industry and working for more than 20 years as an assistant store manager for J. C. Penney, only to be laid off three years ago. He is working again as a retail store executive, but without regaining his old status or income.
Could that happen to the son? Mr. Brandyberry sees growth and promise in the pharmaceutical industry, and he tells that to his father, who replies that he had the same confidence in retailing when he was young. "That is why I want to be financially independent," the son said.
Right now, however, the Brandyberrys are stuck on the spending treadmill. Their only car is a 1992 Honda Civic that Mr. Brandyberry drives to work; it has 125,000 miles on it. They plan to buy a used minivan for Mrs. Brandyberry -- yet another expense.
"We feel we need something bigger for the two kids," Mr. Brandyberry said. "I guess need is a strong word. We would like a minivan as the second car."
 
The Strugglers
Wishes Deferred And Plans Unmet
When the Fraziers -- Carl, 65, and his wife, Geraldine, 54 -- imagine the good life, they think of the vacation they take almost every year in a $400-a-week condo in Fort Myers, Fla. "The sand is so white," Mr. Frazier said. "You are sitting on the porch, looking out over the bay. All you have to do is change your bathing suit once in a while."
The Fraziers have a slightly greater annual income than the typical family -- more than $50,000 a year -- yet in their own perception, life has been hard. They are the only couple of the four still living in their original home -- a single-story, three-bedroom brick house in the northwestern part of Cincinnati. They bought it for $19,500 in 1971, the year they married. The long stay was not Mr. Frazier's intention.
"My original plan was to use this house as a stepping stone," he said. "I was a real estate broker then, and I got this house on a repossession. Segregation, as far as home-buying was concerned, was winding down, and there were good houses available. I was going to upgrade my neighborhood."
The civil rights movement, however, diverted him. Mr. Frazier worked at General Electric's big jet aircraft engine plant here. After service in the Navy, he went to night school for four years, earning a degree as a specialist in electrical power. And G.E. picked him as the first black to work in technical publications, writing manuals and other material about the engines.
But some of his new office colleagues resisted his presence, Mr. Frazier said, refusing for a while to break him in on the job. Dealing with that absorbed his energy and blunted his progress. Racial tension at a public school affected one of the four children in the Frazier household, eating up their attention and energy.
"I was spreading myself too thin," Mr. Frazier said. "I lost my focus on my plan."
The Fraziers today contribute roughly equal amounts to the family's income. Mrs. Frazier, a secretary at the University of Cincinnati, brings home $28,500 a year in a job that also offers group health insurance. Mr. Frazier found himself forced into retirement in 1995 as G.E. downsized. His Social Security and company pension total $12,000 a year, and he works a few hours a day at a Y.M.C.A. for $11,000 more. And Mrs. Frazier signed on for night work with H & R Block during tax season, earning $800, so their income this year will be just over $52,000.
But there are debts -- and desires. Years ago, the Fraziers got in over their heads in credit card spending, and when Mr. Frazier retired they still owed more than $6,000. His severance package and a $35,000 home equity loan, at 7 percent, got their finances in order and allowed the purchase of a minivan and central air-conditioning, along with a dining room table, a living room sofa and stereo equipment (bought at a garage sale).
Mr. Frazier has discovered the interest-free 90-day payment plan and has used it for several recent purchases, including a dining room sideboard and an elaborate outdoor grill. But there are more needs, including a car for Mrs. Frazier to drive to work and various home repairs that Mr. Frazier is resisting. Having avoided new credit card debt, except for a small balance from this year's vacation, he wants to wait until the home equity loan is paid off, at $700 a month for three more years.
That is hard on Mrs. Frazier. "I want my house set, so that when I come to it I have it the way I want it," she said. "But if we make a wrong move, the pressure we had from the bills will come back, and that is painful."
 
The Builders
Dogged Saving And Some Luxuries
Government jobs lift tens of thousands of families into the middle class, offering them a security that the Fraziers do not feel. Gian Nguyen, 51, a Vietnamese immigrant, has taken this route, partly in response to his early hardships in this country. A Navy lieutenant in South Vietnam who had studied there to teach high school math and science, he found himself in America in the late 1970's working as a minimum-wage laborer.
Today, Mr. Nguyen's $44,500 salary as an engineer for Cincinnati's Metropolitan Sewer District doesn't quite bring the family to the national median. But his wife, Kim, 41, also from Vietnam, opened a nail salon two years ago that has finally turned a profit, netting $4,000 so far this year. The shop's success is so important to them that Mr. Nguyen has obtained a license in nail care, so that he can help out in his off hours.
"Whenever she has three or four customers, she calls me, and I run right over," said Mr. Nguyen, who gets home from his city job by 3 P.M. The salon's specialty is false nails, a booming business these days, but there are so many competing salons that Mrs. Nguyen has dropped her price for a set to $25, from $30.
Mr. Nguyen, who earned an engineering degree from Wright State University in Dayton in the mid-1980's, is bent on building up the family fortunes. Consumer spending does not have as much appeal for the Nguyens as it does for many native-born Americans, he and his wife say, although their son and daughter, both born in the United States, are moving in that direction. How much does the family save? "He makes $2,000 and we save $1,800," Mrs. Nguyen said. He corrected her. "It's $1,200," he said.
Mrs. Nguyen explained how they manage: "We don't go out to eat. We don't travel. We buy clothes on sale."
"This dress I'm wearing," she said (it is a long black cotton garment with a white flower design), "cost $10."
The Nguyens, who married in 1981, are on their third house, a single-story, three-bedroom brick home in Norwood bought in 1995 for $113,000. Their $25,000 mortgage is paid off, Mr. Nguyen said. He and his wife have no credit cards. Their 16-year-old daughter, Alice, making $100 a week at a summer job, turns over $70 to her mother to save. Their stock holdings, which they value at roughly $100,000, are regarded as a retirement nest egg.
The Nguyens have embraced the ways of middle-income American families. They receive a visitor in a thickly carpeted, comfortably furnished living room. Their kitchen has all the modern appliances, including a refrigerator with water and ice spigots on the door. Three cars are parked outside. The master bedroom features a four-poster bed and flowered sheets.
"We don't want a bigger house," Mr. Nguyen said, "but we would like a newer house."
 
The Strivers
Goals That Remain Just Out of Sight
Living among neighbors who have more possessions than they do, Tracey and Carrie Jones wonder if they will ever close the gap.
After years of procrastination, as Mr. Jones puts it, he received a two-year degree in mechanical engineering technology in 1993, so that he could compete more effectively against unemployed engineers seeking machinery design work. He had been laid off himself in the early 1990's and worked as a temporary employee for up to $19 an hour before landing his current job at Superior Machine Systems in 1996.
Carrie Jones dropped out of college, where she had studied nursing partly to please her father, a doctor. Only later, while working for a savings and loan association and then Fifth Third Bank, did she realize that accounting was her true calling.
She went to a part-time work schedule after her second child was born in 1994, working enough hours to provide benefits for the family until her husband landed at Superior Machine Systems. The rising cost of child care persuaded her to switch to the bookkeeping job for her dentist on a more flexible schedule, though at less than half the pay.
"I was making $11,000 at the bank and paying the woman who cared for my children $4,500, and I did not feel that was worth it, being away from my kids," she said.
But there are sacrifices. The Joneses have just taken on a $10,000 home equity loan to buy a used car. And there are stressful moments with acquaintances who are in better financial shape. Mrs. Jones remembered driving with a friend who was talking about remodeling and enlarging her kitchen. "And I thought to myself: 'Isn't it big enough? It's plenty big now,' " she recalled. "She asked me a couple of months ago when were we going to upgrade our kitchen, and I said my kitchen was big enough."

HEADLINE: Attention, Wannabe Gazillionaires;
A Company That Captures the Spirit of the Age

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:

To: Potential Investors
From: me@me.com
Subject: Internet Start-up and Initial Public Offering
It's not just young upstarts from Silicon Valley or Silicon Alley anymore. Even the old freight-delivery dowager U.P.S. is declaring itself an Internet player (it ships a lot of stuff bought on Web sites) and announcing that it is going public. The I.P.O. craze has reached the point that the stock exchanges themselves are hatching plans to sell shares. So I believe the time is right to take the Internet-I.P.O. phenomenon a pioneering step further, which I plan to do, with my new company, me.com. 
 The company promises to be an extraordinary opportunity for a select group of investors, and I'm giving you a chance to be one of them. Since I am in the pre-I.P.O. stage, the exact details of my company are still a closely guarded secret. Good buzz, as we all know, can be worth billions in today's frenzied market.
A careful blend of mystery and hype are key ingredients in the marketing plan of any good Internet start-up. As part of the comprehensive marketing strategy, I will also be shaving my head, piercing two or three body parts (as yet undisclosed), and lying shamelessly about my age.
The company is positioned across three markets with explosive growth potential -- the Internet (see company name above), intellectual property (I have lots and lots of ideas) and the human genome project (hey, I have as many genes as anyone else).
Yes, the company's losses are already mounting. But as we all know, in the Internet era there are no losses, only investments. In the hyperspeed land grab for mind share and market share in the New Economy, actually making money is a character weakness -- a sure sign of a worrisome lack of imagination in not being able to come up with more and more ways to spend money. The financially meek, after all, will not inherit the high-tech economy's Next Big Thing.
Me.com has already attracted the financial backing of Dick Digit, the Internet visionary and co-founder of harebrained.com, a company I regard as nearly as path-breaking as my own. Dick, of course, is now a gazillionaire because harebrained.com was acquired only four months after it was founded for a stupifying sum by a major computer company desperate to jump on the Internet bandwagon.
Which brings me to the company's long-term (a maximum of six months) strategy, which is founded upon two plans that are calculated to trigger results. Plan No. 1: Create some buzz and persuade Microsoft that America Online is anxious to buy me.com, which will prompt Microsoft to buy the company so that its archrival will not get it. Plan No. 2: Plan No. 1 in reverse. Convince America Online to snap up me.com to keep it out of Microsoft's clutches. Either way, me.com is a decided winner.
Finally, I think I should say a bit about an aspect critical to business but regrettably neglected in most Internet start-ups -- management. The management structure and philosophy behind me.com is, I'm proud to say, one of its unique features. It is the ultimate "lean" company, quick and responsive, distinctively able to react faster than flame mail over a T3 line. Me.com has a totally flat organizational structure, no layers of bureaucratic flab bogging down the decision-making process. I am the chairman, chief executive officer, chief technology officer and sole employee of me.com. It's all me, just me.
 
Addendum: F.Y.I.
The Net being the Net, if you actually go looking for www.me.com on the Web, as many of you wannabe gazillionaires will doubtless do, it will indeed take you somewhere, though, unfortunately not to me@me.com. Last week, Net surfers would find a page that was part of the corporate Web site for Job 1 Systems Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., a company that provides "financing and strategic services for start-ups." But Brian G. Job, a graduate of Stanford and the Harvard business school, said he had just sold off the Web address, or domain name, to an eager bidder. And like everything else on the Net, me.com is changing fast. STEVE LOHR

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1037 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Fears of Rape and Violence;
Women Newly Seeking Asylum

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
NO one denies that their stories are horrific: beatings, rape, genital mutilation or the threat of it. But foreign women seeking asylum on these grounds have received a mixed welcome in the United States.
Three years ago, the door opened a bit for some women who claimed that their sex rendered them victims of persecution. In a landmark decision, the Board of Immigration Appeals granted asylum to Fauziya Kassindja, who said her clitoris would be cut off if she were forced to return home to Togo. The board, the highest administrative court for asylum cases, agreed that female circumcision was equivalent to the more widely recognized rights violations of political and religious persecution. Ms. Kassindja's case also met other important criteria -- a well-founded fear of persecution because she belonged to a social group, in her case women of her tribe who opposed genital mutilation. 
 But the Kassindja ruling has not, as many women's groups and human rights lawyers hoped, blazed an unambiguous trail for others seeking a safe haven from persecution based on sex. In late June, the board denied asylum to Rodi Alvarado Pena, a Guatemalan woman who had escaped both a brutal husband and apathetic authorities.
Ten of the 15 members of the appeals board said Ms. Alvarado had not proved she was persecuted because of her social class or opinion. Her husband raped and beat her regardless of her beliefs, the judges ruled, and while Ms. Alvarado may merit protection on humanitarian grounds, asylum is not meant to be an all-encompassing remedy for people fleeing oppressive societies.
Because of the attention to these cases, rights advocates are challenging the conventional wisdom. Ms. Alvarado's supporters have petitioned Attorney General Janet Reno and the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco to review the decision by the Board of Immigration Appeals. They also may try a novel tack: portraying Ms. Alvarado as a victim of torture who should not be sent back to her torturer.
"This decision has really garnered the attention of people across the country on different levels -- from Congress to the immigration advocates, to women's groups and people in the Administration," said Karen Musalo, a professor at Hastings College of the Law at the University of California in San Francisco. "But for the time being, it is a binding precedent that has devastating consequences."
Applicants for asylum must first prove they cannot return home because of "persecution or a well-founded fear of persecution on account of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion." The law was a product of the cold war, written with dissidents from totalitarian regimes in mind.
"The assumption was that there is a distinction between political and economic suffering and between what was political and personal," said Gary E. Rubin, the director of public policy of the New York Association for New Americans. "Now the line between personal and political is being renegotiated and things that people thought were personal tended to have political meaning."
In the recent past, the meaning of "social group" has been extended to include those persecuted on the basis of sexual orientation, ethnicity and even, in the case of journalists, profession. Gender as social group seemed the natural next frontier.
IN 1985 the executive committee of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said women facing abuse because they transgress the customs of their society are a special "social group." It took another eight years before the United Nations recognized violence against women as a human rights violation. The same year, spurred in part by the reports of a systematic pattern of rape in Bosnia, Canada adopted pioneering guidelines granting refugee status to women facing persecution on account of their gender. Two years later the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service broadened its own guidelines to give greater weight to women seeking asylum who feared genital mutilation and sexual violence. In 1996 female circumcision, whether part of a woman's culture or not, was outlawed in this country.
But inconsistent rulings in recent cases here and in Canada show that each woman seeking asylum on grounds of gender-based persecution must fight the battle anew. Last year, the board denied asylum to Adelaide Abankwah, a Ghanaian who feared she would be circumcised forcibly if she returned home. The board said she had not proved that her fear was reasonable. Ms. Abankwah was released only on July 20, after two years in a New York City detention center, when a Federal appeals court ruled she could not be expected to provide the kind of proof the board had demanded. "A genuine refugee does not flee her native country armed with affidavits, expert witnesses, and extensive documentation," the court said, and sent the case back to the immigration board.
A different issue, central to Ms. Alvarado's case, is likely to affect asylum seekers fleeing countries where violence against women is considered within the rights of husbands and fathers. Ms. Alvarado's lawyers argued that she belonged to a persecuted social group they defined as "Guatemalan women who have been involved intimately with Guatemalan male companions, who believe that women are to live under male domination." The judges said the group defined was not cohesive enough to qualify for asylum. They also said Ms. Alvarado had not shown that her husband beat her because she was, or he believed her to be, opposed to the patriarchal culture.
Women's advocates say the only act of opposition that women in such cultures can take is to flee their country. And a society that fails to punish batterers or ignores women's basic human rights is enforcing a political policy, they say.
That is the disputed new frontier for women seeking asylum. As an immigration judge in Virginia ruled in 1994 in the case of a Jordanian woman who ran away from an abusive husband, a woman can challenge the system simply by seeking a new life in the United States. The judge, Paul A. Nejelski, wrote, "The respondent has espoused a belief that she is an individual."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Disney's Brave New Town;
Trouble at the Happiest School on Earth

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: CELEBRATION, Fla.

 BODY:
THE start of the school year here is just a few days away, so it was no surprise that there was a line of parents at the Celebration School office the other day. But the reason for the line was: They were queueing up to withdraw their children.
When Celebration School first opened three years ago, some of the same people had lined up to enroll their children in the ballyhooed educational gem designed by top experts from across the country. It was to be a world-class institution that would take children from kindergarten through 12th grade in the highly planned brave new town created here by the Walt Disney Company. The school, at the literal and figurative center of the town, was to use the most advanced educational methods. And the plans even called for an adjoining teaching academy to share the innovations with educators nationwide. 
 But as the beginning of the fourth school year approaches on Aug. 6, administrators, teachers and even executives of Disney's Celebration Company are being whipsawed by turmoil.
Some of the families most deeply involved in the school have transferred their children to other schools or even packed up and left town. Among them are the president of the Parent-Teacher Association and her immediate predecessor.
The frustration has two primary causes. Some people are fed up with the potpourri of progressive methods; few textbooks are used, for instance, and, at first, no grades were given. Others are leaving because they believe the school is pulling back from that progressive approach and the innovations that drew them to Celebration in the first place.
An examination of the sometimes contradictory motives offers a lesson in what can happen when high-minded educational theory collides with the expectations of parents and the realities of public schools in Florida, a state that ranks near the bottom in most measures of educational quality.
Disney, through its Celebration Company, is developing this town, about 20 miles southwest of Orlando, as an alternative to the isolation of suburban sprawl. Since the first residents moved in three years ago, the town has grown to more than 2,000. Most are drawn by the small-town feel, which includes tree-lined sidewalks, ample parks, turn-of-the-century architecture and a convenient town center.
Celebration School is vital to the cozy atmosphere -- and it's a big part of the draw -- but there is nothing old-fashioned about the school. Although it is public and part of the Osceola County school district, the school was designed largely by education experts brought in by Disney from leading universities, including Harvard, Auburn and Johns Hopkins.
"By bringing in experts from places like Harvard and other places and blending their theories with real-world practices, we began to think that there would be a vision of a public school that would be a lighthouse for new ideas," said Don Killoren, the former general manager of the Celebration Company, which is developing and operating the town for Disney.
In brainstorming sessions over two years, long before ground was broken, the experts came up with the kindergarten-through-12th grade approach, something rarely seen these days. This, they said, would provide continuity for students, teachers and families. And resources could be shared among the grades. For instance, an excellent high school teacher might be available occasionally to work with bright children from lower grades.
Classrooms are as big as 5,000 square feet to accommodate the multi-age groupings that theorists like Harvard's Howard Gardner say promote better individual learning. The age range is fairly narrow in the upper grades, but classrooms of up to 100 students serve children from kindergarten through fifth grade.
In the beginning, there were no letter grades. Instead students and parents were provided with "authentic assessments," individualized evaluations of their children's strengths and weaknesses. Standardized tests were replaced by interdisciplinary projects designed by the students themselves, with portfolios, not report cards, as a record of their work. Computers and other technology took the place of textbooks.
Classroom schedules were flexible so students could work at their own pace. Even the language reflected the progressive education theory. Teachers are called "learning leaders" and students are "learners." They meet not in classrooms but "neighborhoods."
MOST of these concepts have been tried in one form or another at progressive schools, but had never been used all at once in a brand-new school. In one of the early planning sessions, Robert Peterkin of Harvard had cautioned that it would take years for everything to work smoothly. "I would just urge Disney to realize that there will be ups and downs, that this is a long haul," he said.
He proved prescient. The school opened in the fall of 1996 in temporary quarters, with about 200 students and a handful of teachers. The adjustment was difficult for parents and teachers alike, but there was always the promise of how well it would go the next year when everyone moved into the new building.
In the fall of 1997, nearly 800 students started school in the new building, but many of the problems remained. Parents complained about the lack of homework and the inability to track progress without grades and tests. The unstructured classes confused some parents and students. Teachers struggled with the burdens of multi-age classrooms and working without a written curriculum, all under the intense scrutiny of worried parents and the national media.
By the summer of 1998, a handful of people had pulled their children out. They felt their children couldn't afford to wait until everything worked smoothly.
Others banded together and sought changes, with some success. Grades were instituted for the high school, largely to help students get into colleges, where portfolios are seldom part of the application process. Textbooks were brought in to augment the technology. More structure was imposed on class schedules.
THE compromises brought a dash of real-world practicality to the ivory tower theories. The simple passage of time helped people adjust and adapt to the new methods. As the school year ended last May, the controversy seemed to have simmered down. Certainly some parents were still dissatisfied and a few decided to leave, but most appeared to sense progress.
"Graduation for me last May was just a real high point because I felt people were finally beginning to feel at home," said Dot Davis, the director of Celebration School.
But then came a bombshell. Officials announced last month that the kindergarten-through-high school concept would be abandoned, and a 2,000-student regional high school would be built in another part of town. The reasons were economic, not educational. Faced with overcrowding and a sparse budget for construction, the Osceola County school district had struck a deal with the Celebration Company, which would donate 50 acres for the high school. The plan would save the district $10 million. And it would save Disney the cost of building more schools as Celebration grows to its projected population of 20,000.
Michael E. Mekdeci, the Celebration Company's liaison officer with the school district, said the company will spend about $25 million on the high school and on expansion of the existing school, which will serve elementary students.
Still, many parents felt betrayed. After three years of fighting for progress in the innovative community school, they were facing a return to what they considered the most traditional of education plans, the huge regional high school.
School officials have tried to mollify parents by promising to maintain the progressive curriculum through a "school within a school" at the future high school. In its contract with the school district, Celebration Company included language specifying that the district would adhere to the initial philosophy of the school.
The departures do not amount to a stampede, but the school has not yet compiled figures on the number of students leaving. And those who are leaving have a myriad of reasons beyond the school. In many ways, the departures represent a normal shake-out in any new venture, particularly in a new town where people came with expectations of a perfect life.
