HEADLINE: The World: Out of Control;
The Internet Changes Dictatorship's Rules

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
IT used to be easier to spot the telltale signs of a revolution in the making. There were the Molotov cocktails, the placard-bearing protesters, the fiery speeches, the subversive tapes made by shadowy underground leaders with ski hoods and thrilling stage names. If and when they succeeded, revolutionaries often tightened their grip on power through the mass media: the heroic movies, stirring music raining down from communal loudspeakers, television news cut and tailored to suit the regime.
But now China, home of the very visible Long March and the agit-prop film, followed by the big-character poster and the Goddess of Democracy, has been caught off guard by a vast, silent, virtually invisible movement (if not exactly a revolution) that came together not on the streets but on the Internet. Its distinguishing activity is collective deep-breathing. Its ideology, if it can be called that, includes the notion that Buddhist-style concentration can cultivate "supernormal" powers. Its leader, Li Hongzhi, is a former office clerk who now lives in New York. Its tens of millions of members appear to dress like the white-collar middle class people they are. 
 The panicked reaction by the Chinese Government -- which in recent weeks banned the movement known as Falun Gong and sent 1,200 state employees who were members to that Asian Communist mind-cleanser, re-education, is perhaps even more startling than the movement itself. It demonstrates in a flash of instant history that totalitarians, already flummoxed by the fax machine and the cellular phone, may be facing the biggest high-tech challenge of all in the Internet.
"This is not the first time that the Internet's been used in China in a way that's been threatening to the Government," Elizabeth Economy, senior fellow for China at the Council on Foreign Relations, points out. She said that the China Democracy Party, whose leaders were arrested last year, was found to have used the Internet to organize across the country. "The thing that was so threatening was certainly not the number of people, but rather that this was inter-provincial, that in over two-thirds of Chinese provinces, the China Democracy Party was able to establish branches. And this was explicitly political in the way that Falun Gong is not. The China Democracy Party still exists. It's still there, and it can emerge at any time because of the Internet."
The Internet's power to change behavior, from consumer buying habits to self-education, self-diagnosis and new directions in leisure activity, is well understood in the West. Its networking power has been used extremely effectively by low-budget civic and political organizations in fields as diverse as environmental protection and international criminal law.
But it has often been assumed in industrial countries that access to computers and the Internet was limited to such small elite groups in the developing nations that there would be little public impact in the near future. Experts have focused on just the opposite trend: that developmental gaps between the people of rich and poor nations, whatever their political systems, would only widen catastrophically in the short term.
Then along came the China Democracy Party and, now, the much bigger Falun Gong with tens of millions of members; they prove that all it takes is an elite that can motivate the masses to give the one-party state a scare. It is worse still for totalitarians when those citizens with access to computers draw on old traditions and religions to broaden the appeal of troublesome sects or cults.
In societies accustomed to sharing a still-rare technological tool, one computer (like one village television receiver or a communal phone) can serve many people, especially if they are hungry for the information being provided. And to a totalitarian state, the Internet is a double fright because it can be simultaneously intensely private and endlessly public, a terror because it operates unseen at both levels. Had 10,000 Falun Gong supporters not suddenly appeared as if by magic in April outside the private residence compound of the Chinese leadership in Beijing, where they proceeded to conduct their peaceful meditative exercises, who would have known the breadth of the movement's reach?
This is a profoundly disturbing discovery for China or any country where there are still unsettled and potentially dangerous political questions about the pace and direction of modernization. Most governments are aware of the need to liberalize the flow of information in order to attract international business and to secure a place in the global economy. International lending organizations are demanding data once withheld by secretive governments.
"The Chinese Government has made the decision that it wants to continue to advance information technology," said Ms. Economy. "They recognize the challenges that it is going to pose for them, but they think that it is too important to their economic modernization to stop. What they are trying to do obviously is to control it."
But to counter the threat, the Government is still falling back on old techniques. For the Chinese Communist Party to compete in the open marketplace of ideas is still anathema. Furthermore, what if independent trade unions or other groups start to organize through the Internet? Re-education, a Maoist method of mind control also recently resurrected widely in Tibet, is now as out of date as the doctored newsreel or the propagandistic "documentary" used by Fascists and Communists alike to drum up pride in the state and its ruler.
Few countries can opt out of the technological revolution, though even the United States sees a need to police it in order to protect national security. Only a regime like Saddam Hussein's in Iraq, which really wants only to sell oil, not establish a modern business environment, can enforce a ban on Internet use under a pervasive reign of terror. In any case, international sanctions have reduced Iraq's telephone service to a ludicrous level, cutting off until very recently those who might have tried to evade restrictions in their hunger for information from the outside world.
Vietnam, clinging to a Communist political-control mindset, has been ambivalent on the issue of technology without borders. India, a democracy and a software exporter, tried at first to monopolize Internet connections but gave up under public pressure for better services. By contrast in Singapore, where one party has dominated politics ruthlessly, but where educated people are recognized as the nation's most valuable natural resource (and foreign companies are welcomed), Internet access has been made simple.
When historians look back on the latter part of the 20th century, they may be tempted in the short term to see it as an era that rendered Orwell passe, an age when exploding technology ended the possibility of totalitarian thought control -- at least until dictators or new mind-closing movements devise new methods of isolating people. There are already fears that racist hate groups or new age religious cults with authoritarian or apocalyptic tendencies are getting ahead of the deprogramming organizations that try to rescue members trapped in mind-altering sects. But on balance, many experts would bet on more opening of minds through interconnectedness.
In the Muslim world, the use of mass communications -- including the Internet as well as a new generation of smuggled tapes and the open discussion encouraged by Qatar's pioneering Al-Jazira satellite television network -- is aiding a significant if still disparate movement for re-examination of the basic precepts and writings of Islam.
"The result is a collapse of earlier, hierarchical notions of religious authority based on claims to the mastery of fixed bodies of religious texts," Dale F. Eickelman, a Dartmouth anthropologist, said in June in the 1999 Templeton Lecture on Religion and World Affairs at the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia. "Quite simply, in country after country, government officials, traditional religious scholars and officially sanctioned preachers are finding it very hard to monopolize the tools of literate culture. The days have gone when governments and religious authorities can control what their people know, and what they think."
At the same time, it is probably worth remembering that the early totalitarians based a lot of their strategy on mastering what was then cutting-edge communications technology. Manipulating film images and broadcasting propaganda were essential to their efforts to imprison rather than liberate people's imaginations. So their heirs in China may be right to have a special fear of a new, barely understood medium like the Internet -- and of any organization clever enough to master this newest technology.
And for the West, the extraordinary success that the Falun Gong has had with cyberspace challenges any optimism that the Internet will promote only rational, enlightened, open-minded patterns of thought.
ACCESSIBLE communications, Professor Eickelman and others say, foster the growth of civil society and strengthen dissent in places like Iran or Egypt. But in Muslim nations, as almost everywhere in the world at the century's end, there is still a race on between the forces of liberalizing change and those of reactionary fundamentalism, between those who would expand tolerance and those who preach hate, between the agents of mind control and advocates of a free exchange of political ideas.
"It is important to remember that the Internet can serve government's purposes, too," said Ms. Economy. "It's not always going to be a force for positive change from our perspective."

HEADLINE: The Worker's Just Reward

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick, the editor of Challenge magazine, is working on a book about productivity.

 BODY:
Businesses across America are bemoaning the shortage of workers, from highly skilled computer professionals to lower-paid clerks. Some New York City restaurateurs, calling it a "crisis," are going so far as to offer health insurance to their waiters and establish training courses because they can't hire experienced personnel. And Wall Street sent stock prices reeling last week on the latest news that wages are up slightly more than expected. The market fears that the Federal Reserve will interpret any increase as a reason to be cautious and raise interest rates.
The culprit in the minds of many is an unemployment rate of 4.3 percent, far lower than most economists believed possible without generating inflation. But, contrary to the prevailing wisdom, little has been better for the country than a dose of full employment. Americans have been unfamiliar with it for so long that they have forgotten how broadly beneficial it is. 
 Consider the inequality of income. Now that the supply of labor is tighter, even low-wage workers have been getting decent wage increases -- about 8 percent after inflation over the last three years. As a result, income inequality, which has been attributed to the need for greater technological skills, growing international trade, the loss of the work ethic and assorted other factors, is now narrowing. Lower rates of unemployment and rising wages may also be contributing to declining crime rates. It is well documented that as unemployment rates have fallen in inner cities recently, so has the incidence of crime.
The country as a whole is surely more confident as well. Generosity seems to be on the rise. Survey after survey suggests that despite Congressional determination to cut taxes, most Americans would rather spend any Federal budget surplus on social programs and education.
Low rates of unemployment will also help the economy over time. It is nice to hear that some New York restaurants are taking such "radical" steps as giving their staffs the benefit of formal training. Rising wages in other industries are also inducing more thought about, and capital investment in, innovative ways to use employees better, including upgrading plants and machinery. Many economic historians have argued that American productivity grew rapidly in its earlier years for just such reasons. Businesses had to pay high wages for scarce labor as far back as the early 19th century, so they invested aggressively in the latest equipment to raise the output per worker.
As incomes rise for all American workers, new, more vibrant markets are created for entrepreneurs. Wall Street should keep in mind that the booms in the auto and housing markets are in part supported by growing demand among middle-income Americans whose incomes generally lagged behind those of their better-off peers until recently. As these workers earn more, they can also afford to train and educate themselves, sensing perhaps that they have a stake in the nation's future again.
But before we get too carried away with the benefits to workers in the current economy, let's remember that wage growth has been extraordinarily slow in the 1990's, even when including the gains of the last few years. Median family income, adjusted for inflation, is only 2 percent higher than it was in 1989. Workers have kept up by having spouses work and borrowing on credit cards and against the house. In fact, despite stories about signing bonuses at fast-food restaurants, wages for lower-paid male workers and for women in general fell in the second quarter.
The willingness of Americans to work long and hard has been one of the foundations of economic growth in the 1990's. A far higher proportion of Americans work than ever worked before. An increasing number of them have two jobs; they travel the continent to look for work, and two-thirds of married women with young children now work.
Trying to push the rate of unemployment much lower than it is today may indeed reignite inflation. Even an unemployment rate of 4.3 percent may ultimately prove inflationary. But when adopting economic policies that will directly harm workers by costing them jobs, the wise folks in Washington should remember that it is the determination and optimism of workers that has kept this economic miracle going.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
Fit for a New Start

 BODY:
As more businesses find clients over the Internet, and as customers increasingly take to the Web to compare prices and offerings, traditional face-to-face sales representatives are finding their jobs endangered. Two sales-intensive businesses where the future may be dim are insurance and investments.
In the last 10 months, nearly 13,000 job cuts have been announced in these two sectors alone, according to Challenger Gray & Christmas, an outplacement company based in Northbrook, Ill. But John A. Challenger, chief executive of the company, says many of the professionals set adrift in those cuts also have unusually promising potential to find new success by starting their own businesses. 
 "Successful agents in insurance and investing are able to develop a bond with their clients in order to learn what their needs and goals are and then formulate a package of products and services to meet them," Mr. Challenger said.
That skill would be helpful in many kinds of businesses. But it would be logical, Mr. Challenger said, for many of the displaced workers in insurance and securities to become consultants in financial planning -- a field that is likely to grow as more and more people try to manage their investments, with the help of the Internet, from their own homes.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: July 26-July 30;
How Will the Summer Page-Turner End?

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
When it comes to plot twists, the American stock market has turned into a thriller, pitting leery investors against a threatening inflation bogeyman.
 For now, the bogeyman has the upper hand. For the second consecutive week, investors slammed on the brakes, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average down 2.3 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq off 2 percent. All three wound up down for July, though each set records mid-month. 
 "The market is trying hard to find a footing," Alan Ackerman, a senior vice president and market strategist at Fahnestock & Company, told Reuters. "One of the factors putting pressure on the market itself is that interest rates might go higher."
 The employment report to be released on Friday may provide more inflation fodder for the Federal Reserve as it considers raising interest rates on Aug. 24. The Fed is already chewing on reports last week that seemed to tip the scales toward a rate increase.
"We're seeing a shift from earnings to Fed watch," Bryan Piskorowski, a market strategist at Prudential Securities, told Bloomberg News. "Every economic indicator will be under the microscope from here on."

The enterprising have found clients, investors, employees and employers in the oddest of settings -- chance meetings on the subway, supermarket checkout lines or even after a fender-bending collision. HEADLINE: Restaurant Association Sees Its Persistence Pay Off

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Standing on a ballroom stage in Las Vegas, Nev., earlier this year, Herman Cain, president of the National Restaurant Association, sang to his members, crooning in a rich baritone: "If I can see it, I can do it; if I just believe, there's nothing to it.
"I believe I can fly; I believe I can touch the sky!" 
 Not surprisingly, the unusual performance from the industry's top lobbyist raised a few eyebrows among the restaurateurs in the audience, who were there for an association convention. But in truth, Mr. Cain had reason to crow, because the restaurant industry is flush.
Americans are eating out more often than ever before. Average check prices are higher than they have ever been. More than 10.2 million people are employed in restaurants, more than at any time in the past. And total industry sales are expected to reach a record high this year, $354 billion.
And yet, association lobbyists managed to convince House Republicans this summer that restaurants were suffering enduring harm from the Government's decision in 1993 to reduce the tax deductibility of business meals, to 50 percent from 80 percent. The House tax cut bill, passed earlier this month, includes a heavily lobbied provision that raises it back to 80 percent. The tax bill that passed the Senate on Friday does not contain the provision, meaning more lobbying lies ahead.
Back in 1993, when the industry was trying to block the cut in the tax deduction, the restaurant association ran television commercials warning of disaster for the industry's most vulnerable employees.
"I'm a waitress, and a good one," Jan Bergwall, from a small town in Maryland, said in one advertisement. "I'd better be, because my three sons depend on me. But I might not have a job much longer. President Clinton's economic plan cuts business-meal deductibility. That would throw 165,000 people out of work. I need this job."
The lobbying effort failed. And as it turned out, the association's own statistics show that restaurant employment set records in 1994 and again in 1995, when restaurants added more than 300,000 employees.
The association is using the same approach now to fight a proposed increase in the minimum wage. Recently it put out the results of a survey taken of its members in support of this lobbying campaign, and the restaurant owners reported cutting "more than 146,000 jobs from restaurant payrolls" after previous minimum-wage increases, in 1996 and 1997.
At the same time, though, Bureau of Labor Statistics figures show that restaurant employment nationwide increased by 162,400 jobs in 1996 and 119,200 in 1997. Lee Culpepper, a vice president with the association, acknowledged the overall gain in jobs, but argued that the rate of increase would have been higher, if not for the minimum-wage increases.
For other lobbying aims, the association likes to make the point that its membership is not dominated by minimum-wage workers. "A popular misconception about the restaurant industry is that it is a collection of low-wage jobs, with nominal impact on a region's economy," one association policy paper says. Restaurant employees at all levels make more money than most people believe, the association says, and play an important role in regional economies.
Because of its broad range of interests, the trade group expends copious energy lobbying on issues that do not seem immediately relevant to the industry. For example, the restaurant association has lobbied to block the Government from taxing airline frequent-flier miles. Tourists eat out, Mr. Culpepper explained. And frequent-flier miles drive tourism.
Even when it works on issues of direct concern to restaurants, the association sometimes uses arguments that do not bear on its direct self-interest.
For example, the group opposes a measure that would lower the legal blood-alcohol level for drivers to 0.08 percent. In most states now it is 0.10 percent.The association's lobbying arguments are framed around earnest constitutional concerns.
"States would be forced to adopt a 0.08 blood-alcohol level or lose precious Federal highway dollars," one association fact sheet warns. That, it adds, is not the way democracy should work, as "states should have the flexibility to enact measures that they feel would work best in their particular state."
The fact sheet never mentions a more fundamental concern: restaurants might sell fewer drinks.
The restaurant association, founded in 1919, is one of the oldest trade groups in the city. But for most of its history it was a sleepy, back water organization. In recent years, though, it has climbed into the top level of Washington lobbying groups. "Last year, Congress didn't pass anything that hurt us," Elaine Z. Graham, a senior vice president for the association, said with a smile and a lift of the chin.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Leaving Black Mark on Unions

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
RICHIE PHILLIPS says he will "fight to the death," but unless the courts bail him out, his umpires union is already gone, shot dead with Phillips's own gun, mostly to the cheers of the audience watching this theater of the absurd.
It's a sad story, almost pathetic. But be it the work of arrogance or gross tactical miscalculation or both, Phillips has apparently wrecked his own union and killed off, at last count, 22 careers, not counting his own. In the long run, though, the greater damage may be to the American labor movement, at a time when it is trying to reverse a decades-long decline and can least afford the public relations fallout from Phillips's horrendous call. 
 "Unfortunately, a story like this one reinforces a very old and inaccurate stereotype of big labor, from the 1930's and 1940's, of Jimmy Hoffa and the teamsters," said Tom Juravich, the director of the Labor Center at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. "It creates the notion that it all hinges on the personality of the larger-than-life leader, when the reality is that trade unions should come down to organization, to the day-to-day rank and file."
It's not just Phillips, not just the few dozen umpires who bought into the cockamamie tactic of negotiation by resignation. When the pro basketball players were locked out last fall, they organized a charity game for themselves and wanted to charge $1,000 for a courtside seat. Brother, they seemed to be asking, can you spare a grand?
As anthems go, that one most likely didn't inspire those young high-tech-sector workers, the ones organized labor is desperate to recruit, to bolt from their work stations and run to the nearest union hall.
People always want to talk about how effective sports can be in at least elevating the debate, educating the masses, on hot-button issues. Magic Johnson's infection with the virus that causes AIDS turned up the volume on safe-sex talk. Cancer scares for athletes like Darryl Strawberry supposedly motivate others to get examined. Lance Armstrong gives cancer victims hope. Mark McGwire speaks out against child abuse, and suddenly the cause has been furthered by his 500-foot clout.
"There's no doubt that sports has a tremendous impact on the society, and in many cases, the first taste the youth of this country will get on an issue is through when they read or hear through sports," said Charles Kernaghan, director of the National Labor Committee, a New York-based human rights watchdog group.
That being the case, the notion of this umpires debacle shaping anyone's union sensibility has to be as scary a proposition for organized labor as Ronald Reagan, a marketing disaster along the lines of the air traffic controllers. And what about all this coverage for 68 umpires who make from $75,000 to $225,000, not including bonuses -- is it proportionately in line with the amount of attention 10,000 striking hospital workers would get? Of course it isn't, but sports unions, which once fought valiantly for benefits that the blue-collar worker could at least relate to, have for the most part evolved to represent the celebritization of organized labor.
Their message, however distorted, has tremendous market reach.
"The fact that popular athletes think unions are good may be a counterbalance, but clearly, sports unions reinforce the notion that unions take a self-serving approach and tend to be primarily about money," said Richard Hurd, a professor in labor studies at Cornell University. "In that sense, it's not great for the labor movement."
The umpires' story is not about money, but then, Phillips did not allow the dispute to reach the point where his membership could at least be viewed sympathetically. Phillips has won many battles through the years, many I applauded, but, sorry, baseball's mandated enforcement of the strike zone does not qualify as workplace abuse. The umpires have in the last few years come off as power-drunk, out of touch with their relative importance to the game. The decision by Phillips to have his membership stick its collective head under the guillotine will be remembered as a landmark act of self-destruction that even Michael Moore can't defend.
Even with the knowledge that sports owners rip off taxpayers and hide profits under the pillow, it has become increasingly difficult to support sports unions as the 1990's have wound down. As Hurd suggested, they have failed to articulate a relevant social message, anything beyond greed. When people like Kernaghan have asked popular athletes to speak out against the companies engaged in sweatshop abuses abroad, they are met with deafening silence, individually and collectively. The opportunity to balance the inevitable resentment of their millions, to get the news media back in their camp, is lost.
The union bashing, unfair in how it ultimately affects real union workers, goes on.
"People tend to make choices about union membership based on their own workplace conditions," Hurd said. "But the sports unions, mainly because of the amount of attention they get, do have an impact on public perception."
Here, then, is the public's perception of Richie Phillips: His blind arrogance has led one-third of his membership to the cusp of unemployment. What Phillips is calling a "fight to the death," most people see as group suicide.

HEADLINE: As Temperatures Rise, a Neighborhood Getaway Beckons

SERIES: SUMMER PLACES: A City Park

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
It was 11:13 in the morning on Wednesday, and the temperature was 88 degrees and climbing. Samuel Marrow, 74, had risen with the sun, but now he wanted out of it. And so, as he had over the course of the last 51 summers, he walked down Quincy Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant and over to the former Tompkins Park, now known as Herbert Von King Park.
A seat in the shade, a moment of mercy after a month of historic heat, was all Mr. Marrow was looking for, and he found it where he always had -- on the bench six strides inside the Greene Avenue entrance. 
 There, in the simple cool, he could see everything, looking back in time as well as straight in front of him. On his right was the tree from which several young boys were hanged in the gang wars of the 1950's. To his left was a line of young children, the children of the neighborhood's poor and working class, running sprints in the sun, the temperature draining from them everything but their smiles.
"I came to Brooklyn from North Carolina after the war," said Mr. Marrow, who back then worked in a shipyard in Kearny, N.J. "I'd get home hot and dirty, but gather my kids and come here. Back then, you could spend the night out in this park. It's always been the coolest park in Brooklyn. There's a lot of history here."
It is the history, in many ways, of a certain kind of summer in New York City, the summers lived out by children for whom a fancy day camp is a pipe dream, summers lived out by fathers and grandmothers for whom vacation is an absolutely local experience. Across the city, there are parks and playgrounds, schoolyards and street corners that have always served as improvised summer retreats, unglamorous, but rich and fully used.
They are found at the backs of falling-apart schools and squeezed between housing projects, or, like Von King Park, standing squarely at the center of a storied neighborhood of culture and strife. And at the height of midsummer, people are driven to them before daybreak, and many don't leave until well past midnight, early bedtimes seeming a needless cruelty.
In those parks and schoolyards, people taste the modest, sweet freedoms and comforts of shade and laughter, invented games, the little dramas of romance and athletics. Of course, they are not places of complete summer sanctity: there is commerce in drugs, sometimes in revenge; people bring their dinner to the park, and others roll dice; anger can rise like the heat, quickly and with menace.
On this day, when the temperature rose to 97 degrees, teen-agers flirted openly, the strength of their hormones undefeated by the heat. And on a center bench, the resident storytellers and wise guys were in full voice, their tales driven by pride and nostalgia, boredom, hope and the brown bags between their feet.
"When it is smoldering everywhere else, there are places in this park that can feel refrigerated," said Lemuel Mial, a Parks Department official who has worked at the park since 1967. "Of course, it's not totally innocent, either. But this, I think, is the bright green spot of the neighborhood. And summer here is going day and night."
To spend 24 hot and unpredictable hours in Von King Park, then, is to appreciate what that kind of summer of constraint and creativity can feel like.
 
6:17 A.M., 78 degrees
Bill Crowder, 54, sat in a quadrangle of the day's first sunlight and opened his flute case. It would be the sixth straight day of temperatures over 90, the 28th day of a month that would become the hottest ever recorded in the city.
"I'm kind of like the gypsy of Bed-Stuy," he said. "Actually, I can play this flute in the house now. My new roommate doesn't mind. But I have to come back to my roots to play. This park is my roots."
Just after daybreak, Von King Park -- its name was changed in 1985 to honor the neighborhood advocate who had earned the unofficial title of "Mayor of Bed-Stuy" -- is populated by the elderly, the unemployed and the ambitious, Tracy Moore's ambition amounting to doing pull-ups on the playground bars before it got too hot and before he had to go to work.
At 6:49 A.M., John Stevens, 73, a former porter, began the park's first game of checkers. "It's too hot and too early to think clearly," he said, laughing, "but it ain't too hot or too early to cheat."
The working people from the streets around the park -- it is bordered by Greene, Lafayette, Marcy and Tompkins Avenues -- also walk through, wearing the uniforms of hospital orderlies and Sanitation Department workers. And they each steal a second or two of breezy relief.
Hard luck can bring people to the park, too. Ruben Gonzalez, 47, played in the park as a child, and he remembered how he used to come dressed in a suit and shoes with his father. Mr. Gonzalez had been away for years, but returned to Von King Park when he was sent there to work for his welfare check.
"They have improved the park a lot, created more things for kids," he said. "I brought my daughter here the other day. I told her it wasn't like this when I was here. But I told her to sit where I had sat. It felt good for me to see that."
By 9 A.M., the sun had climbed up off Tompkins Avenue, a hot coin rising in the sky.
Laurine Harrison, a grandmother and former bookkeeper, sat in a swing, her pleasure nothing more lavish than to stretch her arms and legs. And Eddie Vick, 66, a former boxer who said he twice lost to the former light-heavyweight champion Bob Foster, walked with his grandson, his shirt soaked across his broad shoulders, his grandson's hand lost in his aging boxer's fist.
Marcus Bryant, 11, had waited in his Greene Avenue apartment for hours before getting the final O.K. to go to the park with his brother, Kaheem, to play their invented game of Black Mat Tag. "This park is enough for us," Marcus said.
 
12:49 P.M., 92 degrees
Aaron Jolly, 15, walked onto the basketball court at the southeast corner of Von King Park. There, with five others, the day's first game started. It was a game of dubious shot selections and endless talk, with the chief conversational constant being the total failure to mention the word "job."
"Work? I'm working on my jump shot," said Aaron, his laugh as soft as his shot floating through the netless hoop. Aaron is one of eight siblings, and he said he had worked earlier in the summer at a nursing home. He was waiting to be called back. Now, though, he listened only for the call of "next."
A generational shift had taken place at the park as the afternoon arrived. It is largely the young who are out in the midday heat, and even they treated the sunlight as a flame to dodge.
The youngsters, some of whom are with the day camp run by the Brooklyn Tabernacle Deliverance Center, come from the row houses along the park's borders, and from the Louis Armstrong projects on Quincy Street, a set of buildings that function as squat, remorseless ovens. The children turn the park's asphalt paths into racing strips, and the two sprinklers empty a reservoir's worth of water into the air.
It is not Cape Cod, but it is more than all right, something deeper than simply a last resort.
"I have two options," said Stacey Tyler, the mother of six children, four of whom were with her in the sprinkler. "I can stay at home and run the hose on them, or I can use the city's water. I just got my water bill, and so that settled that."
The park has a rich history. In 1857, it became the first park formally established by the City of Brooklyn, and it was first named for Daniel D. Tompkins, the abolitionist and four-term Governor of New York. Its final design was by Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted, the designers of Central Park. A library once stood at its center, and it was often used for military reviews. It is full of oak and maple trees, their branches forming, in some sections, enormous awnings of protection.
The multiple uses of the park are organized, accidental and occasionally urgent. There are nighttime concerts, and a handful of dance and arts programs are run out of the park building. A local church that had been damaged by fire now conducts its Sunday services in the park's outdoor auditorium.
And it gets used, too, as a place for people to come and hold hands.
"I came because of the heat," Luisa Matos said.
Next to her, Shawn Blake smiled.
"I came for love," he said.
The two, both 19, had just discovered Von King Park, and shortly after 2 P.M., with the temperature at 95 degrees, they sat side by side and talked of their future. They had dated for two and a half years, and had moved to Brooklyn only months before from St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. They had taken an apartment together and were looking for work. Von King Park offered a place for their hearts to calm down.
"I don't know how it will work out," Ms. Matos said. "I want to go to school as well as work. But it's going to be hard, I think." She put her head on her boyfriend's shoulder and closed her eyes.
 
6:10 P.M., 96 degrees
The sun's slow, almost exhausted decline over Marcy Avenue at the west end of Von King Park had done nothing to thwart the temperature's ascent. Through that heat and the first hints of twilight, Homer Stewart walked with his 6-year-old son, Kwame. Mr. Stewart, who works for a bank in Flatbush, had changed his suit for shorts and was about to have his first game of catch with his son, an exercise in sweat and tenderness.
"He's the baseball lover," Mr. Stewart said of his son. "And we are here to register for the park's baseball program."
Soon, the two moved to the ball field at the northwest corner, where the games begin after dusk and amid the eternal illusion that it might be cooler at that time of day.
The park in the early evening is fuller than ever, its characters including the near-permanent residents who have, during the day, moved from one bench to another, their courses charted by their own private maps of quiet desires and distractions.
One of them is Queen Curry, 69. She was born in Camden, S.C., but moved to Bedford-Stuyvesant 30 years ago and raised four children. The park was always there, full of pleasures and perils. She said one of her children had been ensnared by the drug scene that prevailed at the park years ago. "I've made a whole circle around this park," she said, listing the houses she had lived in on the surrounding streets. "But I always walked through it."
Some choose to march through it, and shortly after 8 P.M., the sounds of a drum and bugle corps rose from the park's north end. There, gathering for practice, were the Toppers, who say they make up the oldest active African-American drum corps in the country.
In sunglasses and baseball caps, Victor English and Daniel Wright, bugles in their white-gloved hands, worked their way through a medley as night fell. "We're doing this as a hook for kids in the park," Mr. English said. "I started in 1961, and the drum corps taught me discipline, self-respect. And it gave me the chance to get out of this city."
 
9:11 P.M., 89 degrees
With the darkness, the degrees of separation in the park had grown more stark. Certain corners of the park had grown slightly sinister, taken over by teen-agers and other young men and women, the language often loud and hard.
"People say this park is nice, that it has grass and whatnot," said a 16-year-old who identified himself as Little G. "But young people get hurt in this place, too. And the police precinct is right on the corner. But they don't care."
Still, almost everyone, including police officers at the 79th Precinct at the southeast corner of the park, agrees that Von King Park has come a long way during the last decade on the question of safety. There were years, Officer Jeannette Morales said, when almost all the pursuits of criminal suspects either started, ran through or wound up in the park.
"I don't think we even track the number of incidents in the park these days, the number is so low," said Officer Morales, who has been the precinct's community affairs officer for six years. "Cops even play handball in there."
That sense of security is hardly universal, though. A girl was raped in the park on July 22.
But, as late night approached, there still were mothers in the park with their children, gamely hanging on and hanging out by the sprinklers, the spray of water looking in the dark air like a kind of fine smoke.
Maria Figueroa was there with her daughter Angelica, 3, who ran through the sprinkler endlessly. The night hours in the park are what Ms. Figueroa can manage, for she does not get off work until 6. They would stay until Angelica fell asleep.
"This is a place where you feel like you can break away," Ms. Figueroa said. "Break away from the heat. And, you know, break away from the ordinary."
With midnight coming, and the forecast calling for four more days of 90-degree heat, a breeze still ran through Von King Park, a breeze that felt freighted with something -- rain, mischief, peace, the scent of summer.

HEADLINE: House and Senate Tax Cut Bills Would Give Businesses Billions in Long-Sought Benefits

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
As House and Senate leaders try to reach a deal on tax cuts, it is not just the average taxpayer who has something at stake. A wide array of businesses and industries is fighting to protect tens of billions of dollars in special benefits that have made the competing tax cut bills the most lucrative for business in years.
With the new era of surpluses leading Republicans to push for the largest tax cut since Ronald Reagan's in 1981, the latest bills have proved a bonanza for the lobbyists who clog the corridors outside the House and Senate tax-writing committees. 
 In several instances, the vast $792 billion tax cut measures passed by the House last week and the Senate on Friday give corporations victories that they have been seeking since President Reagan crowned his second term with an overhaul of the tax code. That overhaul made way for a reduction in individual tax rates by closing scores of corporate loopholes.
Many lobbyists say they had been stymied for years because Federal deficits had made tax breaks with a large cost to the Treasury unthinkable. But with a pro-business Republican Congress now dealing with a Federal surplus, Clint Stretch, the director of tax policy at the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche, was only half joking when he said that some of the tax breaks in these bills were ones companies had been seeking "probably since the dawn of time."
Along with broad-based personal tax cuts, the House bill includes $80 billion or more in business tax reductions over the next 10 years, while the Senate bill has about $50 billion. Despite their differences, each of the two bills provides $792 billion in total tax cuts over the decade.
The measures include tax relief for multinational corporations and for small businesses, assistance to the oil and gas industry, aid to the nuclear energy industry, a tax reduction for railroads and one for seaplanes, and a reduction in the corporate capital gains tax that analysts say will be particularly helpful to the insurance and timber industries.
Whatever plan emerges from conference faces a veto from President Clinton because of its size. And it will be months before the shape and contents of a final package will be clear. But industries and their lobbyists were still scrambling to get their provisions into the bills, in hopes that they would be favored for inclusion in the final bill. And some seemed almost giddy at their success.
"We got the sun, moon and the stars," said Kathleen O'Leary, a lobbyist for the National Restaurant Association, which in the House bill won a phased-in provision to make 80 percent of the cost of business meals tax deductible, instead of the current 50 percent.
The business meal deduction had been reduced in President Clinton's deficit reduction package of 1993. Ms. O'Leary said the association had hoped to win it back inch by inch. In fact, the association had been supporting legislation that would raise the deduction to 80 percent only for companies that earned $5 million or less. But the House applied it to all business, at a cost to the Treasury of $8.4 billion.
Republican leaders defend the tax provisions as ones that will help declining industries and keep American business competitive overseas. "These tax relief measures will make sure that we are competitive in the next century and that we can keep our economic growth moving in the right direction," said John P. Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert.
But Congress is promoting such tax breaks at the same time it is struggling to find ways to cut scores of domestic programs by 10 percent or more to stay within the boundaries of the 1997 balanced budget agreement.
And that has led Democrats to charge that Republicans are putting special interests ahead of the common good. "Without a single dime of the surplus dedicated to strengthening Medicare, the Republicans managed to shovel in almost $100 billion worth of tax breaks for special interests," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader.
One Republican, Senator John McCain of Arizona, voted for the Senate tax bill but also excoriated some special interest provisions.
"How can we justify giving a $33 million tax break next year to companies producing electricity from chicken waste, when senior citizens have to forgo some of their Social Security benefits if they must work to make ends meet?" he asked.
Of course, Democrats have their favored causes, too. On the final day of debate on the Senate tax cut, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, won a tax break for maple syrup producers who tap trees on timberlands. Under the provision, they would have the same income threshold for paying unemployment tax as maple syrup producers whose trees are on farms.
In many cases, industries argue that they are just receiving tax treatment equivalent to that granted other businesses or clearing up quirks in the tax laws. But such changes can raise broader policy questions.
Take the tax provision won by military contractors. Since the early 1970's, Congress has used the tax code to subsidize United States exports by allowing American companies to exempt about 15 percent of their export income from tax. But in 1976, Congress decided that weapons exporters should get only half the tax benefits allotted other exporters.
Representative Sam Johnson, a Texas Republican who took up the cause of the military contractors, said in a letter to House members, "Let's stop using the tax code to punish our defense industry."
He argued for and won a provision in the House bill to give the contractors the same tax treatment as other exporters -- at a cost to the Treasury of $1.1 billion over a decade. The Senate bill phases in the change differently, costing $798 million over the same period.
But not all members of Congress see such a subsidy as a public good. "Why in the world, when the U.S. has such a substantial portion of the market, do taxpayers need to subsidize us to promote conventional arms races all around the world?" asked Representative Lloyd Doggett, Democrat of Texas.
In fact, the military contractors' victory may prove short-lived. Lawmakers say a panel at the World Trade Organization recently made a preliminary ruling that this entire provision of the American tax code was an illegal export subsidy.
One of the largest business provisions in the House tax bill is a change in the way multinational corporations are allowed to allocate their worldwide interest deductions. The change has the effect of allowing them to take more credits for paying taxes overseas, and thus reduce their domestic taxes.
In the House bill, which phases the change in faster than the Senate's, the cost to the Treasury is $24.8 billion over a decade. The Senate version would cost $12.6 billion. "It's an expensive provision to fix," said William H. Laitinen, assistant general tax counsel to General Motors, one of the many companies that wanted the change. "But now there's some more leeway from the projected surplus."

HEADLINE: City to Offer Low-Interest Loans For Manhattan Blackout Losses

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
After the Federal Government refused to provide emergency assistance, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would make low-interest loans available to business people in Washington Heights to help them recoup losses incurred because of the July 6 blackout.
The program, extending loans of $3,000 to $50,000, was announced amid harsh recriminations from City Hall, focusing both on Con Edison, which the Mayor has blamed for the blackout, and on the United States Small Business Administration. 
 "The response of the S.B.A. has been outrageous," Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota said yesterday, after several days of requests and appeals to the Federal agency ended with what he called a "flat refusal to help."
Mayor Giuliani, in announcing the loan program, blamed Con Edison's decision to cut power to much of Upper Manhattan during the sweltering heat of July 6 for leaving 200,000 people and 700 businesses without air conditioning, refrigeration or lights.
Under the program, to be administered by the city's Economic Development Corporation, loans would be intended to supplement cash payments by Con Edison, which is offering up to $2,000 to each business hurt by the blackout. To qualify, business people must demonstrate that their damages exceed $2,000, and that the city financing will be used for such things as replacing equipment and inventory.
Jerome M. Hauer, director of the city's Office of Emergency Management, said the interest rates for the loans would be determined by the income of the applicant. He said the rates had not been set, but would be below conventional bank financing.
Mr. Hauer said that a city office would be set up in Washington Heights to administer the loans, but that a site had not been selected. Officials said business people who want to apply for the financing should call the Economic Development Corporation at 212-312 3600.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
What's the Problem?

 BODY:
Now more than at just about any time since World War II, there seems to be no issue that dominates the concerns of Americans. A relatively long period of prosperity, low unemployment and falling crime rates have led to a period when there are few galvanizing public concerns; the worries of Americans are scattered and, possibly, more personal. 
 This leaves potential Presidential candidates with a problem. As they try to stake out their political ground for the 2000 election, there is no obvious, single issue that is sure to appeal to a large number of voters. That was not always so. From the economy to the cost of living to fears about war and nuclear holocaust, Americans have worried in great numbers over the years, giving politicians plenty of guidance about what is likely to nudge them to the polls.
 
From nationwide Gallup polls taken over the last half-century, here are the top topics named when respondents were asked: What do you think is the most important problem facing the country today?

HEADLINE: We Deserve a Tax Cut, but at What Price?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I fear the Republican-led tax cut plan because of what it may do to interest rates (news article, July 30). Like a tax cut, paying off the national debt may have the effect of heating up the economy, but at least it might lower interest rates. 
 Many people who will get little or no benefit from a tax cut will be greatly affected by interest rate increases. The vast majority of Americans who pay most of the taxes will likely see their variable-rate credit cards and mortgages rise far more than any tax-cut savings.
 
DENNIS WALTMAN
Atlanta, July 30, 1999

HEADLINE: We Deserve a Tax Cut, but at What Price?;
Exaggerated Burden

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The "tax share" data that you published in a graph accompanying a July 26 front-page article are misleading. The data, which as you note, were supplied by the Republican staff of the Committee on Ways and Means, were meant to bolster their argument that very high income groups deserve a large share of a new tax cut. Yet because major nonprogressive Federal taxes like the payroll taxes are left out, the data exaggerate the share of total Federal taxes paid by the very affluent. 
 You labeled 40 percent as the "share of taxes" paid by those with individual incomes of $200,000 and up. The Joint Committee on Taxation did estimate 40 percent for the share of income taxes, but for all Federal taxes, their estimate is only 25 percent. The committee also estimates that the share of the House-passed tax cut for this same income group exceeds 25 percent.
 
AL DAVIS
Chief Economist, Democratic Staff
Committee on Ways and Means
Washington, July 27, 1999

HEADLINE: New Housing That Doesn't Break the Bank

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHEN the subject is housing, "project" is a word Frank J. Carito hates. "It conveys a negative image of low-cost housing," he said. "For years we've been working to get rid of the assumption that low-cost housing is undesirable housing."
Mr. Carito, a former mayor of New Rochelle, heads the New Rochelle Neighborhood Revitalization Corporation, a nonprofit company that has built affordable housing in New Rochelle for nearly 20 years. 
 "By creating the group, the public sector was far-sighted enough to acknowledge that the private sector is better suited to plan and develop affordable housing," Mr. Carito said.
"I don't think that there is another community anywhere that can match our record," he continued. "We've constructed or renovated more than 1,000 housing units valued at over $30 million, and it's a shame that other municipalities don't know how to do what we're doing. In addition, we've never had a demonstration or outcry from any group trying to discourage us from bringing low-cost housing into a neighborhood."
One success Mr. Carito likes to tell about is the transformation of what was formerly called the "projects," the MacLeay Apartments, a 3-building, 180-apartment complex built in 1949 on Fifth Avenue in New Rochelle near the Larchmont border.
"By the mid-80's MacLeay was a deteriorated, poorly maintained public housing complex, several hundred thousand dollars in tax arrears and a financial blight on the City," Mr. Carito said. "At the time, taking a public housing complex private was unique in subsidized housing development. We bought it from the Housing Authority and paid the outstanding taxes, completely rehabilitated it inside and out, including the community center for use as an after-school homework center, with teachers from a local middle school, and a computer center, which links the local schools to the apartment complex."
Furthermore, he said, not only are the MacLeay Apartments now a safe and desirable place to live but there has also been a financial turnaround. Before conversion the complex was losing $250,000 a year. Now it makes a profit of more than $600,000 annually.
Housing needs are varied, and shortages in moderate-priced houses and low-income, elderly and family rental housing in New Rochelle have led to the construction of 525 units of various types of housing, including apartments and single-family residences, Charles J. DePasquale, the Neighborhood Revitalization Corporation's executive vice president, said.
Since its creation in 1979, the New Rochelle Neighborhood Revitalization Association has been assisted by grants from agencies including the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation, Westchester County Housing Implementation Funds, the Federal Home Program and Land Write Down Costs by the City of New Rochelle -- which was a key component in acquiring property at a reduced cost -- and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Renewal Development.
The newest development, the Lawn Avenue affordable housing project -- 10 Colonial-style, two-family town houses near downtown -- opened in late May.
It has already helped turn a blighted and deteriorating neighborhood around, Mr. DePasquale said, adding that affordable housing, when occupied by the owner, is the single most important catalyst to the revitalization and stability of a neighborhood. Each town house on Lawn Avenue contains a three-bedroom unit for low-income families and a three-room rental unit for people at least 62 years old. The one-bedroom unit rents for $840 a month but tenants who are at least 62 years old pay only 30 percent of their income in rent, which could be considerably less.
"Those are the two groups most in need," Mr. DePasquale said. "They have been paying up to 50 percent of their income for housing."
The town house project, which cost $3 million, was built with grants from the Federal Home Program, the State Affordable Housing Corporation and Westchester County. The houses, which cost $142,000 each, were drawn by lottery and 370 people applied, and of those only 59 were eligible and of that number, 10 were the winners and became owners.
"We are so happy," said Javier Zamora, a construction worker whoowns a Lawn Avenue house. "It was a big surprise for me, especially since I was the last one picked in the lottery. We lived in a small apartment for 12 years with our two kids and had no hope of getting a house, The kids are jumping all over the place. They love it."
Mr. Zamora's wife, Maria, a Laundromat attendant, is also enthusiastic. "I still can't believe it," she said. "It is a dream come true. I never thought we would have our own house. It is all new and beautiful."
The tenants of the Zamoras, James Moore and Linda Scott, longtime residents of New Rochelle, agreed. Their new apartment is one of the nicest places they have ever lived in. They pay $252 for their apartment, which is 30 percent of their income, following the guidelines for subsidized housing.
"It's wonderful," Ms. Scott, a home health care aide, said. "Everything is so nice and attractive. We're very glad to be here."
Mr. Moore, a retired operations supervisor for the Lillian Vernon Corporation, said: "It's a terrific apartment. The appliances, and everything is brand new."
One of the stipulations of the lottery is that these houses cannot be sold for 10 years, Mr. Carito said. "Such is the pride of home ownership that even when the 10-year restriction prohibiting selling runs out and owners are free to sell their homes at a profit of 25 percent, they choose not to," Mr. Carito said. "That's what we've seen happen with one of our first projects, the 14 town houses built on Lincoln Avenue in 1987. No one has sold."
The most ambitious and most complex project to date, is West End 2000, a $30 million development on a four-acre site bounded by Union Avenue, First Street, Jones Street and Second Street in the western section of New Rochelle, Mr. Carito said.
"The Revitalization Corporation is the sponsor and developer," Mr. DePasquale said. "It's a multiple-use residential development and will contain the first 100-unit, low-income, assisted-living facility in Westchester and 66 single-family duplex homes for first-time buyers. We expect that West End 2000 will stop the ongoing deterioration in this aged and blighted neighborhood."
What has become accepted housing policy today was the idea of a handful of people in the New Rochelle Department of Development, Mr. DePasquale said. When the group of people asked for support from the city to create a nonprofit corporation to implement housing policy and build affordable housing "the idea was truly visionary and untested," Mr. Carito said. "It was also a way to keep politics out of low-income housing.
"The city administration approved the concept of a private not-for-profit corporation directing the programs as long as it wasn't a burden to the taxpayers."
Indeed, it has been anything but that. The construction of 525 new housing units generates more than $340,000 in annual taxes. The Revitalization Corporation earns its revenues from developer fees, service contracts with the city or third-party vendors. "Nor have we taken any direct subsidy for administrative costs," Mr. Carito said. "Our seven board members are volunteers. What says a lot about them is that in 20 years no one has been ousted from the board because of missing meetings. That's our rule: you're out if you miss three meetings."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

An article last Sunday about private development of low-cost housing misstated the surname of the head of the New Rochelle Revitalization Corporation. He is Frank J. Garito, not Carito.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
A Maverick Has Plans for Chicago

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
ANDREW J. FILIPOWSKI, the maverick software entrepreneur who sold Platinum Technology International to Computer Associates last month for $3.5 billion, was reclining in his limousine on Tuesday, listening to his voice mail and shooting off responses -- "Barbara, can you check on this right away?" -- on his way downtown. Between calls, Mr. Filipowski told a reporter that his next challenge was to turn Chicago into a "center for cyberspace," which is why he was on his way to meet Mayor Richard M. Daley. On Wednesday, it was Gov. George Ryan.
"There's no question Chicago has lagged Silicon Valley in a very distant way," Mr. Filipowski said. "The fact is, we need a more diversified economy, and I want to provide financing, support and mentoring to the high-tech community here." As a first step, he is seeking to raise $1 billion in venture capital to finance local Internet start-ups. 
 Politicians are listening to Mr. Filipowski -- "Flip" to his friends -- because no city or state wants to miss the revolution in high technology. And to people here, no one is more capable of bringing the wired world to the land of hog futures. "Until Flip came there was no visionary here," said Darcy Evon, editor of the i-Street Reporter, an on-line newsletter that tracks the city's fledgling venture capital community. "So we're ecstatic; he's going to put Chicago on the map."
He put himself on the map by parlaying a company he started in 1987 in the Chicago suburb of Oakbrook Terrace into the biggest software deal in history, largely by going on an acquisition spree that included more than 70 software companies. He personally netted $290 million from the sale to Computer Associates.
Mr. Filipowski remains something of an eccentric here, with a look that friends describe as part California beach boy, part aging rock star. There's the ponytail, the earring, the Hawaiian shirts and the Tommy Bahama slacks. "You can characterize Flip as an unorthodox C.E.O., with respect to background, appearance and a kind of cult-like personality," said Wendell Laidley, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "But he worked hard to reposition a company that could have easily been destroyed by its competitors."
Mr. Filipowski was born in Chicago in 1950, the only son of Polish immigrants. His father was a butcher and his mother a welder in a family where English wasn't even the second language. "I grew up speaking Polish," he said. "I didn't know anything about English until the first day of school. It was a shock."
Later, he went to a military boarding school, where he liked the discipline but not the dress code. He dropped out of college after a year and took a computer job at Time-Life in Chicago. He later worked at Motorola and Cullinet Software.
By the time he was 28, he was vying for the top spot at Cullinet. When it didn't come, he formed his own data management company. He left it some years later, after a dispute with investors, and founded Platinum Technology. Along the way, he was married, at 19, divorced and remarried.
Friends say Mr. Filipowski has very distinctive traits. He doesn't seem to sleep much ("I get E-mail messages at the most ungodly hours," a friend said); doesn't smoke, drink or even take medicine ("I'm very suspicious of medicine," he said); speed-reads cartons of mail and books on his chartered plane trips (he used to teach an Evelyn Wood course), and collects sports memorabilia (he has a Joe DiMaggio uniform and Joe Louis's heavyweight title belt).
He has also founded myriad companies, going on a Platinum kick: Platinum Construction; Platinum Development, a real estate concern; Platinum Entertainment, a music label, and Platinum Ventures.
The venture-capital company, which backed businesses like Star Media Network, an on-line service for Latin America, will now concentrate on Internet start-ups. He is changing the name to Divine Interventures, brashly alluding to his almost godlike powers here, and is planning a high-technology campus on the Chicago River. The city and state are seeking his help to create their own high-technology incubator.
Not all his ventures win acclaim. The Blue Rhino Corporation, a low-technology public company he founded with his sister-in-law's husband, Billy Prim, exchanges full propane cylinders, mostly for backyard grills, for empty ones. Federal filings show that the company's primary distributors are privately owned companies in which Mr. Filipowski and Mr. Prim have a minority stake. Several analysts have called the relationships between the companies "incestuous" and troublesome, raising questions about whether the distributors would receive overly favorable treatment from Blue Rhino.
Mr. Filipowski, however, said his investments in the distributors were necessary because they did not have the money or clout to support Blue Rhino's operations. "It's nothing to be suspicious about," he said, adding that Blue Rhino's dealings with the distributors were all at arm's length.
For unrelated reasons, Blue Rhino recently had to restate and lower its earnings, one reason the stock has been hammered of late.
Mr. Filipowski would rather talk about charities he has founded, including Panthera Productions, which makes wildlife documentaries, and Digital Schoolhouse, which brings technology to inner-city children.
Now he wants to become a more significant mentor to budding Internet entrepreneurs. "Entrepreneurship can be a truly philanthropic effort," he said. "Helping people start a company is a better form of charity."

HEADLINE: Discipline the Poor?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Gertrude Himmelfarb's July 28 Op-Ed article on "compassionate conservatism" recalled for me, a young historian, the efforts of 17th- and 18th-century England to deal with an increasingly impoverished majority. The English philosophers and economists of that day recommended strict state involvement in dealing with the "idle poor," who were seen as drains on society. Today, however, the liberal ethic that helped build our society remains based on removing the burdens on the poor rather than on trying to discipline them. 
 The concept of "compassionate conservatism" roots itself in a Protestant Christian faith in free-market capitalism in which work is seen as a virtue that leads to salvation. By replacing the word "Christian" with "compassionate," conservatives seek to recast their vision without making fundamental changes in their approach, which has failed to alleviate poverty in the past three centuries.
 
DANIEL BYRNE
Toms River, N.J., July 29, 1999

HEADLINE: MEDIA TALK;
A Growing Internet Business Magazine Adds a Familiar Byline

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
If anyone in journalism has nine lives, James Fallows does. Mr. Fallows, a former editor of U.S. News and World Report, outspoken press critic, author of "Breaking the News: How the Media Undermine American Democracy" and -- most recently -- Microsoft consultant, will join The Industry Standard magazine as a columnist.
Jonathan Weber, the editor in chief of the Standard, a weekly Internet-business magazine published by International Data Group, is expected to announce the appointment tomorrow. And Mr. Fallows will have plenty of company: within the last month, Mr. Weber has lured reporters and editors away from several news organizations, including Thomas Goetz from The Wall Street Journal, Kenneth Li from The New York Daily News, and staff members from Inc. magazine, Wired and The San Jose Mercury News. 
 And on Friday, Mr. Weber hired Amy Bernstein, the editorial director of Brill's Content magazine. He said the editorial staff, which last month had 27 members, would grow to 45 by the end of September.
Mr. Weber said that he had begun to think of the San Francisco-based Standard as the Rolling Stone of the Internet business economy, and of Mr. Fallows as a columnist who will help attract a broader readership.
"We are focused on the phenomenon of Internet business," Mr. Weber said. "But it is such a big and influential phenomenon with so many different dimensions that there's an enormous amount of interest from people who are not in the business."
The Standard's unaudited circulation base is 115,000; by contrast, Wired's is 425,000. The Standard says its advertising pages grew 140 percent from June 1998 to June 1999, with gains averaging 30 percent every quarter since the magazine was founded in April 1998.
Mr. Fallows said that in joining the staff, he was "trying to create some version of my pre-U.S. News life, which is writing books, magazine articles and writing a frequent column."
He added: "My plan is basically to write about the outside world and the Internet. What should the outside world make of these castles being made of sand or of steel girders every day? How should people building these castles think of themselves historically and in the eyes of their citizens? Think of me as an interested amateur observer." ALEX KUCZYNSKI

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Illuminating Dark Secrets in Victorian Buffalo

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

CITY OF LIGHT
By Lauren Belfer
518 pages. The Dial Press. $24.95.
 In one of its dimensions, Lauren Belfer's impressive debut, "City of Light," is a stereopticon of a novel, sepia-tinged at the edges yet bursting with color at its center. Its title refers to Buffalo at the turn of the 20th century, when that city by Lake Erie and Niagara Falls was a leading commercial center, a vital maritime and railway hub, the most important inland port in America, a gateway between East and West and, in the words of Louisa Barrett, the novel's narrator, "flush in an era of extraordinary economic prosperity and civic optimism." 
 The city was proud to have sent two presidents to the White House, Millard Fillmore and Grover Cleveland, and of being chosen as the site of a world's fair to be called the Pan-American Exposition, which, as Louisa relates, "would celebrate the commercial links between North and South America as well as America's technological breakthroughs, particularly in the area of electricity, which was being developed at nearby Niagara Falls."
 About the promise of that electricity, Louisa's friend, Thomas Sinclair, the director of the power station at Niagara, tells her: "I have found light. Literally. It's become a kind of religion to me, as sacrilegious as that may sound: creating electricity from water, using alternating current to send the electricity wherever it's needed." Tom concludes: "Electrification is a fundamental change in the nature of life itself. I know that sounds ridiculous, but it's true."
Of course there are also those who are less optimistic about the city's prospects. The workers who must inhabit industrial shantytowns, the women whose roles are constricted by Buffalo society, the black people who feel misrepresented by the Pan-American Exposition, the so-called Preservationists, who worry that the production of electricity may divert all the water from glorious Niagara Falls: these people see Buffalo as a city of darkness.
In the crosscurrents of these powerful forces, Louisa shares the intimacies of her life with us. To all appearances a spinster and bluestocking whose position as headmistress of the elite Macaulay School has earned her the confidence of the city's leaders, Louisa harbors a secret concerning Tom's young daughter, Grace. As Louisa explains, 10 years earlier her best friend, Margaret Sinclair, after years of childless marriage to Tom, "had feigned pregnancy when she learned that a child from a good family might be available for adoption."
Louisa had been the intermediary in that arrangement, under circumstances threatening to respectability, of whose details she believes she alone is aware. In gratitude the Sinclairs had made her Grace's godmother. In the meantime Margaret had finally become pregnant but had died in childbirth, and Louisa has grown ever closer to Grace and Tom. Now, at the novel's opening, the murder of one of the power plant's engineers not only serves to concentrate the city's contending social forces, it also threatens Louisa's relationship with her beloved goddaughter.
This somewhat fustily Victorian plot is not the novel's strength. The evidence of who committed the murder points so strongly to Tom that the reader knows he cannot possibly have been responsible. And for anyone even dimly aware of American history, the knowledge that eventually President McKinley will show up at the Pan-American Exposition and be assassinated hangs somewhat heavily over the story's development.
Yet the plot, which is serviceable enough, is not really what counts in "City of Light." What matters more is the vivid sense of the time and place that Ms. Belfer has created: the heaviness of the architecture with its classical pillars and coffered ceilings and mahogany wainscoting; the layout of the city with its system of parks designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, and the weight of a social order in which commerce alone conferred power.
Louisa glimpses the light, both literally and figuratively. Here she is, entering Tom's newly electrified house. "I stopped, leaning against the banister to look. To gawk. I had never been in a house lit by electricity. The change was -- miraculous. I'd heard that in cities like New York and Chicago, the rich had been showing off their wealth by installing steam generators and electrifying their homes for the sake of novelty. But here in Buffalo, the old families had no need for novelty, and the nouveaux riches emulated the old. Compared to this, the other homes I visited were shadowy and claustrophobic. Here the air itself seemed clear, vibrant and somehow invigorating. All at once I knew why: Gaslight consumed the oxygen in a room; electricity did not."
But the hypocrisy of a society where wealth matters more than justice threatens to darken Louisa's life. Symbolic is the conduct of Grover Cleveland, who, when he was a rising politician in the city, Louisa reminds us, carried on an affair with a widowed shop girl, Maria Halpin. As Louisa relates it, Cleveland acknowledged the resulting illegitimate son, but "refused to consider marriage to Mrs. Halpin, who was known to have bestowed her favors on other well-to-do men of the community."
Louisa continues: "To console herself, she'd begun drinking, and Cleveland arranged to have his son taken from her by force and adopted by an established local family. When Mrs. Halpin refused to accept this separation, Cleveland had her committed to an insane asylum, where she remained until she saw 'reason.' " The story caused a "national trauma" when it came out during Cleveland's 1884 Presidential campaign, Louisa concludes. But Cleveland was elected for two terms nonetheless, and Buffalo society eventually forgave him and welcomed his return.
Whether we've progressed from those times remains highly debatable. But in her powerfully atmospheric book Ms. Belfer makes them seem real and very far away, and at the same time eerily familiar and relevant to the present.
