HEADLINE: Autonation to Shed Car Rental Businesses

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Trying to raise a sagging share price, H. Wayne Huizenga announced today that Autonation Inc., the giant automotive retailer that he controls, would spin off or sell its struggling car rental businesses, which include National Car Rental and Alamo Rent-a-Car.
Much as the move might look like a retreat from Mr. Huizenga's vision two years ago of assembling an empire that would reap economies of scale by being involved in every stage of selling, renting and servicing new and used cars, he insisted in an interview that it was not a step back. 
 He explained that he hoped to preserve many of the advantages of a large-scale operation by writing a contract with the car rental groups before disposing of them. Under the contract, Autonation will continue to service many cars for the rental businesses and will continue to sell them some new cars, Mr. Huizenga said. He added that he hoped to spin off the rental operations to shareholders or sell stock in them to the public. He said selling the businesses to another company would be his last choice.
The goal of the plan is to increase Autonation's share price by making it purely an automotive retailing company, Mr. Huizenga said.
The move will be the latest in a flurry of changes at Autonation, which also named a new president today, Michael E. Maroone, a longtime Florida car dealer who until now has been the president of Autonation's car dealerships group. Autonation is also looking for a new chief executive with automotive experience to replace its current co-chief executives: Mr. Huizenga, who will remain as chairman, and Steven R. Berrard, who is leaving Autonation's management but will remain on its board. Mr. Huizenga said a new chief would be chosen within three weeks from among three finalists.
In April, Autonation spun off its garbage hauling business and changed its name from Republic Industries. Since 1997, it has also sold its home-alarm business and shifted its emphasis toward new-car retailing and away from used-car superstores and automobile repair shops. The pace of the changes has dismayed financial analysts, who say that the company should choose a strategy and stick to it long enough for its earnings to be better understood.
"It would be nice to see them settle down and put some numbers on the board and have a pure auto retailing business and not try to be re-creating the world at every turn," said Tom Thomson, an auto retailing analyst at First Union Capital Markets.
Autonation's shares rose 31.25 cents today to close at $15.25.
The stock is trading at a third of its level of two years ago. Wall Street was captivated then by Mr. Huizenga's vision of consolidating the automotive business as he had already consolidated the garbage hauling and video rental businesses by building Waste Management Inc. and Blockbuster Entertainment.
Autonation has become the world's largest seller of new cars, with 412 franchises and 42 used-car superstores. It earned $501.2 million, including a one-time gain of $379.3 million from disposal of the garbarge hauling business, on sales of $5.07 billion in the second quarter. It sold 119,000 new vehicles and 84,000 used.
Investor interest in the company has cooled as its profit margins have lagged behind those of some competitors, although Autonation said today that margins inched up in the second quarter.
Mr. Huizenga said he still believed Autonation would transform auto retailing. "Our vision is to change the way customers are treated, to change the way customers buy their cars," he said.
Autonation sells used cars at fixed prices and has said that it will gradually move its new-car dealerships toward the same policy. Though such sales are popular with consumer advocates, who accuse many traditional dealers of unscrupulous negotiating tactics, the policy allows rival dealers to take away business by slightly undercutting Autonation's fixed prices.
Investors have been turning to the stocks of companies that own only dealerships and are run by people with lots of automotive experience. Lithia Motors Inc., which is based in Medford, Ore., has thrived under the control of Sidney DeBoer, a car dealer since 1968. The United Auto Group, which has struggled under a succession of chief executives from outside the auto industry, has won friends recently on Wall Street with the pending sale of a 39 percent stake to Roger Penske, a prominent car dealer who also races cars and controls a diesel engine company.
Rivals like Mr. DeBoer have been skeptical that the highly competitive dealership business has room for new approaches like Mr. Huizenga's. "You're not going to come up with a new concept and turn the world over," Mr. DeBoer said today. "It has all been tried."
The car rental businesses that Autonation plans to dispose of include not only National and Alamo but also a third company, Cartemps U.S.A., which Mr. Huizenga created by buying and renaming two car rental businesses, Spirit and Thrifty, and merging them with Alasys, an affiliate of Alamo.
Autonation said today that its second-quarter operating income from car rentals fell to $30 million from $45 million a year earlier on revenue of $893 million, up 3.2 percent.
Mr. Huizenga, who made one fortune from Waste Management and another from Blockbuster, has many other investments. He sold the Florida Marlins baseball team after it won the World Series in 1997, but he still owns the Miami Dolphins football team and is chairman of a holding company that owns the Florida Panthers hockey team and some hotels. He is also chairman of Republic Services Inc., a garbage hauling company in which Autonation sold its remaining 63 percent stake in April.
Even as Mr. Huizenga has become more focused on selling new cars, the Ford Motor Company has begun following his example to some extent by trying to provide cradle-to-grave services for automobiles. Ford has formed partnerships with dealers to buy up all of the Ford, Lincoln, Mercury, Mazda and Jaguar dealerships in half a dozen cities, and then set common prices at all the dealerships. Ford agreed this spring to buy one company that owns junkyards and another that sells extended-service contracts. And Ford is trying hard to increase sales of auto parts by encouraging dealers to do repair work at more competitive prices.
But Ford has run into other problems. Texas car dealers, for example, recently pushed a law through the state legislature banning manufacturers from owning dealerships. Autonation said today that it had signed an agreement to buy four Ford-owned dealerships in Fort Worth that the auto maker must sell.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 7, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the plans of Autonation Inc. to spin off or sell its car rental businesses misstated the history of the company's Cartemps U.S.A. division. It was formed through the acquisition of Spirit Rent-A-Car Inc. and Snappy Car Rental Inc., not Thrifty Inc., which is a unit of Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group Inc.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Maestros, Insights and Intermission in the Sagebrush

BYLINE: By James R. Oestreich 

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 2

 BODY:
A small town in which James Levine, James Conlon and David Zinman, to name only conductors (and only some of them), roam the streets at the same time? Salzburg, Austria, perhaps?
No, this town is smaller, though not nearly as small as it was even a decade ago. Indeed, as trendy shops proliferate, it begins to resemble the Upper West Side of Manhattan, as an old Aspen hand noted, though styles and prices run more toward Paris. 
 And a major factor in that growth is the Aspen Music Festival and School, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary with the help of those conductors and other figures central to its history. The summer season accounts for some 40 percent of Aspen's annual economy, a study by the University of Colorado, Boulder, which the festival likes to cite, found a few years ago, and summer in Aspen is closely tied to the festival.
The festival, too, continues to evolve. Having unveiled an impressive year-round chamber hall, the Harris Concert Hall, six years ago, it plans to open a new, redesigned concert tent next season to replace the 35-year-old one now in use, whose worn condition (added to inherent acoustical flaws) has been drippingly evident during a rainy summer the rest of the country might envy.
In addition, the festival has announced the creation of an American Academy of Conducting next year, conceived by the festival's music director, Mr. Zinman. But the academy may be hard put to improve on maestros who have already passed through the festival and school.
Mr. Levine, for one, was returning after a 23-year absence to conduct the Aspen Chamber Symphony on Friday evening and the Aspen Festival Orchestra on Sunday afternoon. Both orchestras combine professional players, in principal positions, with students.
The Sunday program consisted of Mahler's Third Symphony, which Ara Guzelimian, a former artistic administrator of the festival, neatly tied to the anniversary in a preconcert lecture. In its searching ambition, Mr. Guzelimian suggested, this grand paean to nature and ultimately to God (whether pantheistic, Jewish or Christian), shares the idealism of those who gathered here in 1949 to celebrate the Goethe bicentennial and ponder the task of postwar cultural reconstruction. Both the festival and the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies grew out of that meeting, the two tendencies being exemplified in the person of one person present, Albert Schweitzer.
Mahler's Third has long been a favorite work of Mr. Levine. When he conducted it a few years ago with the Philadelphia Orchestra, the "Parsifal" effect seemed to be setting in: what Mr. Levine loves, he tends to love to death (or rather, to a shimmering new life), lingering, savoring and caressing at ever greater length.
He added another wrinkle in Philadelphia, injecting an intermission after the first movement, citing Mahler's own precedent at the 1902 premiere (no matter that Mahler took 10 minutes, and a modern intermission is 25). He did the same here, and even more than in Philadelphia, the scale, intensity and eventfulness of the first movement justified -- all but demanded -- an intermission.
The knowledge that an intermission awaits may indeed encourage Mr. Levine to risk more. Here, at any rate, was a magnificent construct of a first movement, gaining momentum in the marchlike section leading into the great central climax, which was perfectly offset by its counterpart at the end. All of this emerged cohesively despite an interruption when a low-flying plane drowned out the music. The musical juncture was opportune, and Mr. Levine simply stopped, waited and picked up again.
The intermission had another advantage here, letting a listener wade hip-deep into sagebrush outside the tent and gaze in awe at majestic peaks receding into the haze toward Independence Pass: the very picture of what had just been heard in Mahler's nature study. And throughout, the wind riffling through aspen trees and whipping the tent flaps enhanced the sense of nature's presence.
Mr. Levine let the four inner movements breathe their more relaxed atmospheres (with Michelle DeYoung a lovely-toned mezzo-soprano and the Colorado Children's Chorus piping attractively but with the women of the Colorado Symphony Chorus sounding unfocused). Then he offered another model of sustained line in the finale, with layer upon layer building to a stunning conclusion.
The playing was, of course, no match for the Philadelphia Orchestra's; the horn players, in particular, struggled repeatedly, but what youngsters would not falter in such music, where professionals fear to tread? Youthful ardor, in any case, counted for more than plushness.
Mr. Levine, for his part, is often praised for the smoothness and polish he achieves, less often for the depth of his interpretations. Yet here, despite rough edges, he elicited one of the finest Mahler Thirds -- one of the finest Mahler interpretations -- this grizzled Mahlerite has heard.
Mr. Levine's other program -- the Bach-Webern Ricercar, Wagner's "Siegfried Idyll," Milhaud's "Boeuf sur le Toit" and Schubert's Fourth Symphony -- afforded less potential for imposing rhetoric, and pelting rain on the tent roof intruded loudly on much of the music. Still, Mr. Levine and the Aspen Chamber Symphony made much of these works, showing a mutual affection as obvious as that in the Mahler.
One event specifically celebrating the anniversary was Bernard Rands's chamber opera "Belladonna," commissioned for the occasion and performed on Thursday evening, with Mr. Zinman conducting. Mr. Rands and his librettist, Leslie Dunton-Downer, seemed focused not so much on a mere 50-year span as on the millennial scale, looking back to the elevated dinner conversation of ancient Greek thinkers and to the Last Supper and Passion of Jesus.
"We prefer to think of 'Belladonna' as music theater rather than opera," they write, but there is little that is truly theatrical, or in many cases even comprehensible, in this elaborate intellectual conceit. Set as a dinner party of five thoroughly modern women, its discussion of love veers from a high-flown scene presented all in Latin (with more Latin in supertitles) to a farcical sendup of opera. (Here, at least, the music mirrors the humor of the libretto, as it does not in earlier scenes.)
Interludes are larded with more Latin (three kinds in all, the authors point out), sung offstage without even the benefit of titles, and scarcely anything registers but the odd sexual swoon. Along with the farce, the presence of a falling-down drunk insures easy laughs, but it is hard to imagine what audience this farrago is intended to attract or will. Only the most literate listener with a taste for slapstick need apply, apparently, though the friendly crowd filling the Wheeler Opera House, a lovely little antique painstakingly restored, seemed to take its cue from the farcical aspects and cheered lustily.
In marked contrast, Mr. Conlon's master class for opera singers in the Wheeler on Saturday morning was all about communication. With intelligence, grace and humor, Mr. Conlon turned fine performances into potentially excellent ones, and indifferent performances into promising ones, making it all look easy.
Along the way he imparted insights, not only to singers but also to a rapt full house made up largely of civilians, on the rendering of texts in Italian and German; fine points of vocal technique, and sheer musical savvy. "Don't you cry," he said of singing Puccini and verismo generally. "Make them cry. Don't reflect too much on your own emotions. That's what turns it into kitsch."
He could have been talking just as well about Mr. Levine's Mahler. Musical ideas, like musicians, have a way of bumping into one another in this little town in the summer.

HEADLINE: Europe Gets Back In Gear

BYLINE: By Norbert Walter; Norbert Walter is the chief economist of the Deutsche Bank Group.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
Europe is finally back on track. You don't see it much in the headlines yet, but watch for the strong seedlings of growth and reform to be springing up all over the European landscape. Most notably, after almost two decades of status quo politics in Germany, the Government is tackling some of the right issues to get the Continent's largest economy moving again.
Under the leadership of the new Finance Minister, Hans Eichel, the German Parliament is not just earnestly debating significant spending reductions, but also agreeing on sensible tax cuts. Germany's high tax rates have long deterred the world's investors. Under the proposed plan, corporate taxes would fall even below the level in the United States. 
 Other changes are falling into place. Take the financing of pensions. Europe's problems are far worse than those in the United States, because the large Continental countries have mostly unfinanced pension plans -- that is, today's employees have to pay for today's pension benefits, rather than accumulating and investing their pension contributions and drawing from them for their own retirements later, as in American 401(k)'s.
This pay-as-you-go system is badly inappropriate for Europe, where the graying of the population is more pronounced than in the United States and where early retirement is common.
Under those circumstances, it is encouraging to see that Walter Riester, Germany's Labor Minister, who used to be a top official of Germany's most militant union, has proposed to establish a supplementary account outside of the state-supported social security to boost the private component of retirement savings. This type of savings account, held in the name of the individual, is also under discussion in the United States as part of the debate on the privatization of Social Security.
There surely are going to be rear-guard battles to limit the extent and speed of the proposed sensible reforms. But already you can see the mood changing in critical places. For instance, on the front pages of Germany's liberal newspapers, the erstwhile promoters of a bloated state sector (which translated into ever higher taxes) are withering away.
What did the trick? The younger generation in Parliament is fast moving into leadership positions. And these lawmakers' 30-something colleagues in journalism are increasingly writing editorials strongly in favor of reform and against the paralyzing status quo.
After a timid start, Germany's Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, has developed a more finely attuned political ear. His left-leaning Government has just started a pro-reform advertising campaign, which is squarely directed at its core constituencies, mainly workers, public employees and retirees. "There are no alternatives" to reforming Germany "from top to bottom," the campaign warns.
The good news spreads well beyond Germany. Italy, too, is tackling pension reform. France is undergoing bruising mergers in the oil, banking and chemical industries. And, in a remarkable departure from past practice, French corporate executives have supported foreign ownership and influence in French stock markets. The Socialist Government has actually accelerated the sale of state-owned companies.
In many European countries, business confidence is rising for the first time in a long while. The new common currency, the euro, has risen appreciably in recent weeks, after falling for the first six months after its introduction.
In assessing the brightness of Europe's prospects -- and hence the shape of the world economy -- the importance of turning Germany around cannot be overstated. After all, Germany accounts for about a third of the gross domestic product of Euroland (consisting of the 11 nations now sharing the euro). A dynamized Germany will have a stimulating effect on the rest of Europe.
Since the Reagan era, Americans have pushed Europe to embrace market reforms. At long last the message has been heard. The United States should welcome this revival of the Europeans' competitive juices. For too long it has been the lone engine of global economic growth.

HEADLINE: Index Predicts Growth Will Last Into 2000

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The United States economy is poised to keep growing at least through the first half of 2000, leaving it on track for achieving the longest expansion ever, according to an important gauge of future activity.
The Conference Board said yesterday that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, which is intended to help spot turning points in the economy, rose three-tenths of a percent in June, to 107.7. That matched the May increase and means that the indicator has posted gains in eight of the last nine months. The last decline, in April, was one-tenth of a percent. 
 The longest economic expansion in the nation's history lasted for 106 months, from February 1961 until December 1969. The current expansion, which began in March 1991, would match the record if it continues through January 2000 and pass it if it lasts until February.
"The expansion is firmly on track," said Michael Boldin, director of business cycle research at the Conference Board. But because of concerns that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates again to fight inflation "some volatility can be expected in the second half of 1999," he said.
Seven of the 10 indicators that make up the leading index rose in June. The most significant increases came in manufacturers' new orders of consumer goods and materials, in money supply, and in the difference between long-term and short-term interest rates.
In a sign, however, that the labor market may not be heating up enough to push up wages, a crucial component of the inflation picture -- the average number of hours worked a week by production workers -- was unchanged.
The Conference Board's index of current economic activity rose four-tenths of a percent, to 124.6 in June. But its lagging index decreased four-tenths of a percent, to 108. The indexes are calculated from a base of 100, set in 1992.
"Taken together, the three composite indexes and their components show a very health economy," the Conference Board report said.
Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, noted that other recent reports show that economic growth is slowing. Last week, the Commerce Department reported that economic growth has slowed to an annual rate of 2.3 percent in the second quarter from 4.3 percent in the first three months of the year.
Yesterday's figures came as investors were trying to predict whether the Fed would raise short-term interest rates for a second time this year.

HEADLINE: House Approves Renewing Trade Benefits for Vietnam

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The House today renewed limited economic ties with Vietnam for another year, a week after Washington and Hanoi reached a tentative trade accord that brings Vietnam a step closer to full trading privileges with the United States.
The vote was 297 to 130 to endorse President Clinton's waiver of a 1974 law. It allows American companies that do business with Vietnam to receive limited Government benefits like loans and guarantees from the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. 
 Vietnam is not eligible for broader trade privileges like lower taxes on Vietnamese goods shipped to the United States until Congress approves a bilateral trade pact. After three years of negotiations, the two countries reached an agreement in principle last week that could be presented to lawmakers in the fall.
Trade between the two countries is relatively small. Vietnam ships $650 million worth of goods to the United States each year. American companies send $350 million in products to Vietnam.
The outcome today was widely expected, and it was viewed by supporters as a steppingstone in the path of improved relations between the United States and its erstwhile enemy. Mr. Clinton capped the efforts by lifting the United States trade embargo on Vietnam in 1994 and establishing diplomatic relations with Hanoi in 1995.
Legislators drew on many of the same arguments they wielded last week, when the House renewed full trading privileges with China. That vote was 260 to 170.
Supporters of broadening commercial ties with Vietnam, and granting the waiver today, argued that engaging Vietnam gave Washington more leverage on issues like improving human rights and resolving the remaining cases of missing American servicemen in Vietnam.
"Americans must realize conclusively that the war with Vietnam is over," Representative Douglas K. Bereuter, Republican of Nebraska, said. "Emotional scars remain with many Americans. But it's time to get on with our bilateral relationship."
Critics contended that Vietnam had not fully cooperated in accounting for G.I.'s who were missing in action, persecuted its citizens for their religious beliefs and hampered the emigration of opponents of the Communist Government.
"The average citizen in Vietnam must still pay $1,000 in bribes -- three times an annual salary -- for access to U.S. immigration programs," said Representative Loretta Sanchez, a California Democrat whose Orange County district has one of the largest concentrations of Vietnamese people in the United States.
The debate paled in contrast to the fight over trade with China, but it evoked powerful emotions from many veterans. Representative Sam Johnson, a Texas Republican who served seven years in a Vietnamese prison after his Air Force jet had been shot down, urged rejection of the waiver.
The lawmakers voted on a waiver to the Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the 1974 Trade Act, which requires annual voting on renewing trading rights for countries that limit emigration.

HEADLINE: House Votes to Cut $2 Billion From Clinton Foreign Aid Plan

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
A $12.6 billion foreign aid bill was passed by the House today but faces a White House veto threat over its deep spending cuts and anti-abortion language.
After three days of debate, the House took nearly $2 billion out of President Clinton's request for the coming year. The State Department called the spending provided in the measure "grossly inadequate." 
 The final vote was 385 to 35.
The bill withholds $500 million that the Administration sought for help in carrying out the latest Middle East peace accords, reached last year at the Wye River Plantation in Maryland. It also cuts $200 million requested for a program of interest-free loans to the world's poorest countries.
The bill also contains an amendment cutting off funds for any foreign group that performs abortions or advocates liberalizing its country's abortion laws. The Senate's foreign aid bill, passed last month, does not include the anti-abortion provisions.
The two foreign aid bills must now be reconciled in a House-Senate conference. Even though most House Democrats voted for the spending bill, many say they will oppose it in the final form unless some of the cuts are restored.
The foreign aid bill serves primarily as a vehicle for financing American allies and American aims overseas and occasionally as a means of questioning or quarreling with the White House and its conduct of foreign policy.
The House bill, like the Senate's, which was passed on June 30, contains $2.88 billion in military and economic aid for Israel, $2 billion for Egypt and $325 million for Jordan.
It makes significant cuts in the White House budget requests for the Peace Corps, the Agency for International Development, the Export-Import Bank, economic development aid for North Korea, and peacekeeping operations.
It provides $725 million for the independent republics of the former Soviet Union, but that is $307 million less than the President sought, and half of the aid to Russia would depend on Moscow's ending its cooperation with Iran on nuclear power and ballistic missile programs.
The bill contains $626.6 million for the World Bank and its subsidiaries. The House cut $200 million by withholding the sum from the World Bank's International Development Association, which provides loans without interest to the least-developed nations of the world.
All told, the House bill includes $7.4 billion in economic aid, $3.6 billion for military assistance, $1.1 billion for various international agencies and $596 million for export aid.
Last week the House also adopted an amendment to the bill that cut off money for recruiting and transporting Latin American military officers to the Army's School of the Americas in Fort Benning, Ga.
The vote, which surprised even the amendment's supporters, was an unusual act for the Republican-controlled Congress. It struck at an institution long criticized by the left for the training it has provided to its students. The ranks of its graduates include Manuel Noriega, the deposed dictator of Panama; the late Roberto D'Aubuisson, a far-right politician and reputed death-squad commander in El Salvador, and other unsavory exponents of the cold war in Central America.
The Senate bill retained the financing for the School of the Americas.
A separate spending bill to provide money for the State Department, which is scheduled to reach the House floor later this week, will raise the issue of whether the United States should pay the $1 billion in dues that it owes the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Annual Cost of Treating Gunshot Wounds Is Put at $2.3 Billion

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

 BODY:
Gunshot wounds cost the nation $2.3 billion a year in medical treatment, and almost half that sum is paid for with taxpayers' dollars, a study by a group of economists has found.
The study, being reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association, used data collected in 1994 to calculate the expense of treating the 134,445 gunshot wounds reported during that year. The total did not take into account other costs, like those of mental health treatment for victims or lost days of work. 
 Because the study was so large, said the paper's chief author, Dr. Philip J. Cook of Duke University, it gives the clearest picture to date of both the financial impact of firearms violence and of who is paying the bills.
"Because almost half of the cost is paid for by the government," Dr. Cook said, "it is clear that even though many people feel that gun violence is essentially someone else's problem, it is really everybody's problem."
Dr. Jens O. Ludwig of Georgetown University, a co-author of the report, said it suggested that programs to curb firearm violence might be worth the expense, by reducing costs in the long run.
In their study, the researchers drew information from 10 large databanks, including hospital stay and discharge figures, outcomes of emergency room treatment, and reports on the cause and outcome of the most expensive of gunshot damage: spinal injuries.
The average cost of a gunshot wound that brings the victim to a hospital is $14,600 for emergency care and $35,400 for lifetime medical care resulting from the shooting, the study found. The researchers established an annual total cost of $2.3 billion by adding all the emergency care expense for 1994 to a figure, arrived at by formula, reflecting that year's share of lifetime medical costs.
Of the $2.3 billion in total annual medical costs, $1.1 billion, or 48 percent, was paid by taxpayers through Medicaid, Medicare, workers' compensation and other government programs, the researchers said. About 33 percent was paid by the wounded themselves or other people, and about 18 percent was paid by private medical insurance.
Wounds that resulted from assaults with firearms, as opposed to accidents or suicide attempts, accounted for three-quarters of the total cost, the study found. In addition, the data showed that while only about 2 percent of gunshots resulted in spinal cord injuries, such cases accounted for half the total cost of gunshot wounds.
Because the study is the largest and most complete of its kind, it is likely to figure in policy debates on gun violence in America.
In a telephone interview, Paul Blackman, research coordinator of the Institute for Legislative Action at the National Rifle Association, said that although the cost identified in the study might seem large, "put in perspective it is only one-quarter of 1 percent of the nation's $950 billion medical costs, and in that way seems less burdensome."
Mr. Blackman also said that others had estimated the portion of the nation's gunshot medical bill paid by taxpayers to be much higher. So the new, more detailed figures, he said, might lower concern about how much of the burden the public is carrying.
Dr. Cook, meanwhile, said he and his colleagues were now working on an estimate of society's total costs, beyond just medical expenses, attributable to gun violence.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
With Billionsin New Issues Due, Treasuries Fall for a 4th Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell for a fourth session yesterday as $52 billion of planned debt sales and concern about a rate increase by the Federal Reserve sapped demand for Treasuries.
The sales include a $5 billion issue from Wal-Mart Stores Inc. this week and a projected $37 billion from the Treasury next week. 
 "I don't see a lot to get real bullish about," said Robert Smith, who helps oversee $525 million at Sage Advisory Services Ltd. in Austin, Tex. "We're not very optimistic."
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 5/32 yesterday, to 87 23/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.16 percent from 6.12 percent late Monday.
Not everyone rushed to sell, though. By noon, $20.7 billion of Treasury securities had been traded, which was down almost 52 percent compared with the average Tuesday in the third quarter of 1998, according to Govpx Inc., which supplies information on prices and trading.
Treasuries may have a tough time recovering losses while investors wait to see whether the Fed raises interest rates at its next policy meeting on Aug. 24.
In June, the Fed lifted its target for overnight loans between banks -- the Federal funds rate -- a quarter-point, to 5 percent, in an attempt to restrain the economy.
The Government's July jobs report on Friday may show whether there are any signs of a cooling down. Economists expect, on average, a gain of 206,000 new jobs and a drop in the unemployment rate to 4.2 percent from 4.3 percent. The chance of a rate increase may reduce buyers' appetite for the new debt, analysts said.
Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, is expected to price its bonds this week.
Fannie Mae, the largest provider of United States home mortgages, plans to sell $3 billion of five-year global bonds as early as some time this week. It also expects to sell $500 million of its 30-year bonds, adding to $1.5 billion it offered in May.

HEADLINE: Pay More Attention to Asia, Quayle Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Former Vice President Dan Quayle said today that the United States should pay more attention to Asian affairs and develop a stronger relationship with India.
Speaking at the National Press Club, Mr. Quayle, a Republican Presidential candidate, said American foreign policy had been tilted toward Europe but the rise of Asia made it imperative that the United States pay more attention to that region. 
 "Asia is much more important today than it was a generation ago," Mr. Quayle said. "We do have to treat Asia economically, politically, militarily and diplomatically as we do Europe."
Mr. Quayle contrasted his foreign policy experience with that of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who leads all Republican Presidential candidates in the polls and in fund-raising.
"On Day 1, I'll be ready to be President," he said. "I don't believe we need another President who has inexperience when it comes to foreign policy. There's only so much you can get from briefings and briefers and crash courses when it comes to foreign policy."
Mr. Quayle said he wanted to bring China into the World Trade Organization eventually and see the country move toward democracy. But he warned that some experts liken China to the Germany of 100 years ago, which was then defeated in two world wars before becoming a solidly democratic nation.
The United States should make it clear that it plans to remain a power in Asia, Mr. Quayle said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

World Wrestling Federation Plans an Initial Offering
World Wrestling Federation Entertainment, the company that promotes and stages the most popular wrestling events, including Wrestlemania, plans to raise up to $175 million by selling a minority stake in the company in an initial public offering.
The company, which produces television shows like "W.W.F. Smackdown," has cashed in on the public's taste for increasingly outrageous competitions. Wrestling dominates the rankings of cable television shows, and those high ratings have produced stellar financial results. Market Place. Page A1. 

Stocks End Mixed With the Dow Up
Stock prices ended the day mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.35 points, to 10,677.31, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.87 points, to 1,322.18, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 35.64 points, or 1.4 percent, to 2,587.99. C12.
 
Bond prices dropped for a fourth session as demand was dampened by $52 billion of planned debt sales and concern over interest rates. The yield on the 30-year issue rose to 6.16 percent from 6.12 percent. C12.
 
U.A.W. Prepares for Contract Talks
Seeking to reassure its members that it is taking a hard line in labor talks, the United Automobile Workers union, led by its president, Stephen Yokich, plans to hold strike authorization votes at all Ford factories on Aug. 17 in preparation for the expiration of national contracts with all auto makers in September. The union holds such votes every three years at all the auto factories it represents, just in case union leaders need to call a national strike if talks break down. A strike this year seems unlikely, most labor and auto officials say. C2.
 
Bill Limits On-Line Liquor Sales
The House overwhelmingly passed a bill that would restrict on-line liquor sales, overriding objections from California lawmakers that the proposal favored liquor wholesalers over small wineries and breweries trying to broaden their reach through the Internet. A14.
 
Debt-for-Stock Swaps in China
Faced with more than $200 billion in bad debt at moribund state-owned companies, Chinese officials said that they would begin a broad program of debt-for-equity swaps that could include some foreign ownership. C4.
 
A Place for Women on the Go
A Web site started by a well-traveled woman for other women offers clear organization and no-nonsense tips. Business Travel. C11.
 
Loss Narrows at Global Crossing
Global Crossing, which is buying long-distance phone company Frontier for about $12.9 billion, sharply reduced its loss in the second quarter. The company, which is based in Bermuda and is building a worldwide fiber optic network, said its loss narrowed to $4.2 million, compared with $193 million in the period a year earlier. Shares of Global Crossing fell $1.875, to $38.125. C9.
 
More Bad News at Waste Concern
Warnings continue at Waste Management, which now says it might restate first-quarter earnings, lowering them by $55.4 million. The company also said that second-quarter adjusted net income rose 53 percent, in line with lowered expectations. C2.
 
S.E.C. Discloses 26 Fraud Cases
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that its second nationwide sweep against small-company stock fraud had resulted in enforcement actions against 82 people and companies in 26 cases that bilked investors of millions of dollars. C8.

HEADLINE: Strong July and Rebates Position Auto Makers for Record Year

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Auto makers dangled rebates in front of their customers last month, and like fish to bait, buyers snapped up new cars and trucks. That led to a brisk annual sales pace of 17 million vehicles and kept the industry on track for a record-setting sales year.
The General Motors Corporation, which was virtually shut down by a strike in June and July last year, saw its sales jump 62.6 percent in July compared with figures in the bleak period a year earlier. Car sales jumped 68.2 percent, while sales of minivans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks rose 57.2 percent. Part of the sales increase was a result of generous rebates and discounted financing deals that G.M. began offering on July 15 on nearly every 1999 model. The deals are good through September. 
 DaimlerChrysler sales rose 10.1 percent, with car sales plunging 14.6 percent while sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans increased 20.1 percent. Sales of its sport utility vehicles rose 36 percent, and sales of the Jeep Grand Cherokee jumped 62 percent after the company offered generous rebates.
"It is unquestionable that the industry is going to see a record year," said James P. Holden, executive vice president for sales and marketing at DaimlerChrysler.
The Ford Motor Company's sales rose 1.4 percent in July compared with figures in the period a year earlier, with car sales jumping 11.3 percent and sales of pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans dropping 4.8 percent. Figures exclude Volvo's car operations, which Ford bought in March. During last year's strike, G.M. had low truck stockpiles, so many buyers chose Ford trucks instead. That artificially propped up Ford's truck sales last year, making them hard to beat this year.
"We believe there are three major factors driving record consumer demand in the U.S.," said Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service. "First, favorable economic fundamentals. Second, prices for new cars and trucks have been stable while incomes and household net wealth have increased. Third, innovative products."
But the high level of rebates, which make cars cheaper for consumers but less profitable for auto makers, has worried some on Wall Street along with auto analysts in Europe. Auto stocks plunged last week after DaimlerChrysler reported that it spent more than expected on incentives and cut into its second-quarter profits. "Our stock price got slammed," Mr. Holden said. But he insisted that whether incentives were offered to customers through rebates, cheap lease deals, discounted financing rates or by forgoing price increases, "everybody's doing it in some fashion."
July's sales showed that the incentives are helping prop up the market, analysts said. "Pricing isn't great, but volume is," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
In the first quarter, for instance, DaimlerChrysler spent an average of $1,284 a vehicle on rebates and other incentives, the company's co-chairman, Robert J. Eaton, said last week. For the second quarter, the company spent an average of $1,345. But by the end of the second quarter, that figure had risen to $1,470, where Mr. Eaton said he expected it to remain in the third quarter.
G.M. refused to disclose how much it spent on incentives but acknowledged that spending rose in the second quarter compared with the year-earlier period.
Ford also refused to disclose per-vehicle incentive costs but said that in the first quarter its total marketing costs in the United States amounted to 10.9 percent of its gross revenue. In the second quarter, marketing costs climbed slightly, to 11 percent of gross revenue from 10.9 percent in the year-earlier period.
Each auto maker blamed the others for high incentives and insisted that it was spending less than its rivals. "Our net price retention has been higher than Ford or Chrysler," said Michael DiGiovanni, executive director of G.M.'s business decision support center.
DaimlerChrysler begs to differ. "Our incentives for the Chrysler brands are still significantly lower than our domestic competition any way you cut it," said Mr. Holden, who added that by some measurements Ford and G.M. incentives were $500 a vehicle higher than his company's.
Economists said that auto makers had been unable to raise prices and had even effectively lowered them by offering rebates because there are more auto factories than demand for their products. Despite the beginnings of a turnaround in Asia, "it still is an industry struggling with excess global capacity," said Diane Swonk, chief economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago.
Some analysts said they were not too alarmed at the high level of incentives because auto makers are cutting costs enough to keep their profits strong. "Yes, incentives are higher than they've ever been, but profitability per unit is higher than it has ever been," said Wendy Beale Needham, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Other large auto makers posted especially strong results. Toyota's sales rose 13.8 percent; Honda's sales increased 7.9 percent, and Nissan Motor's sales jumped 14.3 percent.
But a giant stumbled. G.M.'s market share stalled again last month, this time at 28.4 percent despite the company's generous rebates. The results are particularly troubling because G.M.'s executives said they had been expecting better.
Just two weeks ago, J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, said that the company's market share was poised to increase. It ended the second quarter at 29.5 percent of the United States market, down 2.1 percentage points from the quarter a year earlier. But Mr. Losh noted that the company's share had topped 30 percent in June. "We expect the share to continue to improve as we go through the balance of the year," Mr. Losh said then.
Instead, it continued to slide.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Trading Is Mixed as Internet Shares Fall Sharply Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, but traders said investors remained extremely skittish about high valuations and the direction of interest rates.
"Investors are very nervous right now, and rightly so," said Bill Allyn, head of listed trading at Jeffries & Company. "We have been talking about valuations for months, and now it is finally hitting home." 
 Internet stocks, the epicenter of speculative activity for much of the year, took another hard hit.
TheStreet.com's Internet index fell 20.96, or 3.9 percent, to 519.07, pulled down by stocks like America Online, Yahoo and CMGI. The index has fallen nearly 35 percent since it peaked on April 12.
Interest rate worries pulled down the Nasdaq composite index, which fell for the fourth consecutive session. Big declines in Unum Provident, the insurance company, and Charles Schwab, the big discount brokerage house, dragged down the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and small stocks slumped. But the Dow Jones industrial average managed to move up, largely on strength in Hewlett-Packard and Procter & Gamble.
"This is not just an isolated day," said Bob Gasser, head of United States equity trading at J. P. Morgan Securities. "It is a lot tougher for the market to deal with rising interest rates than with good corporate earnings."
Mr. Gasser and other analysts said the market was likely to remain in a highly unsettled state until at least Friday, when July employment data are scheduled to be released.
The Federal Reserve Board, which meets Aug. 24 to debate whether it should raise short-term interest rates, is likely to pay close attention to that report.
By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average had risen 31.35, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 10,677.31. The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 1322.18, down 5.87, or four-tenths of 1 percent. The Nasdaq composite lost 35.64, or 1.4 percent, to 2587.99. And the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks fell 6.35, or 1.4 percent, to 436.28.
The pace of business quickened a bit from Monday but still remained fairly subdued. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 734.9 million shares. On the Nasdaq stock market, just over a billion shares changed hands.
Much of the action yesterday was focused on Internet stocks.
Early in the day a number of Internet shares rallied on reports that Yahoo was in negotiations to buy Excite@Home. But those rumors were quashed by George Bell, Excite's president.
Yahoo, which dipped lower on the initial reports, fell further later. The stock closed at 125 3/8, down 6 15/16. The stock has lost nearly half its market value since early April.
Stocks of Internet brokerage firms, which have also been beaten up recently, were battered again after Bill Burnham, an Internet analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, issued a report saying the companies might see their first-ever decline in trading volume, in the third quarter, because of weakness in the Internet stocks their companies favor.
"To see growth in negative territory is significant, but not earth shattering," Mr. Burnham said. "I was surprised the stocks sold off as much as they did" after the report was released.
Schwab, the largest on-line brokerage firm, fell 4 11/16, to 37 3/4. E*Trade Group fell 4 5/16, to 24 11/16; Knight/ Trimark Group lost 4 7/32, to 37 1/32, and Ameritrade Holding dropped 2 3/4, to 21 1/4.
America Online, the world's largest Internet service, continued its slump, with the stock falling for the fourth session, shedding 4 1/16, to 88 13/16. Since April 6, when it peaked at 175 1/2, the stock has fallen nearly 50 percent. And CMGI, the Internet venture capital company, fell 6 7/16 yesterday, to 81 7/8.
"The good news from this summer's selling of Internet shares is that the bears will be hard pressed to still call this a bubble market," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "At this point, the easy money appears to have been made in Internet stocks."
Pressure on these stocks extended to new issues. Four new Internet offerings were priced yesterday: 1-800-Flowers.com, Quotesmith.com, Bigstar Entertainment and Splitrock Services Inc. All closed below their initial offered price.
Elsewhere, Unum Provident fell 15 5/16, or 30 percent, to 36 3/8, after the company, one of the nation's largest disability insurers, said that second-quarter earnings fell because of costs associated with the June merger that created it.
Qualcomm was the biggest loser on the Nasdaq, falling 12 1/2, to 140. The stock slid after Motorola said it would make semiconductors for phones to compete with Qualcomm.
Among Dow stocks, Johnson & Johnson gained 2 1/4, to 94 3/16 after an analyst at J. P. Morgan upgraded his recommendation on the stock to "buy."
Proctor & Gamble gained 3 9/16, to 93 11/16. And Hewlett-Packard rose 3 3/4, to 108 1/2.

HEADLINE: Even a Sky Can Have Limits;
Financing and Other Problems Crimp Space Industry's Growth

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The promise of the space business was shown recently when Hughes Electronics announced a $1.5 billion investment from America Online to deliver Internet service via satellite.
The pitfalls of the space business were seen the same day when Hughes disclosed, much more quietly, problems in manufacturing satellites that would require it to write off $125 million and take a big quarterly loss. 
 It was only the latest in a series of setbacks for Hughes, the unit of the General Motors Corporation that is the nation's largest satellite company. Last year one of its satellites failed in orbit, knocking out paging service for most of the nation. Another Hughes satellite blew up when a rocket exploded. The company's assistance to China in analyzing launching failures has placed it under criminal investigation for violation of national security laws. And the resulting furor in Washington forced Hughes to forfeit a $450 million contract for an Asian satellite system.
As Hughes goes, so goes the satellite industry. Rarely, it seems, has an industry been blessed with so much potential and cursed with so many problems. Manufacturing glitches and rocket failures have made it more difficult and costly to get satellites into the sky. Tighter export controls in the wake of the controversy about technology leaks to China are slowing projects.
"The events of the last year have created higher hurdles for the companies to get the work done," said Clayton Mowry, executive director of the Satellite Industry Association, a trade group.
Perhaps the biggest current problem the industry faces is that confronting Iridium L.L.C. The Washington-based company, which owns a 66-satellite system offering worldwide mobile telephone service, has failed to attract subscribers and is struggling to stave off bankruptcy. Indeed, just today, Iridium acknowledged that the Chase Manhattan Corporation contends it has defaulted on an $800 million loan. Iridium and Motorola, its biggest investor with an 18 percent stake, deny the contention. Page C8.
All these problems have taken some of the bloom off the commercial satellite business, which has only recently surpassed the government-owned satellite market in size. Investors are growing wary of pumping billions of dollars into systems to provide phone service or high-speed data transmission. Many projects will be scaled back, analysts say, or might never get off the ground.
ICO Global Communications, which is developing a satellite-based phone service to compete with Iridium, failed to raise the $500 million it sought from a public rights offering -- despite extending the deadline twice. It is now scrambling to complete a deal with unnamed investors. In an example of how tightly knit one company's fortunes are tied to others in the industry, should ICO fail, Hughes, which is building the satellites for it, could have to write off as much as $500 million.
And the Boeing Company has shelved plans to buy control of Ellipso, another company planning a satellite phone system.
Even so, Mr. Mowry and other executives and analysts shrug off the difficulties as short-term issues. "I don't think the problems we're facing today are any more severe than the industry faced after the Challenger explosion," said Michael T. Smith, the chairman of Hughes, which is based in El Segundo, Calif.
"This is a risky business, and we've never said anything but. But it's also high reward."
Robert B. Kaimowitz, an analyst at ING Baring Furman Selz, was even more upbeat, saying, "Everything in the industry is going great right now." He expects the global industry to grow 12.8 percent a year.
Indeed, both Boeing and Lockheed Martin, the nation's two biggest aerospace companies, are trying hard to move into commercial satellite communications, which is potentially faster growing and more profitable than military contracting.
Boeing is developing a satellite system to provide Internet service to airline passengers. And Lockheed Martin's new global telecommunications division, is trying to buy Comsat for $2.7 billion and has joined with the TRW Corporation and Telecom Italia to develop Astrolink, a $3.6 billion satellite system to deliver Internet service and high-speed data.
If anything, some recent technical problems satellite companies have run across seem to have been caused by a rush to fill orders. "The development capability is stretched to the thinnest," Mr. Smith of Hughes said. "We had gotten to the point where we skipped tests, and that's not wise."
In the last year, six well-publicized rocket failures prompted inquiries by the Pentagon and by Lockheed and Boeing, which made the rockets. There have also been "more in-orbit satellite failures than we have been used to," said Rick Hauck, president of Axa Space, a space insurance underwriter in Bethesda, Md.
Hughes had component failures in six orbiting satellites in the last year, though only the paging satellite failed completely. Lockheed Martin posted a second-quarter loss, in part because orders for satellites dropped and component defects caused a six-month manufacturing delay.
Launchings are also being postponed. Arianespace, the European launch company, was supposed to have supervised six launches so far this year but has handled only two because the satellites are not ready.
Still, the biggest money is not in building or launching satellites, but in services using them; that is where most investor attention is focused.
For example, despite its satellite problems, Hughes's share price -- it trades as a tracking stock, G.M.'s class H stock -- has held steady because of its DirecTV division, which delivers dozens of digital channels to 18-inch home dishes by satellite. Cai von Rumohr, an analyst at S. G. Cowen & Company, estimates that the domestic DirecTV business is worth $50 a share, many times the worth of the satellite manufacturing operations. Hughes shares closed today at $53.6875.
And shares of DirecTV's rival, the Echostar Communications Corporation, a service company not held back by satellite manufacturing, have soared from a 52-week low of less than $9 to $88.25 last month, though they closed today at $71.50.
Neither DirecTV, which has 7.5 million customers, nor Echostar, which has 2.6 million, is profitable yet. But each is adding 100,000 subscribers a month and is on track to move into the black in a year or so.
Indeed, the satellite TV business seems to have clear skies ahead. Through mergers, the industry has already shrunk from five players to two. And broadcasting -- one-way transmission from a single source to many receivers -- is well suited for satellite technology. A satellite in orbit 22,300 miles above the Earth can beam its signal to much of the nation, the way a spotlight widens as it gets farther from its source.
Conversely, the satellite-based telephone business has not yet gone through a consolidation. And using a broad beam to carry phone conversations, which go between two points, does not seem to make as much sense. Moreover, the calls are two-way; the phones must transmit to the satellite as well as receive.
Thus, the Iridium failure is more serious than the industry's recent technical problems because it raises questions about the fundamental demand for satellite services.
Iridium's system, which cost $5 billion, is intended to allow calls to or from anywhere in the world. But Iridium, which began service in November, had only 10,300 subscribers at the end of March, far short of the 52,000 called for in its agreements with lenders.
Even before today's dispute with Chase, Motorola had said it would not provide Iridium more money unless other backers do. The company is hustling to restructure its finances and avoid bankruptcy or liquidation.
Iridium has suffered from technical glitches and marketing errors. Its phones are bulky compared with cellular phones and initially cost about $3,000. Calls cost around $7 a minute. And because an uninterrupted line of sight is needed between the phone and the satellite, Iridium calls can be made from the top of Mount Everest -- but not from inside buildings or cars or even on city streets near tall buildings.
Moreover, cellular service has spread rapidly since Iridium was conceived. Standards now enable some phones to be used in more than one country, reducing the need for satellite phones.
Iridium has slashed the price of phones to less than $1,000 and the price of service to about $3 a minute, and its executives hope for a turnaround. "In the last six months we were in a trial launch mode when we told the whole world we were in full commercial launch," said John Richardson, the chief executive.
Rivals are betting many billions of dollars that Iridium's failure is the result of poor execution, not lack of demand. Globalstar Telecommunications, a company backed by Loral Space & Communications, plans to begin service in September.
Globalstar and some other planned satellite phone services intend to serve not only business executives but also remote villages in the developing world not now reached by wires. Even if residents in these villages cannot afford phones of their own, a phone booth can be set up in the village center.
"There are 3.5 billion people who don't have any communication in a modern sense," said Bernard L. Schwartz, chairman and chief executive of both Loral and Globalstar, calling this "probably the largest market in the world today."
Globalstar recently arranged a credit line of $500 million, securing the financing to begin service. Its stock has done relatively well, even as Iridium's has collapsed and ICO's has dropped by half since its initial offering last year.
Globalstar's phones will initially be priced at $1,100, and air time will sell for only about 65 cents a retail minute. An ING Barings report says that since Globalstar and ICO will have more capacity than Iridium, Globalstar could break even selling service wholesale for 14 cents a minute and ICO for 23 cents, compared with $1.37 for Iridium.
Similar questions about demand are facing companies that plan to deliver high-speed data and Internet service by satellite. The biggest gamble is made by Teledesic, a company backed by Craig McCaw, the cellular telephone magnate, and Bill Gates. Teledesic plans a $10 billion system of 288 satellites, to begin in 2004. Despite its Iridium problems, Motorola is Teledesic's prime contractor and has committed $750 million to it. Over all, Teledesic has raised more than $1.5 billion.
But satellite services are racing against cable and phone companies to provide high-speed Internet access. Phone and cable companies have an economic advantage in urban areas, while satellites probably have one in less dense areas.
Teledesic also faces competition from less costly systems, some of which will be in operation before it is. Those include Hughes's $1.5 billion Spaceway, the Lockheed-led Astrolink, and the $4 billion Skybridge, backed by Alcatel of France. Teledesic, though, says its system will provide Internet service quality unavailable from the others.
With such sums being wagered, one thing is certain. As Mr. Schwartz of Loral put it: "It's a large business. Our failures are going to be large. Our successes are going to be large."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
North Korean Missile Alters Asia Dynamics
North Korea's preparations for the test launching of a new long-range missile this month have caused a dramatic change of course in defense strategy and diplomacy for both Japan and South Korea. While Japan is considering stretching the constitutional limits on its military, South Korea is beginning to overcome deep suspicions of Japan and consider ways to cooperate in the face of a common threat. A1
 
Test-Ban Ratification Urged
The failure of the United States and other nuclear powers to ratify an international treaty that bans nuclear testing undercuts decades of arms control and is making the world much less safe, says a report by nuclear arms experts commissioned by Japan. A6 

Indonesia Vote Made Official
President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia officially accepted the results of a Parliamentary election on June 7. The move ends nearly two months of delays and squabbling by elections officials. The party of his main challenger, Megawati Sukarnoputri, had finished first, with nearly 34 percent. A4
 
House Passes Foreign Aid Bill
A $12.6 billion foreign aid bill was passed by the House but faces a White House veto threat over its deep spending cuts and anti-abortion language. After three days of debate, the House took nearly $2 billion out of President Clinton's request for the coming year. The State Department called the spending provided in the measure "grossly inadequate." A3
 
Cambodian's Trial Delayed
The Cambodian Government moved to postpone a trial for a Khmer Rouge commander, Ta Mok, endorsing a law that would extend his pretrial detention period to three years from six months. The proposed law, which would apply to people charged with genocide, war crimes or crimes against humanity, was endorsed by the two leading parties and is due for a vote in Parliament next week. A4
 
Death Toll Climbing in India
Rescue workers continued to pry the dead from railroad cars that were crushed on Monday in a head-on collision in eastern India. So far, 258 bodies have been recovered, and some officials fear that the death toll will climb to 400. A4
 
Vietnam Trade Ties Renewed
The House renewed limited economic ties with Vietnam for another year. The vote, 297 to 130, came a week after Washington and Hanoi reached a tentative trade accord that brings Vietnam a step closer to full trading privileges with the United States. The vote to endorse President Clinton's waiver of a 1974 law allows American companies doing business with Vietnam to receive limited Government benefits. A6
 
World Briefing A6
 
NATIONAL A8-16
 
G.O.P. Reaches Accord On $792 Billion in Tax Cuts
Republicans reached general agreement on their $792 billion tax-cut plan. The measure, which includes a reduction of each income tax rate by one percentage point, is expected to lead to a veto showdown with the White House. A1
 
Limits for Children's TV Viewing
The American Academy of Pediatrics for the first time has laid out a plan for how pediatricians and parents can deal with television. The academy said that television viewing could affect the mental, social and physical health of young people. A1
 
$16 Million for Zapruder Film
A Federal arbitration panel announced that the Government must pay the heirs of Abraham Zapruder $16 million for his film of President Kennedy's assassination. A1
 
Emergency Aid for Farmers
Republicans and Democrats struggled over sending emergency aid to American farmers. The Republicans tossed aside the Democrats' plan in favor of their $7 billion package, which could pass as soon as today. A14
 
U.S. to Allow More Cuba Flights
The Administration announced that it would permit direct charter flights to Cuba from New York and Los Angeles. But the ban on visits by American tourists remains in place. A8
 
Solar Panels for Polluted Sites
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson today will unveil the first step in a project to use solar panels at polluted sites to make much-needed electricity without disturbing buried contaminants. A8
 
Limits for On-Line Liquor Sales
The House overwhelmingly passed a bill to restrict on-line liquor sales. The bill passed despite objections from California lawmakers that it favored liquor wholesalers over small wineries and breweries. A14
 
Sugar Intake Guidelines Sought
A coalition of leading health experts and organizations asked the Food and Drug Administration to require that food labels provide more information about added sugar and to set a recommended daily intake. A9
 
Gunshot Wounds Cost Billions
Gunshot wounds cost the nation $2.3 billion in medical treatment each year, and almost half that sum is paid for with taxpayers' dollars, a group of economists reported. A12
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-7
 
State Spending Bills Finally Get a Vote
The Legislature began passing a $73.3 billion state budget. The budget, which was four months overdue, provides large increases in aid to schools and child care for the poor, and makes none of the cuts originally sought by Governor Pataki. A1
 
Plan to Commit Mentally Ill
Governor Pataki and legislative leaders have agreed on a plan that gives the courts new authority to hospitalize mentally ill people against their will. New York is now set to join nearly 40 other states that have enacted similar laws. B1
 
Police Lawsuit Filed
A former New York City deputy police commissioner who investigated complaints of workplace harassment filed a Federal lawsuit in which she claims that she was forced from her job after resisting pressure to revise a report that criticized a high-ranking police official. B1
 
Attica Award Overturned
A Federal appeals court panel overturned a $4 million award stemming from the bloody Attica prison rebellion in 1971, and chastised a lower court judge and the State of New York for allowing a suit filed by more than 1,281 inmates to drag on for 25 years. The $4 million verdict was awarded to a former inmate in 1997. B3

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 157 words

HEADLINE: Cut Taxes? First, Cut the Deficit

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert H. Frank (Op-Ed, July 31) takes as a given that a certain level of "bad" spending by government is acceptable so long as it includes "good" spending on worthwhile projects. How much waste is Mr. Frank willing to tolerate? Twenty percent? Fifty percent? Or would he go even higher for something particularly dear to his heart? 
 This is essentially the philosophy that has given us a $5.6 trillion national debt that will consume almost $230 billion this year in interest payments. Arguing about the amount of a tax cut while this huge debt still exists, as the Democrats and Republicans are doing, is like arguing about which water bucket to use while your house is burning down.
If we can't pay down the deficit when economic times are bad, and we won't pay down the deficit when economic times are good, when are we going to rid ourselves of this fiscal albatross?
 
MARY EILAND
Brooklyn, July 31, 1999 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (50%);

HEADLINE: Cut Taxes? First, Cut the Deficit

 BODY:

To the Editor:
With Social Security projected to have a large long-run deficit, the President has proposed giving some general revenues to Social Security. Instead, the Republicans want to cut taxes, giving the bulk of the tax cut to the wealthy (front page, July 31). 
 After such a tax cut there would not be general revenues left to give to Social Security. To maintain Social Security benefits, it would become necessary to increase the payroll tax.
Without admitting it, the Republicans are thus proposing to increase the payroll tax in order to cut the income tax for the wealthy. Or possibly they propose to decrease Social Security benefits to give the wealthy that cut.
 
PETER DIAMOND
Lexington, Mass., Aug. 2, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL BRIEFING;
Take the Money And Narrow the Field

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
It is an old political ploy for incumbents: raise enough money early enough and possible challengers will think twice before taking you on.
Which probably helps explain why Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who got a bit of a re-election scare back in 1994 from a well-financed candidate, has been raising money for more than a year for his seventh re-election bid, in 2000 -- even though no challenger is yet in sight. 
 So far, Mr. Kennedy reported on Monday, he has pulled in almost $2.5 million, much of it in Massachusetts, but much from other states, too, a measure as much as anything of the national stature he has achieved by pushing a broad spread of social and economic issues.
If the money ploy works, Mr. Kennedy will be more than just home-free. He will be free to travel all over the country, using his huge fund-raising and crowd-drawing ability to help raise campaign cash and support for Democratic senators, or Democratic candidates running for the Senate, who face strong Republican opponents.
This being politics, what goes around comes around. Those Mr. Kennedy helps today will be those who help him tomorrow.
The system works the same way at the state level, of course, which helps explain why Gov. Gray Davis of California, a Democrat who has been in office seven months and does not face re-election for three more years, reported on Monday that he had already packed his campaign kitty with more than $8 million.
Election officials in the state say that in his first six months in office, Mr. Davis collected more money and held more fund-raising events than any other newly elected governor in California history.
Such prodigious raising of campaign cash may very well drive off all potential challengers, or it may enable Mr. Davis to build up a hugely handy reservoir of good will with fellow Democrats. But, in the meantime, he is catching a lot of flak.
Republicans and some public interest groups say Mr. Davis runs the risk of becoming too cozy with special interests who are major donators. Democrats say they wish he would spend as much time in Sacramento pushing the party's stalled legislative agenda as he does scouring the state for money.
The Governor's response to the Republicans is that he is his own man. His response to Democrats is that he does what he does only to help the party.

HEADLINE: LEADERS OF G.O.P. REACH COMPROMISE ON A TAX-CUT BILL

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Republican leaders completed work tonight on a revised tax-cut proposal, adopting a new approach to cutting income taxes as they prepared for a showdown with President Clinton.
After a marathon negotiating session in private, leaders from the House and Senate said they had settled on a common plan that draws from the tax bills passed in both chambers over the last two weeks but that adds some new twists. 
 At its heart is a reduction of one percentage point in all income tax rates. Under the plan, the current 15 percent income tax bracket, which is the lowest, would be reduced gradually to 14 percent starting in 2001. The current 28 percent bracket would gradually be reduced to 27 percent, and the top rate of 39.6 percent would decline to 38.6 percent.
The Republican plan also includes a reduction in the top rate on capital gains to 18 percent from 20 percent. It would provide a tax break for many married couples, and would phase out the inheritance tax on large estates.
Over all, the plan would cut taxes by $792 billion over the next decade. Republicans said they were intent on pushing the measure through both chambers by the end of the week, giving the party a chance to send a clear message about its priorities as the nation debates how best to take advantage of projected Federal budget surpluses.
"It's a happy day for the American taxpayer," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Archer announced the deal along with Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, after nearly 36 hours of negotiations.
Mr. Clinton has promised to veto the bill, because he says the Republican plan would risk a return of Federal budget deficits, disproportionately favor the wealthy and leave too little money for Medicare, the military, education and other programs.
Democrats in Congress, who were excluded from the negotiations, said the tax plan was nothing more than a plank in the Republican campaign platform for 2000.
The Republicans, said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, were primarily interested in "writing their talking points for why the President is a Scrooge for vetoing this Christmas-in-July package of tax cuts."
The package is likely to win strong support from conservative Republicans in both the House and the Senate.
But some of the provisions, particularly the one-percentage-point reduction in all income tax rates, alienated some moderate Republicans in the Senate, raising questions about whether the party would have enough votes to pass the measure.
"Things aren't looking very good from our perspective, and our understanding is that other moderates are having similar problems," said Nicholas J. Graham, a spokesman for Senator John H. Chafee, a moderate Republican from Rhode Island who has said he favors a smaller tax cut.
Aides to several of the four Democrats who had voted for the Republican bill in the Senate said they would also have trouble with any new plan that reduced all income tax rates because such an approach would give a bigger tax cut to those in upper income brackets than to those in lower brackets.
To deal with objections from moderate Republicans in the House who said the plan risked the nation's fiscal health, the new plan makes the full reduction in the income tax rates contingent on there being no increase in interest payments on the Federal debt.
As under the Senate plan, the tax cuts would phase out after 10 years, a limitation imposed by a procedural rule that Republicans could not sidestep.
Assuming that they can pass the final bill this week, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, plan to sit on the legislation until after Congress returns from its summer vacation in September and then send it Mr. Clinton for the promised veto.
But the Republican leaders are under some pressure from their own members to adopt a less confrontational strategy and to seek negotiations with the White House before forcing a showdown.
Saying that forcing the issue now would probably "lead to a hardening of positions that could imperil any possible negotiated agreement later in the fall," Senator Olympia J. Snowe, a moderate Republican from Maine, urged Mr. Lott today in a letter to seek a cooling-off period over the next month followed by talks with the White House.
Republicans released only the broad outlines of their deal tonight.
Aides to Mr. Archer said the proposed reduction in the top capital gains tax rate to 18 percent would apply to all transactions starting with Jan. 1 of this year. They said the plan would also eventually allow for capital gains to be indexed for inflation, meaning that increases in the price of a stock or another asset would be subject to capital gains only to the degree that they exceeded the inflation rate.
Mr. Archer said the income tax reduction would account for about $320 billion of the total $792 billion in tax cuts. That is less than under the original House plan, which called for a reduction of 10 percent in all income tax rates, but more than the original Senate plan, which called for a one-percentage-point reduction only in the current 15 percent bracket.
Mr. Archer said the new plan would allocate about $100 billion over 10 years to addressing the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leaves many two-income couples paying more in taxes than if they were single.
Under the plan, the standard deduction for married couples filing jointly would increase to twice the standard deduction for single filers, and the amount of income subject to the 15 percent income tax rate for couples would increase to twice the amount for single people.
The deal also included one of Mr. Roth's main priorities, an increase in the maximum allowable contribution to Individual Retirement Accounts to $5,000 from $2,000.
