HEADLINE: Aid to Farmers Puts Parties In 'Political Bidding Contest'

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Locked in what one Senator called a compassion competition, Republicans and Democrats struggled today over sending billions of dollars of emergency aid to American farmers.
Democrats littered the rhetorical landscape of the Senate with images of Dust Bowl days and the Great Depression, but they lost a bid to add a $10.8 billion package of emergency aid to the annual agriculture spending bill. 
 Republicans tossed that proposal aside in favor of their own $7 billion emergency package, which they would finance by dipping into next year's projected budget surplus. They showed through procedural maneuvers late today that they had the votes to pass it, probably on Wednesday.
"We're competing to show our compassion," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "It's a political bidding contest here. You're seeing figures made up on both sides of the aisle."
Vice President Al Gore came to the Capitol to argue the Democrats' case for more aid, saying that conditions were ripe for "the worst crisis our farmers have ever experienced," and that Republicans were "pretending that this tremendous suffering out in farm country is not taking place."
The minority leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said "a silent death in rural America" was killing off farms and destroying farmers' livelihoods. He said that 2,000 farmers in his state had given up tilling the soil in the past year and that their farms now lay fallow, creating scenes "the likes of which we have not seen since the Great Depression."
But Senator Gramm questioned just how grim the plight of American farmers was today. He said the Senate was proposing "spending vast sums of money when we have no documentation of the magnitude of the problem."
There is plenty to suggest that farmers are hurting. International markets for their goods have shrunk, particularly in Asia, and prices for most agricultural products have plummeted this year.
But the pain and the politics have little to do with heat and drought, despite the designation of both parties' aid packages as emergency assistance, which allows them to set aside the spending rules and take the money out of next year's much-anticipated budget surplus.
There is an argument over how deep the suffering is. Net farm income will fall less than 1 percent this year, to $43.8 billion after this fall's harvest from $44.1 billion in 1998, the Agriculture Department estimates. That includes more than $12 billion in direct Federal payments to farmers.
Some of the economic pain may be self-inflicted. Despite the drought in many parts of the country, American farmers are growing far more grain than they can sell, which helps drive prices down. Nearly a billion bushels of wheat, half the American harvest, will find no market this fall.
"Were having a hard time giving it away," said Tom Buis, a vice president of the National Farmers Union.
Mr. Gore, in a brief speech just off the Senate floor, fueled a competition between the political parties to see who could appear more generous to farmers -- some of whom work the soil of Iowa, the scene of the first Presidential caucuses next winter -- as he chided Senate Republicans for their farm policies and fiscal programs.
"Here we have the biggest surpluses in the history of the world," Mr. Gore said, "and that bunch in control in there is trying to blow it all on a risky tax scheme while the whole farm sector of our economy is on the verge of absolute bankruptcy."
The sponsor of the Republican aid package, Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi, agreed in an interview that "overproduction, not just here but all over the world" is part of what plagued American farmers. Nonetheless, he said, the need for aid exists.
Of the $7 billion in the Cochran bill, $5.6 billion would come in the form of direct payments to farmers under the system Republicans created in 1996 to replace the farm-subsidy system long controlled by Democrats. Much of the rest would come in subsidies intended for livestock and dairy farmers, soybean and oilseed producers and growers of peanuts and beet sugar.
Mr. Cochran suggested that the need was not as urgent as the Democrats argued and that the aid could wait until the next fiscal year begins on Oct. 1.
Farmers are still spending some of the $6 billion that Congress lashed together as part of a last-minute $21 billion emergency spending bill in October.
If the emergency package wins the Senate's approval, the House would have to consider similar legislation.
"I would be very supportive of it," said Representative Larry Combest, the Texas Republican who heads the Agriculture Committee. "Seven billion dollars -- you can't sneeze at that."

HEADLINE: 2 WARY NEIGHBORS UNITE TO CONFRONT NORTH KOREA ARMS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 4

 BODY:
North Korea's preparations to test a new long-range missile this month have led to a dramatic change of course in military planning and diplomacy for Japan and South Korea.
Japan is considering stretching the constitutional limits on its military, while South Korea is beginning to overcome deep suspicions of Japan and consider ways to cooperate in the face of a common threat. 
 Japan has agreed to take part in a missile-defense system that Washington is developing that would use rockets to shoot down incoming missiles. And Japan is speeding its plans for a satellite surveillance system.
Most surprising is Japan's decision to consider providing its largely toothless air force with airborne-refueling and attack equipment that would enable its F-15's to retaliate against North Korea.
Although older North Korean missiles are already able to strike parts of Japan, public concern over the new test is relatively recent. In a poll published today in the newspaper Yomiuri, 70 percent of respondents said they were worried about a war.
Seoul, which lies within easy range of the North's existing missiles and artillery, has already indicated its desire to build missiles capable of reaching much of North Korea.
Under a 1979 agreement, South Korea must obtain Washington's consent to build missiles with a range of more than 112 miles. But last week Defense Secretary William S. Cohen indicated that Washington would work with Seoul to overcome that limit, which could be accomplished if South Korea joined the Missile Technology Control Regime.
Through high-level visits and a cascade of statements aimed at the North Korean Government, Washington has sought to dissuade it from going ahead with the test while reassuring allies in the region.
The message is that by launching a new missile with an estimated 3,700-mile range -- enabling it to hit Alaska or Hawaii -- North Korea has nothing to gain and everything to lose.
Still, this activity shows that in the short and medium term, Washington and its allies suffer a dearth of options in dealing with perhaps the most isolated and unpredictable country.
Secretary Cohen seemed to acknowledge as much during a news conference here last week. Referring to the carrot-and-stick approach, he said, "We are prepared to work with North Korea to open economic and political opportunities, and North Korea should seize this chance to build a new and positive relationship."
"A refusal to show restraint," he said, would result in "stalling or indeed stopping potential cooperation."
Speaking in Seoul last week, Mr. Cohen said the United States would mobilize "all available means" against North Korea if it fired the new missile, the Taepodong 2. But this does not include the use of military force, he said.
This statement reflected the options being considered in Washington, Tokyo and Seoul, where the growing assumption is that nothing can be done to prevent the test.
The options include attempts at working with North Korea, particularly on the "agreed framework" under which Pyongyang has forsworn deployment or proliferation of nuclear weapons. In exchange, the North is entitled to economic assistance in the form of food and fuel, and help in building a light-water nuclear reactor to generate electricity.
Robert Manning, a former senior State Department adviser, has suggested letting North Korea "stew in its own juices" as it confronts a near economic collapse and one of the worst famines of the century. In response to a missile test, the United States, Japan and South Korea must "cut aid and restrict contacts," he wrote in a recent policy paper.
Undermining arguments for either approach, however, is a fundamental uncertainty about what drives North Korean decision-making. What the West sees as carrots -- increased trade, aid, travel and political contacts, for example -- may be what some in North Korea fear most because the withered economy is so fragile that even gradual attempts at opening it up could be deeply destabilizing.
If the problem is seen through this prism, those suggesting the firmest responses may inadvertently be Pyongyang's best allies. According to this view, nothing perhaps is more important to President Kim Jong Il's rule than furthering a view of the outside world as hostile and predatory.
"There haven't been very many satisfactory options for dealing with North Korea for 40 years," said Morton I. Abramowitz, author of a recent policy paper published by the Council on Foreign Relations that advocates a mixture of continued engagement and limited sanctions in case of a missile test. "They are a dying state, or a near-dying state. To change that, they have to change the way they do business, and this involves opening up, which some undoubtedly find terrifying."
If North Korea goes ahead with its test, however, as is widely expected, it may find its unpredictability matched by the reactions of its neighbors, and even by Washington.
Already South Korea's President, Kim Dae Jung, is facing domestic criticism over the perceived slimness of returns from a "sunshine policy" toward the North, which has involved encouraging investments by South Korean companies and authorizing lucrative but tightly controlled tourism to North Korea.
In Japan the prospect of the missile test has transformed the debate over military matters in ways that would have scarcely been imaginable only two years ago.
A previous generation of North Korean missiles, the Rodong, were able to strike parts of Japan. Even after the launching of the Taepodong 1 missile last year, on a flight that crossed Japanese airspace, public opinion on military questions, which has been deeply pacifist, scarcely countenanced any change in the Government's stance.
In recent months, though, as the new test has drawn nearer, some Japanese have increasingly questioned aspects of the country's traditional and constitutionally mandated antimilitarism. This has contributed to a wave of more nationalistic sentiments among mainstream politicians.
"Gradually Japanese people are becoming aware that they are facing a threat from North Korea, and this has been a very good chance for the society to re-evaluate our security posture," said Tomohisa Sakananaka, president of the Research Institute for Peace and Security, a private policy organization.
"The Japanese Constitution since 1953 allows the country to take defensive measures against any threat against the nation's existence; that is not new. But this is completely theoretical. We don't have any capability to attack North Korea."
It is now believed that the new test by North Korea would go a long way toward changing this position.
"We have four options," said Toshiyuki Shikata, a retired general with Japan's National Self Defense Force. "We could just keep smiling and continuing the 'sunshine policy' toward North Korea, or develop our own long-range missile, which people in the region and our own public opinion would oppose.
"Between these two extremes we are choosing two other options: developing a theater missile-defense system with the U.S., which would take several years, and giving Japan retaliation capability through its air force. If a Korean missile should fall in Japanese territory, and particularly cause casualties or some destruction, the Prime Minister could then order the destruction of North Korean missile sites, and I believe the Japanese public would support the Government in these measures."

HEADLINE: 4 Months Late, Albany Passes Budget for 2000

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Wednesday, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Four months overdue, the Legislature completed passage of a $73.3 billion state budget early this morning that was incubated in partisan anger and hatched in weary compromise. It provides large increases in aid to schools and child care for the poor, and makes none of the cuts originally sought by Gov. George E. Pataki.
The Senate passed the 11 huge spending bills making up the budget on Tuesday evening, while the Assembly did not approve the last of the bills until 1:33 A.M. today. As a result, the Legislature tied the record for tardiness in passing a budget, set two years ago, at 126 days late. State law requires approval of the budget before April 1, the start of the fiscal year, but New York has violated that law 15 years in a row, a record not approached by any other state. 
 The budget mostly split the difference between the proposals made early this year by Mr. Pataki, a Republican, and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, and the final product resembled the middle ground taken by the Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno.
The three leaders also agreed Tuesday to allow financially troubled Nassau County to impose a 1 percent tax on real estate sales over the next 18 months, as Democrats dropped their demand that the county's finances be overseen by a state control board. In an unrelated matter that had been linked to the Nassau deal in negotiations, lawmakers also agreed to renew a property tax break that will save the owners of 280,000 New York City co-ops and condominiums an average of $580 a year, a provision that expired a month ago.
This year's state budget process was conducted in the long shadow cast last year, when the Legislature passed a budget with little input from the Governor only to see him veto $1.6 billion in spending items, most of them sought by the Democrats. For months, Mr. Silver insisted that the Governor promise not to veto items this year, while Mr. Pataki refused to get involved in the budget negotiations. Real progress began only in mid-June, when the Governor joined the talks, and he eventually agreed not to make broad use of vetoes, in return for limits on the overall size of the budget.
The brittle relationship between Mr. Silver and Mr. Pataki helped drag out the process. Between calling each other names and accusing each other of leading the state to ruin, each man and his aides contended that the other could not be trusted. It did not help matters that under a new law that raised legislators' salaries, their paychecks were withheld for as long as the budget was late. In the end, everyone involved expressed something closer to grim satisfaction than elation.
"You have to negotiate in good faith," Mr. Bruno said. "You have to have the will to do a budget, and in my mind, the will hasn't been there until these last several weeks."
Mr. Silver said Tuesday: "My conference gave me a mandate on this budget: no wholesale vetoes, restore pre-K, reduce class size, eliminate the Governor's health care cuts and eliminate the cuts to the tuition assistance program. I'm happy to report that we're doing a budget tonight that accomplishes those goals." But he conceded that he was forced to retreat on spending for schools, colleges, hospitals and nursing homes.
The strong economy has made it possible, for the third year in a row, for the state to raise spending significantly, even while cutting taxes. But this year's spending plan is more cautious than the last two, which were approved as Governor Pataki ran for re-election. State lawmakers are being less aggressive this year than in the last two years on both spending and tax cuts, in part because the state is still absorbing the commitments made in 1997 and 1998.
Mr. Pataki achieved one of his major goals for the year, an agreement not to spend the $1.8 billion surplus accumulated in the last fiscal year, which will be saved to help the state pay for tax cuts to take effect next year. New York, which had just a few hundred million dollars' cash reserve at the beginning of 1998, now has nearly $3 billion.
But the Governor clearly did not reach his other main objective, to keep the rise in spending within the rate of inflation, now under 2 percent. Overall spending is projected to grow by 3.8 percent, though the true number may be smaller because lawmakers routinely overestimate costs of programs. The state's general fund, the part generated by state taxes and fees that is most closely watched by independent fiscal analysts, is projected to grow by 2.4 percent, to $37.4 billion, and it would be higher if not for some accounting maneuvers that moved some spending out of the general fund.
Mr. Pataki also gave up on the deep cuts that he proposed for Medicaid, tuition aid for low-income college students, and the year-old effort to bolster education for the youngest children.
That education program, the product of the 1997 budget deal, included making prekindergarten and full-day kindergarten classes available in every community and reducing class sizes in kindergarten through the third grade. Mr. Silver was furious at the Governor for going back on that agreement, and made adhering to it his highest priority this year.
Just as Mr. Pataki backed away from his proposed cuts to Medicaid -- at $28 billion, the largest segment of the budget -- Mr. Silver dropped his attempts to reverse cuts that were made in 1995 and 1996. In the end, Medicaid was barely changed.
The biggest changes from last year are in child care and in education, which in recent years has supplanted health care as the fastest-growing part of the budget.
At Mr. Pataki's initiative, the budget will nearly double the amount that the state spends to subsidize child care for low-income working parents, to $839 million this year from $460 million last year. That will provide 100,000 or more new day care slots, mostly through vouchers to the parents, who can spend them with any day care provider registered with the state. Like advocates for the poor, the Governor has asserted that providing child care is a crucial component of moving people from welfare into jobs.
Lawmakers raised operating aid to school districts by 7.7 percent, to $12.7 billion. Of the $913 million increase, the largest ever in raw dollars, $140 million is for expansion of prekindergarten and related programs. The overall increase is far more than the Governor called for, less than what the Assembly sought, and roughly equal to the Senate proposal. Adjusted for inflation and the number of children in public schools, school aid is now at an all-time high, exceeding the previous peak set in 1990, just before the last recession.
Lawmakers also provided $1.3 billion for school construction and renovation, $430 million more than last year's record sum.
The budget includes $378 million a year in new tax cuts, to be phased in over the next two years. The largest are $150 million in cuts for the insurance and banking industries, and a $125 million expansion of a tax credit for 1.1 million low-wage workers, most of them with children.
Lawmakers are also postponing elimination of the sales tax on clothing, up to $110 per item, from the Dec. 1 date decided on last year to March 1 next year, but they provided for two tax-free weeks in the meantime, in September and February.
But the greater impact on the state's finances comes from more than $1 billion in tax cuts enacted in the last two years but only taking effect this year. The largest is a property tax reduction for homeowners outside New York City, which is being phased in over four years.
In mental health, the budget provides $50 million for construction of group homes and other community-based housing for 900 mentally ill people, an initiative by the Assembly Democrats, and $25 million for similar housing for 980 mentally retarded people, a measure sought by the Governor. Both resulted from news reports that prompted calls for state action: two incidents of people being pushed in front of subway trains by mentally ill people, and reports of mentally retarded adults living in homeless shelters.
The Assembly Democrats, after resisting for more than a year, also agreed to approve the money to finish a partially constructed, 750-bed state prison in western New York.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
Elemental as Water: The Pool House as Muse

BYLINE: By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI 

 BODY:
THE pursuit of delight, especially in the garden, has been an architectural commandment since the Roman architect and engineer Vitruvius set down his own Mosaic laws in the first century B.C. (The goals were to include "commodity, firmness and delight," he declared.)
Architecture history is well endowed with pavilions that deliver their occupants to panoramas of nature; designers shaping garden rooms are often hypnotized by the prospect of adding another chapter to this rich tradition. Unencumbered by the functional demands of kitchens, closets and bedrooms, pavilions can be designed without the usual constraints and without the safety net of excuses. Designers do not toss them off lightly. 
 Pool houses in suburbia, though, are another matter. Working cousins of the more aloof garden follies -- with their ancestral pedigrees -- these chlorine-perfumed repositories of musty towels, Ping-Pong tables and teen-agers have been overlooked as a serious genre.
In one backyard in West Hartford, Conn., however, the New York architect David Kriegel elevated the pool house from its status as a common utility structure to a true garden pavilion. A plywood shanty had existed next to the kidney-shaped pool belonging to Joseph and Sonia Gerber. (Mr. Gerber had designed and built the plywood pool house himself.) After demolition, all that remained was a concrete pad and a back retaining wall, both of which would be integrated into a new building.
Mr. Kriegel offered four designs for the small structure, but Mr. Gerber, an inventor and industrialist who won the National Medal of Technology in 1994 (awarded by President Clinton), had an engineer's sense of economy. He encouraged the architect to use as few elements as possible. "He was an excellent critic," Mr. Kriegel said of Mr. Gerber, who died three years ago, shortly after the pool house was built. "The first designs were complicated, and I stripped elements away until I was left with only what was needed. It was an exercise in reduction."
Mr. Kriegel finally drew inspiration from the simplicity of the surrounding garden, whose serpentine stone walls complemented the curves of the pool. "I wanted to integrate the pool house with the landscaping," he said. The architect extended the idea of the low garden wall with a spiral of stone that encloses an outdoor shower, open near the ceiling. A few steps away he built two changing cabins, sheathed in redwood. "Redwood doesn't rot outdoors, and it's dimensionally stable," Mr. Kriegel said.
The cabins look very much man-made, in contrast with the naturalistic shower wall. Steel columns carry a carefully designed assembly of redwood beams and rafters, supporting a corrugated fiberglass roof, whose aqua coloring and wavy profile echo the water in the pool. The structure, which is 100 square feet, cost about $30,000.
The solution was rational. "That appealed to my clients," Mr. Kriegel said.
But the design went beyond the rational. "I love the contrast in textures," said Mrs. Gerber, who was trained as an artist. "I like the openness to the out-of-doors."
The lyricism of the spiral and the naturalism of the materials are tempered by a quirky asymmetry: on one side, a single steel column holds a pair of beams, and on the other, a pair of columns supports a single beam. "It does have a sense of humor," Mr. Kriegel said.
The elemental quality of the wood and stone is contradicted by the aqua-colored columns and the translucent fiberglass roof, which tints the interior blue-green. "I've never done anything this small before," said Mr. Kriegel, who designed the vast, hyperkinetic Virgin Mega Store in Times Square.
Small, perhaps, but packed with mixed messages. Nesting against the old retaining wall, and built of stone and natural wood, the pool house recalls Frank Lloyd Wright's simple Usonian houses, odes to democratic building and nature that often intensified the landscape. Mr. Kriegel throws a swerve at the idyllic harmony with the corrugated fiberglass and aqua paint, and with the puckish humor of the columns.
"Each of the components has a different personality that speaks to the others," Mr. Kriegel said. The simplicity of the straight-lined structure with the floating roof is also related to Mies van der Rohe's pavilions. But Mr. Kriegel's structure, with its diverse elements, has a complex simplicity.
An object of contemplation across the pool, the pool house is an object lesson in his practice, influencing his subsequent designs. "In many ways, it was architecture without interference, without compromises," he said, "which is unheard of. The pool house remains one of my favorite projects, as tiny as it is."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Yes, There'll Always Be An England, or Two

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

FOREVER ENGLAND
By Beryl Bainbridge
174 pages. Carroll & Graf. $22.
Considering the differences between the North and the South in the United States, one might find it hard to believe that in relatively compact England similar disparities are thought to hold true. Yet that is the subject of Beryl Bainbridge's quirky new book, "Forever England." As the author explains in her preface, the book is based on a television series "which, in an attempt to examine the roots of that evergreen assumption, the notion that England is two nations, focused on the expectations and attitudes of six families, three in the North and three in the South." Much of the perceived difference is based on myth, Ms. Bainbridge, who grew up in Liverpool and is best known as a novelist, writes in her introduction. "In the South they rode to hounds and went to Ascot; in the North we kept pigeons and raced greyhounds. When we had our tea, people in London sat down to their dinner dressed up as if they were off out to a Masonic hot-pot supper." 
 "All the same," she continues, "these simplistic myths, matters of manners and money and location, never for one moment obscured the real differences that separated us, hid the severing wound that well-nigh cut us in half and could never be healed, for hadn't we been plundered by the South, laid waste, bled white? It was not just industrial. They had drained away our talent and our brains; who had ever heard of anyone once they got on in the world, from William Gladstone to Thomas Handley, who had been content to stay in the North? We learned this from our parents."
To test both myth and parental lore, Ms. Bainbridge interviewed people on the dole in Liverpool, fishermen in Hastings, descendants of coal miners in Barnsley, the extended family of a financier in Bentley, sheep farmers in Northumberland and a multiracial family in Birmingham.
A few arresting generalizations emerge. "Up here in the hills we have crisis after crisis," says the wife of a tenant farmer who keeps 2,000 sheep. "There's no time to consult with anyone else. It could make you very self-opinionated, this sort of life. If you were in the South, you wouldn't need to be so determined, so dogged."
"It is a softer life down here in the South," Ms. Bainbridge concludes after visiting with the fishing family in Hastings. "They're not given to self-analysis, and perhaps the so-called southern reserve is not so much a matter of unfriendliness as a detached complacency born of comparative affluence."
But since the people she visited with seem selected to illustrate her various points, one finds it hard to put much stock in them as a sampling. Their main value is to fix in our minds the geographical distinctions of various regions in England.
Far more diverting are the autobiographical tangents on which the interviews inspire Ms. Bainbridge to take off. Her return to Liverpool triggers memories of her parents, of her father's contradictory ways -- he lamented the loss of the empire yet always voted for Labor -- and of her mother, whose hands were always full "painting the furniture and rearranging the ornaments."
Her visit to Hastings reminds her of a novel she once wrote in which she had to send her protagonist on vacation somewhere. "I didn't think he should go to Brighton -- Brighton was too flashy for him. So I chose Hastings. The name came out of my head like a number out of a hat. I say that, but then nothing is ever as random as it appears. In my opinion there's no such thing as imagination -- in the sense that we have the power to form images of our own making -- for unless we've already acquired images in the first place, from somewhere, how can we possibly summon them into existence, reformed or not?"
A discussion of politics reminds her of the Cuban missile crisis, when she was chosen to go and protest to the American consul but was "struck dumb with admiration" because he looked like "a cross between Gregory Peck and Rasputin."
What emerges from these musings besides the portrait of an amusing, original, opinionated individual? Because Ms. Bainbridge rarely wastes a word in her fiction -- the most recent of her novels are "Master Georgie," "Every Man for Himself" and "The Birthday Boys" -- you look for a hidden pattern here, some subterranean message that helps you to see beyond easy generalizations.
But in vain. Instead what you get is the story of one unusual individual. "If you come from the North as I do," she writes, "and you left it, as I did, you have ambivalent feelings towards the old working communities. It's an uneasy mixture of pride and irritation, sentimentality and mistrust, for you broke away from a narrowness of outlook and a lack of expectation which well-nigh crushed you. And yet -- the heart lies back there in the past, and everyone longs to return and find things just as they were, the arguments in full spate and the home fires still burning."
In "Forever England," Ms. Bainbridge doesn't find the home fires still burning. But she manages to set a few on her own.

HEADLINE: U.S. Factory Orders Rose 0.7% in June

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories, bolstered by higher demand for automobiles and electronic equipment, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, a fresh sign of recovery for manufacturing.
The increase followed a 1 percent gain in May, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts had expected factory orders to rise by three-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
 Orders for automobiles and car parts rose, offsetting a decrease in demand for airplanes and aircraft parts and contributing to a 2.3 percent increase in orders for all transportation products in June. That was down from a hefty 9.9 percent gain the month before.
"We are on our way to a record level of vehicle sales for the year," said Paul Taylor, an economist with the National Automobile Dealers Association.
Excluding the volatile transportation category, factory orders still would have risen a solid half-percent in June.
"The numbers are surprisingly good," Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said, adding that factory orders were running 4.1 percent higher than in June 1998.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment, the sector that includes household appliances and communications equipment, rose 2.4 percent in June after a drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The overall gain in June factory orders came despite a steep 5.1 percent decrease in orders for industrial machinery and equipment, the sector that includes computers. It was the second consecutive monthly decline. In May, orders for industrial machinery fell 4.5 percent.
Economists said United States manufacturers are gradually recovering from a global financial crisis, which dampened overseas demand for American-made goods and increased competition from a flood of cheaper imports. Since March 1998, about 488,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost.
Orders for durable goods -- items expected to last at least three years -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June. Orders for nondurable goods, like food and fuel, increased, posting a 1.2 percent gain, after a gain in May of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Separately, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported today that business activity outside the manufacturing sector expanded in July, but at a slower pace than the month before. The purchasing managers' index of nonmanufacturing business fell to 59.5 in July, from 61 in June.

HEADLINE: In Days, India, Chasing China, Will Have a Billion People

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Sometime in the next week or so the population of India, which adds more people to the world each year than any other nation, will officially cross the one billion mark, just in time for Indian Independence Day on Aug. 15, according to United Nations demographers.
Fifty-two years ago, when India threw off colonialism, it had 345 million people; since then, its population has tripled. 
 India, with its population growing 1.6 percent a year, is expected to overtake China as the most populous nation in the next four decades. China, with more than three times the area of India, reached the one billion level in 1980 and now has 1.27 billion people, with a growth rate of only 0.9 percent. Indians say China achieved the lower rate through coercion, including forced abortion, a course that democratic India could not condone.
Between them, India and China already account for more than one-third of the world's people. The global population is expected to reach six billion on Oct. 12.
By 2016, India, slightly more than a third the size of the United States, is likely to have more people than all of Europe and the rest of the industrial world, excluding Russia, United Nations demographers say.
The profile of India that emerges from the demographers' computers is replete with big numbers because everything about this Asian nation is measured in superlatives, said Joseph Chamie, director of the United Nations Population Division. Mr. Chamie, an American, and his wife worked on family planning projects in India as Peace Corps volunteers 30 years ago.
"This is a remarkable country," he said. For example, India has about 600 million people of voting age, and a healthy democracy to accommodate them. India has the most births annually among nations, 25 million, and many more children survive each year because of better, if still rudimentary, health care.
Despite its considerable problems, often worsened by population pressures, India has increased life expectancy to 63 years, from 39, in less than half a century, and has cut its fertility rate from 6 births for each woman of child-bearing age to 3.1.
The latest population estimate is built on an array of such birth, death and fertility statistics, with further adjustments for migration.
There are other big numbers that tell a less happy story, World Bank experts have found. India has a large majority of the world's illiterates, nearly 500 million. It has more than 320 million abjectly poor people unable to muster an income equivalent to the $1 a day that is needed to buy basic foods.
Development experts and demographers say India is in danger of being overwhelmed by numbers as gains made in fields like education, health and agriculture fail to stay ahead of the surging population. While poverty rates decline steadily in India, the World Bank found, the actual number of people living in poverty continues to rise.
"Poverty imposes an oppressive weight on India, especially in the rural areas, where almost three out of four Indians and 77 percent of the poor live," the World Bank said in its last report on poverty in India, in 1997. An update now being completed does not show much better results, World Bank officials say.
At the Worldwatch Institute in Washington, an independent research organization, Lester Brown, its president, said in an interview that population growth "has put pressure on all of India's resources."
Underground water supplies are shrinking as more farmers turn to pumps when surface irrigation fails or is unreliable. Indians have sunk eight million wells and are using them to water fields where double-cropping has been introduced for higher food production.
"Well before it reached a billion people, India was using water at an unsustainable rate," he said. "You have to wonder, what in the world happens when you add another half billion? To formulate an intelligent population policy, you have to know something about hydrology. I have the feeling that the population policy in India is put together in a vacuum.
"After a while the Government -- trying to educate young people, trying to find them jobs, trying to deal with environmental fallout -- gets stretched so thin it just can't respond. I think the Government is already suffering from demographic fatigue."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
After 5 Days of Declines, Price of 30-Year Treasury Rises

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasuries rose for the first time in five sessions yesterday, giving momentary relief to a bond market that has been bracing for higher interest rates ahead of an important employment report that will be released tomorrow.
The market rally was touched off by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers's announcement that the Government would cut its debt sales. Mr. Summers said that while the Treasury would go ahead with its $37 billion sale of new notes and bonds next week, it would eliminate the May auction of 30-year bonds and limit their sales to February and August. The Treasury is also planning to curtail sales of one-year bills and two-year notes and will propose rules to buy back selected issues of high-yield Government debt. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury rose 25/32, to 88 16/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.09 percent from 6.16 percent on Tuesday.
Any reduction in supply has a tendency to bolster prices, traders noted. But while bonds rebounded yesterday, some market participants do not think that the yearlong decline in prices is about to reverse itself. Weighing on the market is the sale of about $54 billion in Government and corporate debt scheduled for the coming weeks and the deep-rooted concern that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its next policy-making meeting, on Aug. 24.
The largest of the corporate sales will be this week's $5.5 billion issue from Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which could reduce demand for Treasury securities as investors sell Treasuries to make room for the higher-yield paper.
The Government report tomorrow will contain details about employment and wages in July. If the number shows the economy grew at a strong clip, it could worry financial markets by increasing the likelihood of an interest rate increase.
The market is nervous and any economic data that show a stronger-than-expected economy are not going to be taken well by Wall Street. The warning by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, in Congressional testimony that the central bank would move quickly if there were any signs of a resurgence in inflation was not lost on investors who had thought that inflation was dormant and that no rate increase was imminent.
The central bank raises interest rates to avert potential inflation, although such actions tend to hurt stock prices by taking money out of the economy as it becomes more expensive for companies and consumers to borrow money.
"The probability of a Fed tightening at the Aug. 24 Federal Open Market Committee meeting has increased markedly in the aftermath of Greenspan's comments during his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony and a plethora of data indicating continued economic buoyancy coupled with a perceptible pickup in the overall rate of inflation," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
Mr. Fine says that if the consensus projections of a 200,000 increase in payrolls, an unchanged unemployment rate and a rise of three-tenths of a percent in average hourly earnings are close to the mark, the expectation of a Fed tightening toward the end of the month will become even more firmly entrenched.
Mr. Fine said the bond market had already priced in a small increase, giving the Fed a green light to make another pre-emptive strike later this year to ward off inflation. "Quite clearly, market observers will now require upcoming data to persuasively suggest that a tightening move will not be forthcoming at this next F.O.M.C. forum," he said.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's quarterly refunding, $15 billion of five-year notes to be auctioned on Tuesday were being offered at a price to yield about 5.78 percent, while $12 billion of 10-year notes being sold on Wednesday were priced to yield 5.88 percent and $10 billion of 30-year bonds for sale on Thursday were priced to yield 6 percent.

HEADLINE: Travel Agents Express Anger On Internet-Only Plane Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Travel agents reacted with anger and disappointment yesterday to the latest airline offers of additional discounts on tickets booked over the carriers' World Wide Web sites.
"No matter how the airlines dance around it, this is an attempt to put travel agents out of business," John Hawks, president of the Association of Retail Travel Agents in Lexington, Ky., said of the latest round of discount offers. Mr. Hawks added that he expected Congress to take a critical look at Internet-only fare offers when it returns to the topic of airline passenger rights, possibly later this year. 
 The American Society of Travel Agents in Alexandria, Va., also opposes Internet-only fares. "All fares should be available to all travelers," said Dina Long, a spokeswoman for the association.
Airlines say they are simply doing what every business tries to do -- lower costs.
"We're not trying to put anybody out of business," said Dave Swierenga, the economist for the Air Transport Association, the industry trade group. "But now we have a new technology that bypasses a big part of the labor component of writing tickets, and obviously that's hard for agents to deal with. This is simply a rational business decision in a world that's changing, and travel agents need to recognize that the ticket-writing function can now be done more simply by technology."
That new technology is, of course, the Internet, which allows passengers to buy tickets directly, without having to go through travel agents, who book about 80 percent of airline tickets, or reservations agents. Travel agents can match fares loaded into the computerized reservations systems as well as most fares posted on an airline's Web site, but special low fares for last-minute weekend travel are usually made available only to an airline's E-mail subscribers, while other bargain fares are increasingly found only on the Web sites of airlines.
Airlines offer Internet-only fares in hopes of persuading more passengers to book electronically because it saves the carriers money. "It costs Delta up to 400 percent more to book and deliver a ticket using the traditional processes," Vince Caminiti, a Delta executive, said in a speech to a business travel association in Minneapolis last month.
The airline industry's ticket commission costs fell to $5.2 billion in 1998 from a high of $7.6 billion in 1993, mainly because in 1995 the carriers succeeded in scrapping the traditional 10 percent agent's commission and imposing a maximum $50 fee for each transaction. Over all, commission rates fell to 6.3 percent this June from 10 percent in June 1994. To help pick up the slack, travel agents have increased their sales of cruises and land excursions, package tours and hotel rooms. Many also charge customers a fee for such once-free services as rewriting tickets and planning itineraries.
On Monday, Northwest Airlines reduced leisure fares by as much as 25 percent for travel between next month and December. Most other airlines quickly matched Northwest, including Delta Air Lines. Then on Tuesday, Delta offered an additional 10 percent off the sale fares for passengers who book their tickets on the Delta Web site. Other airlines matched those reductions as well. Unlike an unsuccessful attempt by Delta last January to charge $2 for each round-trip flight not booked on its Internet site, this week's Internet moves appear likely to succeed. At least for now.
"The airlines are very brave at doing such things when we're in a robust economy," Mr. Hawks said. "But if there's any business that's cyclical, it's airlines, and when the downturn comes, as it will, travel agents will remember how they were treated."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The Dwindling Market in U.S. Treasury Bonds

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
For nearly two decades, the Government securities market has grown exponentially as Uncle Sam has regularly relied upon it to help finance the nation's $5.5 trillion in debt. But looking ahead, the financial markets are heading into strange territory, a landscape in which Treasury securities -- a mainstay of professional hedging strategies, an influence on consumer and corporate borrowing costs, and a safe haven for those with no appetite for risk -- will become increasingly scarce.
What has been a suspicion since Government surpluses first began to emerge 18 months ago became more of a certainty yesterday, when Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers announced an unusual proposal that, if carried out, would allow the Federal Government to begin buying back some of its old bonds and notes. Indeed, President Clinton has said that he would like to pay off the entire national debt by the year 2015. 
 A world without Treasury bonds? No one in the current market seems to think that is likely. But market participants agree that a profoundly important shift is occurring -- one that could ultimately affect consumer and business borrowers, coupon-clipping investors, mutual funds and their shareholders, and professional money managers who rely on Treasury securities to hedge their riskier debts here and around world.
"This is a sea change," said James M. Keller, senior vice president and portfolio manager for Treasury securities at Pimco Advisers, an asset management firm. "I was struck by the Treasury's observation that the last time there were two back-to-back years of budget surpluses was in 1956 and 1957. I wasn't alive then, so this is a new thing for me."
Mr. Keller added: "The marketplace is really in search of a new benchmark, one that they can price other investments off of. And we don't really know what that's going to be."
While the nation's interest rates over the long run tend to reflect its fundamental economic health, a shrinking supply of Treasury bonds would probably cause the price of those securities to rise relative to corporate and mortgage bonds, said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist of Bank of America.
"Everyone has been aware of this trend, but the Treasury has sounded a wake-up call," Mr. Levy added. "The total publicly held Treasury debt is beginning to shrink." And because supply and demand matter, he added, that is likely to drive up the price of bonds, pushing down their yields. That would be good news for corporate and consumer borrowers whose loans are tied to the benchmark Treasury rates.
Moreover, as the nation's debt was ballooning in the early 1980's, there was widespread concern that Uncle Sam would elbow out other borrowers, making it harder and more expensive for them to raise money. Thus, it is logical to hope that the reversal of that trend would result in cheaper and more abundant credit for other borrowers. Already, as the budget surpluses have grown, the Government's share of the market for newly issued bonds has dropped, to 18 percent today from 40 percent in 1990.
But falling interest rates on Treasury bonds, the safest and most liquid fixed-income securities in the market, would also trim the interest income that new Treasury investors receive -- a development that may prompt those wary investors to seek riskier investments to maintain their standard of living.
The same quandary may well face people who invest in Government bonds through the mutual funds. Short-term Treasury bills and notes are the daily bread of the popular taxable money-market funds, some 685 of them holding more than $1.1 trillion in assets, that are used by millions of investors as a place to park their short-term cash. Longer-term Treasury securities are stuffed into a variety of other government-bond mutual funds whose assets, as of the end of June, totaled $82.6 billion.
Mr. Keller, the portfolio manager, already anticipates that the Treasury's proposal could have a two-edged impact on his own fund. "My holdings are in some of these bonds that the Treasury might be seeking to retire," he said. "So I may face a one-time gain, yes. But going forward, there will be less of these cheaper issues out there. And there will be another competitor in the marketplace for them -- the Treasury, with deeper pockets than I have."
And beyond the plain-vanilla world of mutual funds, Treasury securities are used in a variety of sophisticated hedging and investment strategies -- as the world discovered last fall when a large hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management in Greenwich, Conn., nearly capsized after a stampede of investors into the Treasury market battered the bets the fund had placed on the future relationship of various pairs of interest rates.
Traders interviewed yesterday said they did not think that a gradual reduction in Treasury debt would alter interest-rate trends sharply enough to cause a similar disturbance this time. "I think people have been gun-shy of putting those kinds of strategies on," said James Hamilton, head of swaps market-making in Europe for the Bank of America's London branch.
Indeed, Wall Street has been pushing for some new tool that would allow the Treasury to streamline the inventory of bonds that are in the public's hands, according to Mr. Keller. The hope, he explained, was that the Treasury would be able to buy back "the odds and ends" -- bonds in the less popular maturities -- and replace them with bonds that have become more useful as hedging instruments.
If the Treasury does begin to focus its borrowing on certain maturities, the esoteric derivatives and swaps markets would find it easier to adapt to a world in which Treasury securities are in short supply, said Paul Spraos, the publisher of the Swaps Monitor, an industry newsletter.
Treasury bonds have long been the swap market's equivalent of Greenwich Mean Time, the point from which the prices of all sorts of over-the-counter interest rate swaps are determined. "But over the past two years, we've seen a gradual cutback in the number of auctions," Mr. Spraos said. "Over time, the market has adjusted. But there will come a time when it could be a problem."
Indeed, as Mr. Summers announced the proposed debt buyback yesterday, he also said that the Treasury would auction new bonds only twice a year in the future, in February and August, eliminating the auction traditionally held in May.
Jerry del Messier, a managing director of Barclays Capital, the investment banking division of Barclays Bank P.L.C., said he thought the continued shrinkage in the Treasury market would ultimately expand the swaps market. "Nothing will ever replace the Government bond as the true risk-free interest rate," he said. "But we are seeing an increasing willingness of investors to look to the swap rates as the benchmark. Swaps are a better hedge. We have seen that in the sterling markets. And we are seeing an increasing willingness of investors to accept swaps as proxies for buying fixed-income securities."
Mr. Keller agreed that the interest rates established in the swaps market are becoming increasingly influential among professionals on Wall Street; indeed, many trading desks are already using them, he said.
But he said he thought the bonds issued by more familiar Government-sponsored agencies like Fannie Mae are more likely to emerge as the new benchmark for consumer-driven money managers.
"For a mutual fund manager like myself," he said, "it is easier to go from cash Treasury securities to cash agency debt than to make the leap over the chasm to an instrument that is still perceived as very exotic."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Oil and Those Slippery Anti-Dumping Laws

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
On Monday the Commerce Department is scheduled to weigh in on a trade dispute that a number of economists say could take the country's fair-trade laws to new heights of absurdity.
Twelve independent oil producers that take nearly depleted wells from major oil companies and pump out the last remnants have accused Saudi Arabia, Mexico, Iraq and Venezuela of selling oil in the United States for less than what they spend to produce it. That is a violation of the trade rules that is known as dumping. The plaintiffs are calling for the United States to impose taxes of up to about 170 percent of the price of oil imported from these countries. 
 Economists often mock anti-dumping laws because they punish foreigners for doing something kind for consumers: selling products at low prices. Dumping would be a genuine threat if foreigners could credibly drive American competitors out of business in order to take over an industry and raise prices later on. But such cases occur rarely, if ever. In the case of oil, the dumping accusation makes even less sense.
Oil is a commodity that is priced in a world market. One producer, even if willing to absorb losses for a time by selling at below-market prices, could never expect to recoup its losses by raising prices above market levels in the future. Other suppliers would strip away its customers.
Moreover, it is hard to make the case that dumping is occurring when one of the accused exporters, Saudi Arabia, spends only about $1.50 or so to produce a barrel of oil that sells for about $15.
Economists point out other holes in the dumping charge. The oil market is worldwide. It does not matter whose oil goes where. A tax slapped on four oil exporters will drive down imports from them. But it will not drive down imports over all. Other exporters will take up the slack.
Oil that Saudi Arabia would have sent to the United States will go instead to Europe; oil that Kuwait would have sent to Europe will come to the United States. Once the markets figure this out, oil supplies and prices will not change very much. "Victory," said Philip K. Verleger, an economist for the Brattle Group, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., "cannot help domestic producers."
It might seem that a flawed case would be swiftly rejected by the Government agencies that administer the trade laws. Not so, Mr. Verleger said. The plaintiffs could easily triumph on Monday. "When it comes to dumping, economically ludicrous cases prevail all the time," he said.
Mr. Verleger's point is that the anti-dumping laws are so stacked in favor of domestic companies that the Government agencies in charge of adjudicating trade cases almost always side against foreigners.
For example, it is a common practice during times of economic slack for United States companies, including oil companies, to cut prices simply to generate enough cash to cover their operating costs even if they lose money over all. This is perfectly legal. But when foreign companies engage in similar price-cutting, even as a defensive move to meet prices charged by concerns in the United States, they end up violating anti-dumping laws.
A second bias creeps into the process in this case because under the law, the Commerce Department does not even have to establish that Saudi Arabia's price falls below production costs. Instead, it need only find that Saudi Arabia charges less in the United States than it does somewhere else. The plaintiffs say that Saudi Arabia sets lower prices in this country than it does in Japan. Maybe so. But how that practice harms the United States, or proves that Saudi Arabia is selling oil below its cost, remains unexplained.
The plaintiffs take advantage of another oddity in the anti-dumping rules when they accuse the Mexican Government of subsidizing the sale of exports by Pemex, the state oil company. But the plaintiffs conveniently ignore, as the United States laws may allow, the offsetting amounts of money that Pemex routinely turns over to the Mexican Government. According to figures provided by the Mexican Government, it provides no net subsidy to Pemex.
Michael Stein, a lawyer representing a group of domestic oil producers that oppose the complaint, says the behavior of oil exporters hardly fits accusations of dumping. "I have fought to enforce the anti-dumping laws, first as a long-time Government official, then as lawyer for plaintiffs in anti-dumping cases," he said. "But this time I'm lining up against the plaintiffs because they are abusing the trade laws."
Mr. Stein points out that the plaintiffs represent a small fraction of the oil industry, yet they seek to raise prices for everyone. The major oil companies opposed the case. So do many independents. The anti-dumping laws are supposed to require that plaintiffs account for a substantial proportion of the domestic industry. But the law gives the Commerce Department wide discretion to ignore production by Mobil, Exxon and other large domestic companies that do business with foreigners when it determines the fraction of domestic production provided by the plaintiffs. Commerce is expected to decide on Monday whether the plaintiffs in the oil case meet the law's threshold.
Though economists often belittle the economic case for anti-dumping laws, they acknowledge a coherent political rationale for the laws. Low-price imports benefit hundreds of millions of consumers, but threaten a small number of domestic producers, driving them to seek cover from Congress. The laws mitigate anti-trade fervor by committing countries to rules of fair play. The laws also dilute opposition to open trade by channeling plaintiffs into a legal mechanism stacked in their favor.
But the economic arguments are so weak in the oil case that some of the economists and lawyers opposed to the plaintiffs speculate that their real purpose might be to negotiate with the Clinton Administration for a tax break or some other consolation prize if they dropped their charges.
Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, an ardent critic of the anti-dumping laws, best exposes the peculiarity of the case when he considers the consequence of a victory by the plaintiffs. "There is a silver lining in an otherwise dark cloud," he said. "The absurdity of the result might finally cause Congress to amend the dumping law in a pro-consumer direction."
Indeed, if there is any reason for thinking that the Government might side with consumers this time, it is that the Commerce Department's normal anti-import stance could cause Vice President Al Gore severe embarrassment. He no doubt wants to kick off his Presidential campaign with something other than an announcement from the Administration that it thinks Americans don't pay enough at the gas pump and the home heating depot.

HEADLINE: Dubuque Journal;
The Slight That Years, All 75, Can't Erase

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 31

 BODY:
It has always struck the people of this proud old Iowa town as an awfully snooty remark.
In a 1925 prospectus for The New Yorker, Harold Ross, the magazine's founder, boasted that it would not be "edited for the old lady in Dubuque." 
 Presumably all the old ladies who were in Dubuque in 1925 have since passed from the scene, as has Mr. Ross. But the remark still stings.
"We've been sitting here seething for 75 years," David Rusk said, not altogether in jest. "And by golly, it was time to respond."
Mr. Rusk is the editor of Julien's Journal, a monthly here, and in the June and July issues he gave The New Yorker, and New York, a taste of their own medicine, accusing New York of provincialism, at least when it comes to a condescending view of Dubuque.
"The Dubuque area magazine has at long last come to the defense of the community it serves, nose to nose, magazine to magazine," Mr. Rusk wrote.
"Ross and The New Yorker," his article said, "were actually ill equipped to know the real Dubuque and, as a result, cast their aspersion without sufficient grounds. They didn't know our community then, and they don't know it now."
Iowa likes to claim the highest literacy rate in the nation, and its high school test scores are consistently at or near the top. But Mr. Rusk complained that the "old lady" remark forever cast Dubuque as "the quintessential notion of provincial, non-metropolitan Middle America."
Asked about Mr. Rusk's grievance, people at The New Yorker said they had not known they had a battle on their hands. "We wish all the people in Dubuque well," said a spokeswoman, Perri Dorset.
To be sure, not everyone here is losing sleep over the 75-year-old slight. At 60, Betty Baule, a reference librarian, is far from an old lady. But she plans to be one someday, and she said: "I love The New Yorker. A lot of people in Dubuque read the magazine."
Besides, she added, stereotypes run in both directions. "I'm sure there are people in Dubuque," she said, "who have stereotypical views of New York."
For his part, Mr. Rusk says he feels no great animosity toward New York. He has friends and family there, and the Rusk Institute for Rehabilitation Medicine at New York University Medical Center was founded by a distant relative, Dr. Howard A. Rusk. (Another relative was Dean Rusk, the Secretary of State under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson.)
It's just that he wouldn't want to live there. "Too much city, too much humanity, too much crime, too much traffic, too much of everything," he wrote. "It costs too much to live well there."
He conceded that some people would regard Dubuque as too much the opposite: too small, too contained, too provincial.
"I say, good for you," he wrote. "Stay in New York and leave us to our own. But do let us visit. And please visit us as well. We can both do with a bit of broadening."
Both Dubuque, an old Mississippi River town, and Julien's Journal were named for a French explorer, Julien Dubuque, the city's founder.
These are good times for Dubuque, which has rebounded from the disastrous 80's, when unemployment soared to nearly 15 percent and housing values plummeted. In those days, the city relied heavily on meatpacking and the manufacture of farm implements, and a downturn in the agricultural sector brought big trouble for Dubuque as a whole. Now the local economy is much more diversified, with much of the job growth in computer programming, publishing and marketing.
With more jobs than workers, Dubuque civic and business leaders have run a campaign in recent years to lure back young people. The campaign, "Come back to your future -- come home to Dubuque," has succeeded in reaching some native sons and daughters who moved far away when the economy here was a shambles.
Boosters note that for a town of 60,000, Dubuque has a rich plate of cultural offerings. The Mississippi River Museum is the centerpiece of a $28 million riverfront project under construction here, and the town also has the Heartland Ballet Company, the Dubuque Symphony Orchestra and a theater group, the Barn Community Players.
All that may be small potatoes compared with New York, and Mr. Rusk acknowledges that his own, 23-year-old magazine is certainly small potatoes compared with the storied if financially struggling New Yorker. Nonetheless, he likes where he's sitting.
"Our magazine," he noted, "is making money."

HEADLINE: Struggles in His Past, Burdens in His Present

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The life of C. W. Bill Young, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, arguably the most powerful body in Congress, sounds like the world's saddest country-and-western song.
He grew up in a shotgun shack in a dirt-poor Pennsylvania coal town during the Depression. His father fled. The river washed away the shack when he was 6. His mother fell ill, and he dropped out of high school to support her by hauling concrete blocks and mixing mortar. 
 "In my short life," said Mr. Young, a 68-year-old Republican who has represented the St. Petersburg, Fla., area in the House for nearly 30 years, "I've been shot, I've been hit by a truck, survived an airplane crash, I've had my chest opened and my heart rebuilt. And it's sort of hard to get me flustered after all that."
Utterly unacquainted with money and power in his youth, Mr. Young is now burdened with both. On his shoulders, which are as wide as a side of beef, rest $538 billion and the prestige of the Republican Party.
Without benefit of a high-school diploma but with a penchant for numbers, the uncannily genial Mr. Young is responsible, as Appropriations chairman, for deciding how to spend that huge sum to run the Government. Thirteen subcommittees wrangle over 13 spending bills that provide the money, for the fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1. Mr. Young presides over all of them with extraordinary patience while squabbling swirls around him.
The process began with House Republican leaders freezing or cutting money for almost every agency except the Pentagon, which got a $19 billion increase. Then hundreds of members came privately to Mr. Young seeking some $80 billion in new spending, much of it for pet programs. "We had to say no to an awful lot of them," he noted.
He has since marched 10 of the 13 bills through the House, often in midnight sessions and not without fierce floor fights undertaken by conservative colleagues determined to cut all the bills to the bone and sometimes even deeper. All the while, he has been surrounded by lawmakers' incessant snarling and sniping over how to spend the people's treasure, a battle with all the grace and subtlety of greedy children pouncing on their parents' inheritance.
If that battle is not settled soon, and the bills cannot be enacted by the end of September, Congress may be facing alternative fiascoes: The lawmakers could wind up in a spending free-for-all in which they define some routine expenditures as emergency appropriations, exempt from painful spending caps. Or, if the spending process collapses, the Government could be shut down, and Republicans might well be burdened again by wrath from a public that perceives them as incapable of making the Federal trains run on time. Any festering of that anger, Mr. Young knows, could cost the Republicans their tiny House majority, now just five votes.
Yet he displays a calm that in another man might be attributed to either Zen meditation or mood medication. His secret?
"I've got so many scars on my back," he said, "I don't feel the whip anymore."
The lash keeps falling, wielded mostly by his fellow Republicans, some of whom want even deeper cuts than the $26 billion by which spending on domestic programs for next year has already been reduced, relative to this year's budget. Under the caps, that spending, excluding entitlements, has dropped to 3.4 percent of the American economy, its lowest level since 1962.
"You're talking about medical research, education, embassy security, problems all around the world, immigration problems all along our borders, all the law-enforcement agencies, including the F.B.I.," Mr. Young said.
Mr. Young is juggling a few billion here and a few billion there to keep the troops in line, but he concedes that this is no solution.
"We're robbing Peter to pay Paul," he said. "Trouble is, Peter doesn't have anything more to rob."
Through the 16-hour days, he needs every inch of the tough hide he picked up during his hard youth and a political lifetime spent mostly in the minority.
Born into poverty in 1930 in Harmarville, Pa., near Pittsburgh, Mr. Young had few prospects before him. He was 16 when he was shot in a hunting accident, and then things got worse.
"My mother got quite sick," he said in an interview in his committee's suite, all gilded mirrors and glittering chandeliers. "My uncle had a little camp in Florida. This camp was a tent, really. But we went down there. Then my mother got really sick. She was in the hospital in a coma. So I went to work. We stayed in Florida. Less expensive to stay there than try to get back home."
"It was very difficult to find jobs," he said. "I carried cement blocks, mixed mortar. I had left school, and I didn't have anybody in the family closer than a thousand miles to help me get a job or to get an introduction to anything."
Finally, he said, at 25 "I realized, 'I got to get out of this rut.' " He applied for a job as a salesman with the Federated Mutual Implement and Hardware Insurance Company. And the way he got it boded well.
"They were very reluctant to hire me, because I did not have a formal education," he remembered. "And they gave me a test. They gave you a list of numbers, and you were to figure out the missing numbers and tell them what those numbers meant. And they said I was the only one who had ever answered these questions correctly. I could see the patterns."
This turns out to be a useful skill for Mr. Young, who now has to find missing billions and pattern them in politically acceptable ways.
Mr. Young found insurance a very good living. The St. Petersburg area, where he worked, was booming with Yankee newcomers -- many of them Republicans -- and he made his fortune. In 1960, he went into a new line of work, becoming the only Republican state senator in Florida. He ran for Congress in 1970, and survived a campaign-trail plane crash to win his seat.
His 10 years in the minority in Tallahassee were followed by 24 years in the minority in the House,until the Republicans took control there in 1994 for the first time in four decades. Now Mr. Young has real power. But he seems to have sympathy for people who do not.
"In the minority, I got shot down a lot," he said with a weary smile. "I received a lot of scars. Political scars. They taught me a lot."
