HEADLINE: Dow Chemical Says It Plans to Buy Union Carbide

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it was acquiring the Union Carbide Corporation for $9.3 billion in stock in a deal that would join two household names and create a chemical giant second only to DuPont in size.
Although neither company makes consumer products any longer, names they made famous, like Dow oven cleaner and the former Union Carbide brands Prestone antifreeze, Eveready batteries and Glad bags, still show up on supermarket shelves, made by others. 
 Dow and Union Carbide now make lesser-known products like polypropylene and ethylene glycol, so-called intermediate and basic chemicals that crop up in everything from computers to food wrapping.
Declining profit and a cyclical slump in chemical prices put Union Carbide in the market for a partner, and Dow is counting on trimming its already low costs even further to help it compete in a rapidly consolidating market. The merged company, which will have combined revenue of about $24 billion, expects annual savings of about $500 million.
The new company, which will keep the Dow name and be based in Dow's current home, Midland, Mich., plans to eliminate about 2,000 jobs, leaving a global work force of about 49,000. Although Union Carbide -- and presumably its headquarters in Danbury, Conn. -- will cease to exist as a separate entity, neither company would confirm that the Danbury operations would be shut down or where the cuts would be.
"Dow has a number of businesses outside Midland, and maybe we'll run some functions out of Danbury," said William S. Stavropoulos, Dow's chief executive and the man who will head the merged company. "This is for the merger integration team to decide."
Despite the size of the new Dow, there are so many chemical companies scattered across the globe that the merged company is unlikely to command more than 12 percent of the market for any one chemical market. Thus, analysts say it is unlikely to run into antitrust obstacles.
Carbide's investors have seen their investment stagnate in recent years. But yesterday Carbide's shares soared, to $59.375, up $10.5625. In contrast, Dow stock went down by $6.0625, to $118.625, on the prospect that the company will issue new shares to close the deal.
Carbide is one of the 30 companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average -- a spot that some on Wall Street speculated would go to the Microsoft Corporation but that history suggests may be taken by the merged company.
The merger comes at a time when the companies that make building-block chemicals -- look-alike products like ethylene and propylene that are sold by the ton and differentiated primarily by price -- have been joining forces throughout the world. Lyondell Chemical, Millennium Chemicals and Occidental Petroleum pooled their basic chemical businesses, while oil mergers like that of Exxon and Mobil are creating huge chemical entities in addition to oil giants.
Merger mania has also embraced companies that make specialty chemicals -- inks, foams and other technologically complex products with small niche markets and high margins.
Dow and Union Carbide have products in both camps, yet both have marched against a broader trend in the chemical industry -- the shift of many basic chemical companies toward agricultural chemicals, pharmaceuticals and other so-called life sciences businesses.
That may be one reason that DuPont seems unfazed by the prospect of a huge new competitor.
"The term 'chemical company' doesn't accurately reflect the DuPont of today," said Catherine L. Andriadis, a DuPont spokeswoman. "DuPont is a science company with a highly diversified portfolio, and there are few areas where we compete with either Dow or Union Carbide."
Dow and Union Carbide, in contrast, have remained focused on using technology to become both the lowest-cost producers of older-style chemicals as well as finding more uses for them.
Union Carbide is among the largest makers of polyethylene and polypropylene, two of the most commonly used plastics. It is also a leading supplier of solvents and other chemicals to the paint industry, and of various chemicals used in automotive, wire and cable and personal care products.
Dow, too, makes many forms of plastics and solvents. But Dow, more than Carbide, has narrowed its sights in the last six years. It sold its consumer products business to S. C. Johnson & Company two years ago and also shed its share in the drug company Marion Merrill Dow. And while it has acquired some agricultural technologies, it has expanded primarily by beefing up its existing solvents, coatings and other process chemicals. It has squeezed $2.2 billion out of its costs, and its profits and stock price have risen accordingly. "This merger now is jump-starting the growth phase of our strategy," Mr. Stavropoulos said.
Union Carbide has a less successful tale to tell. The company exited consumer products in 1985, primarily to raise cash to fight off an unwanted takeover attempt. It has formed numerous strategic partnerships with other chemical companies over the last few years, but few analysts have been able to define a coherent strategy for growth. Although its stock has run up nicely since April, most say it was because of renewed interest in chemical stocks in general, not any investor love for Union Carbide.
"Union Carbide has long been seen as a disappointment," said James N. Kelleher, an analyst with Argus Research. "It remained static while everyone around was taking aggressive steps, and that was the same as stepping backward."
Indeed, the company was badly hit by the Asian economic crisis and by costly problems at its plant in Kuwait. To bolster lagging shareholder confidence, William H. Joyce, Carbide's chief executive, promised that he and several of his senior team would forgo their base salaries if earnings did not hit $4 a share in 2000; few analysts were expecting earnings to even hit $3.
The merger, thus, may be saving Mr. Joyce and his executives a lot of money. But, in a sense, it is costing them their jobs. Mr. Joyce, 63, will be vice chairman of the new company and will lead the integration team but is unlikely to be involved in day-to-day operations. And only one other Union Carbide person will join the Dow board.
"A significant proportion of Carbide's management will not be with Dow Chemical a couple of years down the road," said Paul T. Leming, an analyst with ING Barings.
Most analysts agree that the sum of the two companies will be far greater than either part. Dow says the merger will add to earnings from Day One, and that within two years it will have wrung $500 million a year out of the merged company's annual costs. Analysts believe them -- and expect the picture to get even rosier over the next few years, when chemical prices are expected to rise.
Although the two companies have some overlapping product lines, they have far more that are complementary. Both, for example, sell various chemicals to paint makers; now they will be able to offer large customers like Sherwin Williams one-stop shopping.
Under the terms of the deal, Union Carbide shareholders will receive 0.537 share of Dow for each share of Union Carbide.
Based on both stock's closing price on Tuesday, that meant the deal was valued at $9.3 billion. Dow will also assume $2.3 billion in Union Carbide debt.
Both companies have survived potentially catastrophic lawsuits and public outrage over the last few decades.
In the early 1970's, Union Carbide had the dubious distinction of being named one of the nation's dirtiest companies by the Council of Economic Priorities, a corporate-responsibility gadfly group. And in 1984, the company got worldwide notoriety when one of its plants in Bhopal, India, leaked toxic gas, eventually killing as many as 10,000 people. Union Carbide paid a $470 million settlement in India's Supreme Court in 1989.
Dow, meanwhile, was the target of widespread student protests in the 1960's because it made napalm -- jellied gasoline -- for use in the Vietnam War. Dow was the focus of litigation over the defoliant Agent Orange, and its lethal byproduct, dioxin, which many Vietnam War veterans said caused severe illness. The company was also embroiled in litigation over silicon breast implants, made by its joint venture, Dow Corning, which some women said caused health problems. Dow Corning has offered to pay $3.2 billion to settle the claims.
Few of those cases represent financial threats for the future, analysts said. Still, the bitter aftertastes continue to tarnish their corporate reputations. "Those issues have had lingering impacts on their valuations on Wall Street," said Mr. Leming, the analyst.
But even environmentalists acknowledge that both companies are making strides to clean up their act.
"They have demonstrated efforts to improve their environmental performance," said Romi I. Gottfrid, an environmental research associate at the Council on Economic Priorities, who cited the merger as an opportunity for the combined company "to emerge as an environmental leader in the chemical industry."
Goldman, Sachs & Company advised Dow on the transaction, while Credit Suisse First Boston advised Union Carbide. Mayer, Brown & Platt provided legal advice to Dow. Sullivan & Cromwell advised Union Carbide.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Chemical to Acquire Union Carbide for $9 Billion
Dow Chemical said it was buying Union Carbide for $9.3 billion in stock in a deal that would join two household names and create a chemical giant second only to DuPont in size. Although neither company makes consumer products any longer, names they made famous, like Dow oven cleaner and Prestone antifreeze, are still common sights on supermarket shelves. 
 Declining profit and a slump in chemicals prices put Union Carbide in the market for a partner, and Dow hopes to reduce its already low costs even further to help it compete in a rapidly consolidating market. Page A1.
 
Cadbury Bottler's Future Uncertain
A pair of acquisitions by Cadbury Schweppes 18 months ago was supposed to have ended the company's heavy dependence on a fragmented network of independent bottlers to get its Dr. Pepper and 7-Up soft drink brands onto store shelves. But the Cadbury venture, called American Bottling, has run into problems and analysts say it may go on the block. C5. 
 
Factory Orders Post Strong Gain
Strong demand for automobiles and electronic equipment helped lift orders to United States factories by seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, a fresh sign of recovery for manufacturing. The increase followed a 1 percent gain in May, the Commerce Department said. Separately, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that business activity outside the manufacturing sector expanded in July, but at a slower pace than in June. C12.
 
Steelmaker Gains U.S. Toehold
Gerdau, one of Brazil's biggest steelmakers, moved to expand its manufacturing operations into the United States with the acquisition of a 75 percent interest in Ameristeel from Kyoei Steel of Japan. C4.
 
Discounted Air Fares Draw Fire
Travel agents reacted with dismay to a new move by airlines to cut costs by offering consumers discounts on tickets booked on line. A Delta executive said on-line ticketing is far less expensive than traditional methods. C8.
 
Executive Won't Join E*Trade
E*Trade Group said that Frank J. Petrilli would remain at its rival, TD Waterhouse Group, instead of taking over E*Trade's retail brokerage business. C12.
 
A TV Deal in Europe Wobbles
A $615 million deal that would have united Central European Media Enterprises, founded by Ronald S. Lauder, and SBS Broadcasting of Luxembourg has been thrown into doubt by a dispute over Central European Media's only money-making asset, the Czech television station TV Nova. The former general director of TV Nova, Vladimir Zelezny, above, has tried to seize TV Nova's broadcasting license in a dispute that is now in the courts. C4.
 
Neuberger Berman Reveals Results
Neuberger Berman, a New York-based money manager planning to sell $250 million in common stock in an initial public offering this fall, said in a regulatory filing that net income for the first six months of the year was $141.1 million, a 5.8 percent decline. C10.
 
Agencies Taking a Regional Focus
A deal that will create a new agency owned by Omnicom Group is indicative of efforts by giant agency companies to augment their offerings in regional markets like Atlanta. The new agency, Bayless/Cronin, will result from the merger of Bayless & Partners with Merley Newman Harty's Atlanta office. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C8.
 
Merrill Plaintiffs Seek Mediation
Lawyers for the plaintiffs in a sex discrimination case against Merrill Lynch plan to pursue mediation for all 900 claims against the firm, rejecting its assertion that only a third of the claims may have merit. The claims involve female Merrill employees who said discrimination curbed their earning potential. C2.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO BUY BACK BONDS AND SAVE INTEREST

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Like a family that suddenly finds itself with enough cash to pay off both its credit cards and its mortgage, the Clinton Administration moved today to take advantage of projected Federal budget surpluses by overhauling the way the Government handles its finances.
For the first time since 1972, the Treasury Department wants to buy back debt, a change in its strategy for handling the $3.6 trillion it owes to the public in the form of Treasury bonds and other securities as it seeks to minimize its interest expenses. 
 With the Government already running a budget surplus if its excess Social Security revenues are included, the Treasury has been using much of the extra money for the last two years to reduce the national debt.
The debt will decline by about $87 billion this year, and if the surplus grows as projected over the next decade, the pace of debt reduction could accelerate substantially.
As with most issues involving the surplus, this one is caught up in politics. President Clinton used the prospect of cost-efficient debt reduction as an argument today against the $792 billion, 10-year tax cut that the Republican-controlled Congress plans to pass in final form this week in the face of his veto threat. Page A18.
The centerpiece of the Administration's debt-reduction plan would allow the Treasury to buy back some high-interest-rate debt from investors before it matures and to replace it with new securities that carry lower interest rates. Much of the debt issued by the Treasury over the last three decades carries interest rates higher than those for Government securities being issued today.
While arcane, the changes have substantial implications for the bond markets, where the Government and private companies compete to borrow money. Page C1.
Details of the plan are still being worked out and it is unlikely to take effect until next year. Whether and when the plan might be carried out will depend in large part on interest rates remaining low enough for the debt buybacks to make sense. It would not require approval by Congress.
By itself, swapping high interest-rate debt for lower rate debt would not accelerate the pace of reducing the national debt, which depends on the growth of the surplus. But in general the Treasury is issuing progressively less new debt relative to the amount that is maturing or that might be repurchased.
"These prepayments -- in many ways analogous to a homeowner refinancing a mortgage or a company refinancing its debt -- would hold out the prospect for reducing Federal borrowing costs over time," said Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers.
Under its current policy, the Government has simply been paying off Treasury securities when they mature, regardless of their interest rate, and issuing smaller amounts of new debt in their place, an approach that limits its ability to swap higher cost debt for low-rate debt.
The Government has not bought back debt in any way since the Nixon Administration, and it has not repurchased debt for cash at least since World War II and probably not in this century, Treasury officials said.
And the changes are the leading edge of what could be even broader shifts in the nation's financial strategy as it confronts the possibility that it could substantially reduce or even wipe out the Government debt held by the public over the next 15 years.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Government will generate $2.9 trillion more in revenues over the next decade than it needs to pay for its programs under current law. Of that, $1.9 trillion is nominally designated for Social Security, but in practice it is likely to go to reducing the debt held by the public. The two parties are fighting over what to do with the other $1 trillion.
Economists said the Treasury plan was a common-sense approach to making the most of the surplus.
But the debt plan could run into questions from some Republicans because it would require that the Government absorb some costs in the short run -- in the form of the premium it would have to pay to convince investors to sell their Treasury bonds -- to reap the interest savings in the long run.
Although the Administration did not say how big a debt repurchase plan the Treasury Department might undertake, or when it might begin, analysts said the short-term costs could be substantial enough to be a factor in the battle over the surplus, since the Republicans are counting on as much as possible of it for tax cuts. Congress is already heading toward spending all or most of next year's non-Social Security surplus to finance a variety of domestic programs.
"I'd much prefer to use that money for reductions in marginal tax rates," said Lawrence Kudlow, an economist and former Reagan Administration official who is influential with conservatives in Congress.
The techniques being developed by the Treasury Department "would, in effect, allow us to refinance old debt and pay it down on the best terms possible, saving taxpayers billions of dollars in the process," President Clinton said during an appearance in the White House Rose Garden this afternoon.
"Paying down the debt creates wealth, creates jobs, creates opportunity," Mr. Clinton said. "It's the right and responsible thing to do, and we have the chance of a lifetime to do it."
To protests from Republicans, who say their budget plans do more to reduce the national debt than his plan, Mr. Clinton has sought to frame the current debate over the surplus as a choice between an irresponsible Republican tax cut for the wealthy and a prudent division of money between debt reduction, increased spending and modest tax cuts for working people.
The debt securities issued by the Treasury generally are not callable -- that is, the Government cannot demand that investors sell them back. Instead, under the Treasury's new plan, the Government would announce that it is interested in buying back a particular bond issue, and then ask the investors who own it to name a price. Treasury would accept those offers that made sense to it.
Gary Gensler, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, used the following example to illustrate how the debt plan would work. In November 1991, the Government sold a 30-year bond carrying an interest rate of 8 percent. The bond currently trades in the market at an interest rate of 6.41 percent.
Treasury could repurchase that bond, and replace it with a combination of 30-year bonds, which currently carry a rate of 6.16 percent, and 10-year bonds, which currently trade at 5.95 percent, giving an average rate of around 6.07 percent.
Over the years, even tiny reductions in interest costs could yield substantial savings to the Government. Mr. Summers said today that for every three one-hundredths of a percentage point in reduced interest rates on the total debt, the Government ultimately saves $1 billion a year in interest costs.
But beyond just swapping high-rate debt for lower rate debt, Mr. Gensler said, the plan would increase the volume of new bonds being issued by Treasury.
Because new bonds are more actively traded than older ones, and can be more easily bought and sold, investors are willing to pay a bit more for them, meaning their interest rates are lower.
It is that increase in the tradability of the bonds, and the corresponding decrease in interest rates, that could bring the biggest benefits to the taxpayer, Mr. Gensler said.
Keeping the market for the bonds active is a major goal of the plan, Mr. Gensler said, because as the national debt falls, Treasury is issuing fewer and fewer new bonds and other securities. Over the last 12 months the Treasury had made 26 debt offerings, he said; in the prior year the number was 39. Just today Mr. Gensler announced that Treasury would sell its 30-year bonds twice a year from now on instead of three times.
Economists said such problems could become more acute if the national debt eventually approached zero. The market for United States securities is the worldwide benchmark for safety and security in investments, and if it were to dry up it could make it more difficult to judge relative risks of various investments.
The Treasury would want to find a way to keep an active market in Government securities in case a war, a deep recession or some other event led the Government to need to borrow a lot of money quickly.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton, reflected in a glass door, on his way to the Rose Garden, where he spoke of buying back securities to reduce the national debt. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. A20)
 
Chart: "Retiring Debt, Little by Little"
 
The Treasury plans to pay off some of its debt before it is due by holding what is called a reverse auction.
 
ISSUING DEBT -- For years, the Treasury has issued short- and long-term debt to pay for budget shortfalls.
 
BUYING IT BACK -- Now, the Treasury wants to buy back debt that carries the highest interest rates. It will tell dealers who buy Government debt which notes it wants to buy and how many of them.
 
SETTING A PRICE -- The dealers will tell the Treasury how much of a premium over the face value of the notes they will sell them for and the Treasury will accept some of the offers.
 
PAYING FOR THE NOTES -- Some money from the Federal budget surplus will be used to buy the debt. But, to keep the Treasury market working properly, the Government will also issue new notes to pay for some of the old notes. (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: Rescue Time at the Apollo: Time Warner to Control Board

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN and RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
State officials are working out final details of an arrangement that would give Time Warner a controlling role in rescuing Harlem's financially troubled Apollo Theater, officials and corporate executives said yesterday.
The negotiations are also expected to resolve a lawsuit brought by the state accusing a six-member majority of the Apollo board of failing to collect millions of dollars owed the theater by Percy E. Sutton, a prominent businessman and former Manhattan Borough President. The settlement would require Mr. Sutton and his associates to repay $1 million to the theater, according to people involved in the negotiations. A company controlled by Mr. Sutton produces "It's Showtime at the Apollo," a weekly variety program for television. 
 The agreement is expected to be presented to the Apollo's board at its meeting on Monday. The settlement would also include a financial contribution from Time Warner, estimated at $400,000 to $500,000.
As part of the settlement, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, a powerful Harlem Democrat, would step down as chairman of the theater's nine-member board and would be replaced by the actor Ossie Davis, and Time Warner would add 10 people from the entertainment industry to the board, expanding it to 19 members, said Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner. The theater, once Harlem's golden stage on 125th Street, is owned by the state but operated by the nonprofit Apollo Theater Foundation.
The close involvement of Time Warner, the world's largest entertainment and media company, with revenues last year of nearly $27 billion, was supported by State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer as a way to bail out the long-deteriorating Apollo, where Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Nat (King) Cole and other legends entertained.
Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the agency that owns the theater, said the state had approved Time Warner's plans to take control of the board and was eager for the rescue effort to begin.
The suit's settlement has been stalled for weeks while lawyers for Mr. Rangel and Mr. Sutton negotiated with the State Attorney General's office over how to resolve the accusations made last November in a lawsuit filed by Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco. Mr. Rangel and five other board members were accused of failing to collect at least $4 million from Inner City Theater Group, a company controlled by Mr. Sutton, a close friend and longtime political ally of the Congressman.
Mr. Rangel has repeatedly said he will not sign an agreement that did not exonerate him. He said yesterday that the precise wording was still being negotiated.
"I don't need anybody to vouch for my honesty," said the Congressman, a 15-term House veteran and the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Sutton, who became a defendant in the lawsuit last month at his own request, is also seeking language that would clear his name.
"Percy Sutton has acted honorably at all times in his relationship with the Apollo Theater," said Peter Parcher, one of his lawyers, "and if there is a resolution, it will reflect that fact."
The complaint said Mr. Sutton was required to give the theater 25 percent of his gross profits from the show, which would have amounted to $4 million over a five-year period. But Mr. Sutton and Mr. Rangel said the contract they signed included confusing language that had been misinterpreted and that the show had consistently lost money.
In April, Mr. Spitzer, who replaced Mr. Vacco as Attorney General, came up with another figure, saying the theater was owed "well over one million." Mr. Spitzer said in a letter to the foundation's lawyers that this figure was derived from an audit commissioned by the theater. But lawyers for the foundation have said he misread the audit.
Mr. Spitzer would not speak on the record about the proposed settlement yesterday. But lawyers working on the case said that an agreement was expected to be reached before Monday's meeting of the Apollo Theater Foundation board. The new members would be added at that meeting.
Time Warner officials provided details of their role for the first time yesterday. The company's involvement is not a surprise. Mr. Rangel and Mr. Parsons, who have worked together on Harlem economic development issues, have said they have long wanted to bring Time Warner into the Apollo. In March, the company said it was eager to adopt the Apollo, but only if the allegations of wrongdoing had been cleared up.
Outlining his company's plans yesterday, Mr. Parsons said George Wein, the jazz impresario who created the Newport Jazz Festival, and six other people, three of them officials of Time Warner, had agreed to join the board.
The new board members will also include Val Azzoli, the co-chairman of Atlantic Records, a Time Warner subsidiary; Keith Clinkscale, the former chief executive of Vibe, a publication owned by Time Warner; Byron Lewis, the founder of Uniworld, an advertising and marketing agency aimed at African-American consumers, and Jonelle Procope-Terrell, a lawyer.
Although Time Warner will control the board, Mr. Parsons denied that the company was taking over the theater. "It's definitely not a takeover," he said. "It's a partnership that we're forming between Time Warner and the Apollo Theater Foundation." Company officials said the entertainment company would not run the theater, and would not have the power to hire or fire its executives.
Among the first issues facing the new board will be whether to approve or rebid a multiyear contract for Mr. Sutton's company to distribute "It's Showtime at the Apollo" for forthcoming television seasons.
A rival distributor, Frank Mercado-Valdes, president of the African Heritage Network, whose charges of favoritism led to the state investigation last year, said yesterday that he had considered it futile to bid on a new contract under the existing board, but said he would like to do so now with a new board in charge.
Time Warner's contribution will be part of a financial package that will include Mr. Sutton's settlement as well as some city, state and Federal government money and charitable donations. About $400,000 is expected to come from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.
Mr. Parsons is the chairman of that program, which uses Federal, state and city money to stimulate economic development. Mr. Gargano said the Empire State Development Corporation had already agreed to give the theater $300,000, but the money was held up pending resolution of the lawsuit.
Acknowledging that the sums were small, Mr. Parsons said his company would help start an endowment campaign to raise more money for the theater, which he described as a cornerstone for economic development in Harlem.
"I don't think you can bring life back to Harlem without bringing life back to 125th Street," he said, "and you've got to start with the Apollo." Reviving the theater would also spur other development, including new restaurants.
Under the proposed agreement, Mr. Sutton and some of his associates in the Apollo deal would be responsible for repaying the $1 million that Mr. Spitzer contended last April was due the Apollo foundation out of profits reaped by the distributors, according to an audit by the accounting firm KMPG.
His predecessor, Mr. Vacco, had contended that as much as $4.4 million was owed to the foundation, but after reviewing the audit, Mr. Spitzer said that $1 million was a fairer figure.
The initial dispute between the state and Mr. Sutton and Mr. Rangel centered on whether the percentage due the foundation was to come from net or gross profits.
The foundation later sued its lawyers at White & Case, an action not affected by the proposed agreement.
Some of the money going to the Apollo will be used to replace the theater's dilapidated marquee and broken-down seats and to create a souvenir shop, Mr. Parsons said. But he said that the theater was in "functionally sound shape" and needed to attract top performers and large audiences even more than it needed renovation. Most nights the fabled theater is dark.
Mr. Parsons said the goal was to bring "interesting and inspired multidimensional programming" to the theater, perhaps by using it for a new television talk show starring the rap performer Queen Latifah, or for movie premieres or televised beauty pageants.
Mr. Rangel said he was delighted that Time Warner was finally getting involved in the theater, but he emphasized that he, and not the Attorney General, should be given the credit for bringing in the company.

HEADLINE: First Lady Hears of Economic Fears, but Marriage Is Hot Topic

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: JAMESTOWN, N.Y. Aug. 4

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton resumed her exploratory trip to New York today, listening to an assortment of complaints about the sluggish economy of western New York and facing a barrage of media questions about comments she made in a magazine article about her husband's marital infidelity.
It was Mrs. Clinton's first public comment on the subject of her marriage since the appearance of the article, which was published this week in the premiere issue of Talk magazine. In that article, Mrs. Clinton said she thought President Clinton had overcome his womanizing 10 years ago. She also said that he was scarred by abuse he suffered as a child. 
 Many news reports and columns have linked Mrs. Clinton's remarks about the President's womanizing and his childhood. But while Mrs. Clinton's comments on the two subjects appear in the same part of the article, she is not quoted citing cause and effect.
Today, in response to reporters' questions, she said she had not intended to offer her husband's childhood problems as an excuse for his behavior.
In Washington, President Clinton also addressed the article, saying that nobody "could fairly read the article and think that she was making any excuses for me."
After answering the questions about her marriage, Mrs. Clinton, who has avoided discussing her personal life publicly, said she would no longer entertain such questions.
Her comments came during Mrs. Clinton's fourth so-called listening tour of the state since she began contemplating a run for the United States Senate. Her trip took her to the Crawford Furniture Manufacturing Company's factory here to listen to local business leaders, entrepreneurs and workers, as well as to a series of private meetings with local politicians, most prominently former Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine.
Before taking questions from reporters -- most concerning the magazine article -- Mrs. Clinton conducted her meeting with local citizens in a style very much like the others she has undertaken since forming an exploratory committee early last month to consider running for the Senate seat being vacated next year by Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
She sat in the middle of a semicircle of a few local leaders, facing a group of about 50 citizens -- registered Democrats and Republicans who were selected by the furniture plant's owner and the Chautauqua County Executive, Mark Thomas, who is a Democrat. On a plant floor covered with sawdust, Mrs. Clinton heard a wide range of concerns, from the high prices for airline travel to and from western New York, to the lack of trained personnel for high-skill jobs.
The format offered Mrs. Clinton a chance to speak at length on some issues, like the inequality between the Federal taxes New Yorkers pay and the money that Washington returns to the state. "It may be that we'll never get a dollar-for-dollar exchange," she said. "But we sure ought to get more than we're getting now. Were I in the Senate, I would try to create a coalition of the big states to stand up for our interests."
In some cases, playing the role of mere listener allowed her to brush aside other topics. For example, one woman offered a lengthy complaint about what she considered to be the detrimental effect of the North American Free Trade Agreement; Nafta passed in 1993, championed by President Clinton. To criticism that the trade agreement contributed to unemployment in the region, the First Lady offered only a brief but courteous, "Thank you very much."
The listening tours have all the trappings of a campaign in the weeks before an election -- complete with people lining the routes of Mrs. Clinton's events and a media caravan of dozens of reporters. But several of the people invited to today's discussion said they were keenly aware that Mrs. Clinton has not yet declared her candidacy for the 2000 election and they wondered whether she was serious about running.
"I get more interested in running every day," Mrs. Clinton said, responding to a reporter's question. "And I especially get interested when I can talk with people about the real issues that are confronting them and their lives. The more that I go around listening to New Yorkers, the more excited and encouraged I get that I might be able to make a contribution in the Senate on behalf of the people of New York."

HEADLINE: Europe Isn't Taking a Needed Fiscal Step

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Norbert Walter (Op-Ed, Aug. 4) doesn't mention the most important economic problem facing Europe. As many prominent economists have argued, one of the main reasons for high unemployment across Europe is the tight monetary policy being pursued by the European Central Bank. 
In 1992, when the United States was last in a downturn, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, lowered the short-term interest rate to the rate of inflation, making the real interest rate -- the gap between the interest rate and inflation rate -- in the United States virtually zero. Even after a recent rate cut, the real short-term interest rate in Europe is still close to 2 percent.
If Mr. Greenspan had pursued the same sort of monetary policy in the United States, it's a safe bet that the economy would not have grown as rapidly.
 
DEAN BAKER
Washington, Aug. 4, 1999
 
The writer is a senior research fellow, Preamble Center.

HEADLINE: Europe Isn't Taking a Needed Fiscal Step

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Unless day trading is checked, this speculative fever may lead to social, economic and financial disasters (news article, July 31). The Federal Reserve should prohibit the extension of margin loans to day traders and limit commercial banks' lending to day trading brokerage firms. Higher capital requirements on these firms should be imposed. Regulators should mandate that funds devoted to day trading by any day trader should be restricted by that individual's overall net financial resources. 
 And regulators should limit the number of trades by an individual day trader and his brokerage firm on any given day.
 
E. MAGNUS OPPENHEIM

HEADLINE: Clinton Veto Looming, G.O.P. Tries to Shore Up Tax Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton renewed his vow today to veto a sweeping tax-cut bill, as Republican leaders began carefully counting to make sure they had the votes to pass the plan that Senate and House negotiators approved on Tuesday night.
Outside the public eye, the Congressional tax staff worked against tight deadlines to fill in the details of the negotiators' framework. 
 The House and Senate plan to vote on the measure before leaving this week for a monthlong recess.
The central element of the measure would reduce the lowest income tax rate, now 15 percent, to 14.5 percent in 2001 and to 14 percent in 2003.
The rates for more affluent taxpayers, now ranging from 28 percent to 39.6 percent, would also be reduced by one percentage point, but that would not happen until 2005.
Altogether, the legislation, an amalgam of bills approved last month by the Senate and House, would lower taxes by $792 billion over 10 years.
"If they conclude this plan and send it to me, I will veto it," President Clinton told reporters today in the Rose Garden. "I will refuse to sign any plan that signs away our commitment to America's future, to Social Security, to Medicare, to paying down the debt."
Republicans in the House met this morning, and leaders said afterward that the rank and file was enthusiastic about the bill and would pass it.
The situation is more ticklish in the Senate. The measure is now more favorable to the wealthy than the bill the Senate approved last week, 57 to 43. On that vote, four Democrats supported the bill and two Republicans voted against it.
The word from leaders' offices was that the four Democrats would vote against the new version, as would the two Republicans who voted no last week, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and George V. Voinovich of Ohio. Another Republican, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, is also expected to vote against the bill.
If all other senators stand pat, that would make the vote 52 to 48 in favor of the bill. But three other Republicans, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and Olympia J. Snowe and Susan Collins, both of Maine, were said to be on the fence.
One school of thought among Republicans is that the best possible outcome would be for the Senate to deadlock, 50 to 50, leaving Vice President Al Gore to cast the tie-breaking vote defeating the tax cut.
That kind of partisan calculation was rampant in the Capitol today. Everyone knows that the votes this week are for exercise and that one way or another this particular bill will never become law.
Musing on the situation, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said it was like drawing up a Christmas list when you knew Santa was not coming.
Partisan maneuvering is the daily bread of Congress, but what makes this issue so unusual is that each side seems convinced that it has the political advantage.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, said he could hardly wait to present the tax-cut measure to the people during the Congressional recess.
"Republicans in the House and Senate have kept our commitment to protect the taxpayers and not the tax takers," Mr. Archer said.
Republican leaders have decided that even if Congress gives final approval to the legislation this week, they will not send it to the White House until after Labor Day. That will give them a month to promote it.
 Democrats were equally confident that they held the strong position.
"They're rolling the dice," Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said of the Republicans, "and in my view, they're going to come up the big losers here."
The bill the Republican leaders agreed on starts small and mushrooms over the next decade. The total tax reduction in 2000 would be only $5.2 billion. In the first five years, the cuts would total $156.1 billion, but they would continue to mount so that in 2009 alone, taxes would be reduced by $130 billion.
Calculations by the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche showed that a couple with two children under 17 and an income of $50,000, near the national median, would get an annual tax cut of $265 when the bill was fully in effect.
A similar couple with an income of $200,000 would get a tax cut of $2,720, and one with an income of $1 million would receive a cut of $9,861.
In percentage terms, the $50,000 couple would have taxes reduced 9 percent, while the taxes of the $200,000 couple would be lowered 7 percent and the taxes of the $1 million family would be reduced 3 percent.
Citizens for Tax Justice, an organization sponsored by labor unions that usually makes reliable calculations, figured that nearly half of the tax reduction from the rate cuts alone would go to the wealthiest 10 percent of taxpayers, those with incomes above $89,000.
Other provisions of the Republican bill would be even more favorable to the affluent, including a reduction in the top capital gains rate to 18 percent from 20 percent, effective Jan. 1, 1999, and a gradual abolition of the inheritance tax on large estates.
The bill would also adjust capital gains, the profits from investments, so that inflation after Jan. 1, 2000, would not be counted when the profits were figured. This provision would cost the Government significantly in the long run, but it would result in a short-term windfall.
In order to take advantage of the inflation adjustment, taxpayers would have to pay the capital gains tax in 2000 on profits accumulated to date. This would raise $15 billion in 2000. Without it, no tax cuts would be possible in 2000 without creating a budget deficit.

HEADLINE: A New Idea of 'Get Me the Coast';
Hollywood's Major Competition Is in Western Queens

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Even as plans to create a Hollywood-style movie studio at the Brooklyn Navy Yard have seized all the attention, Kaufman Astoria Studios is expanding its entertainment complex and quietly solidifying the position of western Queens as the center of the city's flourishing television and film production industry.
Astoria Studios said yesterday that its $8.3 million project would include an 18,000-square-foot sound stage and support space in a new building on 36th Street, between 34th and 35th Avenues. It would be the seventh studio in the complex, which already has the largest sound stage east of Hollywood and is home to the CBS television comedy "Cosby" and the Children's Television Workshop programs "Sesame Street" and "Cinderelmo." The feature films shot at the studios include "Ransom," "First Wives Club" and "Marvin's Room." 
 "We're as close to a Hollywood studio as you're going to get on the East Coast," said Hal G. Rosenbluth, president of Kaufman Astoria Studios. "I'm thrilled. It's a project we've been working on for a long time."
Astoria Studios dates from the 1920's, when the film industry was based in New York and more than 110 silent movies were made there. After a drought in the early 1990's, film and television production is booming in New York, and studios like Astoria are desperate to capture more of the new business. The number of films shot in New York City jumped to 221 last year, from 69 in 1993. The number of television shooting days rose 113 percent to 7,680 during the same period.
The announcement by Astoria Studios comes only three months after Silvercup Studios in nearby Long Island City began work on a $20 million expansion, with five new sound stages of 16,000 square feet each. The HBO series "Sex and the City" and "The Sopranos" are shot at Silvercup, which with Astoria Studios, Paris Film Productions in Long Island City and Broadway Studios in Astoria account for about two-thirds of the film and television production space in New York City, industry executives.
But there are a number of other proposals for television and film studios, including the Navy Yard plan, which was unveiled in May by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He said at the time that the city would subsidize a $150 million project by the actor Robert De Niro and Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax Films, to turn a 15-acre site into a glamorous film factory.
Many people in the industry welcomed the idea, but questioned the wisdom of building a dozen large and expensive sound stages all at once. New sound stages are expensive to build and operate because film producers, unlike office tenants, rent space for only a few months at a time and do not pay top dollar.
Complicating the situation further, the major studios began laying off workers and reducing the number of films in production this year because of declining profits. Last month, Dreamworks SKG abandoned its plan to build a $250 million studio in Los Angeles. And many companies are moving film and television production to Canada and Europe, where costs are considerably lower.
"It's a hard business in which to make money," said Alan Suna, chief executive of Silvercup Studios. "That's especially true when you have no long-term commitments."
The studios in New York say that a slowdown in film production this year has been offset by a continuing surge in the number of television and cable series being made here. But they say that the ambitious project at the Navy Yard could turn out to be a white elephant.
"It's a great idea," said Gary Paris of Paris Film Productions in Long Island City, where Kevin Costner recently completed "For the Love of the Game." "But it's not cost-effective. I don't think it's going to fly."
Walter L. McCaffrey, the City Councilman from western Queens who helped get the Astoria Studios project off the ground, also questioned the Giuliani administration's touting of a project in Brooklyn that could undermine the film and television industry in Queens, which is home to three of the five largest grip and lighting companies as well as major costume- and scene-building companies. Astoria Studios, in particular, operates under a long-term lease on city-owned land, he said. The Astoria Studios are also home to WFAN radio and to the Lifetime television studios.
"It's always been mind-boggling to me that we were sort of undercutting our own investment with the Navy Yard proposal," Mr. McCaffrey said yesterday. City officials say they can handle all the projects.
Although the De Niro project has been mired in disputes and has yet to lock down its financing, the City Council is providing a $2.5 million grant toward the $8.3 million expansion at Astoria Studios, while the Empire State Development Corporation is contributing $1.7 million in grants and loans and the city's Economic Development Corporation is lending $1.2 million.
"There is a genuine shortage of sound stages in New York," said Charles Gargano, chairman of the development corporation. "Unfortunately, sound stages aren't moneymakers. But without them, you could choke off the industry in New York."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY COURT OVERTURNS OUSTER OF GAY BOY SCOUT

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Equating the Boy Scouts with such public accommodations as restaurants, libraries, schools and theaters, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the organization's expulsion of a gay Eagle Scout in 1990 violated the state's antidiscrimination law.
In a unanimous 7-to-0 decision, the court first rejected the Boy Scouts' arguments that it is a private organization and that its decision to remove the scout, James Dale, was protected by the First Amendment. The court also dismissed the Scouts' contention that homosexuality is immoral, comparing that view to discrimination against women and blacks. 
 After saying Mr. Dale's dismissal was "based on little more than prejudice," the Chief Justice, Deborah T. Poritz, wrote: "The sad truth is that excluded groups and individuals have been prevented from full participation in the social, economic and political life of our country. The human price of this bigotry has been enormous. At a most fundamental level, adherence to the principle of equality demands that our legal system protect the victim of invidious discrimination."
The case of Mr. Dale, who is now 29, is the second one to have reached the highest court in a state. But the result is just the opposite of the earlier case. In March 1998, the California Supreme Court ruled that the Scouts could expel homosexuals, agnostics and atheists. That court held that the Boy Scouts were a private organization not covered by California's civil rights law and that the organization had constitutional rights of freedom of association and freedom of expression to expel homosexuals.
In a concurring opinion in the New Jersey decision today, Justice Alan B. Handler, widely considered the court's staunchest liberal, said he agreed with much of his colleagues' legal reasoning. Then Justice Handler, who is retiring after this term, concluded his 44-page opinion with something of a sociological and philosophical lecture. "One particular stereotype that we renounce today is that homosexuals are inherently immoral," Justice Handler wrote. "That myth is repudiated by decades of social science data that convincingly establish that being homosexual does not, in itself, derogate from one's ability to participate in and contribute responsibly and positively to society.
"In short, a lesbian and gay person, merely because he or she is a homosexual, is no more or less likely to be moral than a person who is heterosexual."
Paul Stevenson, a public-affairs spokesman for the Boy Scouts of America at their national headquarters in Dallas, expressed disappointment with the New Jersey ruling and said the group planned to appeal it to the United States Supreme Court.
The California ruling was not appealed because it did not turn on any claim of Federal constitutional law.
"The Boy Scouts of America is a private organization with the right to set our membership and leadership standards," Mr. Stevenson said. He contended that New Jersey's anti-discrimination law did not supersede the organization's First Amendment rights of association. Consequently, he reasoned, New Jersey's high court had used the state's anti-discrimination law to discriminate against the Boy Scouts.
Mr. Dale, who was an assistant scoutmaster at Troop 73 in Matawan, N.J., when he was expelled, said he was elated with the ruling.
"The Supreme Court of New Jersey is wonderful," he said as he appeared with his lawyer at the headquarters of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund in Manhattan. "This is what Scouting taught me: Goodness will prevail."
The lawyer, Evan Wolfson, called the ruling "a strong, clear powerful decision by one of the nation's most respected state supreme courts."
"The decision we got today is a win-win decision," Mr. Wolfson said. "It's a victory for Jim Dale and it's a victory for other gay men like him."
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman applauded the ruling during a public appearance in Bergen County. She said she did not believe in discrimination "in any form" and said a person's sexual orientation was a private matter. "If the troop leader is a good leader, there's no reason to worry" about his sexual orientation, Governor Whitman said.
Mr. Dale, who lives in Manhattan and helps arrange health fairs for people with AIDS, said he wanted to return to Scouting. The ruling ordered his reinstatement and instructed a lower New Jersey court to take up his request for compensatory and punitive damages against the Boy Scouts.
Mr. Dale joined Scouting in 1978 at age 8, obtained more than 25 merit badges and Scouting's highest rank -- Eagle Scout -- and eventually became assistant scoutmaster. The Boy Scouts considered him an exemplary member, the ruling said.
But in July 1990, his photograph appeared in a local newspaper identifying him as co-president of the Lesbian/Gay Alliance at Rutgers University. Soon afterward, the Scouts sent him a letter informing him of the expulsion and saying that the Scouts' standards for leadership forbade membership to homosexuals.
Today's decision said Mr. Dale asked various Scout executives for a copy of the standards of leadership but was never given one. In late 1990, the organization's lawyers told him that the Boy Scouts "does not admit avowed homosexuals to membership." He began his legal fight soon afterward.
During court arguments over nine years, the Scouts argued that the organization believed homosexuality was immoral and that belief was both explicit and implicit in the Scout Oath that a scout is "morally straight" and in the Scout Law that a scout is "clean."
The court disagreed with that argument in its 89-page ruling.
In finding that the Scouts were a "public accommodation" as defined by the state's antidiscrimination law and not a "selective" private organization, Chief Justice Poritz wrote that Congress had chartered the organization, that 87 million boys and men had joined Scouting since its inception in 1910, and that churches and police and fire departments routinely sponsor local troops.
"Most important," she wrote, "it is clear that Boy Scouts does not limit its membership to individuals who belong to a particular religion or subscribe to a specific set of moral beliefs."
She said the Boy Scouts teach tolerance and the understanding of differences in others and that the group's charter and bylaws do not permit exclusion of any boy.
"Boy Scouts is not 'distinctly private' because it is not selective in its membership," the Chief Justice wrote. Largely because of its broad membership and large size, she dismissed the Boy Scouts' arguments that First Amendment freedom of "intimate association" -- usually reserved for family relationships and small groups whose members share common thoughts and beliefs -- shielded the organization from the antidiscrimination law.
In dismissing the argument that the First Amendment right of "expressive association" allowed the dismissal of Mr. Dale, the Chief Justice said the organization's ability to disseminate its message would not be impaired if he was a member.
"Boy Scout members do not associate for the purpose of disseminating the belief that homosexuality is immoral," she wrote. "Boy Scouts discourages its leaders from disseminating any views on sexual issues; and Boy Scouts includes sponsors and members who subscribe to different views in respect of homosexuality."
The Chief Justice said the court agreed with the Scouts' espousal of moral values. But she said it disagreed with the contention that the Scout Oath's principle of "morally straight" and its admonition that a scout be "clean" meant that homosexuality is immoral.
"The words 'morally straight' and 'clean' do not, on their face, express anything about sexuality," she wrote. Thus, she said, Mr. Dale's membership does not violate the Scouts' right of expressive association.
That, she concluded, "suggests that Dale's expulsion constituted discrimination based solely on his status as an openly gay man."
Expelling him was not justified by the need to preserve the organization's expressive rights, she said. And she held that expulsion solely on the ground of sexual orientation was "inconsistent with the Boy Scouts' commitment to diverse and representative membership."
Justice Handler, in his concurring opinion, said the Boy Scouts' legal contention in the Dale case that homosexuality is immoral is out of touch with current law, public policy and social mores.
"Boy Scouts' adherence to 'traditional moral values,' its 'belief in moral values,' " Justice Handler said, "remain undisturbed and undeterred by Dale's open avowal of his homosexuality."

HEADLINE: Most Off Welfare Get Jobs, but Not All Long Term

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Two-thirds of the people who left New York State's rapidly declining welfare rolls found jobs within the year after they stopped receiving public assistance, according to a new study commissioned by the state.
It also found, however, that only 40 percent of the people who found jobs worked continuously during that time. 
 The study, done by independent researchers using state data, also found that of the people who left welfare during that period, more than 80 percent were still off public assistance a year later, although many did not report wages.
Conducted by the Rockefeller Institute at the State University of New York in Albany for the Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, the study examined the fate of roughly 9,000 single mothers whose cases were closed in early 1997 and followed them throughout the next year. It has not been published, but it has been circulating among policy makers and a copy was provided to The New York Times.
The report is the most detailed analysis to date of what has become of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who have left welfare in recent years. It also offers the first documentation of claims by Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that new welfare policies intended to push people off the rolls have moved them toward self-sufficiency, not destitution.
The findings, experts say, suggest that the combination of a robust economy and tough new policies aimed at nudging people off welfare have led many former recipients to find jobs. But the report does not answer many crucial questions, such as the types of jobs that former recipients secured during their first year off welfare and whether they were advancing in the workplace. Nor does it say how many of the people who were tracked are working part time or how many are working off the books.
In the end, both opponents and proponents of New York's new welfare policies found something in the study that supported their positions. While state officials pointed to the employment figures as evidence that their policies were helping former welfare recipients become self-sufficient, advocates for the poor said the study showed how difficult it was for former recipients to hold onto jobs, even in flush times.
The report, for example, noted that while 66 percent of the people found a job within the 12 months after they left the welfare rolls, slightly more than half -- 53 percent -- still had a job at the end of the 12-month period. Many of those people may have taken low-paying jobs or jobs without benefits, the report noted. About 20 percent of those who left welfare returned to the rolls.
The study was financed by the Federal Government to determine the initial impact of the 1996 Federal welfare overhaul, which gave states sweeping new powers to impose new requirements and restrictions on public assistance.
Richard P. Nathan, the director of the Rockefeller institute and one of the main authors of the study, said that while crucial questions remained, the study provided a valuable glimpse of life after welfare. "This is a first step in understanding the effects of the widespread changes in welfare policy in New York," he said. "But we need to know a lot more. This is the tip of the analytical iceberg."
That said, the results suggest that people who left welfare in New York may actually be doing better than former recipients in some states that have been celebrated for their welfare-to-work efforts, like Wisconsin and Massachusetts.
In a survey released last January, Wisconsin reported that 62 percent of former welfare recipients surveyed were working full time or part time when they were interviewed and that 83 percent had worked at some point since leaving welfare.
But the Wisconsin survey deliberately excluded anyone who had left welfare during the first three months of 1998 and then returned over the next nine months. By excluding those who returned to welfare, Wisconsin officials got significantly better results than if they had included former recipients who were unable to find work and went back on the rolls.
By contrast, New York included people who returned to the welfare rolls, and it achieved largely the same results.
Nearly 690,000 people have left the state's two main welfare programs -- Aid to Families With Dependent Children and Home Relief -- since 1995, according to state social-services data. About 470,000 of them left welfare in New York City in that period.
As the main part of the study, researchers compared lists of people whose benefits ended during the first quarter of 1997 with records of wages that were reported to the state by employers through March of 1998. Employers are required to file wage reports to the state each quarter.
The study has certain limitations. It did not track people who are self-employed, who recently married an employed person or who moved out of New York for a job. Nor did it include information from employers who are not required to report wages at all, like farm owners.
The study also did not track 66,000 families who came off the rolls after the state managed to collect child support payments from delinquent parents. Those families, while off welfare, do not show up in the state's wage reporting system.
More than that, though, the study does not attempt to track the fate of childless, single adults who received aid under the state-financed program called Home Relief. The rolls in that program have declined by 224,316 since 1995, and advocates for the poor have long contended that people in that program are among the most difficult to employ because they often have disabilities like substance-abuse problems.
Rather, the study sought to determine what had become of the roughly 465,000 single parents and children who had left the rolls since 1995. For the purposes of the study, the researchers did not count people who returned to the rolls within two months of their cases being closed. Those cases were excluded from the study, the researchers said, because welfare cases are often closed inadvertently and then reopened once the error is noticed.
The study's authors estimated that when people with unreported employment were factored in, more than 70 percent of former welfare families had some kind of employment during their first year off welfare, and about 60 percent were employed when the year was over.
But the study counted anyone with even the most minimal employment as having had a job; the threshold was just $100 per three-month period in income. Even so, researchers found that by the fourth quarter after leaving welfare, the average family income was $4,230 for the quarter, equivalent to $16,920 for a year. When that figure was adjusted to reflect income that might not have been reported, the average was $5,034, or $20,136.
Another major finding was that of the people whose cases were closed, 29 percent were receiving food stamps a year later and 48 percent were receiving Medicaid, suggesting that some people may have taken low-wage jobs or jobs without medical benefits.
Sheldon Danziger, a professor of social work and public policy at the University of Michigan, said the overall employment figures among former recipients in New York generally mirrored the findings in other states. He credited the good economy, as well as new restrictions on welfare, with leading recipients into jobs. But he added that the true test of the new welfare policies would come when the economy becomes sluggish and there are fewer jobs.
"The states are clearly pushing recipients into a labor market in which employers need more workers," said Mr. Danziger, who is working on the tracking of former welfare recipients Michigan. "But we won't know the full impact until a recession comes."

HEADLINE: Judge, Faulting Agencies, Halts Logging Deals

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Five years after the Clinton Administration hammered out a landmark plan to settle legal and environmental disputes over logging across the Pacific Northwest, the region's timber wars are flaring up again.
The same Federal judge who once issued rulings to protect the northern spotted owl has now blocked nine major logging deals and threatened to stop dozens of others by declaring that Federal officials have failed to take proper steps to insure that other species are being protected as well. 
 Siding with environmentalists and enraging the logging industry, Judge William L. Dwyer of Federal District Court in Seattle ruled on Monday that the United States Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management had unlawfully neglected to conduct detailed wildlife surveys on Federal forest land, as required by the 1994 compact, before approving contracts allowing logging of parcels in old-growth forests west of the Cascade Mountains in Washington and Oregon and in northwestern California.
The ruling could ultimately affect logging on half a million acres or more of Federal land.
The Clinton Administration brokered the compromise in 1994 under pressure from environmentalists and the logging industry, and Judge Dwyer lifted his 1991 a ban on logging on about a third of remaining federally owned old-growth forests designed to protect spotted owl and its habitat. In his ruling this week, Judge Dwyer declared that the agencies' actions under the plan had been "arbitrary and contrary to the plain language" of that plan.
The ruling effectively put the land agencies's efforts to protect wildlife back under a degree of court jurisdiction imposed in 1991 until they could show they were doing a better job of monitoring the logging's effects on 77 animal and plant species that include rodents, snails, salamanders, mollusks and wildflowers.
Many of the species are considered indicators of the overall health of the old-growth forest ecosystem. Under terms of the 1994 plan, all were supposed to be surveyed by the Federal agencies, which say they believe they have followed those terms. But the environmentalists, in a suit against the Government, said the agencies had failed to do complete surveys before granting logging permission.
Judge Dwyer's ruling has the immediate effect of blocking logging plans for about 100 million board feet of timber, enough to build about 7,000 average-sized homes. But even more broadly, the judge indicated that his court's approval would be needed before new logging could occur under about 200 other deals in the region. If upheld on appeal, after a likely challenge from the industry, the ruling could significantly curtail logging in the majority of contracts approved by the Federal officials in the last three years in the region.
The ruling is being hailed as a "blockbuster victory" by one of the lawyers for the 13 environmental groups that joined forces in the lawsuit. A spokesman for the timber industry said it was "disappointed that the judge feels he knows the plan better than the professionals in the Federal Government."
The forest service said it was still studying the ruling to assess its impact. "Our lawyers are still going through it," said Rex Holloway, a spokesman for the agency in Portland, Ore. "They're hesitant to say anything until they've had a chance to talk among themselves." But he said the forest service believed it had correctly followed the guidelines of the 1994 agreement.
At this point, it is unclear whether the red tree vole, a small rodent favored as food by the spotted owl, or the blue-gray tail-dropper, a tiny snail, will acquire the emotional symbolism that the owl brought to the fight over old-growth forests. Both are among the species at issue in the case.
But it is certain that the fight is renewed, and that environmentalists are again on the offensive, trying to move toward a much broader ban on logging in the Northwest.
"There's so little old-growth left, there's no good place to cut it anymore at all," Doug Heiken, western Oregon field representative for the Oregon Natural Resources Council, said in a telephone interview today. "All of it should be protected for future generations."
The group, one of those that filed the lawsuit, says that only 10 percent of the region's old-growth forests are left, and that about 30 percent of that area remains eligible for cutting under the 1994 plan.
The industry, meanwhile, says the judge's ruling imperils hundreds of logging jobs and the local economy in some pockets of the Northwest and many are pressing Congress to relax the survey regulations.
Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, has sponsored legislation to relax some of the requirements of the environmental surveys, making it easier for many of the timber deals to go through, and the judge's ruling is likely to intensify the fight over the issue.
Still, the region as a whole is far less dependent on logging than it once was -- in Oregon, for example, the high-tech industry is now a bigger source of jobs than forest-products companies. And even in some places that were once deeply reliant on logging, tourism built on the area's natural beauty is now a mainstay of the economy, which leads at least some local business people to oppose the logging.
"It messes up the area, big time," said Tom Vuyovich, owner of the All Seasons Motel in Detroit, Ore., on the edge of the Cascades, who said much of his clientele is tourists drawn to the area's natural beauty and its many recreational possibilities.
"A lot of them look around, there are clear-cuts visible all around, and they say, 'What happened here? Where are the trees?' They want to know where the old growth is, and I can carefully point them out to the last few spots that have been saved -- so far."
Chris West, a spokesman for the Northwest Forestry Association, an industry group, said today that the judge's ruling was just "the tip of the iceberg" and that it could eventually lead to a ban on logging for lumber that could be used to build nearly 100,000 homes.
Such a ban would not in itself be likely to significantly affect building activity or drive up the cost of lumber in general, but it would curtail the amount of the old-growth wood on the market. Many builders and prospective home owners, both here and in overseas markets, consider it particularly desirable.
Many environmentalists say there is no good reason to allow logging of the old-growth forests at all, and concern over the forests is what sparked the first of the legal battles that have been revived by the judge's ruling this week.
In 1991, Judge Dwyer issued a sweeping ruling that temporarily halted all logging in the spotted owl's habitat region under Federal jurisdiction, nearly 25 million acres in all. He ruled that the Bush Administration was breaking Federal laws by allowing so much logging on public lands that the owl could become extinct.
Pressed by both environmentalists who wanted the logging permanently stopped and by industry officials who described the judge's ruling as economically devastating, President Clinton moved shortly after he took office in 1993 to broker a compromise. He did, permanently setting aside about 10 million acres of Federal land on top of millions of acres of owl habitat that were already protected because they were in national parks or other wilderness areas.
The compromise, including the requirement for the wildlife surveys, cleared the way for Judge Dwyer to lift his ban. But it satisfied neither side, and there is still a debate over whether the plan is sufficiently protective of the owl.
The Forest Service estimates that there are 8,000 pairs of owls in the Northwest. A recent Federal survey found that the owl population is declining at about 3.9 percent a year. Agency and industry officials said the rate of decline was significantly less than what it had been and was in fact an indication that the plan for recovery of the species was working.
Environmental groups said the continued decline called into question the whole plan, and they renewed their push for a half to all logging on old-growth land.
The Clinton Administration has said it is committed to shifting forest policy toward conservation. It announced earlier this year, for instance, that it would continue its suspension of logging-road construction in most of the national forests.
So the judge's ruling will also set the stage for a likely battle within the Administration over how the Forest Service should respond -- in other words, whether it should contest the ruling or use it as a continuing reason to halt logging projects.
Mr. Heiken, of the Oregon Natural Resources Council, said the group was not opposed to the 1994 plan, as long as it was scrupulously followed. He disagreed with the forest industry's contention that it was being subject to renewed and unfair oversight.
"This is exactly what the courts are here for," Mr. Heiken said. "The point is, the agencies are going to have to come up with a way to do it right."

HEADLINE: North Korea's Dangerous Missiles

 BODY:
North Korea threatens to escalate tensions in Asia and heighten its own isolation if it goes ahead with another long-range missile test in the next few weeks. The Taepodong 2 missile, first tested last August, has a range of 3,700 miles, which makes it capable of hitting Alaska and Hawaii as well as Japan and American military targets throughout the Western Pacific. A second test would rightly be taken as a return to belligerent behavior by a country that recently seemed to be signaling an interest in more constructive relations with the outside world.
The United States, Japan and South Korea have warned North Korea not to go ahead with the test. All three countries have been exploring improved relations with Pyongyang through diplomatic encounters, trade discussions, humanitarian relief projects and tourism. Such efforts would be stopped short by a missile test. Further, Japan could be pushed to strengthen its air force and add missile defenses, which some of its neighbors, including China, might find troubling. 
 Unfortunately, North Korea has learned to use threats of menacing behavior as a bargaining tactic to extort economic and diplomatic rewards. That approach began in the early 1990's when Pyongyang appeared ready to reprocess nuclear reactor fuel into bomb ingredients. Washington responded imaginatively to that crisis by negotiating a useful agreement that committed the North to abandon reprocessing. In exchange, the United States, South Korea and Japan agreed to finance fuel-oil imports and construct a new, more safely designed reactor.
But North Korea later renewed its threatening behavior. Last year it began excavations for what appeared to be a new reprocessing plant and then demanded increased food assistance for allowing inspection of the suspect site. As it turned out, no new reprocessing plant had been built. Now the North may be trying to win new concessions with its missile test preparations.
In both earlier cases, North Korea backed off in time to avoid a crisis. But if it now proceeds to a missile test, it should get a very chilly response. Washington should withdraw its recent proposal offering the North an end to most economic sanctions and steps toward diplomatic recognition. That offer is conditioned on constructive North Korean behavior and is not compatible with long-range missile tests.
In addition, Seoul should suspend its new tourism arrangement with the North and Tokyo should block payments home from North Korean citizens living in Japan. America's reaction should not include military steps or suspending the nuclear agreement, which continues to serve the interests of the United States and its Asian allies.
A missile test would not violate any international treaty or agreement with the United States. But it would be a clear sign that North Korea is more interested in developing its military strength and capacity to export dangerous weapons than in pursuing the American offers of help and cooperation. North Korea should think carefully and draw back.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 6, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial yesterday erred in saying that North Korea tested its Taepodong 2 long-range missile last August. North Korea has not yet tested this missile. A medium-range missile, the Taepodong 1, was tested last August.
