HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Steelmaker to Add U.S. Link to Pan-American Chain

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Gerdau S.A., one of Brazil's biggest steelmakers, moved to expand its manufacturing operations into the United States today with a deal to acquire control of the Ameristeel Corporation.
Gerdau said it would purchase a 75 percent stake in the company, held by Kyoei Steel Ltd. of Japan, which would give Gerdau a pan-American production network extending from Canada to Chile. The deal for Ameristeel would also mean that nearly half of Gerdau's revenue would come from outside Brazil. 
 Gerdau is a leader among Brazilian companies that are expanding abroad to insulate themselves from the uncertainties that have buffeted Latin America's biggest economy. "This is a smart move by Gerdau because it shields them from the volatility in their home region," said Mauricio Reveco, who covers Latin American steel companies at Salomon Smith Barney in New York.
The process is expected to be completed within 60 days. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.
With the purchase of a controlling stake in closely held Ameristeel, which has 2,100 employees, four manufacturing sites and estimated annual sales of $600 million, Gerdau reinforces its position as a leading maker of steel for the construction industry.
Since the 1980's, Gerdau, based in the southern city of Porto Alegre, has acquired steel mills in Uruguay and Argentina, as well as in Canada and Chile.
Gerdau's purchase also touched off speculation about the future of the Brazilian steel industry, which has been hurt by Brazil's economic slowdown after a currency devaluation crisis in January. There have been predictions of a consolidation among steelmakers.
Gerdau, considered among the healthiest, has been mentioned as the most likely candidate to take over Companhia Siderurgica Nacional, or CSN, the country's largest steel company. Since the devaluation of the Brazilian real, CSN has had difficulties servicing its substantial foreign debt.
But Gerdau's acquisition of Ameristeel throws the assumption that it could also buy CSN into question.
"It would be highly unlikely for Gerdau to make a move now on CSN," said Daniel Altman, a Latin American steel analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "Ameristeel should be a significant investment for them, although we still don't know how much."
Another reason analysts now believe that CSN could be sold to a foreign concern such as Thyssen Krupp A.G. of Germany or Arbed S.A. of Luxembourg, which have shown interest in the company, is that Gerdau is in a substantially different business from CSN.
Gerdau produces "long" steel, used in the construction of buildings or to produce heavy machinery like food harvesters, while CSN makes "flat" steel, used in products like refrigerators or cars.
The same distinction is what excludes Gerdau from an agreement reached last month between the Governments of the United States and Brazil to avoid punitive tariffs on Brazilian steel imports. The agreement, which established a quota system for the next five years, applied to flat steel producers like CSN.
"We've been talking to CSN, and the major shareholders in CSN, but were not swimming in money," Osvaldo Schirmer, Gerdau's financial director, said in a telephone interview from Tampa, Fla., where Ameristeel is based.
Nonetheless, CSN shares advanced on news of the Ameristeel acquisition, reflecting speculation that it could be next. Its American depository receipts rose $1, to $24, on the New York Stock Exchange. Gerdau's ADRs rose 37.5 cents, to $16.75.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about the proposed purchase of a controlling stake in the Ameristeel Corporation of Florida by Gerdau S.A., a large steelmaker in Brazil, misstated the financial condition of Companhia Siderurgica Nacional, or CSN, Brazil's largest steelmaker. CSN, which has been the subject of speculation as a possible purchase by Gerdau, has $700 million in cash on hand. It has not had difficulty servicing its foreign debt since the Brazilian currency was devalued in January.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Rental Complex Offers Open Space in East Village

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Amid the densely packed streets of the East Village, a two-building rental complex is taking shape that will offer amenities unusual for the neighborhood. Prime among them is open space.
The $17 million project, at 190 East Seventh Street between Avenues B and C, will have 125 studio to two-bedroom apartments, with 450 to 720 square feet, as well as some three-bedroom penthouses, with just under 1,100 square feet. The units, including some duplexes, will be spread between the two seven-story buildings, which will overlook a 6,600-square-foot landscaped plaza and be on the edge of two garden areas to the east. 
 Tompkins Square Plaza, named for its green space and proximity to Tompkins Square Park, will have a health club, laundry room and 24-hour doorman. It is rising on part of a midblock site, extending to East Sixth Street, that once housed an elementary school, Public School 71, but has sat vacant for decades.
The new rental complex, brokers said, underscores Manhattan's strong housing market and the area's growth as a less expensive alternative to neighborhoods like SoHo and the West Village, as well as to emerging residential areas in the financial district. While rents in the East Village have risen, they are still 15 to 20 percent lower than those for comparable units elsewhere in Manhattan, said Brian G. Edwards, director of leasing at the Halstead Property Company, a Manhattan brokerage.
Leasing began two weeks ago at the first of the East Seventh Street project's two buildings, which contains 72 apartments, including 18 duplexes that are split evenly on the lower two and top two floors. So far, contracts have been signed for 30 apartments, all of them single-level units, at rents of $1,800 to $3,400 a month, which is competitive for the area, said Paul W. Stallings, who, with several limited partners, is developing the project as P.S. 71 Associates L.L.C. of Manhattan. Monthly rents for the duplex units, for which leasing will start later this month, will be $4,000 to $5,500, he said.
Mr. Stallings has been active with conversion and rehabilitation projects in the East Village for the last two decades and owns and manages 12 rental buildings there, with a total of 130 apartments. Tompkins Square Plaza is his first new construction project.
"Interest in the neighborhood has exploded in the last three years, making it a 24-hour community," he said. "But until recently, nobody was building residential projects, especially large ones, or for the broader economic group of people moving to the area."
Reasons for the limited construction have included the difficulty in assembling large building sites and the lack of financing from conventional sources, said Mitchell Adelstein. He is president of Capstone Realty Group, based in Englewood, N.J., which helps developers and investors, including P.S. 71 Associates, secure funds.
"Now," he said, "such lenders are more apt to look at less traditional neighborhoods like the East Village, where rents have strengthened, making it ripe for new construction."
Tompkins Square Plaza is among the largest of a spate of projects under way in the East Village. GMAC is providing a $13.5 million construction loan, with the rest coming from the partners' own equity.
The partners began assembling the site, comprising four different lots, two years ago. They bought the largest lot, where the school once stood, for $2.8 million from a developer who did not proceed with a planned housing project. Six months later, they acquired three additional smaller lots at a city auction for about $700,000.
Residents of two adjacent cooperative buildings used two of those lots as community gardens. Zoning restrictions require that they be retained as gardens or redeveloped as an "accessory use," including a garage, for the adjacent new building.
To move his project ahead, Mr. Stallings said, he struck a compromise with the co-op residents, enabling them to retain access to and shared control over the gardens. Meanwhile, the development rights over the gardens were transferred to the new project, allowing the partners to build it to its current scale and increase the number of units to 125 from 80.
Robert Altemus, president of the co-op board at 613 East Sixth Street, said of the compromise: "I'm pleased because it is the best case we could come up with without getting our arms ripped off trying to stop progress."
Les Grant of Samu Realty, who is the marketing director for Tompkins Square Plaza, said the project "fills a new niche" in the East Village for more upscale services, which developers "have been slow to meet."
Mr. Edwards of the Halstead company agreed, adding that there was sufficient demand for the project's smaller units from young professionals willing to venture to the East Village for its character and lower rents. But the real question, he said, is if the larger, more expensive duplex units will rent.
Mr. Stallings said that if there was resistance to the higher rents, they might need to be modified.
Each of the new buildings, designed by Simon Fouladin of Long Island City, Queens, will have stone bases and be faced with the same tan and yellow brick found on existing neighborhood structures "so they will look as though they have been there for 80 years," Mr. Stallings said.
Both buildings will have a single stone-floored lobby, whose entrance will be on Seventh Street, and connected by the interior plaza, which will feature a seating area and two fountains, as well as a skylighted passageway under the plaza. That underground space will also house the health club and laundry room.
The entire project is to be completed in January.

HEADLINE: Swiss Lawyer Is Set to Head U.N. War Crimes Tribunals

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A Swiss lawyer with wide experience in fighting money laundering and organized crime is expected to be named chief prosecutor of the international war crimes tribunals for the Balkans and Rwanda.
The lawyer, Carla Del Ponte, Switzerland's Attorney General and Federal Prosecutor, would replace Louise Arbour, a Canadian judge who has been appointed to Canada's Supreme Court. 
 Secretary General Kofi Annan met with Mrs. Del Ponte today and was expected to forward the nomination to the Security Council overnight. United Nations officials do not expect opposition in the Council, which created the tribunals and formally appoints the prosecutor and judges, because members have been consulted in advance.
Mrs. Del Ponte, 52, will be the first experienced prosecutor to hold the job on the war crimes tribunals. Her predecessors, Ms. Arbour and Richard Goldstone of South Africa, were both judges. The chief prosecutor is appointed for a four-year term and is based in The Hague.
Switzerland is not a member of the United Nations, but Swiss citizens often serve in professional United Nations jobs. In this case, Switzerland's neutrality -- it is not a member of NATO -- is considered an advantage for Mrs. Del Ponte, who will be working on cases involving the conflict in Kosovo. The Balkan tribunal already has before it an indictment of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President.
In Africa, Mrs. Del Ponte will be responsible for the separate Rwanda tribunal, which has been plagued by management problems at its headquarters in Arusha, Tanzania. The Rwanda tribunal has, however, a growing list of indictments and convictions of people involved in the mass killings of Tutsi and moderate Hutu in 1994.
In recent years, Mrs. Del Ponte became well known in Europe for breaking a Sicilian Mafia money-laundering operation in Switzerland, pursuing former Soviet bloc officials who may have been stowing illegal funds in Switzerland and investigating Swiss bankers suspected of misappropriating money, in some cases in collaboration with Latin Americans. She also produced the evidence for Pakistan to bring money-laundering charges against Benazir Bhutto, a former Prime Minister, and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari.
In the course of her international investigations, Mrs. Del Ponte has worked with American officials, including Louis Freeh, the F.B.I. Director.
Mrs. Del Ponte suffered a setback last month when Switzerland's highest court overturned the confiscation by her office of $90 million from Swiss accounts belonging to Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of a former President of Mexico. The court ruled that Mrs. Del Ponte had no authority to seize the $90 million only on the suspicion that it included money from drug-trafficking. But the ruling did not absolve Mr. Salinas of the charges.
Born in Lugano on Feb. 9, 1947, Mrs. Del Ponte was educated in Geneva and Bern and in Britain. She began her career in a law firm in Lugano and three years later, in 1975, set up her own practice. In 1981 she was appointed investigating magistrate and then public prosecutor in the office of the Lugano district attorney.
In 1994, Mrs. Del Ponte, who speaks English, French, German and Italian, was named Attorney General of Switzerland, and she has also served since then as the country's chief prosecutor.
In addition to aggressive investigations into money laundering and other economic crimes, she also turned her attention to arms trafficking and support for terrorist organizations.

HEADLINE: Labor Costs Rose in Spring While Productivity Slowed

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Growth in worker productivity slowed considerably in the spring while a gauge of wage pressures surged, Government figures showed today. The potentially troublesome developments could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
The Labor Department reported that productivity -- output per hour of work -- increased at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the second quarter, far below the 3.6 percent rate in the first three months of the year. At the same time, unit labor costs, considered a crucial measure of wage pressures, surged at an annual rate of 3.8 percent, the worst showing since the end of 1997. 
 Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and many private economists think strong productivity growth has helped to keep inflation low. With productivity rising sharply, employers are able to raise wages and pay the higher salaries through increased output rather than higher prices. But Mr. Greenspan warned Congress two weeks ago that if productivity slowed, wage pressures were likely to emerge, given that labor markets are the tightest in nearly three decades. He pledged that the Fed would act to raise rates at the first signs of inflation.
Financial markets have been jittery over the prospect that the Fed will raise interest rates when policy makers meet on Aug. 24.
The productivity report gives the central bank fresh ammunition to do just that, some economists said.
"Chairman Greenspan has most of the ducks in a row to hike interest rates on Aug. 24," said a Wells Fargo economist, Sung Won Sohn. "These numbers are a couple of the ducks he was watching carefully."
Economists said another important report would be Friday's unemployment report. If the July unemployment rate inches back down to a 29-year low of 4.2 percent and if hourly wage costs show a big jump, many analysts said, that will make it even more likely that the Fed will raise rates. The unemployment rate in June was 4.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Berlin Journal;
Skirmish in the Store Wars: The Souvenir Caper

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Called everything from Rambo to an apostle of German freedom, his courage compared to that of the people who brought down the Berlin wall, a middle-aged department store executive with a very big mustache has emerged as the most talked-about man in Germany.
His name is Gunter Biere and his much-discussed revolution has consisted in opening the large Kaufhof department store on Alexanderplatz here on a Sunday. In so doing, he defied the labyrinthine shop-closing law intended to insure that Sunday remains a rest day. 
 It is true that his coup occurred as newspapers here pondered how to fill their August columns. It is also true that most Germans are at the beach. The Chancellor is in Positano, an Italian resort, and the substantial Toskana-Fraktion (Tuscany Set) in Parliament has retired to its villas. Still, Germany is about as close to abuzz as it ever gets.
"This is not about me," Mr. Biere, 55, said as he tugged a strand of his mustache out toward his left ear. "It is about changing an absurd situation. Our law on Sunday shopping is as full of holes as a Swiss cheese, and I decided to indulge in a little provocation designed to bring Germany into the modern world."
Mr. Biere should know about Swiss cheeses -- he has been in retailing at various Kaufhof branches for 41 years, rising from an apprentice to store manager. Along the way, he clearly learned how to market an idea.
For there is now little doubt that his brazen challenge to the law, applauded by the 50,000 people who shopped at Kaufhof last Sunday, has touched a nerve in a country increasingly torn between custom and innovation, control and deregulation, and between the different desires of its eastern and western parts.
Kaufhof occupies the building that was formerly the main department store for state-produced goods in Communist East Germany, and that neatly symbolizes the fact that challenges to a stolid, complacent western German society are increasingly coming from the brasher east.
Commenting on the Sunday store opening in what was until 1989 the main square of East Berlin, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung commented that the "conventions of western Germany" were being challenged by a movement "whose message was clear -- free at last."
That may seem a lot for Germany's most serious newspaper to read into buying sheets, shirts or sugar on a Sunday. But then shopping is a lot more than shopping when done on German soil. It is a legally intricate, culturally charged, emotional and sometimes frustrating undertaking.
Its rules are defined with the laborious detail of a tax code, complete with exemptions, special conditions and rigorous deadlines. Its significance is often charged with the weight of a cultural conflict between America's frenzied materialism and the gentler pace of a caring European society.
"Of course the American drugstore has to be open at any time when the cowboy swings by," said Ingo Schwoppe, an official at the union representing about 200,000 store employees. "But ours is a different, less consumerist culture. Our members still think it is important that Sunday be a day for the family."
The current law bans shopping on Sundays in most of the country, except in airports, gas stations and train stations. As a result, some new shopping malls, like the 140-store complex in Leipzig opened in 1997, have been built in train stations.
Stores can generally open until 8 P.M. on weekdays, and until 4 P.M. on Saturdays. But they can open for two hours longer on the four Saturdays before Christmas, and on four Sundays a year, provided they have closed by 2 P.M. on the preceding Saturdays. The rules for the hours personnel can work are more intricate still.
One significant loophole permits Sunday shopping for a limited number of articles -- including sun-cream, umbrellas and souvenirs -- in so-called "tourist areas." These are places German legislators believe tourists frequent. When the Berlin city council extended Berlin's "tourist area" to Alexanderplatz at the end of July, Mr. Biere pounced.
Having prepared his move by having 600,000 "Berlin Souvenir" stickers printed and by reaching an agreement with his 1,000 employees granting a 20 percent pay bonus for Sunday work, Mr. Biere opened the Kaufhof from noon to 5 P.M. Every article sold was labeled a "souvenir."
The success was overwhelming -- sales were 15 percent higher during a five-hour day than during a normal 11-hour day, Mr. Biere said. Most customers were ecstatic. Opinion polls quickly appeared showing broad approval. But the Office for Workers' Protection, which oversees shopping laws, was not amused.
"Souvenirs must be specifically related to the area they are from," said Robert Rath of the Berlin Workers' Protection office. "Putting a little souvenir sticker on a washing machine does not make it a souvenir. Perhaps an iron would qualify if its grip was in the form of the Brandenburg Gate. But only then."
Mr. Rath said a fine of 50,000 marks ($27,500) already imposed on Kaufhof might be doubled if the store opened next Sunday, and the police might be called in to force the store to close. A Berlin court ruled today that Kaufhof cannot open on Sunday, but Mr. Biere said he would appeal the decision.
"Personally I prefer American culture, and I go to America four times a year to shop," Mr. Rath said. "But the law is the law."
Kaufhof has appealed the fine, and Mr. Biere said he was determined to fight on. He has hired 20 new employees to work on Sundays, and argues that Sunday opening could help create jobs in a society with a 10.3 percent unemployment rate. He also sees the issue as an important battle between east and west.
"Only stupid tradition of an old Germany is against this," said Gabriele Muller, who works for a German subsidiary of the United States Can Company in the eastern town of Schwedt and came to Kaufhof to shop. "People work all week, and it only adds to their stress if they cannot shop on Sunday. We should accept our Americanization."
But it was regulation, not deregulation, that cemented the postwar success of Germany's social-market economy, with its emphasis on solidarity, consensus and order. The system is ailing, especially in its inability to create jobs, but the attachment to it remains, especially in labor unions and churches.
"The men and women who wrote our Constitution saw the need to make Sunday a work-free day," said Manfred Kock, the president of the Evangelical Church of Germany. "We should respect them and preserve a day of communal tranquillity for social as much as religious reasons."

HEADLINE: South Africa Blacks Lose Control of Black Empowerment Company

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 5

 BODY:
South Africa's flagship black empowerment company, recovering from an investor revolt that ousted its chairman, has announced a reorganization that creates more accountability to shareholders but means the company no longer will be controlled by blacks.
The revamping of New Africa Investments Ltd., announced earlier this week, may spell the end of the black empowerment trend, a push toward economic equality that gained force with the election of the African National Congress in 1994. 
 From a strictly financial point of view, the move by New Africa Investments is considered long overdue: More equitable ownership rights for shareholders and a more open, understandable corporate structure that could become a model for all South African companies.
The 95 percent of shareholders who now hold nonvoting shares will get voting rights; blacks will control only about 10 percent of the company.
At its height, the black empowerment trend saw the big mining and insurance conglomerates that dominate this economy regularly spinning off subsidiaries and, through tricky financing, handing them over to black control.
But black trade unions and the black investment clubs called "stokvels" are no longer leaping into such arrangements. After a brief fad of investing in them, big investors began to shun these companies.
Most big early deals went sour. The 100-year-old mining house JCI Ltd. was broken up after its black chairman, Mzilikazi Khumalo, was ousted in an insider-trading scandal; its best gold mine passed to the white Kebble family that had backed him. Another conglomerate, Johnnies Industrial, is still headed by Cyril Ramaphosa, a former General Secretary of the African National Congress, but it is really just a holding company with a large portfolio of shares in other companies.
Commenting today on the passing of this brief era, Business Day, a financial newspaper here, reacted with both regret over the failure of an ideal and pleasure that financial standards had prevailed. Referring to New Africa Investments Ltd. by its acronym, it said, "As the cases of NAIL and the likes of JCI have shown, being an owner means little if the owner himself is not on a sturdy financial footing." Defining empowerment only as control, the editorial went on, ignores the value of managing a division or starting a small business.
Dikgang Moseneke, the executive director of New Africa Investments, who introduced the revamping plan, said the company would now concentrate on empowering blacks by employing more of them, training them as executives, and helping the disadvantaged.
The company's structure is to be more like any American or European counterpart: major shareholders will get seats on the board and the company will concentrate on profits. "If we don't add value, we will be prepared to walk the plank," Mr. Moseneke promised shareholders.
The company will split into two divisions, one with interests in insurance and banking, the other in newspapers and radio stations. Then, "like Siamese twins," Mr. Moseneke said, they will be separated into two companies.
New Africa Investments was founded in 1993 when the South African National Life Insurance Company decided to spin off 30 percent of Metropolitan Life, its subsidiary that wrote policies for blacks, and turn it over to black control. As chairman, it chose Dr. Nthato Motlana, an old friend and personal physician of Nelson Mandela.
The insurer, widely known as Sanlam Ltd., is an Afrikaner-dominated conglomerate whose directors thought it wise to lift blacks rapidly into positions of economic power, both to compensate for the damage of apartheid and to curry favor with the African National Congress Government about to be elected. (Sanlam itself was an empowerment vehicle for Afrikaners -- it was founded 50 years ago when the National Party took office, and Government contracts that formerly went to English-speaking insurance companies were steered to it.)
Under the revamping, New Africa Investments will undo the pyramid of holding companies that kept control in the hands of its founders. Pyramid-style ownership is frowned upon in the United States and Britain, but common in South Africa.
For example, despite directly owning only 8 percent of the shares, the Oppenheimer family controls the De Beers diamond-mining company and its sister conglomerate, Anglo American P.L.C., which together once accounted for a quarter of the country's gross domestic product. The Rembrandt Group and Liberty Life, two other big conglomerates, are controlled by the Rupert and Gordon families the same way.
When New Africa Investments was created, there were two classes of stock: 83 million common shares controlled by the directors, and two billion nonvoting N shares sold to outside investors. The common shares were controlled by four family trusts for the benefit of Dr. Motlana; Zwelakhe Sisulu, a member of Parliament and son of the A.N.C. stalwart Walter Sisulu; Mr. Moseneke, who also has A.N.C. connections and is chairman of the national telephone company, and Jonty Sandler, a white businessman who had made and lost a fortune building an amusement park near the black township of Soweto and was considered a wizard at creative financing. The four trusts owned Phaphama Holdings, which owned 96 percent of Corporate Af rica, which owned 55 percent of New Africa Investments.
In April, shareholders revolted. The big banks and insurers who held the bulk of New Africa Investments' stock were outraged at plans by board members to award themselves options worth $20 million and to increase the number of nonvoting shares by 50 percent, particularly since the company's stock had lost half its value since early 1998.
In a humiliating retreat, the board scrapped the compensation plan a day before the annual meeting. A month later, Dr. Motlana and Mr. Sandler resigned.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
AT&T and British Telecom to Buy Canada Mobile Phone Stake

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 5

 BODY:
AT&T and British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today they had agreed to invest almost $1 billion in a mobile phone company controlled by Rogers Communications of Toronto, creating the framework for a cable and phone communications network to take on the domestic giant, Bell Canada.
The investment in Rogers by AT&T and British Telecom is the second foreign deal undertaken by the two phone giants since they formed what was described as a $10 billion joint venture last year. In April, they invested more than $1.8 billion in Japan Telecom. 
 Rogers Communications owns Canada's largest cable television and mobile phone companies. It also has a 16 percent interest in AT&T Canada, which was created in June with the merger of four phone companies that had been competing for long-distance service to business customers. Rogers Cantel is an important subsidiary of Rogers Communications, accounting for 40 percent of its revenue of $2.5 billion last year.
The combination of phone and cable, following the recent pattern of mergers and acquisitions in the United States, has given life to Rogers shares over the last six months, even though the company has seldom made money and has amassed almost $3.4 billion of debt.
Yet Rogers Cantel, which had recently risen amid speculation about possible ventures with foreign partners, fell on the news announced today. On the Toronto Stock Exchange the shares lost 4.9 percent to $31.95 (Canadian), or $21.36 (United States). The parent company's B shares fell 1.6 percent, to $27.90 (Canadian), or $18.65.
Although investors remain intrigued by the broad communications potential of phone combined with cable, the partners in Rogers Cantel are focusing on business customers. Canadian companies, said AT&T's president, John D. Zeglis, "will enjoy the seamless worldwide services they need to compete in the economy of the 21st century."
In the first of a two-step agreement, AT&T and British Telecom will pay $934 million in cash for a 33 percent interest in Rogers Cantel Mobile Communications Inc., after which Rogers Communications will own 51 percent of the mobile phone company. British Telecom will then insure that it participates in future developments by buying one-third of AT&T's 31 percent stake in AT&T Canada for $402 million.
Paul Holman, a vice president of the Dominion Bond Rating Service here, said the investment gave Rogers's mobile phone company more marketing power just as the use of wireless transmission for data is expected to surge. "This brings the international arena to the domestic doorstep," he said.
The parent Rogers Communications also benefits, though indirectly, through the ability to use some of the new investment to help lower its debt, and by establishing a financial rather than just a marketing relationship with the two global giants, Mr. Holman said.
Last month, Rogers Communications took an important step in that direction when the Microsoft Corporation made a $400 million investment in its shares.

HEADLINE: Alliance Set by Exchanges Based in Chicago and London

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange, known as Liffe, said today that they had formed an alliance to give customers electronic access to each other's products, a move aimed at cutting traders' costs and improving their efficiency.
The connection will allow customers to trade futures contracts for securities pegged to short-term interest rates for both markets on one computer screen, officials for the two exchanges said in a joint news conference from Chicago and London. 
 The alliance is set to begin early next year and will provide the exchanges' customers access to both the Merc's Globex2 and Liffe's Connect electronic trading systems.
Officials also said they planned a for-profit joint venture to develop products and services -- a proposal that requires regulatory approval in the United States and Britain.
The move is a response to a growing number of alliances in electronic trading, including a recently approved deal between Eurex -- Liffe's Swiss-German competitor -- and the Chicago Board of Trade, the Merc's rival.
"Partnerships like the one we are announcing today are the wave of the future," said Scott Gordon, chairman of the Merc's board, who began revamping the Merc after his election last year.
In years past, there has been resistance to electronic links between the world's exchanges from traders in United States commodity markets who rely on the "open outcry" method of yelling and gesturing to set prices on contracts for future delivery of everything from uncured bacon to financial securities.
But Mr. Gordon said that has quickly changed -- adding that electronic trading is quickly becoming a complement to open outcry.
The deal is not, however, as extensive as the Eurex alliance with the Chicago Board of Trade. That deal calls for the Board of Trade to acquire Eurex's electronic trading system. But officials at the Merc and Liffe say their alliance is unique because it is an "open" system that allows each exchange to set up more trading alliances.
"This is not one exchange merging with or taking over another exchange," said Brian Williamson, Liffe's chairman. "It is not for the benefit of both exchanges; it's a benefit to our customers."

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Increase by 4,000

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The number of American workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose last week, while the less-volatile four-week average fell to its lowest level in four months.
First-time unemployment claims increased by 4,000, to a seasonally adjusted 279,000, for the week ended July 31, the Labor Department said today. 
 That follows a decline of 40,000 in the previous week, to 275,000.
Even with the rise, last week's level was still the second lowest in two years.
The four-week average for new claims, which smooths out the volatile weekly data, fell to 295,000 last week -- the lowest level since the week ending March 27 -- from 300,000 the previous week.
"The job market is super hot," Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said before the report.
Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News expected jobless claims to rise to 295,000 last week.

HEADLINE: Retailers Report Surprisingly Strong Increases

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The strong United States economy combined with a heat wave blanketing much of the country gave Americans a reason to head to air-conditioned stores and malls in July, pushing retail sales to surprisingly strong levels.
The better-than-expected July sales reported yesterday followed big gains in May and June. As a result, Wall Street analysts expect to see robust second-quarter profits when retailers begin to report earnings next week. 
 Sales in stores open at least a year, a crucial industry measurement, rose 6.1 percent last month, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index. It rose 6.5 percent in June and 5.6 percent in May.
"The sales in July were much better than we thought they would be," said Jeffrey Feiner, managing director at Lehman Brothers Inc. "That shows that the consumer feels good about the economy and just keeps buying."
The big winners in July were the discount chains, as shoppers turned to outlets like Wal-Mart Stores and Kmart for a wide selection and affordable prices.
Also faring well were the specialty clothing chains the Limited and Ann Taylor, and Federated Department Stores, which includes the Bloomingdale's and Macy's chains. Stores offering consumer electronics and jewelry also reported strong sales in July.
Even J. C. Penney, which has been struggling in recent months, reported surprising sales gains last month.
While July is often considered a clearance month, retailers did not have much merchandise to unload this year since sales have been strong in recent months. That means that they sold most of their summer inventory at full price, which bodes well for second-quarter earnings.
Already, the Limited and a few other retailers have said their quarterly profits will top Wall Street forecasts.
One weak spot in July was the Gap, which is typically one of the strongest apparel merchants. Analysts cited a deliberate delay in the introduction of fall merchandise and noted that that weakness in the Gap chain offset a solid showing from its Banana Republic and Old Navy units.
Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, reported that sales from stores open at least a year rose 9.6 percent compared with July 1998, while total sales rose 11.6 percent.
J. C. Penney said that sales from stores open at least a year increased 4.1 percent. Its Eckerd drugstores had a sales jump of 8 percent at stores open more than 12 months. Total sales for Penney rose 8 percent.
Kmart said sales from stores open at least a year rose 3.8 percent and total sales were up 6 percent.
Sears, Roebuck reported that sales from stores open at least a year were up nine-tenths of a percent, but total sales were down 4.3 percent.
Sales were up 4.7 percent for Federated Department Stores open at least a year and total sales increased 15.7 percent. Federated's total sales include revenue from the Internet and the catalogue seller Fingerhut, which was acquired in March.
Dayton Hudson had a 3.3 percent increase in sales at stores open at least a year and a total sales jump of 8.1 percent.
May Department Stores reported that sales from stores open at least a year rose 1.9 percent and total sales jumped 6.4 percent.
Limited said sales from stores open at least a year jumped 7 percent and total sales were also up 7 percent.
At the Gap, sales from stores open at least a year increased 2 percent and total sales rose 22 percent.
Ann Taylor said that sales from stores open at least a year rose 7.2 percent and total sales were up 19.5 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1818 words

HEADLINE: SENATE CONFIRMS U.N. APPOINTMENT AFTER 14 MONTHS

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Senate voted today to confirm Richard C. Holbrooke as chief American delegate to the United Nations, ending a 14-month nomination battle that left the Clinton Administration without a high-profile representative to the United Nations during military conflicts in the Balkans and the Persian Gulf.
The Senate approved Mr. Holbrooke, the former American Ambassador to Germany and the architect of the 1995 peace agreement in Bosnia, on a vote of 81 to 16. 
 No Democrats opposed the nomination. Among the senators voting against confirmation -- 15 Republicans and one independent -- was the majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi.
A spokesman for Mr. Lott, who had questioned Mr. Holbrooke's fitness for the United Nations post, said that the Senator "was too concerned with the apparent ethical lapses of this nominee to give him his vote."
The Clinton Administration hopes that Mr. Holbrooke will inject a new sense of American leadership at the United Nations and that he can repair some of the recent damage done to the relationship between the United States and the world organization.
The relationship has frayed as a result of the Administration's failure to persuade Republican Congressional leaders to pay more than $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations, and because of a perception among senior United Nations officials that the Administration sees the organization as a backwater, with diminishing importance to American foreign policy.
That perception worsened as Mr. Holbrooke's nomination languished month after month, leaving the United States without a permanent representative to the organization.
United Nations officials also were dismayed at the Administration for cutting the United Nations out of the decision-making as NATO warplanes devastated Serbia. They also felt slighted during last December's American-led strikes against Iraq, set off by Baghdad's decision to expel international weapons inspectors, suggesting the strikes were conducted without explicit United Nations approval.
Administration officials believe that Mr. Holbrooke -- whose friends routinely describe him both as the most talented American diplomat of his generation and as a Machiavellian bully of extraordinary ambition -- may be able to find a way to get the back dues paid.
"What has worked on occasion with Milosevic might work with Capitol Hill," said a senior Administration official, referring to Mr. Holbrooke's intense negotiations over the years with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.
When he moves into his office suite at the United States Mission in Manhattan, Mr. Holbrooke will find himself confronted with the problems of rebuilding Kosovo, an issue he knows well from his long service as a diplomatic troubleshooter in the Balkans.
The United Nations has been given the task of administering Kosovo in the aftermath of the NATO-led assault that forced the Serbian military out of the province, an operation that is among the most complex and expensive ever undertaken by the organization, which is already strained for money and resources.
It will also be left to Mr. Holbrooke to defend American interests on a range of other foreign policy disputes involving the United Nations, notably with Iraq, which has found important foreign allies in its effort to have economic sanctions lifted despite Washington's objections.
The vote today was made possible when the last of four Republicans to invoke senatorial privilege announced earlier this week that he had relinquished his "hold" on the nomination. The lawmaker, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, had delayed the vote over a State Department personnel issue unrelated to Mr. Holbrooke. Mr. Grassley voted today in favor of confirming Mr. Holbrooke.
The President announced in June of last year that he intended to nominate Mr. Holbrooke for the United Nations job, replacing Bill Richardson, who became Energy Secretary.
But the nomination was plagued by delays -- first as a result of Federal ethics investigations into Mr. Holbrooke's contacts with embassies after his resignation from a Government post, then as a result of procedural maneuvers in the Senate.
Many in the Administration are waiting eagerly to see what sort of relationship develops in the Cabinet between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Mr. Holbrooke, who was runner-up for her position during President Clinton's second term. Mr. Holbrooke, 58, is close to Vice President Al Gore and is seen as likely to lead the State Department in a Gore Administration.
Although Mr. Holbrooke will technically answer to Ms. Albright in his United Nations post, many who know him well believe he will not fit comfortably into the role of her subordinate.
Ms. Albright released a statement today welcoming the appointment. "I feel certain that Ambassador Holbrooke will serve the American people well at the U.N," she said.
In his own statement, Mr. Holbrooke, who was reported today to be on his way to Alaska for a vacation, said that he was "deeply gratified" by the confirmation vote.
While members of Congress might have questioned Mr. Holbrooke's role in policy-making in the Balkans or his larger philosophy of statecraft, they did not dispute that his resume is one of the most impressive in the Foreign Service since World War II.
He joined the State Department shortly after graduating from Brown University in 1962. He rose quickly after his first foreign posting as a junior diplomat at the United States Embassy in Saigon.
In May 1968, he was sent to Paris as a junior member of the American delegation led by W. Averell Harriman to embark on peace talks with Vietnam. In the 1970's, he left Government to edit Foreign Policy magazine but rejoined the State Department in 1977 as Assistant Secretary of State for Asian and Pacific Affairs in the Carter Administration.
Mr. Holbrooke, who has long been allied with the Democratic Party, left Government again with the election of President Reagan and went to Wall Street as an investment banker.
He remained in New York until the 1992 election of Bill Clinton, who named Mr. Holbrooke Ambassador to Germany and then Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs. It was as Assistant Secretary that Mr. Holbrooke oversaw the arduous negotiations that led to the Dayton peace agreement in 1995, ending the war in Bosnia.
During a 35-minute debate before the Senate vote, Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, said that he knew of no nominee to a foreign policy post "more qualified for the job for which he was nominated."
Senator Joseph Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said that Mr. Holbrooke is "one of America's great natural resources."
Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican, was the only Senator to speak against the nomination during the debate. She called Mr. Holbrooke a "principled man" and said she admired "his dedication, his tenacity." But she said that he was responsible for a Balkans policy she considered a failure.
"I believe our policy in the Balkans is to force factions to live together in an American model when the circumstances are different from anything we have ever had in our country," she said. "I cannot in good conscience vote for someone who has taken our country in the wrong direction."
Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the powerful Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, did not vote. He had agreed not to block Mr. Holbrooke's nomination after the Administration lent its support to legislation he co-sponsored that was intended to reduce the American contribution to the United Nations.
His staff said that Mr. Helms was notified only a few minutes before the vote and could not get back to the Senate chamber in time. A spokesman had no comment when asked how the Senator, who supported the nomination when it came before the committee, would have voted. The larger of the Federal ethics inquiries into Mr. Holbrooke began only days after President Clinton announced his intention to nominate Mr. Holbrooke, when an anonymous letter arrived at the offices of the State Department's Inspector General.
The letter questioned whether Mr. Holbrooke, now an investment banker in New York at Credit Suisse First Boston, had done favors for the firm even before resigning from the State Department in 1996 as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.
The investigation ended in February, when Mr. Holbrooke agreed to pay $5,000 to the Justice Department to settle civil charges that he had violated Federal lobbying laws in his contacts with the United States Embassy in South Korea shortly after his resignation. He denied any wrongdoing in his contacts, which included a request that the American Ambassador in Seoul set up a meeting for him with South Korea's President.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Net Stocks Rebound; Nasdaq Rises

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Internet stocks rebounded yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index for the first time in six sessions, as many investors sought out bargains and Treasuries rallied.
"We saw a major rebound in the Internet stocks today," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation. Even so, many investors appear to be awaiting this morning's report of the national unemployment figures for July. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 119.05 points, or 1.12 percent, to close at 10,793.82, in a turbulent session in which it dropped as much as 108.59 points in early trading.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rallied 8.38 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 1,313.71. The Nasdaq, which had its biggest intraday upswing since mid-April, closed up 25.83 points, or 1.02 percent, to 2,565.81.
Many technology issues swung wildly during the trading session. Ebay, for example, traded as low as 70 9/32 before closing at 92 7/8, up 17 1/8. Amazon.com was ahead 8 13/16 for the day, to 97 1/4. And Yahoo slumped to 110 before rallying to end at 128 3/8, up 7 3/8.
Even America Online, which suffered from word that it may face Internet competition from Microsoft, regained some lost ground. The stock, which was the most actively traded of the day with 57.1 million shares changing hands, plunged to 76 15/16 before climbing back to 83 15/16, down 3 1/2.
Although many analysts had eagerly awaited productivity figures from the Labor Department, they seemed to have had minimal impact in a session that also experienced a flight to quality in the bond market, the successful completion of a huge Wal-Mart financing and a lingering glow from Wednesday's disclosure that the Treasury plans to redeem some debt early.
The productivity gain, which Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, cited in his recent Congressional appearances, was at a slower-than-expected 1.3 percent pace in the second quarter. But unit labor costs, which are considered a crucial measure of wage pressures, grew faster than economists had forecast. They surged to an annual rate of 3.8 percent.
"These are the kinds of data -- the combination of increased compensation and lower productivity -- that are confirming the Fed's fears," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at the Bank of America.
The Federal Reserve policy makers are scheduled to meet Aug. 24 to decide whether the economy is slowing enough on its own -- without further interest rate increases -- to avoid a pickup in inflation.
But Rosanne M. Cahn, equity economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, contended that productivity "wasn't bad" considering the quarter's slowdown in output.
Before the market opens today the Labor Department will report on the employment situation for July, one of the most important Government economic statistics each month.
Among the winners yesterday was I.B.M., which set the pace for the Dow Jones blue chips, rising 4 11/16, to 123 3/16. I.B.M. said its scientists made a major, though early-stage, breakthrough in storage technology.
American Express gained 3 5/8, to 127 1/8, as it announced heavy investment in Internet products.
Union Carbide, which will be acquired by Dow Chemical, gained a further 3 9/16, to 62 15/16, while DuPont rose 2 1/2, to 74. Dow Chemical rebounded 5 11/16, to 124 5/16, after losing 6 1/16 on its Wednesday bid for Union Carbide.
General Motors was down 1 13/16 to 61, and Goodyear declined 1 5/16, to 52 11/16.
Several oil stocks posted hefty gains, with Royal Dutch up 2 3/16, to 62 9/16, with the help of a better-than- expected 4.7 percent profit gain.
Despite the turnaround experienced yesterday, said Peter J. Canelo, a Morgan Stanley strategist, the market is likely to continue to be under pressure from forced liquidation in Internet issues. That "bubble is bursting," he said.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues held a 3-to-2 margin over advancing ones, with 203 stocks making new lows and only 40, new highs. Volume was 854.2 million, up from 781.2 million on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bear Stearns Agrees to Pay Fines of $38.5 Million
Bear Stearns has agreed to pay $38.5 million in fines and restitution relating to its role as the processor of securities trades for A. R. Baron, a small New York brokerage firm that collapsed in 1996. 
 Although the $38.5 million that Bear Stearns has agreed to pay is immaterial to the wealthy firm, the damage to its reputation among clients, creditors and peers will almost certainly be great. Page A1.
 
F.C.C. Relaxes TV Ownership Rules
William E. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said the group had decided to relax rules that have limited television station ownership. The new provisions will allow a single company or network to own two stations in the nation's largest cities. One immediate result of the decision may be a rush by big TV companies to buy stations in cities where they already own a station. A1.
 
Congress Passes Tax Cut Plan
Congress approved a Republican tax cut plan that would lower the income taxes of all Americans who owe them, but President Clinton has said he intends to veto it. A17.
 
Retail Sales Rose 6.1% in July
The strong economy combined with a heat wave blanketing much of the country gave Americans a reason to head to air-conditioned stores and malls in July, pushing retail sales to a surprisingly strong 6.1 percent gain. C7.
 
Gain in Output Slows as Costs Rise
Growth in worker productivity slowed considerably in the second quarter, to an annual rate of 1.3 percent, while unit labor costs surged at an annual rate of 3.8 percent. C2.
 
Majority Stake Sold in Travel Site
Rosenbluth International, the travel management company, bought a majority stake in Biztravel.com, an Internet site for making business travel arrangements. C2.
 
Yield on the 30-Year Treasury Falls
Treasury prices rose for a second day as the pricing of a huge debt issue by Wal-Mart Stores failed to hurt the sale of Government paper. But traders expect that Treasuries could have a difficult time pushing higher in the weeks ahead, with about $44 billion more in debt sales scheduled. The yield on the 30-year issue fell to 6.04 percent from 6.09 percent. C7.
 
Phone Giants Make a Deal in Canada
AT&T and British Telecommunications said they had agreed to invest almost $1 billion in a mobile phone company controlled by Rogers Communications of Toronto, creating the framework for a cable and phone communications network to take on the domestic giant, Bell Canada. C4.
 
France's Bank Struggle Continues
With only a day left before investors must choose sides in France's three-way bank struggle, Banque Nationale de Paris appeared to inch closer to victory in its hostile bid for Paribas, one of two rivals it is seeking to control. But investors in the other target, Societe Generale, appeared deeply split, raising the prospect that a final verdict may fall to French regulators. C4.
 
Abercrombie & Fitch Turns to TV
Abercrombie & Fitch, the clothing retailer that aims its apparel at college-age consumers, is expanding its marketing campaign from magazine-style catalogues to commercials that will run on cable TV and on monitors in stores nationwide. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
F.C.C. WILL PERMIT OWNING 2 STATIONS IN BIG TV MARKETS

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission voted yesterday to relax rules that have limited television-station ownership for most of the century, allowing for the first time a single company or network to own two stations in the nation's largest cities.
One immediate result of the decision may be a rush by big TV companies like the broadcast networks to sweep up any available television stations in cities where they already own a station. As one memo to top corporate officers at a broadcast network put it, "The race is on." 
 Networks and other big station companies want to own more than one station in a market because it increases their presence in areas that are becoming increasingly crowded with other viewing options, like cable and satellite channels. It also allows them to save money on programming and personnel costs and gives them another outlet for shows they own.
For viewers in the biggest markets like New York, the change could lead to more local news and sports programming, which the networks said yesterday they would look to add to their new channels.
For example, in New York, Fox, which owns Channel 5, could buy Channel 31, which is owned by Paxson Communications, or even Channel 9, which is owned by Chris-Craft Industries, and use it for additional programming.
 "For the economic model, it's great to own two stations in one market," said Paul T. Sweeney, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "I think we are going to start seeing a lot of big-ticket deals."
The chairman of the F.C.C., William E. Kennard, said the commission was acting to update regulations that were put into place largely in the 1930's and 1940's to insure a diversity of media choices.
Mr. Kennard called the changes "common-sense rules that recognize the dramatic changes that the media marketplace has undergone" in the last 30 years.
The new F.C.C. standards will allow dual ownership in cities where there are a sufficient number of "media voices," which include all radio and television stations, large daily newspapers and cable systems. Specifically, a city must have at least eight independently owned television stations for a single company to own two. And a company cannot own more than one of the four top-rated stations in any market.
All of the country's top 50 cities have that many, but several have only eight, which may mean "an intense game of musical chairs," as one senior network executive put it. "The 'voice' test means you know you may have to get in fast."
"It's going to be a land rush to some degree," the executive added.
The decision will not result in a wholesale changeover in the control of stations, which had been feared by some station owners six months ago. Still, many industry executives said yesterday that the opportunity to own two stations in a single market was likely to encourage a surge in station sales in the coming months. Networks like CBS and the News Corporation's Fox broadcasting unit are expected to be especially aggressive in seeking second stations in cities where they already own one.
Mr. Kennard said that the F.C.C. enacted the changes because TV station ownership had become a morass of confusing waivers from regulations. Numerous stations, for example, are operated under local marketing agreements, in which one company owns a TV station and controls programming on another station ostensibly owned by another company. Such exemptions, Mr. Kennard said, are a "kind of artifice" intended to circumvent existing limits.
"We are bringing some certainty and coherence to a situation plagued by confusion and rule by waiver," Mr. Kennard said. "The marketplace was crying out for coherence."
The commission voted 4 to 1 for the new system, which enacts rules that spell out more clearly what constitutes ownership of a station, how many stations one company can own and under which circumstances it can own more than one station in a single market.
While it loosened rules on TV ownership, it tightened them for radio stations in some cases, limiting one company to six stations in a city with at least 20 total stations, or seven if the company owns only one TV station. Until now, the F.C.C. had issued waivers allowing one company to own as many as eight radio stations in one market, along with one TV station.
The ruling did not affect ownership of other media, including newspapers. Current rules prohibit newspapers and television stations to have the same owner in the same market, but some dual-ownership situations have been grandfathered in.
The F.C.C.'s decision was widely praised by both industry executives and public-interest advocates. Martin D. Franks, a senior vice president at CBS, said, "Bill Kennard deserves a lot of credit for cleaning up the mess accrued from seven to eight years of regulating by waiver."
Several station groups have been able to operate two stations in markets, usually smaller ones, by winning waivers from the F.C.C. that allowed local marketing agreements.
"Once you create this class of waiver people, it becomes unfair to people who are playing by the rules," Mr. Franks said.
Andrew Jay Schwartzman, the president of the Media Access Project, a public-interest group in Washington, said that while he had hoped for more steps to insure diversity in station ownership, the commission deserved praise for closing loopholes in station-ownership restrictions that had rendered the existing rules unfair.
"Now if you run it, you own it," Mr. Schwartzman said. "It had become like the Wild West. I think over all Bill Kennard did a good job under severe political pressure."
But perhaps most pleased were the owners of stations who may now become the subjects of bidding wars by suddenly unfettered buyers. Among the logical targets is KCAL, an independent station in Los Angeles, which had been put up for bid along with other stations by Young Broadcasting several months ago only to be withdrawn when no satisfactory bid was forthcoming.
Another likely winner is Lowell W. Paxson, whose Paxson Communications owns stations in the 20 biggest cities and 43 of the top 50. Mr. Paxson said he was about to uncork champagne last night.
"If we're going into the duopoly game, we're the prettiest girl at the duop dance," he said.
After struggling for the last two years to begin his own network, one based on family programming, Mr. Paxon said he would now consider offers to sell his holdings. "If I got the right price, I would owe that to my shareholders," he said.
Mr. Paxson said he would also consider a joint venture with a partner who, under the new regulations, could buy as much as 32 percent of his company. He said he had already had some preliminary discussions with potential bidders.
The big station-owning groups, which include the four biggest networks, have actively sought deregulation to expand their holdings. They have argued that with the ever-multiplying array of viewing choices -- including hundreds of cable channels, satellite channels and coming digital channels -- they need to be able to compete by adding more channels of their own.
The F.C.C. now limits station groups to ownership of stations that cover no more than 35 percent of the country's households, and yesterday's ruling did not address that regulation.
Mr. Kennard said that issue was likely to be taken up in the fall, and he has not taken a public position on that ownership cap. "I will have something to say about it then."
All the networks are close to that cap, with Fox and CBS at the limit. Only through this decision on dual ownership can they expand in the short term.
Jessica Reif-Cohen, an analyst for Merrill Lynch, noted that the biggest cities have more than enough stations to go around for acquisitive networks -- 16 in New York, 19 in Los Angeles, 13 in Chicago.
She said that the networks could use a second station for a variety of purposes -- adding programs produced by the existing station's news department, for example, or running repeats of shows that the parent network owns, or to provide a home for sports programs.
Fox has such wide interests in sports, especially in Los Angeles, where the company owns the Dodgers, that KCAL may be an especially inviting prize. "Fox has sports and kids programming, it could fill that channel easily," Ms. Reif-Cohen said.
Fox also has a large library of other programming, including films. One Fox executive noted that a Fox all-movie channel on cable has had little impact so far. "Would that programming be better served on a second broadcast outlet in major cities?" the executive said.
Not every network official saw yesterday's ruling as momentous. One senior executive called the changes "small potatoes" in terms of what the networks need to do to protect themselves financially. The networks, he said, must own many more outlets to compete with cable and other viewing options.
Mr. Schwartzman, the public-interest advocate, called that position nonsense, saying, "The networks are thriving businesses that are not suffering and dying." He argued against further regulation that would open the industry only to owners "with deep pockets."

HEADLINE: Montenegro Moves to Alter Tie to Serbia

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PODGORICA, Montenegro, Aug. 5

 BODY:
In a prelude to a bid for independence, Montenegro said today that it wanted to abolish its federation with Serbia in Yugoslavia in favor of a loose partnership that would allow each republic to go its own way.
A draft plan approved today by Montenegro's government would give it the right to maintain its own army, foreign ministry and currency while remaining loosely linked to Serbia in an "Association of the States of Serbia and Montenegro." 
 President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is almost certain to reject the proposal, in which case Montenegro plans a referendum on full independence.
That possibility has raised widespread fears that Mr. Milosevic might try to intervene with force, as he did in the former Yugoslav republics of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and most recently in Kosovo, the southern province in Serbia.
Montenegro, with 630,000 people, and Serbia, with 10 million, are the only two republics left in Yugoslavia, which began to disintegrate violently eight years ago after the collapse of Communist rule. Montenegro's Western-leaning government has been sharply at odds with President Milosevic over his handling of Kosovo, the economy and foreign relations.
The plan "represents a major step toward a sovereign Montenegro because we are moving from the dead end called Yugoslavia," said Zarko Vukcevic, a member of Montenegro's ruling coalition.
With Serbia regarded as a pariah by many nations, Montenegro has sought to distance itself. The prime minister, Filip Vujanovic, said the plan would free Montenegro to "secure democratic and economic development" and join European and world institutions without "harming" Serbia.
In Washington, the Clinton Administration again expressed its support for Montenegro, and accused Belgrade of trying to strip Montenegro of its constitutional rights and powers. The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said Montenegro's leaders were showing "a measured and rational approach to political and economic reform," which he said the United States supported.
At the same time, the Administration has opposed independence for the republic. "We think that they should continue to work within Yugoslavia to insure their rights are protected," Mr. Rubin said.
The republic's president, Milo Djukanovic has said Serbia would have six weeks to accept or reject the proposal before a referendum on independence would be called.
Mr. Milosevic's spokesman refused to comment.

HEADLINE: School Agency Ignored Report, State Says

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
State investigators said in court papers filed this week that school construction officials were warned of structural problems at a Bronx elementary school two weeks before a section of its wall collapsed in the spring.
The investigators said that despite the warnings, the School Construction Authority "failed to take adequate measures to prevent the collapse or assure the safety of the students, teachers, workers and other persons in and around the school." 
 The investigators work for a special commission that Gov. George E. Pataki appointed to examine possible corruption and mismanagement in the New York City schools.
A 28-foot section of masonry fell into the courtyard of Public School 89 on the evening of April 7, but no one was injured, in part because the school was closed for spring vacation. Construction officials and the school's principal had also immediately closed the courtyard after the initial warning that the wall was unsafe.
A spokesman for the construction authority, which is responsible for the construction and rehabilitation of the city's schools, said yesterday that the commission's charges were unfair. The authority took action as quickly as possible, he said, including closing the area to teachers and children.
The investigators contend that the School Construction Authority has withheld key documents describing the collapse. Lawyers for the commission have asked a State Supreme Court judge to order the authority to turn over the documents.
In the court papers, investigators said they want to know how the construction authority responded to the warnings. The papers note that the authority did not award an emergency contract to fix the wall until after the collapse.
At the time of the collapse, P.S. 89 was undergoing limited repairs, including the replacement of some windows, the court documents said. On March 24, one of the contractors working at the school warned the principal that a section of the brick wall appeared to be unsafe, officials at the Board of Education said. After examining the wall, the principal and the construction authority closed the courtyard.
On April 1, according to documents that the construction authority provided to the commission, an architect examined the wall and reported a problem with the brick facade to authority officials. In the report, he said that the situation was an emergency and "requires your urgent and immediate attention."
An engineer also checked the wall. On April 7, the day of the collapse, he reported that the "condition represents a serious safety hazard" and "should be addressed immediately," according to the court records.
In the court papers, the commission said that the construction authority took preliminary steps to assess the condition of the wall, but never ordered an emergency contract to prevent the collapse. The court papers also said that masonry work was performed at the school several years before the accident, and that the commission also intends to investigate how that work was performed.
A spokesman for the construction authority said yesterday that the commission's charge that the authority failed to safeguard public safety was not upheld by the facts. He said the authority moved as quickly as possible. "We were aware of the crack, we met with the principal, and the courtyard was closed," said Jack Deacy, the authority spokesman. "We sent in engineers who made a survey. By the time they got the survey to us, there was a collapse."
The court papers said that the commission has received documents from confidential informants, including photocopies of construction authority reports about the collapse. The authority did not provide some of these documents after the commission had issued subpoenas, the court papers said.
"From the outset of this investigation, the S.C.A. has consistently attempted to shield itself from criticism and avoid responsibility for its own failures," Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the commission chairwoman, said yesterday. "The agency has intimidated its employees to prevent candid and objective testimony and has withheld critical documents that reflect its mismanagement of a dangerous condition that jeopardized the safety of students and teachers."
Authority officials said yesterday that they have copied thousands of documents in compliance with commission requests. They said that if documents were not provided, it was probably due to an oversight and the problem would be corrected.
"We are bending over backward to cooperate with them," said Charles Stillman, an authority trustee. "Our people are doing their level human best to provide the documents required."

HEADLINE: Arms Sales Are Down Worldwide but U.S. Still Leads in Exports

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The United States remained the world's biggest arms exporter in a sluggish market last year, as the weak economies in Asia and among oil producers in the Middle East dragged global sales to developing countries to the lowest level since 1991, according to an authoritative Government report.
The report, released today by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress, showed that the United States negotiated new agreements to sell $7.1 billion worth of weapons in 1998, nearly 31 percent of the $23 billion in sales worldwide. The United States easily surpassed Germany, which sold $5.5 billion, and France, which had $3 billion in new sales. 
 The United States also led the world in delivering arms ordered in previous years, making $7.8 billion worth of deliveries in 1998.
Russia, which four years ago briefly knocked the United States out of the spot as the world's top arms merchant, has seen its exports steadily drop, despite increases in sales of fighter aircraft and other weapons to China. In 1998, Russia reached agreements to sell only $1.7 billion worth of arms, compared with $3.3 billion in 1997 and $5.3 billion in 1996.
The $23 billion in worldwide arms sales showed a slight increase over 1997, when the worst of the Asian economic crisis hit, but it was far below the levels in the early 1990's, when the collapse of the Soviet Union and the Persian Gulf war led to an arms-buying spree. In 1993, arms sales worldwide reached $37 billion.
Arms sales to the developing world -- defined in the report as all nations except the United States, Russia, Western Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand -- dropped sharply overall. But the United States increased its sales to those countries to $4.6 billion, from $2.6 billion the year before.
The report predicted that the Asian economic troubles and the relatively low prices for crude oil would prolong the slump in arms purchases by developing countries, which until recently have accounted for a majority of international arms sales.
"Competition for available arms sales continues to intensify among major weapons suppliers," the report said. "The limited resources of most developing nations to expend on weapons and the need to many selling nations to secure cash for their weapons continues to place constraints on significant expansion of the arms trade."
The report said Saudi Arabia, in particular, was struggling to keep up with earlier purchases and that the country, the world's largest arms buyer, had trouble meeting the monthly payments for its contracts.
Thomas A. Cardamone Jr., an analyst for the Council for a Livable World Education Fund, which advocates arms control, said the report's findings underscored the fact that the United States was continuing to put more arms into the hands of others than any other country.
He noted that the United States retained its dominance of the international arms markets without any multibillion-dollar sales being completed. Instead, most sales involved less costly items, including upgrades to existing systems. "It's $7 billion worth of spare parts," he said. "Without a major arms sale last year, the U.S. still leads the world."
This dominance is likely to grow, he added, if the United States completes pending deals. Israel is to purchase $2.5 billion worth of F-16's, and the United Arab Emirates nearly $8 billion worth of the planes.
