HEADLINE: A Battlefield of Dreams for Iowa Farmers

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: DYERSVILLE, Iowa

 BODY:
All that really happened here is that someone shot a movie.
It's not the house where Elvis was born. Or the theater where Lincoln was shot. In fact, what is striking is how people can get nostalgic over make-believe these days, steered by the emotional pull of a vivid Hollywood invention. 
 But that is not how people here see it. They consider themselves custodians of a slice of the American dream. They paint it as a battle between entrepreneurial freedom and the moment that a landmark, even a made-up landmark, becomes too commercial.
And since it is an American story, it is, of course, also about baseball.
The place is a cornfield in eastern Iowa where Hollywood built the set of "Field of Dreams." The 1989 movie was a sensation, a fanciful, sentimental story of a farmer (Kevin Costner) who hears a voice telling him to build a baseball diamond in his field -- "If you build it, he will come" -- and is rewarded with the magical appearance of his dead father and the unfairly maligned Shoeless Joe Jackson.
Suddenly, as the film's famous line promised, some 50,000 people a year did start coming to the baseball diamond in the cornfield.
People still come, but now the object of their pilgrimage is ensnared in a bitter disagreement between the farm couple who own most of the outfield and the farm couple who own most of the infield. One side feels the other has over-commercialized things and is going to court to try to stop it.
Each side has its own entrance sign. Don and Becky Lansing, who own right field, most of the infield and the white farmhouse used in the movie, have a sign proclaiming their property the "Original Field of Dreams Movie Site" and calling the gravel road to their side the "main entrance."
Steps away, on a parallel gravel road, Al and Rita Ameskamp, who own left field, most of center field, third base and the cornfield from which the movie's phantom ballplayers emerge, have a sign promoting "Left and Center Field of Dreams" and directing visitors to "enter here."
Each side has a gift shop, with the Lansings selling white pickets from the movie fence for $25 apiece and the Ameskamps selling $2 vials of "dream dirt" from the field, complete with an "affidavit of authenticity" signed by Al and Rita. (Both shops, incidentally, sell "temperature-sensitive" T-shirts featuring a cornfield that reveals baseball players when the shirts get warm.)
This summer, for the movie's 10th anniversary, the Ameskamps wanted to attract tourists with a cornfield maze, shaped like Shoeless Joe at bat, with trivia questions along the way, like Who directed the movie? (It was Phil Alden Robinson.) They got their property rezoned for the maze, and since July 31 they have charged visitors $6 to walk through.
To the Lansings, who say they want the movie site to be "authentic" and not "over-commercialized," this was the last straw. The couple, who no longer allow organized events, like ball games, on the infield, have filed to try to prevent attractions like the maze in the future.
"Everything we want to do, they say no," Mrs. Ameskamp said. "Sometimes it brings tears to your eyes. We love our Field of Dreams."
Mrs. Lansing, who says her side wants only to make enough money to keep up the site, was asked if the two farms could mend fences.
"What's going to make Communist countries and non-Communist countries come together?" she retorted. "What's going to make men and women come together? What's going to make blacks and whites come together? We're just trying to protect this piece of heaven. We want to tell the world that preserving historical sites is important."
This friction saddens the author of the book on which "Field of Dreams" was based, W. P. Kinsella, who is on Christmas-card terms with both families and is not offended by the corn maze.
"It's too bad that they can't get along because I think they both sort of want the same thing," Mr. Kinsella said from his home in Chilliwack, British Columbia. "The Lansings sell souvenirs and stuff, so what's the difference? People expect that sort of thing from a tourist attraction. If I were the Lansings, I would certainly make a buck out of it."
Mr. Kinsella noted that in his book, "Shoeless Joe," and the movie, the seemingly foolhardy step of plowing up corn for a ball field drew people willing to pay $20 apiece.
"I would go by the book, by my book," he said. "If I owned the property, I'd be charging $20. After all, this is America."
Truth be told, for a figment of Hollywood and a tourist site that could easily turn kitschy, the Field of Dreams is remarkably unspoiled. Anyone can come without charge and hit balls, run bases or stroll the cornfield where the actors James Earl Jones, Ray Liotta and Burt Lancaster disappeared.
Except for a highway billboard (paid for by the Lansings) and competing tourist brochures and Web sites, there is little promotional hoopla. And people go miles out of their way to recapture the movie's nostalgic air, rekindle father-son relationships or play ball with tourists they do not know.
The ball field was built on two farms because the movie people needed both to get the sunset lined up the way they wanted. After the filming, Mr. Lansing built the first souvenir stand. Mr. Ameskamp plowed under his portion and planted corn for a year or two, until tourists asked for the outfield back.
In the early cinematic afterglow, the farms jointly managed their famous base paths and cornstalks. They allowed Buick and Wheaties commercials and a fantasy camp.
In 1995, Becky, 45, came as a tourist from Colorado and met and married Mr. Lansing, 57, who grew up on his farm.
Things began to change. The Lansings say they felt the movie site's essence would be compromised by commercialism. They objected in 1996 when the Ameskamps leased their property and made a profit-sharing arrangement with a group called Left and Center Field of Dreams, financed by four out-of-state investors and run by a former Dyersville farmer. The group manages the gift shop, the maze and the Ghost Players, who stage baseball exhibitions in old-time uniforms.
The Ameskamps, 63 and 59, farmers here for 32 years, say they were about to retire and merely wanted things managed by skilled people.
When the Ameskamp side sought zoning board permission for batting cages and a gift shop expansion, the other side lobbied successfully to block the cages and to allow the shop to grow only as big as the Lansings'.
At some point, the Lansings stopped organized infield events, including free Ghost Players exhibitions. (The players, several of whom were in the movie, now emerge from the corn and play only on left and center field, putting down makeshift bases.) A July 4 tournament held this year by the Ameskamp side to promote putting Shoeless Joe in the Baseball Hall of Fame held games on community ballfields.
The Lansings have also put up signs that say things like "The souvenir stand at third base is operated by an out-of-state investment banking firm and is not associated with the Lansing farm or family."
This summer, the Ameskamps decided to rezone part of their farm commercial so they could charge admission for attractions like the maze without getting approval each time. Mrs. Lansing has filed to get the zoning overturned, warning that commercial zoning could lead to "hotels, bowling alleys, bus depots."
Keith Rahe, who manages Left and Center Field of Dreams, said the rezoning barred permanent structures. He said his side wanted only occasional events like baseball demonstrations, which he said would help Dyersville, a town of 3,700 that rests on a limping farm economy and whose other attraction is the National Farm Toy Museum. Mr. Rahe added that the events would bring money to the Lansings, too.
"You have this trivial little squabble over this," Mr. Rahe said.
Mrs. Lansing said it was hardly trivial.
"You think the Field of Dreams and the issues that involved one of the most popular movies at the end of the 20th century is petty and small?" she said with a gasp. "You think it's silly for us to protect a vision? It's not petty. It's huge."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Wall Street Salaries Up 10 Percent in '98

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Wall Street traders and investment bankers earned almost $200,000 on average last year, a 10 percent jump over 1997 that dwarfed the raises of other New York City workers, said a state report released yesterday.
The report, by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, said the earnings gap between Wall Street and the rest of the city continued to widen in 1998 despite pay advances in other sectors. Workers outside the financial arena earned an average of $41,700 last year, a 5.2 percent increase over 1997. 
 "In the last five years," Mr. McCall said, "Wall Street salaries have shot up 72 percent while salaries in the rest of the city's economy have only grown 17 percent."
The pay gap highlights another distressing fact for many city residents: bulging wallets and sizzling profits on Wall Street are pushing prices for Manhattan real estate and rental apartments out of reach for many workers.
Economists, however, say there is a trickle-down effect. Herbert Gans, a professor of sociology at Columbia University, said well-heeled Wall Streeters patronize expensive shops and restaurants, which employ lower-paid workers.
Beyond the trickle-down effect, Mr. McCall warned that the city's dependence on Wall Street profits put it at risk if the sector should hit a downturn. Financial services employees earn 18 percent of the total wages in the city, but hold only 4.8 percent of all New York City jobs.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
30-Year Yield Isat Highest In 20 Months

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Yields of United States Government bonds surged yesterday to their highest level in 20 months after the Labor Department's July employment report added to the mounting concern that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month.
Federal Reserve policy makers raised the target rate for overnight lending by a quarter-point, to 5 percent, on June 30. 
 "The strength depicted in the July employment report assures an Aug. 24 Federal Reserve firming," Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond dropped 1 20/32 to a price of 87 19/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed to 6.17 percent, from 6.04 percent on Thursday, the highest since 6.20 percent on Nov. 20, 1997. For investors, the day's loss amounted to about $16.25 for each $1,000 invested in bonds.
Over the last two weeks, three inflation signals have pushed bond prices lower: yesterday's wage data, Thursday's bigger-than-expected increase in unit labor costs and last week's jump in the Government's employment cost index.
The Government reported yesterday that the economy had added 310,000 jobs in July, while wages rose half of 1 percent and the unemployment rate remained at 4.3 percent. All pointed to an increased threat of inflation.
Jack Ablin, president of Colonial Asset Management Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., said the strength of the bond market's decline had done much to remove uncertainty about the timing of the next interest rate increase.
"The bond market certainly has been betting the Fed will raise rates, but the question up until now has been the timing of such a move," Mr. Ablin said. "Now market participants are pretty sure and are positioning themselves for an August Fed move."
Also weighing on bonds is a heavy schedule of Government and corporate issues, starting with next week's $37 billion Government quarterly refunding.

HEADLINE: Nairobi Embassy Blast Survivors Still Struggling

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Until Aug. 7, 1998, one year ago, Douglas Sidialo was a car salesman who drove around Nairobi for his job. He tells a dark little joke about why that line of work is closed off to him now. "If I drove cars," he said, "I would knock people over."
He was blinded completely by glass and debris that exploded through his windshield that day when terrorists bombed the United States Embassy here. More than 200 people were killed and 5,000 wounded here and in a simultaneous attack on the American Embassy in Tanzania. 
 His story is one of the more inspirational. He started a group of survivors -- called, with a vein of irony, Visual Seventh August -- to provide counseling and job training and to watch over how aid money is spent. He wears a smile and sunglasses, both oversized, and works hard to set an example for other victims without his resilience.
"I can't reverse the blast," Mr. Sidialo, 29, said. "I have to accept what happened and move on."
Yet he still has no job. The other day he went to the local Red Cross, along with perhaps 100 other victims of the blast, to pick up free food -- a few bags of cornmeal and cooking oil -- to help him survive.
The bomb may have been aimed at Americans, as many people here bitterly remind each other, but there is no question that Kenyans have suffered the most. A year later, they are still coming to terms with such devastation. It has been hard even for the optimistic ones, like Mr. Sidialo, and simply grim for others.
And so the nation's recovery from the bomb blast has come with its own set of victories and setbacks.
Many Kenyans, split by ethnic, religious and class differences, say the blast gave them a greater sense of unity, just as they pulled together a year ago hauling the wounded from the rubble or donating blood en masse. A Government fund to compensate victims apparently did not fall prey to the nation's legendary corruption.
Some outsiders who have helped Kenya recover from the blast -- the United States has donated $42.3 million -- say they have noticed subtle differences in Kenyan society, some out of bomb-related necessity.
"When I started, mental health was seen as a service only provided to people who were blatantly psychotic," said Dr. Lorin Minless, a Boston psychiatrist who is a consultant for counseling services for some 2,000 bomb survivors and their families. "The idea of getting help outside of the family didn't exist. The bomb blast helped sensitize people."
But on some level the unity was short-lived. People have not even agreed how to commemorate the bombing's anniversary, marked in a weekend of rallies, concerts and other events: there are four separate memorial services on Saturday, each claiming to be the official one.
And the money handed out by the Government that was supposed to make life easier for the victims has backfired in some cases, the compensation squandered or stolen.
Doreen Auma's husband, a shoe salesman, was killed in the blast. As she took his body to western Kenya for burial, she said, his family decided not to recognize the marriage and emptied their house of everything: furniture, dishes, even the stove.
Of the roughly $9,200 that the Government paid for her husband's death, his family took $6,500. Now she is nearly broke.
"I have spent everything," Ms. Auma, 25, she said as she, too, collected the free Red Cross food to feed their two children, ages 6 and 7.
There is also still much anger in Kenya over the blast. Some of it remains directed at the United States, criticized in the early days for seeming to care more about the 12 Americans killed than the more than 200 Kenyans. Now, with unemployment sky-high and per capita income dropping, many people say the United States should do more.
"What the Americans gave to the victims was not enough," said Julius Mashalia Isalambo, 37, a grocer in downtown Nairobi. "It's like we are fighting their war."
Mr. Isalambo is not a victim of the blast and, interestingly, most of the victims themselves say they do not blame the United States, even though some 2,500 of them have joined in class-action lawsuits against the United States Government.
Francis Gitu Maina, 33, clenched his fists on a recent evening when asked if he was angry at anyone over the blast.
"So much," he said. But he said he blamed "the ones who came to bomb," suspected to be Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile, who has denied any role in the bombing, and his suspected associates, eight of whom have been arrested.
"If they did not bomb, I would not be in this trouble," Mr. Maina said.
His trouble is worse than most: he was on the No. 126 bus, stalled in traffic in front of the embassy, when the explosion went off. He spent four days in a coma, then four months in the hospital.
He lost his right eye and cannot see well in his left. He can barely walk, because his right leg was broken so badly. When his wife saw that he could not provide anymore, he said, she left with their two children.
"I was the king of -- " he started to say, then stopped. "I'm the husband. And now I got that trouble. That is why she went."
He said his life was now divided between the doctor and sitting alone in his little room with walls and roof made of tin in the town of Kiserian, about an hour southwest of Nairobi.
A former clothes hawker, he has no clear vision of the future, except that he would like buy a little plot of land, build a few apartments and start selling clothes again. But he does not have the money.
"The situation is very bad," he said. "When I think about my life before, I don't feel good."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Indexes Fall as Jobs Report Fans Fears of Rate Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks resumed their slide yesterday, as a strong report on employment solidified Wall Street's belief that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 79.79 points, to 10,714.03, erasing more than half its 119-point gain on Thursday. 
 The blue-chip index ended a choppy week 58.08 points higher, a gain of half a percent. For the year, the Dow average is up 16.69 percent.
Broader stock indicators like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index fell modestly yesterday, capping a week of steep losses. The S.& P. index was down 13.42 points, to 1,300.29, and is up 5.78 percent so far in 1999. The Nasdaq composite index declined 17.86 points, to 2,547.97, and is up 16.2 percent so far this year.
Stocks tumbled after the Labor Department reported that employers added a larger-than-expected 310,000 jobs to payrolls in July and that average hourly earnings, an important gauge of inflation pressures, rose 3.8 percent from a year ago.
Investors have grown increasingly worried that tight labor markets will force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as a pre-emptive strike against inflation. Higher interest rates cut into corporate profits by raising the cost of borrowing.
"If the Fed needed fuel to consider raising rates, they have it now with these new numbers," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president at Fahnestock & Company. "The strong jobs report tilted the optimists upside down."
The Labor Department also reported the unemployment rate remained at 4.3 percent last month, near a three-decade low.
"That pace of job growth is unacceptable to the Fed," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Interest rate concerns hurt financial services stocks as J. P. Morgan and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter fell. Those businesses would see lending volume shrink if higher interest rates made it more expensive to borrow money.
"The stock market is trying really hard to fight reality right now -- interest rates will probably be rising," said Brian G. Belski, chief investment strategist at George K. Baum & Company in Kansas City, Mo. "But some sectors can't escape the selling pressure."
While the broad market was down, bargain hunters were buying certain technology issues, most notably semiconductor stocks. Strong forecasts for personal computer sales have supported the stocks of companies that make computer parts.
Internet companies, which rallied sharply Thursday, struggled once again. Yahoo slipped back from early gains despite a ratings upgrade from Goldman, Sachs. It closed at 126 15/16, down 1 7/16. America Online also struggled to hold on to a gain and closed up 13/16, at 84 3/4.
Ebay, the on-line auction site, plunged as its system shut down. It slumped 9 5/8, to 83 1/4.
While most market indexes ended the week fairly flat amid low volume, trading was volatile all week.
"It's tough to call all the turns in this market," Mr. Ackerman said. "It is like the Indianapolis 500. Everything keeps changing lap after lap."

HEADLINE: Pastor of Harlem Church Nominated to Head SUNY at Old Westbury

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d has been formally nominated to be president of the Old Westbury campus of the State University of New York, a job he said he would welcome. He would retain his role as pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, one of New York City's most influential religious institutions.
Old Westbury's College Council, an advisory board, issued its recommendation of Mr. Butts on Wednesday to the Chancellor of SUNY, John W. Ryan. A spokesman for Mr. Ryan said yesterday that he would probably approve it and send it to the board of trustees for ratification. 
 The board is aiming to vote on Aug. 16 or soon afterward, in time for Mr. Butts to assume the post at the Long Island campus by the start of the fall semester on Aug. 31, said Jon Sorensen, vice chancellor for university and government relations. The recommendation, which came just eight days after the search committee held its first meeting, has stirred controversy on campus. The Faculty Senate has charged that the search was rushed and politically tinged, and has sent a letter of protest to Gov. George E. Pataki.
But Mr. Butts, who has never held an academic position, is thought to enjoy wide support among the 16-member board of trustees, 15 of whom were appointed by Mr. Pataki. Mr. Sorensen said that a well-known figure like Mr. Butts could help recruit students and dollars to a campus that has struggled with declining enrollment and other maladies.
Mr. Butts, once known for fiery criticism of mainstream politicians, has forged ties with Mr. Pataki in recent years. The Governor appointed him an unpaid member of the board of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state-financed economic development agency. In a move that angered other black leaders, Mr. Butts endorsed Mr. Pataki's bid for re-election last year.
Mr. Butts has contemplated entering politics, possibly as a candidate for Congress or the mayoralty. He said yesterday that he would set aside those aspirations if offered the presidency of Old Westbury.
"I feel good about assuming the position," said Mr. Butts, adding that he would not leave the stewardship of the Harlem church, which has long served as a source of social and political action.
"I would remain as pastor," Mr. Butts said. "It is the soil in which I am rooted."
He said the church had a long tradition of ministers' splitting their time with other work, including Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and his predecessor, Samuel Proctor, who held professorships for much of the time he served as pastor.
Mr. Butts declined to say how he would juggle his duties and split his time between Harlem and Old Westbury, which is 22 miles from Manhattan in Nassau County. Mr. Sorensen said that the university would work out housing arrangements for Mr. Butts but that plans were not yet firm. The position pays $112,411 to $141,910 a year, but no salary has yet been negotiated.
Mr. Butts, who is 49, said he hungered for the challenge of leading the campus, which has 3,700 students, roughly half of them members of minority groups.
"I feel very comfortable about this," said Mr. Butts, who has been with the church since 1972 and pastor since 1989. He attended Morehouse College in Atlanta and the Union Theological Seminary in New York, and has a doctorate in church and public policy from Drew University in Madison, N.J. "College presidents and ministers have enjoyed unique roles of leadership, and I hope to continue that in some form or fashion," he said.
Nevertheless, leaders of the Faculty Senate, an advisory panel that sets some school policies, have questioned the haste with which Mr. Butts was recommended and the appearance of political overtones.
The president of the Senate, Gretchen Johnson, who is a professor in the teacher education program, sent a letter to Mr. Pataki yesterday complaining that Old Westbury had not followed SUNY's guidelines for recruiting presidents. Those guidelines call for, among other things, a national search and the development of a list of 20 candidates. The letter also raised questions about the timing of Mr. Butts's candidacy, coming just as the Legislature passed a law allowing nearly 200 acres of the 600-acre campus to be transferred to the university's foundation for leasing to private sources.
"A wide variety of sources have linked you, and Republican political patronage, to every major player in these events," Dr. Johnson wrote to the Governor.
Mr. Butts's candidacy was advanced in part by a SUNY trustee, Randy Daniels, who serves on the board of the Empire State Development Corporation with Mr. Butts, something Dr. Johnson and others in the Senate take as a clear indication of political favoritism.
Dr. Johnson also questioned whether Mr. Butts could be "an independent and vigilant steward" of the college's interests as it examines the development of the property to be leased by the Old Westbury Foundation, which is seeking to raise millions of dollars by leasing space for such things as a baseball stadium for the college team, a high-tech office park, a criminal justice institute and other uses.
T. R. Ahlstrom, the executive director of the foundation, said that anything built would have "a very clear educational nexus," and Mr. Butts promised a careful review of any plans.
William R. Howell, the chairman of the campus College Council, said that any suggestion of political motivations behind Mr. Butts's nomination was "absurd on the face of it."
Mr. Pataki stood behind Mr. Butts as well.
"Calvin Butts is an innovative leader who would be a positive force for the students at Old Westbury," said Charles Deister, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki. "It is unfortunate that there are always defenders of the status quo who will complain about change."
Mr. Sorensen, the vice chancellor, said that the committee was free to conduct the search as it pleased, and pointed out that the guidelines were just that, and should not be construed as regulation or law. He said that the timing of Mr. Butts's candidacy and the approval of the legislation was a coincidence and that he believed that faculty members were upset that the College Council had not recommended the interim president, W. Hubert Keen.
Old Westbury has been without a full-time president since June 1998, when L. Eudora Pettigrew, who had drawn no-confidence votes from the faculty, stepped down.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Volvo to Buy Another Swedish Truck Maker for $7.4 Billion

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
In a $7.4 billion deal that will create the world's second-largest maker of trucks and buses, Volvo A.B. of Sweden is buying one of its archrivals, the Swedish truck maker Scania.
The agreement, announced yesterday in Sweden, comes just 15 months after the merger of Chrysler and Daimler created the world's largest truck and bus maker. 
 Under the terms of the deal, Volvo will buy the 49 percent of Scania's shares now owned by Investor A.B., the holding company that is the main investment vehicle for Sweden's wealthy Wallenberg family.
Volvo will pay Investor 315 Swedish kronor a share, or about $38.55, in cash for 60 percent of the shares; the rest of the payment will be either in cash or in a swap of six shares of new Volvo stock for five Scania shares. Volvo also said that it will offer a similar deal for all remaining outstanding shares of Scania.
The deal did not surprise analysts, who had been expecting Volvo to announce an acquisition ever since it sold its car business to the Ford Motor Company earlier this year. "No one thought they were getting out of passenger cars so they could sit around idly and reap 5 percent on their cash," said James N. Kelleher, an analyst with Argus Research.
Rumors have emerged throughout the year that Volvo was looking at Deere, Case, Navistar, Cummins Engines and other players in the truck market. "This takes a little heat off other companies that thought they were targets," said Robert S. Murley, an investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Actually, there were early signs that Volvo had its sights set on Scania. Volvo had been accumulating Scania shares throughout 1999, and already owned 13 percent of its rival when it began negotiating with Investor to buy its stake.
Still, Volvo's and Scania's shared nationality makes the deal a bit unusual in the rapidly consolidating truck industry. It has been far more common for companies in different countries to set up alliances, if not full mergers, in order to take advantage of each other's markets.
General Motors, for example, has a 49 percent stake in Isuzu of Japan. The partnership gives G.M.'s truck division an edge in Asian markets, while the link to G.M. helps Isuzu in the United States and Europe.
Earlier this year, there was speculation that Fiat of Italy would try to buy Investor's share of Scania.
For most of these companies, more is at stake than added truck revenue. Many automotive companies view sales of commercial trucks as a way to establish their brands in emerging economies.
The Scania-Volvo deal will create a truck manufacturer that had combined sales of $15.8 billion last year, and a work force of about 76,000. Scania will remain a separate unit in Volvo, with its own brands and distribution networks, but the sister divisions are expected to combine purchasing power, eliminate duplicate overhead and otherwise cut costs.
Scania's American depository receipts rose $7.1875 or 24 percent, to $37.50. Volvo A.D.R.'s fell $2.50, or 8.3 percent, to $27.50.

HEADLINE: With Fiscal Battle Plans Drawn, Lawmakers Begin Recess

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
With passage of a $792 billion tax cut secured, Congress left for its August recess early today and set the stage for a high-stakes autumn confrontation with President Clinton over the nation's fiscal priorities in the new era of projected Federal surpluses.
The battle over how to divide the expected $3 trillion windfall among tax cuts, Federal programs and debt reduction through the next decade is the most far reaching of many ideologically charged policy disputes expected to be joined in the fall. Others include debates over gun control, regulation of managed care and an overhaul of the campaign finance laws. 
 On one of those issues, managed health care, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert tried to divide a group of Republican dissidents today by pledging to bring to the House floor a bill that will include some expansion of the right of health plan members to sue their plans. His decision was the first time that Republican leaders have put forward such a provision, and it created a rival bill to one agreed to Thursday by Republican rebels and House Democrats.
So far this year, with the razor-thin margin in the House heightening the partisan competition, the two parties in Congress have put less focus on legislating than on sharpening their differences for the 2000 campaign. And Republicans believe their tax cut will help shape their identity next year.
It is far from clear whether the President and Congress will be able to reach some grand compromise on tax cuts, spending, Medicare and perhaps health care legislation after Mr. Clinton makes good on his promise to veto the Republican tax cut measure.
This month both parties expect to wage a battle for public opinion. The Republicans have said they would hold town meetings across the nation to showcase different aspects of their tax cut, which, if adopted, would be the largest since 1981. It has elements intended to appeal to an array of constituency groups including social conservatives, women and business.
The Democrats plan to highlight their call for some of the surplus to be used to overhaul Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.
Mr. Clinton sounded the Democratic rallying cry today, by again vowing to veto the Republicans' tax cut. "I am disappointed, though not surprised, that the majority party in Congress has chosen to pass its massive tax cut, one that plainly would damage our economic future," Mr. Clinton said at the White House before leaving for Arkansas.
"I want to insure the American people, because this tax cut will not save and strengthen Medicare, because it will not add a day to the Social Security trust fund, because it will not pay down the debt and pay it off for the first time in 150 years, this tax cut will not become law," the President said.
The Republicans, who see the tax cut as the crown jewel of their legislative program, predicted that their bill would resonate with the American people and that public opinion would force Mr. Clinton to embrace it.
Senator Trent Lott, the Mississippi Republican who is majority leader, said that if Mr. Clinton vetoed the bill "it will be the strongest indication so far that he is entering the phase of being a lame duck, because it will say to the Congress, the American people, 'I don't care what you say or do, I'm going to veto this and I'm not going to work with you.' "
Mr. Clinton has proposed a far smaller tax cut of $250 billion, and prefers to use some of the surplus to expand Medicare and increase spending on such domestic programs.
But some Republicans believe that Mr. Clinton, with little more than a year left in his Presidency, will want to burnish his record. That yearning, they say, will lead him to strike a bargain with Congress, where Republicans will get large tax cuts in exchange for the new Medicare prescription drug program that he has proposed.
"He's got one more year," said Representative Joe Scarborough, Republican of Florida. "He's run his last campaign. He would like to have a good tax cut and some good reforms. I don't know how to say it without sounding cliched -- he's playing for history."
Democrats counter that Mr. Clinton considers the healthy economy his proudest accomplishment and that he will not strike a compromise that does not begin to pay down the Federal debt.
"They are misreading what is motivating the President," Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, said of the Republicans. "What motivates him is that he has achieved a very good economy and he has made some real strides on crime and education. And he doesn't want to make a deal that would compromise or jeopardize those accomplishments."
There is another factor this year that provides an incentive for a stalemate. During the days of deficits, an inability to act meant that the deficits grew. But this year if the parties cannot agree on a tax cut, the surpluses automatically go toward paying down the nation's $5.6 trillion accumulated debt. Both sides say it might not be so bad if they do not reach agreement and take their competing visions into the election.
"There's a sense that we've done something if we've done nothing," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader.
Beyond fiscal issues, the fate of other high-profile legislation is also unclear. Many of the topics on the fall agenda -- campaign finance overhaul, managed-care regulation and gun control -- are favorite issues of the Democrats. Republicans view these confrontations as ones they cannot win, and will try to dispense with them with minimal damage. They will hope to do as little as possible while Democrats will be leery of accepting weak compromises.
A signal of the intensity of the struggle came today when Mr. Hastert and other Republican leaders agreed just before 2 A.M. to allow a managed-care proposal, which is being assembled by two Republicans, Representatives Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and John Shadegg of Arizona, to move forward in the fall.
Their decision was prompted by an announcement by dissident Republicans on Thursday that they had reached agreement with House Democrats on comprehensive legislation. They predicted they would rally a majority of the House around their bill.
Dr. Coburn, a family physician, and Mr. Shadegg were still drafting their rival measure, which was expected to be similar to the bipartisan plan. But Dr. Coburn has said that he wants to keep the right to sue provisions more limited than in the bipartisan measure. He would require patients to prove that they were injured before they could sue.
The second bill created an even fiercer battle over 20 to 30 Republicans who could decide what kind of managed-care bill passes the House. But Democrats were expected to oppose this version because it would contain several tax credits meant to help the uninsured obtain coverage. That would likely include tax-free medical savings accounts, which Democrats oppose, saying such accounts would draw the healthiest and wealthiest people out of the insurance pool.

HEADLINE: Banking Expert Nominated To Be Fed ViceChairman

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
President Clinton yesterday nominated Roger W. Ferguson Jr., a management and technology expert whose monetary views are not widely known in the investment community, to be vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Ferguson, who has served as a Fed governor for two years, was a banking industry consultant and partner at McKinsey & Company in New York before he joined the Fed. He is viewed as an expert in the operations of banks and financial institutions, an important specialty as the Year 2000 nears. Only the third black American appointed a Fed governor, he would be the first to serve as vice chairman. 
 While the appointment would raise Mr. Ferguson's profile considerably, the Fed's decision-making will still be dominated by its chairman, Alan Greenspan. The seven Fed governors form the core of the 12-member Federal Open Market Committee, which sets interest-rate policy.
If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Ferguson, 47, would replace Alice Rivlin, who resigned last month to rejoin the Brookings Institution.
Mr. Ferguson, who was not widely known before his appointment two years ago, was brought to the attention of Clinton Administration by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, a classmate of Mr. Ferguson at Harvard University. Before McKinsey, Mr. Ferguson was an attorney at Davis Polk & Wardwell, a New York law firm. He received degrees in economics and law, both with honors, from Harvard, where he later received a Ph.D. in economics.
The nomination follows Mr. Clinton's selection Thursday of Carol Parry, a former senior executive at Chase Manhattan Bank and an expert in community reinvestment laws, to replace Susan Phillips, a Fed governor who resigned last year.
The Administration is a strong proponent of community reinvestment laws, but Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, chairman of the Banking Committee, has sought to restrict the laws. A spokeswoman for Mr. Gramm's committee said Friday that both "nominations came in too late for Senator Gramm to have a chance to look at the papers, so he won't have a comment until after" Congress resumes in September.
Asked about Mr. Ferguson by reporters, Mr. Clinton responded: "He is superbly qualified. He has served well. And I am very excited about the prospect of his service. I'm glad he's willing to do it."
Mr. Greenspan said in a statement that Mr. Ferguson is "a person highly respected by his colleagues," and "an outstanding public servant, with broad experience and sound judgment."
Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Schroder & Company and a former Reagan Administration budget official, said Mr. Ferguson's monetary policy views are little known in the investment community. "There may be a discovery process here," Mr. Kudlow said. "Up till now, he's compiled a voting record in accordance with Greenspan, and I think around the Fed he is viewed more as a management consultant and administrative guy."
But Mr. Kudlow added that the appointments of Mr. Ferguson and Ms. Parry "may create the potential for two inflation doves who might be at loggerheads with the chairman's view or certain hawkish views" among other board members.
Ms. Rivlin advocated the view that the economy is better able now to grow without inflation than in past years, and she was more sympathetic than other governors to the notion that growth and lower unemployment was an acceptable trade-off for the risk of a slight increase in prices.
At his confirmation hearing two years ago, Mr. Ferguson emphasized that he believed the Fed's most important mission was price stability. The Fed's legislative mandate also calls for it to promote maximum employment, but under Mr. Greenspan, it has stressed inflation control. Mr. Ferguson also said he was concerned with issues like income inequality and job creation.
The other African-Americans to serve on the Federal Reserve were Andrew Brimmer, who was nominated by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1966, and Emmett Rice, who was nominated by President Jimmy Carter in 1979.

HEADLINE: Violence Among Israelis Sets Off National Wave of Soul-Searching

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 6

 BODY:
His hair a shellacked, platinum blond, his face framed by a pair of hoop earrings, Miki Abutbul, 16, an Israeli from a working-class suburb, was sprawled with friends on plastic chairs in a crowded pedestrian walkway in central Jerusalem just after midnight this morning, talking about violence in Israel.
"Even my 10-year-old brother carries a knife," Miki was saying when shouts of a nearby fight suddenly pierced the cool air and sent him and the rest of the crowd scurrying in different directions. 
 Within minutes, army troops and policemen descended on Zion Square, broke up the trouble and arrested two Israeli youths.
"For every small thing someone seems to pull a knife these days," offered Miki's friend, Shai Hugi, 16.
Israel has always had a rough edge, always been a society where aggression and rudeness were accepted as byproducts of life under siege. But there has been an abrupt shift in this view in recent months.
After several exceptionally brutal crimes -- two men killed their wives and children and set their bodies on fire -- and new studies detailing the level of brutality in the schools, there has emerged an intense focus on violence among Israelis that has temporarily pushed aside the historic focus on conflict with the Arabs.
"We have to deal with this exactly as we have dealt with terrorism," said Zeev Friedman, director of health, welfare and social services for the city of Tel Aviv, "because this is nothing less than an internal form of terrorism."
While there are no firm data showing a rise in violence, what has changed, many experts suspect, is Israel's sense of itself, its attitude toward such behavior.
Since the fear of war is lower than it has ever been and Israel's links to the West, especially the United States, are closer than ever -- a result of cable television, computers, commerce and increased travel -- Israelis are less willing to excuse shortcomings in their society as byproducts of the need to survive.
Others say the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 was a watershed, when suddenly it seemed that life had become cheap in Israel.
Today's issue of the dominant daily newspaper, Yediot Ahronot, illustrates how widespread that view is. Although Israeli-Palestinian relations are tense over land-for-security arrangements, and the new Government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak seems to be getting ready to negotiate the return of the strategic Golan Heights to Syria, neither issue made the front page.
The main article concerned the latest attack of a feared figure known as the Tel Aviv Rapist. A second article told of a paroled convict who visited his girlfriend and threw her baby daughter out a window. The dealings with the Arabs were relegated to inside pages.
Since the focus on internal violent behavior is so recent, there are virtually no data to confirm the widely held view that violence in Israel, a nation of six million, is on the increase or that the increase is due partly to the arrival of so many people from the former Soviet Union in the last decade.
Data for many forms of violence have been collected only for the last five years and show mixed trends. Spousal and school violence, two areas of particular focus in the press, have shown no increase in that time. The number of homicides declined from 79 in the first half of 1998 to 61 in the first half of 1999.
"We are less involved today with security problems," noted Zemira Mevarech, chief scientist at the Education Ministry, who recently called for a comprehensive program, including rewards for teachers and staff, aimed at reducing school violence. "As concerns over security go down, the focus on quality of life goes up."
American influence is significant. When two Colorado students went on a shooting spree in their high school in April, killing 12 fellow students and a teacher, the story was big news for days here. Many commentators suggested that such a massacre could happen here, since a recent study showed that 7 percent of high school students carried weapons.
Moreover, the latest hero in the Israeli press is Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, whose name is invoked frequently by those who think that policing of minor and major crimes in Israel has been lax.
Last month, an Israeli artist named Gil Mitchell was knifed to death after asking two men not to scrape his car with theirs. That prompted Haim Yavin, the state television's long-serving news anchor, to offer a rare Op-Ed article in the newspaper Haaretz and call on Israel's police to take a lesson from New York's.
"A metropolis of crime, drugs and dirt has become one of the most flourishing cities in the world," Mr. Yavin wrote of New York. "Mayor Giuliani's task has been to teach millions of New Yorkers to respect the rule of law."
Israelis should take a lesson, he added: "Today, Israel is more than a little similar to the New York of 20 years ago. Instead of the rule of law, we have the rule of the knife and the revolver."
The idea that Israel is following an American path or should learn from the United States is in marked contrast to how this country saw itself two or three decades ago. Then, when Americans faced decaying cities, drug addiction and violent youth, most Israelis happily noted that their country was different.
American problems were seen as a result of American societal conditions, including the lack of mutual concern and cohesion that characterized Israel in its early decades.
Today, American-style problems and American-style solutions are seen as almost inevitable, since this country has come to resemble the United States more than ever. The economy, for example, once one of the world's most egalitarian, is now characterized by a huge gap between richest and poorest.
The Police Ministry is trying to learn how police officers in the United States deal with domestic violence. It is widely suspected that since the Israeli police tended in the past to focus on external, meaning Arab, threats, they had little training and little interest in domestic crimes.
A new program trains detectives in such work, and there will soon be a doubling of the 170 detectives assigned to such tasks.
The Education Ministry is trying to devise an American-style curriculum that teaches pupils sensitivity toward one another and reduces violent confrontations. Tel Aviv is seeking help from Los Angeles on how to fight domestic abuse.
But more Israeli-style approaches are also being contemplated.
"Just like every Israeli has been trained over the years to report a suspicious package in the street in case it is a terrorist bomb, today Israelis need to learn to detect signs of domestic violence around them so that lives can be saved," suggested Mr. Friedman, the Tel Aviv director of social services.
Yossi Harel of Bar-Ilan University, outside Tel Aviv, spent 11 years at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, where he was in charge of the youth survey system and helped plan surveys for some 30 countries on youth health and violence.
The most recent study, for 1998, shows Israel eighth out of 28 countries on the question of what percentage of youths have been bullied at school. For Israel it was 50 percent. That was behind the United States, in 18th place with 34 percent.
When Professor Harel published the results of the first such study in 1995 with similar results for Israel, he said, no one took it seriously. But when he published the 1998 results this year -- including the finding that more than half of the students in grades 6 through 10 were involved either as perpetrators or victims of violence -- the ground was fertile and his study became major news.
"It took a long time to build awareness that we really have a problem on our hands in terms of the banality of violence as a part of daily life for Israeli youth," Professor Harel said. "Kids here use verbal and physical violence to cope. My interpretation is that as a society and system we have failed to provide the youth of this country with alternative resources for coping with frustration and anger."
He said violent attitudes were endemic throughout society -- on the roads, in Parliament, in public places, on television talk shows -- and the youth were drinking it all in.
The problem is also difficult in the home. Malka Soffer, head of the crime victims section in Israel's national police, said that until the early 1990's, spousal and child abuse were treated by the police as occasions to mediate between offender and victim rather than act as law enforcement agents.
Today there are special instructions, and domestic abuse is considered a crime of great urgency, she said. "Today we think that if a violent crime is committed within the family, it is more severe than if it is committed among strangers, because of the risk of repetition," she said.
Feminists have been raising concerns over spousal abuse here for several years. But many Israelis had trouble believing that Jewish husbands were really guilty of such activity. Accepting that such problems exist in Israel has been part of the country's maturation, some say.
"There was this big myth that Jewish husbands wouldn't do this sort of thing," said Ronit Lev-Ari, director of the department of family violence prevention for Naamat, a women's group. "But we are like everyone else. It may be very sad for some, but Israel is normal.
"Like elsewhere, most Israeli husbands who beat their wives were themselves beaten as children and, like other societies, we need to learn to stop them and to treat them."

HEADLINE: Political Notes;
On Spending, Pataki Has His Own Math

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 6

 BODY:
What will the inflation rate be for the next year? For Gov. George E. Pataki, the question is not academic.
He voiced two goals for this year's state budget: saving the surplus and increasing spending no faster than inflation. He succeeded on the first count. On the second, well . . . 
 The New York Times, among others, reported that the budget approved this week raised spending faster than inflation. No big deal -- Mr. Pataki's stance was a bargaining position, and he still gets credit for banking the surplus and increasing spending only modestly.
But his aides have worked hard to persuade reporters that the budget really, truly grew less than inflation, and by doing so they have drawn more attention to the issue. For a Governor looking for national prominence in the Republican Party, this apparently matters.
For the record, the Consumer Price Index rose 2 percent in the last year. The new budget, by the administration's own estimate, raises spending 3.8 percent. But Joseph Conway, spokesman for the Governor's Division of Budget, insists that what matters is not the whole budget, but the half called the General Fund, which is slated to grow 2.4 percent.
Yet that figure was arrived at by accounting legerdemain that moved items into other funds. And even that number is above most economists' inflation predictions.
So, is it below inflation? Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, replied simply, "Oh, please."
 
A Rush to Cash Checks
State legislators don't often stand in line -- they have people who do that for them -- nor are they known for getting an early start on the day.
But at 8:30 Wednesday morning, just seven hours after the Assembly had adjourned the previous night, several lawmakers were queued up when an office near the Capitol opened to dispense the first paychecks they had received in four months. Under a new state law, as long as the budget was late, legislators were not paid. The Assembly passed the last budget bill at 1:33 A.M. Wednesday, 126 days late.
Senator Dale M. Volker, a Republican from the Buffalo area, said that when he left home for Albany this week, "My wife said, 'Don't call me back until you pass a budget and get paid.' " His marital communications are no doubt better now, but like many of his colleagues, he had to borrow money to get by.
Legislators grumbled bitterly -- about their debts, about putting off needed purchases or home repairs -- but mostly off the record, for fear it would sound like whining. One New York City Democrat said, "You try going four months without pay and see if you don't whine."
The new law was supposed to speed the state's creaky budget process. Not even close. "I think all it did was aggravate people," Mr. Volker said.
 
Motive Behind the Money
For four years, the Governor has frozen money for AIDS programs. Last year, the Legislature added a few million dollars, but Mr. Pataki vetoed the addition.
But groups that work on AIDS prevention and assist people with the disease were caught off guard this week, when Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver secured a $6 million increase for the programs. It was more of a surprise that Mr. Silver took the money from the pool used for lawmakers' pork-barrel projects.
Some advocates were elated, calling it an act of principle by the Speaker. But others surmised that Mr. Silver was making amends for the Assembly's passage last year of a law, opposed by AIDS groups, requiring that the names of all people who test positive for the virus that causes AIDS be reported to the state.
"Like anything else that happens here, it's not entirely without political content," said Michael Kink, lobbyist for Housing Works, a group that finds housing for people with AIDS. "But there's a public health benefit, too, so we don't care why it happened."
 
Echoes of a Special Election
 For the second time this year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may be wishing there never was a special election in May to fill a State Senate seat from Rockland County.
The Senate's Republican leaders, by their own admission, pulled out all stops to hang on to the seat, promising projects for the district, and hinting at legislation for interest groups.
The New York City correction officers' union endorsed the Republican, Thomas P. Morahan, who won. On Thursday, the Senate passed a bill allowing those correction officers to draw money from the city's pension fund and pocket it. Democrats called it the Senate Republicans' payback for the support of Mr. Morahan.
The bill was slipped onto the Senate calendar on the last day of the 1999 session, and many Senators had not seen it until an hour before the vote. Now, the bill, which had already passed the Assembly, goes to the Governor, who has not said whether he will sign or veto it.
Mr. Giuliani has complained bitterly about the bill, which he says will cost the pension fund and the city more than $100 million a year. (The union says $6 million.) Aides to the Mayor thought the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who has been promoting Mr. Giuliani's undeclared candidacy for the United States Senate, would not allow a vote on the bill.
Four months ago, state lawmakers, their eyes squarely on the Rockland race, abolished the city's tax on suburban commuters, over Mr. Giuliani's strenuous objections.

Drug-Trafficking Charges For Wife of U.S. Colonel
The wife of a U.S. Army colonel involved in counternarcotics operations in Colombia is facing Federal charges for shipping a total of 15.8 pounds of pure cocaine to the United States earlier this year. Laurie Anne Hiett, the wife of Col. James Hiett, has denied any illegal activity. A1

New View on India Killings

HEADLINE: Giuliani Vows To Veto Bill Regulating Food Markets

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
The City Council and the Giuliani administration are heading for a showdown over proposed legislation that the Council says would protect the rights of employees at New York's wholesale food and produce markets.
Administration officials said yesterday that the legislation would only make it harder to keep the markets free of organized crime. 
 The bill, which will be the subject of a public hearing on Tuesday held by the Council's Economic Development Committee, seeks to amend a 1997 law that regulates public markets, including the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx and the Gansevoort Meat Market in Manhattan. A separate law governing the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan might also be amended.
Among the changes proposed by the Council is one that would guarantee the rights of employees and their unions to picket directly in front of a business involved in a labor dispute. Another provision would limit the liability of employees for legal violations related to their employers' equipment, shifting the responsibility for such violations to employers.
Bruce R. Bender, chief of staff to the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said employees in the markets were often subject to large fines for violations like driving an unregistered forklift; the Council believes those fines should be the employer's responsibility. And he said guaranteeing the right to picket was a matter of constitutional law.
"This is America," he said. "You should be allowed to protest." Pickets are now restricted to public streets outside the markets.
The bill would also allow labor unions, wholesale trade associations and other market businesses to register with the city's Department of Business Services once every five years, rather than once every two years as currently required. And it would give businesses and their officers 30 days to report some specified occurrences to the city, as opposed to the current requirement of immediate reporting.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who made his name crusading against the mob as a United States Attorney, considers rooting out organized crime from the city's public markets and the various laws intended to keep those markets free of mob influence to be high among his achievements. His aides said yesterday that he would veto the legislation if the Council passed it.
"This bill is not about employees' rights," Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota said. "This bill is about diminishing the power of the administration in ridding the public markets of organized crime."
He added that the bill as it was written did not have the support of the administration and would be subject to a veto. He said the bill would "coddle the interests of organized crime."
Mr. Bender said the Council had been negotiating with the administration in hope of reaching a compromise and that several recommendations from the Mayor's office had been incorporated into the bill that would be discussed at the public hearing. He called the proposals fair and said the Council would not back down.
"If we can't compromise, we'll go toe to toe," he said.
The Democratic majority in the Council, if united, could override any veto by Mr. Giuliani, who is a Republican. But forcing such a battle could prove politically risky for the Council -- particularly for Mr. Vallone, who is contemplating a run for mayor in 2001 -- given Mr. Giuliani's reputation as a crusading crime fighter. And Mr. Giuliani is likely to go to great lengths to twist legislators' arms.
The strong opposition by the administration came as something of a surprise to Council officials, who this week had thought a compromise might be at hand. Of five proposed changes to the law, the officials said, there were agreements on three, and the Mayor's office had proposed two additional changes that the Council accepted.

HEADLINE: Jobs and Pay Grow, Stoking Inflation Fear

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Employers hired new workers at a surprisingly robust pace last month and had to pay substantially more to find them, the Government reported today.
While good news in most respects, the report underscored the mounting pressures in the labor market and significantly increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its next meeting, on Aug. 24, as a hedge against an upward spiral in wages and prices. 
 The unemployment rate in July remained steady at 4.3 percent, the Labor Department said. Employers added an estimated 310,000 nonfarm jobs in the month, 50 percent more than analysts had anticipated, suggesting that economic growth rebounded early in the summer after tailing off in the spring.
Average hourly earnings in July rose by one-half of 1 percent, to $13.29 from $13.23, continuing a gradual acceleration of wage growth in recent months. Earnings in July grew 3.8 percent over the previous year, up from a 3.5 percent annual pace in May and a 3.7 percent annual rate in June.
"Labor is getting more expensive per hour, and we're still using a lot of it," said Donald Ratajczak, the director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University.
On Wall Street, which is far more attuned to the dangers of resurgent inflation and higher interest rates than to the benefits of full employment and rising wages, stock and bond prices fell.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 79.79 points to close at 10,714.03. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond plummeted, sending its yield, which moves inversely with the price, to 6.17 percent late in the day, from 6.04 percent on Thursday.
With the economy eight and a half years into an expansion that has kicked promptly back into high gear every time it has shown signs of flagging, the Labor Department's report showed that job growth, adjusted to take account of normal seasonal variations, was strong in almost all industries.
Of special note was a jump of 31,000 in manufacturing employment, the first increase in that sector since General Motors workers returned from a strike last August, and the first not related to the strike since March 1998. Manufacturers had been hit especially hard last year by the fallout from the global financial crisis that began in mid-1997.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said last month that the central bank was watching intently for any signs that the combination of low unemployment and strong job growth was generating wage increases that could ignite inflation.
Some economists said today's data provided more than enough ammunition for the Fed to raise its benchmark Federal funds target rate by another quarter-point later this month, to 5.25 percent. The central bank raised rates by a quarter-point June 30. At the time, it said it was concerned that wage growth in a tight labor market could outstrip the strong gains in productivity generated by huge investments in computers and other technology.
The economists said that today's numbers reinforce a trend seen in various economic reports in the last few weeks. These include signs of a decline in the growth of productivity, or hourly output per worker, and a rise in the wage component of the employment cost index.
"The data confirm the reacceleration in the economy that I've been looking for in the summer," said Richard Berner, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He estimated that growth is now running at an annual rate of 4 percent, up from 2.3 percent in the second quarter.
"At the same time they also suggest we're seeing the impact of tight labor markets on wage-setting," he said. "The gentle acceleration we're seeing in average hourly earnings confirms the trend we're seeing in the employment cost index and means the Fed will almost certainly tighten policy on August 24."
Based on trading in the futures markets, investors are all but certain that the Fed will raise rates this month to 5.25 percent. Futures contracts on Federal funds for September, which will come due after the Fed's meeting, already yield 5.23 percent.
Other analysts said that the case for a rate increase this month was not air tight, though they acknowledged that if the Fed did not move this month it would probably do so at its next meeting in October.
The Fed cut interest rates three times in quarter-point increments last fall when economies and financial markets around the world showed signs of seizing up. Many analysts now expect the central bank to rescind the remaining two of those cuts and perhaps tighten policy a bit more in the next six months or so if the economy remains strong.
That prospect is already generating political pressure on Mr. Greenspan not to squeeze the economy too hard in an effort to eliminate inflationary pressures that so far have been more theoretical than real. Despite rising wages, general price increases so far have been well contained, and some sectors of the economy, including agriculture and manufacturing, complain that monetary policy is too tight.
Steve Forbes, the Republican Presidential candidate, began running radio advertising this week in Iowa, ground zero in the dismal farm sector, criticizing Mr. Greenspan for pushing rates too high at a time when crop prices are depressed. The National Association of Manufacturers released a pointed analysis today concluding that even an acceleration in labor cost growth to 4 percent would result in only a small pickup in inflation.
Still, Mr. Greenspan has made clear his view that an ever-tighter labor market is a threat to generate inflation and endanger the stability of the long expansion. Should it continue, the current expansion will surpass at the end of this year the record set in the 1960's. And while the unemployment rate has hovered at 4.2 to 4.3 percent since March, the pace of job creation has picked up in recent months.
The 310,000 new jobs created in July "followed a 273,000 gain in June and was well above the average monthly increase of 208,000 for the first half of 1999," said Katharine G. Abraham, the Labor Department's commissioner of labor statistics. "Manufacturing and construction employment increased over the month, and several service-producing industries posted sizable gains."
The rate of job growth in the last year is still relatively moderate at 2.3 percent, said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Bank. But he said that even at that rate the pool of available workers is being steadily depleted because the labor force has been growing at only 1.4 percent.
In Congressional testimony last month, Mr. Greenspan said that "if the pool of job seekers shrinks sufficiently, upward pressures on wage costs are inevitable," and that such wage increases "have invariably presaged rising inflation."

Job Creation Surged in July; Jobless Rate Unchanged
Employers added an estimated 310,000 nonfarm jobs in July, 50 percent more than analysts had anticipated, suggesting that economic growth rebounded early in the summer after tailing off in the spring. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate in July remained steady at 4.3 percent, the Labor Department said. 
 The report underscored the mounting pressures in the labor market and substantially increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its next meeting, on Aug. 24, as a hedge against an inflationary spiral in wages and prices. Page A1.
 
Clinton Nominates a Bank Expert
President Clinton nominated Roger W. Ferguson Jr., a former management consultant whose monetary views are not widely known, to be vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Ferguson, who has served as a Fed governor for two years, was a banking consultant and a partner at McKinsey before he joined the Federal Reserve. C2.
 
Dow Jones Average Falls 80 Points
Blue-chip stocks resumed their slide. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 79.79 points, to 10,714.03, erasing more than half its 119-point gain on Thursday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 13.42 points, to 1,300.29, and the Nasdaq composite index declined 17.86 points, to 2,547.97. C4.
 
Yields of Treasury bonds surged to 6.17 percent, from 6.04 percent on Thursday, the highest since 6.2 percent on Nov. 20, 1997. C4.
 
Jury Awards $23 Million in Diet Suit
In the first verdict from among thousands of cases pending against makers of the diet pills popularly known as fen-phen, an east Texas jury awarded $23.36 million to a woman who said she suffered heart damage after taking the drugs to lose weight. A7.

In a $7.4 billion deal that will create the world's second-largest maker of trucks and buses, Volvo of Sweden agreed to acquire its archrival Scania. The agreement comes just 15 months after the merger of Chrysler and Daimler created the world's largest truck and bus maker. C2.
 
G.M. Moves Toward Daewoo Deal
A General Motors executive said the company had signed an agreement with South Korea's struggling Daewoo Group that could lead to an alliance between G.M. and Daewoo Motor, Daewoo's core holding. A deal between the two companies would help G.M. increase its share of car sales in Asia, while for Daewoo it would bring much-needed capital as well as management expertise. C2.
 
French Bank's Bid Still Uncertain
The Banque Nationale de Paris chairman told a French daily he was certain of obtaining "indisputable power of control" over Societe Generale and that Banque Nationale had firm commitments through investors to get more than 50 percent of Paribas shares. But the statements by Michel Pebereau fell short of asserting that Banque Nationale would receive enough voting stock in Societe Generale to assert clear control. C2.
 
Standoff Over Bank of Japan Eases
Japan's Liberal Democratic Party said it would not press the Bank of Japan to buy Government bonds that are likely to be used to finance further fiscal stimulus programs. Economists had viewed a standoff over the issue as a test of Japan's commitment to free market principles, including maintenance of a central bank free of political interference. C2.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
New Haven Gets a Grant For Clock Factory Plan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
The City of New Haven has been awarded a $490,000 Federal economic development grant to help finance its Clock Factory Redevelopment Project, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development said yesterday.
The project is for a site that for more than 100 years was the home of the New Haven Clock Company. but has not been used for 20 years. The grant money will be used for demolition and preparation for a proposed 30,000-square-foot addition to a factory next door. 
 The addition to the factory will mean 25 jobs will be saved and 20 jobs created, said the factory's operator, Palmieri Food Products Inc.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BOOK OF HAPPINESS, by Nina Berberova. (New Directions, $23.95.) Set in the years surrounding the Russian Revolution, this novel of passionate candor allows its characters to love without irony and to speak ingenuously about what they really want (including happiness).
 
THE colony of unrequited Dreams, by Wayne Johnston. (Doubleday, $24.95.) An eloquent biographical anti-epic novel whose protagonist, the nebbishy but effectual Joseph Smallwood, betrays its real hero, the great, mysterious island of Newfoundland, into incorporation with Canada.
 
FRANCE ON THE BRINK, by Jonathan Fenby. (Arcade, $27.95.) A British Francophile -- the most hardened, inveterate kind -- reports on a France that he sees turning into just another country, with supermarkets, Marlboros and boring bread.
 
IN SEPTEMBER, THE LIGHT CHANGES: Stories, by Andrew Holleran. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Finely made stories, sharply awake to the idioms, cadences and concerns of gay life in the late 20th century, obsessionally aware of the passing of friends, health and youth.
 
ITALIAN FEVER, by Valerie Martin. (Knopf, $22.) Consciousness rather than plot develops in this novel that uses Italy as background to examine the effects of lovemaking on its reflective heroine.
 
THE PALACE, by Lisa St. Aubin de Tern. (Ecco, $23.95.) Glittering, passionate, minute description of material acquisitions enhances this novel about a former political prisoner who rises in society and builds a palace for the girl of his dreams.
 
REMEMBERING RANDALL: A Memoir of Poet, Critic, and Teacher Randall Jarrell, by Mary von Schrader Jarrell. (HarperCollins, $22.) NO OTHER BOOK: Selected Essays, by Randall Jarrell. Edited by Brad Leithauser. (HarperCollins, $27.50.) A charming, personal but discreet memoir of the last years of the astute and generous critic, by his second wife; and an essay collection that fairly represents his best work.
 
SAINT AUGUSTINE, by Garry Wills. (Lipper/ Viking, $19.95.) An informed rendering of the life and thought of the small-town African (A.D. 354-430) who became the most durable of theologians; usefully translated from the Churchly (for "Confessions," read "Testimony").
 
STILL WATERS IN NIGER, by Kathleen Hill. (Triquarterly/Northwestern University, $24.95.) Memory and anxiety are intertwined in a lyrical autobiographical novel, set in West Africa, that illuminates the losses and lapses of motherhood.
 
WHO DO YOU LOVE: Stories, by Jean Thompson. (Harcourt Brace, $23.) Emotional needs are rarely stated and more rarely met (romance and family don't help) in these quiet, devastating, all-downhill-from-here short stories.
