LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: 'The Utmost Mental Awareness'

BYLINE: By Paul Mattick; Paul Mattick is the author of "Social Knowledge" and editor of the International Journal of Political Economy.

 BODY:

Walter Benjamin
Selected Writings: Volume 2, 1927-1934.
Edited by Michael W. Jennings,
Howard Eiland and Gary Smith.
Translated by Rodney Livingstone
and others.
Illustrated. 870 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The Belknap Press/
Harvard University Press. $37.50. 
 I HAD just finished a couple of recent academic books on Walter Benjamin, the German philosopher and critic who killed himself while fleeing the Nazis in 1940, when this second volume of his selected writings came into my hands. No change of scene could better confirm Benjamin's judgment, made in a letter to a friend even while he was struggling to win a professorship, that university life was not for him.
When Benjamin's writing is obscure it is not because he uses jargon to signal membership in a restricted caste but because of the singularity of his thought and style, a singularity that for the most part expresses itself in prose that is clear, strong and illuminating. Even the ideas he shares with others of his time, like his insistence on the revolutionary effects of photography on visual and social experience, emerge in new forms shaped (to cite his description of Proust's writing) by "the constant attempt to charge an entire lifetime with the utmost mental awareness" and to put that charge in words.
For those who know only the small selection of essays and longer texts previously translated into English, this book may be a revelation. "Selected Writings: Volume 2," spanning the period from his abandonment of academia and his emergence as an important literary journalist in 1927 to his near silencing after the Nazis seized power and his exile in 1934, shows the writer at his sparkling best. His determination to "be considered the foremost critic of German literature," together with his need to earn a living, led to a stream of book reviews, meditative essays, travel pieces, radio lectures and occasional pieces written for newspapers and other periodicals. All his published work of this time is included here, from a few longer essays on themes as varied as the history of photography and Kafka to three-page pieces on recent French fiction, art history, "the crisis of the novel," food and the effects of hashish.
The new book also includes a generous selection of Benjamin's notes, diary entries and drafts. Interesting in themselves, and indispensable to anyone seeking insight into Benjamin's thinking, they also offer a view of the writer at work, developing different aspects of a thought or recycling successful paragraphs from one assignment to another. The book includes a useful chronology of Benjamin's activities and extensive notes for which (despite a few errors) readers will be grateful; the number of things -- from turn-of-the-century German litterateurs to political events -- that the editors feel it necessary to identify indicates the depth of the vanished culture Benjamin took for granted in his readers. Oddly, length restrictions in the Frankfurter Zeitung, the newspaper in which he published regularly, complemented Benjamin's devotion to the aphoristic, fragmentary style of German Romanticism, recast as modernist montage or collage.
Taken as a whole, these writings show Benjamin's response to two great influences: modern French literature and the Communist movement that emerged from World War I. Benjamin was well enough known as a critic of French writing to win an exclusive interview when Andre Gide visited Germany in 1928. Despite his lifelong admiration for Gide, he was most affected by Proust (he translated four volumes of "Remembrance of Things Past") and by the Surrealism of Louis Aragon and Andre Breton, which extended the archetype presented by Proust's madeleine to the transformation of Parisian monuments into real-world dream symbols. Benjamin applied the lesson to the Berlin of his childhood: "But isn't this, too, the city -- the strip of light under the bedroom door on evenings when we were 'entertaining'?" he asks in "A Berlin Chronicle," recovering an evanescent detail in which all the exciting promise of "night life" seems to glimmer on the other side of the child's bedroom door. And in the morning the daylight world of labor and so of class difference arises with "the carpet beating that came in at the window . . . and engraved itself more indelibly in the child's memory than the voice of the beloved in that of the man -- this carpet beating that was the language of the nether world, of servant girls, the real grown-ups."
The effective, if indecisive, break with the upper-middle-class expectations of his parents that Benjamin achieved with academic failure threw him into the "crisis of the intellectual" that preoccupied the Weimar intelligentsia, for whom the problem of making a living in a period of runaway inflation was combined with the problem of assuring themselves of their significance under novel social circumstances. Just as Benjamin found in the furniture and habits of his childhood milieu an objective correlative of his class origins, he took Communism to embody a solution to this personal and professional preoccupation. Having lived through the German revolutionary upheavals of the early 1920's without, apparently, engaging with them, he discovered Marxism-Leninism first in the person of a Latvian actress and director, Asja Lacis, whom he met on Capri in 1924, and then in a friendship with Bertolt Brecht, whose knuckleheaded opinions on literary and political matters he felt compelled to grapple with, though not to accept.
Benjamin's inability to distinguish Marxism from the Stalinism into which Leninism was rapidly turning was due to the same distance from actual politics that allowed him to take Marxist materialism as a version of the Surrealist idea that people's relation to everyday objects provides a key to the understanding of social experience. Whatever its limitations, however, his version of Marxism gave him the idea of "the author as producer" (the title of a famous essay of 1934), a participant in the social division of labor rather than a free-floating emanation of "Spirit"; it freed him to see the literary world he inhabited more clearly than many another writer. In a short article on Goethe's house in Weimar, for instance, this idiosyncratic materialism allows him to turn a simple travel piece into a meditation on the past and present of literature: reflecting on the simple furnishings of Goethe's home, dedicated exclusively to sleep and work "before the hellish dawn of bourgeois comfort began to cast its light in at the window," he saw in the poet's modest bed, chairs and desk "the forces that bade a world give him answer when he struck the sounding board of his innermost being." Today, he said, we "have to make an entire world resound in order to cause the feeble overtone of our inner being to ring out."
Benjamin celebrated Breton for perceiving "the revolutionary energies that appear in the 'outmoded' -- in the first iron constructions, the first factory buildings, the earliest photos, objects that have begun to be extinct, grand pianos, the dresses of five years ago." Such things embody the modernist dream of progress that modern society, with its world wars and daily destructiveness, reduces to ruin; to value them is to reject the world as it exists in the name of the happiness that the world as it exists has made people want. With a paradoxical twist, Benjamin insists on rejecting not technology but what is called culture, together with "the traditional, solemn, noble image of man, festooned with all the sacrificial offerings of the past." In its place he called in 1928 for attention to "that group of arts which is reckoned inferior but will not necessarily remain so," from photography through radio, film and "the electronic television of our own day." And five years later he asserted, in the face of the National Socialist catastrophe, that "in its buildings, pictures and stories, mankind is preparing to outlive culture, if need be."
This thought must have represented considerable effort on the part of a cultivated German, able to write the magisterial study of Goethe included in this volume and occupied, while turning out his newspaper pieces, with assembling a thousand pages of materials for a study of 19th-century Paris. But at the center of this remarkable intelligence we find, over and over in the texts collected here, a deep feeling for the activities and viewpoint of children. Along with texts Benjamin collected toys. "When the urge to play overcomes an adult," he asserted, "this is not simply a regression to childhood." While children "use play to create a world appropriate to their size," the adult, "who finds himself threatened by the real world and can find no escape, removes its sting by playing with its image in reduced form." And play, like dreaming, is not to be taken lightly: "What is truly revolutionary is the secret signal of what is to come that speaks from the gesture of the child."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 25; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 670 words

HEADLINE: Old Faith, New Soil

BYLINE: By Gustav Niebuhr; Gustav Niebuhr is a religion correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

Islam in America
By Jane I. Smith.
Illustrated. 251 pp. New York:
Columbia University Press. $35. 
 A religious group may think itself truly established when its presence no longer seems remarkable. Islam is a distance from that point in much of the United States, but the faith has become far more deeply rooted here than many Americans realize.
Most medium-sized American cities now have at least one mosque. The military employs Muslim chaplains. And the White House has taken to sending out greetings on Id al-Fitr, the feast that ends Ramadan.
Given such developments, Jane I. Smith's fair, accessible and detailed book, "Islam in America," is most welcome. Hers is a straightforward account of the emergence in the United States of a major religious tradition, one with about
a billion adherents worldwide. Smith covers beliefs, history, Muslim family life and the challenges believers face in a culture that esteems individualism and consumerism. She includes, too, an admirably extensive bibliography of primary sources, books, periodicals, videotapes and Internet sites. Go and learn is the message.
The volume can serve as a corrective to popular misconceptions. In no small part because of the violence of Middle Eastern terrorist groups, Islam seems exotic and sinister to many Americans. Yet its principles are easy to grasp. Its Five Pillars demand belief in God and Mohammed as God's prophet, ritual prayer, charitable giving, an annual fast and, if one is able, a pilgrimage to Mecca. Islam's historic roots lie in the Arabian peninsula, but its center of gravity is more South Asian than Middle Eastern, with the largest Muslim populations in places like Indonesia, India and Pakistan.
Immigration from these countries, as well as from Egypt, Iran and Turkey, has altered the American religious landscape, especially over the last 30 years. Today there are about six million Muslims on United States soil. But American Muslims are not a new phenomenon. As Smith, a professor of Islamic studies at Hartford Seminary in Connecticut, notes, evidence exists that some slaves brought from West Africa were Muslims. (One even left behind a diary, now in the University of Georgia archives.)
Organized worship in America dates back nearly a century. Muslims in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, claim the country's "mother mosque." It has been functioning for 70 years.
But confusion may arise among people who want also to account for the group known as Black Muslims. Just as Muslim immigrants were creating their first communities in the United States, some African-Americans were establishing black separatist movements combining a message of economic self-help with a peculiar theology that borrowed language and ideas from Islam. The most successful was Elijah Muhammad's Nation of Islam.
Malcolm X joined the Nation while in prison but moved on to embrace orthodox Islam before his assassination in 1965. Of greater importance to the development of Islam in the United States is Elijah Muhammad's son, Warith Deen Mohammad. After his father's death in 1975, he led many members into the faith's mainstream. (Louis Farrakhan broke with the younger Mohammad and revived the old organization.)
"Warith Deen emerged from this long process as a significant, recognized and respected leader of American Islam, one whose vision highly influences American blacks, both Muslim and non-Muslim," Smith says. "He has been called the contemporary mujaddid, the renewer of the religion of Islam for his age."
American Muslims have organizations that work toward public awareness and understanding. But the ultimate measure of Islam's integration into the American mainstream will be its recognition by secular organizations, and Smith points to some interesting developments -- a Detroit hospital that offers Muslim patients copies of the Koran, the new airport in Denver, built with a chapel designed for Muslim prayer. Her worthwhile study suggests that such examples will surely multiply in the future.

HEADLINE: The First Squillion Years

BYLINE: By Dick Teresi; Dick Teresi is writing a book about the non-European roots of science.

 BODY:

The Five Ages
of the Universe
Inside the Physics of Eternity.
By Fred Adams and Greg Laughlin.
Illustrated. 251 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $25. 
 In 1966, when the cosmologist Edward Harrison accepted a teaching post at the University of Massachusetts, he was handed the Redbook, a manual for faculty members that explained what a university was, and what it wasn't. It cited two courses one wouldn't find in a curriculum of higher education: witchcraft and cosmology.
Fred Adams and Greg Laughlin have written a book about cosmology. In most cases, cosmology is the study of the universe as a whole, its history and origin, but for Adams, a professor of physics at the University of Michigan, and Laughlin, a postdoctoral fellow at the University of California, Berkeley, this is too small a canvas. "The Five Ages of the Universe: Inside the Physics of Eternity" goes far beyond the past and present universe. It describes in graphic detail the story of our cosmos from the big bang until 10,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000, 000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 years later. This number, written as 10100 in scientific notation, is sometimes called a googol, or as we cognoscenti say, a squillion. By comparison, the universe today is about 10,000,000,000, or ten billion (1010), years old.
Cosmologists have always struggled with ambitious goals and meager data. They take whatever scant secondhand evidence they can glean from the sky, mix it with popular norms and wisdom, toss in a bit of math and construct a model of the universe that provides solace to the populace, themselves and their benefactors, though not necessarily in that order. The medieval European universe was comforting and static: humans at the center; heavens populated by angels; a sphere of fixed stars; beyond that the primum mobile, a sphere maintained in constant motion by divine will; and, finally, the empyrean, a realm of pure fire where God lives. Medieval cosmologists provided their followers with purpose and place in the Christian universe, though to do so they had to borrow heavily from the Arabs, who supplied the primum mobile.
Today's leading cosmological model is the big bang (or, as cosmologists write it, Big Bang). It, too, is a beauty. Tenaciously bourgeois, the universe generated by the big bang is a masterpiece of marketing. With its fiery explosions, wormholes, white dwarfs, red giants and black holes, the big-bang universe satisfies our Lucasfilm sensibilities. It also features an abrupt beginning to appease our Judeo-Christian creation myths, and is constantly expanding, like our economy. It is the biggest-budget universe ever, with mind-boggling numbers to dazzle us -- a technique pioneered by fifth-century A.D. Indian cosmologists, the first to estimate the age of the earth at more than four billion years. We are not at the physical center of the big-bang universe, and there is no God, yet it is an anthropocentric model. The huge numbers -- the comparative strengths of the four forces, the surplus of matter over antimatter and so forth -- are delicately balanced to result in the evolution of intelligent life (i.e., cosmologists). Once again, a human-constructed universe ends up with humans, at least mathematically, at its center.
All previous Western cosmologies have succumbed to their successors. The big bang's fate seems obvious. "The notion that we have lifted all the veils," Harrison says, "can't be true. We would leave no new universes for our descendants to discover."
Adams and Laughlin have left nothing for their descendants. They begin by telling us the birth of the universe is "now understood in stark rigid detail." This despite the admission that the closest observational data take us back no farther than 300,000 years before the big bang. This is like an anthropologist describing the cave painters of Lascaux after examining Versailles.
From that starting point, the authors' self-confidence continues to inflate at superluminal velocities. They divide the first squillion years of the universe into five epochs. The Primordial Era is the first 10,000 years, when the universe is dominated by radiation. We humans are living in the middle of the Stelliferous Era, dominated by stars, galaxies, clusters and superclusters. The Degenerate Era is darker and colder. The galaxies have run out of hydrogen gas, and no new stars are formed. The Black Hole Era begins when all the protons have decayed, and the only stellar objects left are black holes. As you can imagine, the lighting is poor. It gets worse. When all the black holes have evaporated, the Dark Era arrives. This appears to be the end of the road, but the authors show how new "child universes" can be created. (There are drawings, presumably for those adept with tools.)
Along the way, Adams and Laughlin relate many entertaining scenarios: the ejection of Earth from the solar system when it is visited by a red dwarf, the tribulations of a large (a million solar masses) and diffuse individual named Bob, the transformation of Tang at high speeds and a computer composed of several black holes.
One derives a certain perverse joy from watching Adams and Laughlin struggle to construct Saganesque comparisons. "A cubic centimeter of neutron star material, the size of a sugar cube," we are told, "has the mass of nearly a billion elephants!" Three paragraphs later we are informed, "A black hole the size of a baseball has about five times the mass of Earth." One must convert baseballs to sugar cubes and Earths to elephants to compare the densities of neutron stars and black holes. I had to call the Bronx Zoo to inquire about the mass of a neutron star. Patrick Thomas, the curator of mammals, said it depends on the species and sex of the elephant. A dainty Asian female would result in a neutron-star sugar cube of 2,300 billion kilograms, whereas a robust African bull would provide a cube of 4,500 billion kilos, almost double the mass. The African neutron star would have tusks.
The real problem with Adams and Laughlin (who have a collective mass roughly equivalent to two Salman Rushdies) is credibility. "The Five Ages of the Universe" might be cosmology, but it probably isn't physics, as the subtitle claims. Since the time of Galileo, physics has been an experimentally falsifiable science. The early universe, however, has yet to be replicated, and the future is . . . the future. The authors are extrapolating from the unfalsifiable to the unknowable.
The veils have not all been lifted. In fact, we're still trying to think of the right questions. Three scientists recently suggested that we ought to count the stars, carefully, comparing one galaxy with another. In the movie "The Truman Show," 29-year-old Truman Burbank believes he is living in a small city, when in reality he has spent his life on a set populated by only a few dozen actors who are cycled past him endlessly to create the illusion of random citizens. This is possible because humans have a very low number sense, 4. This is the number of things we can distinguish between without counting. We are superior to cats in number sense, on a par with crows. Truman is fooled because, like most of us, he isn't counting. In one scene, Christof, "the creator," errs, looping only three objects -- lady on a bike, man with flowers, dented Volkswagen -- around Truman, who immediately senses the deception.
IN a recent issue of Scientific American, Jean-Pierre Luminet, Glenn D. Starkman and Jeffrey R. Weeks -- two astrophysicists and a mathematician working on ways to determine the topology of the universe -- said that our large, apparently endless universe could be illusory. Light from stars could bounce around a cleverly shaped universe, taking multiple paths to our eyes. If galaxy A in the east looks like galaxy B in the west, maybe it's the same galaxy. Are we living in a cosmic "Truman Show"? We'd have to count the stars. Richard Kron, an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago, says that could be done, but it wouldn't be high on his list of priorities. Who wants to live in a smallish, low-budget universe? PBS would have to overdub the television series "Cosmos," with an awe-struck Carl Sagan staring at the sky rhapsodizing about "hundreds and hundreds" of stars.
One advantage of this universe is that some light paths would be longer than others; we could see our planet in an earlier epoch. Imagine an astronomer looking back at us ages hence. Perhaps he can read the bound galleys in my hand. Maybe he will be kinder than I have been here.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 16; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1532 words

HEADLINE: The Avant-Garde: Follow That Backpack

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY; JESSE McKINLEY writes the On Stage and Off column for The Times.

 BODY:
CALL them budgeteers or independent travelers or plain old backpackers, but those who travel light and cheap are often the trailblazers of the tourist set.
With limited cash and a thirst for uncommon sights, backpackers have pushed into challenging territory well before the big-money resorts or tchotchke merchants. In the late 1980's and early 1990's, that meant backpackers in the cobblestoned streets of Prague, hitting its dirt cheap bars and soaking up the city's glimmering, storybook architecture. At the same time, closer to home, Costa Rica, with its eastern beaches and western jungles, was gaining favor even as much of Central America struggled with political and military strife. A generation earlier, Americans and Europeans flocked to warmer places like Bali, where beautiful beaches and inexpensive hotels continue to draw sun- and bargain-worshipers. 
 So where is the backpack crowd headed now? An informal survey indicates that points east and southeast continue to appeal.
Heading the list is Thailand, which many travel professionals say has become the top low-cost destination in Asia. Jesse Walkershaw, a part-time backpacker and full-time manager at Airtreks.com, a San Francisco-based travel service, said his clients usually arrive via Bangkok, and then trek either north to the highlands around Chiang Mai or south to the coastline near Koh Samui. "The north is hill tribe country," he said. "The south is all about the beaches."
Edward Hasbrouck, the author of "The Practical Nomad: How to Travel Around the World" (Moon Publications), said Vietnam remained hot. The appeal, he said, is its untouched flavor. "It's very easy to get off the tourist track" in Vietnam, Mr. Hasbrouck said. "It's a country as big as California with twice as many people." One caveat, however: Tourist visas are commonly limited to a month.
The recent -- and long-term -- economic struggles in the region have also made Thailand, as well as Laos and Vietnam, "super cheap," Mr. Walkershaw said. That appeals to people like Joey Kern, a college-age traveler who lives in New York. "I hear for $4.50 you can make it for three months," said Mr. Kern, who is planning a trip there. "O.K., maybe $4.75."
O.K., that is an exaggeration, but Mr. Walkershaw says $10 a day is reasonable.
Nick Paonessa, a graduate of New York University who backpacked across Europe last summer, said Thailand was next on his list. He put his fascination down to "The Beach," a recent novel by Alex Garland, a young British writer, that tells the story of a compulsive 21-year-old traveler and his friends who, in pursuit of unspoiled nature, head to Thailand. "I want to go there and try that out," Mr. Paonessa said.
Other classic Asian locales for those looking for enlightenment -- or just good, cheap fun -- include India and Nepal.
Latin America offers an enormous number of choices. Peru, Mexico, Bolivia and Central America have long been destinations for backpackers seeking close contact with nature and indigenous cultures.
David Kirby, a writer who travels about once a year to Mexico on a daily budget of $10 to $40 a day, says that outside of Cancun and other high-end resort areas, backpackers in Mexico can travel like kings. "When you backpack through Europe, which I did, you feel poor," he said. "But in Mexico, $20 a day can get you three basic meals and a decent room. You don't feel deprived."
While Palenque and the states of Chiapas and Oaxaca are fixtures on Mexico's backpacking trail, Mr. Kirby said, the often overlooked central state of Michoacan is gaining adherents for its colonial towns, pristine lakes and Indian villages.
A modest budget can also take you far in Peru and Bolivia. Christine Corcoran, a graduate student at Columbia University whose trip to Machu Picchu two years ago was a "life altering" experience, spent as little as $8 for a room in nearby Cuzco.
As adventurous as Asia and Latin America sound, many budget travelers still head to Europe for their first trips. London, Paris and Amsterdam continue to draw hordes of backpackers, said Caroline Sherman, the editor of "Let's Go: Europe '98," the popular budget guidebook series put together by Harvard students. But even in Europe, less obvious locations are being scouted out. Ms. Sherman said, via E-mail, that Cracow, Vilnius and Berlin were all hot; Mr. Walkershaw mentioned Bratislava.
Farther west, Portugal has recently taken advantage of overflow crowds from Spain. And money and sunny matter. "It's less expensive than Spain," wrote Ms. Sherman. "And has great beaches." That sentiment was echoed by Mira Svatovic, 20, a student at the University of Wisconsin at Madison. "The beaches are the most beautiful thing I've ever seen," she said. "Rocks protruding out of the water and underwater caves." Her favorite place was the coastal city of Lagos in the Algarve, where her hotel was $30 a night and she ate cheap seafood from the blue waters of the bay.
On the other end of the thermometer, Iceland is also cool right now. Backpackers rave about the budget accommodations and hostels, which usually include a bed and a sleeping bag and are uniformly clean, though prices are considerably higher in summer. Part of the island's popularity can be traced to a continuing promotion by Icelandair, which allows short stopovers between the United States and Europe. On a low-budget trip to Reykjavik last spring, I was impressed by the rugged landscape, the northern lights and, most of all, a night life that lasts past dawn -- which, above the Arctic Circle, is about 3:30 A.M.
Prague, too, apparently continues to hold a Saturnalian appeal. "Prague is probably still the hottest city around," Mr. Paonessa said. "It's so beautiful and so cheap. It's 50 cents for a pint, and for three bucks you can get steak and a drink." Which raises the question of whether young backpackers are seeking new frontiers or just a good party.
Another party destination that continues to lure crowds of backpackers is the Spanish island of Ibiza, in the Balearic Islands of the Mediterranean. Several travelers said the scene there -- with stadium-sized discos and a crush of youngsters from across Europe -- was legendarily libertine. "Everybody's sleeping on the beach," Mr. Paonessa said.
That is not the usual type of accommodation for today's backpackers. While European travelers still prefer the affordability of hostels, many visitors to Asia stay in swankier hotels, bungalows or guesthouses for as little as $5 a day.
Some popular locations in Europe have suffered of late because of the turbulence in the former Yugoslavia. Ms. Sherman said that was especially true of Greece and Turkey. "Istanbul and the west coast of Turkey had really taken off," she said. But since the war in Kosovo and the trial of the Kurdish rebel Abdullah Ocalan, tourist trade to Turkey's western coast has "slowed down considerably."
Mr. Kern, 22, said his buddies have also cooled on Russia, in vogue in the early 1990's. "You get the feeling that they're so poor it just wouldn't be fun," he said.
Regional instability has had an impact elsewhere. Mr. Walkershaw said some American backpackers have steered clear of Central and East Africa since last summer's terrorist attacks on the United States embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. That may be a boon for countries like Mozambique, which is slowly recovering from a 17-year civil war. "Things keep getting hairier and hairier in East Africa," Mr. Walkershaw said. "And Mozambique is picking up a lot of that action."
Neighboring South Africa is also on the rise, Ms. Sherman said. The Tourism Bureau of South Africa reports that approximately 200,000 backpackers visited the country's hostels in 1998, an increase of some 20 percent from the previous year. The coastal city of Durban and the entire Kwa-Zulu/Natal region are particularly popular with backpackers.
What of the future? Travel professionals regard China as most likely to succeed. The World Tourism Organization predicts that China will be the most popular destination in the world in the early 21st century. But free-spirited backpackers may be put off; most travelers are strictly scheduled on tours, with little latitude for exploration.
Mr. Walkershaw suggested that Iran might be an up-and-comer, though backpackers would have to adapt: "They ain't going to put up with you doing whatever you please," he said. "There'll be no girls in halter tops, that's for sure." (Recent student protests and a crackdown by the Government have since caused concerns about the area's safety this summer.)
Mr. Hasbrouck, who has circled the globe twice, says Iran is on his wish list despite the problems. "Everyone I know comes back and says, 'This is a wonderful place, you have to go.' " He also mentioned India and other parts of the subcontinent.
"I think there's a backlash among backpackers against the commodification of travel and the homogenization of the world," said Mr. Hasbrouck. "Simply going to a town you find on the map, or riding a bus to the end of the line, can be wonderful experiences. And you don't find them in brochures."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 8, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Page 37; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4418 words

HEADLINE: The Precarious Triumph of Human Rights

BYLINE: By David Rieff; David Rieff is finishing a book on humanitarianism.

 BODY:
The age of human rights is upon us. This spring, the United States fought a war in the Balkans in the name of human rights and humanitarian imperatives -- the first war in recent memory, as President Clinton has said, waged in the name of values rather than strategic interests. Similar sentiments have been voiced by America's allies in Europe. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has been campaigning for "a new internationalism based on values and the rule of law." In these post-Communist, post-modern times, human rights seems to have become the dominant moral narrative for thinking about world affairs.
No longer does national sovereignty provide blanket protection for human rights abusers -- as Slobodan Milosevic learned when, at the height of the Kosovo conflict, he was indicted for war crimes by an international tribunal at The Hague. An even stronger signal was sent last October, with the arrest in London of the former Chilean strongman Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The very idea that the British police would honor a Spanish judge's request for extradition based on crimes committed in Chile is astonishing; such a complex web of cooperation would have been inconceivable 10 years ago. But it shows that the old assumption that national sovereignty trumps all other principles in international relations is under attack as never before. 
 The human rights movement has achieved other victories. The 1997 signing of an international treaty prohibiting land mines is the most significant abolition of a weapons system since the use of poison gas in wartime was banned in 1925. The ad hoc international tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia inspired plans for a permanent International Criminal Court, one with the power to judge people charged with gross violations of international humanitarian law under the legal principle of universal jurisdiction. The revival of this principle was largely the brainchild of human rights lawyers.
A political New World Order may be even further off than it was when President George Bush proclaimed it a decade ago. But in the eyes of many Western intellectuals, there is a New World Moral Order -- one ruled by ideas like civil society, humanitarianism and, first and foremost, human rights. The writer Michael Ignatieff calls this "a revolution in humanitarian concern" and celebrates "the emergence of vast constituencies of human rights activists, development workers and aid experts whose moral rationale is the indivisibility of human interests and needs in an interdependent world."
It is a revolution that has happened with surprising swiftness. In the 1960's, the budget for Amnesty International was somewhere around $20,000. Human rights groups were barred from many if not most parts of the world, and they had great difficulty getting Governments even to listen to them. Today the situation could not be more different. Human Rights Watch, the most powerful and influential Western human rights organization, has a budget of $15 million -- thanks to generous financing from donors like George Soros and the Ford Foundation -- and its leaders meet regularly with top Government officials. President Jimmy Carter's exhortation that human rights must be the "soul" of United States foreign policy has been institutionalized. The State Department now boasts an Ambassador at Large for War Crimes Issues and an Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights (currently, Harold Koh, who used to sit on the board of Human Rights Watch). And few foreign-aid programs now go forward without "democracy building" and human rights stipulations.
Yet paradoxically, at the very moment when its ideas have become mainstream, the human rights movement seems adrift. The movement's signature strategies -- releasing shocking reports detailing abuses, exploiting the media to shame Western leaders into action -- no longer have the impact they once did. More important, an entrenched moral absolutism has made it all too easy to ignore the cries of activists. Institutions like the United Nations High Commission for Human Rights, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch are sure to condemn any peace treaty or political accord that promises to let human rights abusers off the hook -- even when continued conflict risks destroying a country, as was the case recently in Sierra Leone. A serious consequence of activists' blinkered worldview has been a marked failure to establish widespread support among ordinary citizens. For all its influence in elite circles, the human rights constituency is a tiny fraction of that commanded by grass-roots organizations of either the right or the left. Without a broad base of support, it may have reached the limits of its effectiveness. Whether its leaders know it or not, the human rights movement is in trouble.
The modern age of human rights began just half a century ago. In the aftermath of the Second World War, an international system of rights was drafted. It included aspects of the 1945 United Nations Charter -- the statutes that formed the legal basis for the Nuremberg trials, the Genocide Convention and, above all, the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The declaration's preamble proclaimed the need for Governments and individuals to promote and defend a panoply of social, political, cultural and economic rights "nationally and internationally." Eleanor Roosevelt, one of the declaration's animating spirits, imagined that its adoption would strengthen that side of human nature that "reaches for the stars."
But it proved to be a false dawn. The gap between the laws on the books and the realities on the ground could scarcely have been wider. In retrospect, the European powers were more intent on trying to maintain their colonial empires than on giving human rights a central role in international affairs. State sovereignty remained all but absolute; what states did within their own borders to their own citizens, no matter how hideous, was judged to be nobody else's business.
In the 1960's and 1970's, the human rights movement shifted its focus to the plight of imperiled individuals -- especially political prisoners and torture victims. Amnesty International led the way. Gradually, other human rights groups, notably Human Rights Watch, began to expand the scope of protection, focusing above all on the issues of women, children, refugees and civilians in war. They also began to try to develop interdependent, collaborative relationships with activist groups in countries where abuses were taking place.
Improbably, the Reagan Administration played the central role in legitimizing the American human rights movement. Aryeh Neier, the dean of American human rights activists, who, after directing Human Rights Watch, is now president of the Open Society Institute, has said that Reagan-era officials like Jeane Kirkpatrick and Elliott Abrams were "our greatest allies." He is not being ironic. "They helped us," Neier explained, "because they presented the confrontation between the U.S. and the Soviet Union as one between a totalitarian system and one based on civil liberties. But then they had to pretend that everyone on our side of the cold war was not violating human rights. That allowed Human Rights Watch to point out the gap between pretense and practice. It created enormous embarrassment." By documenting the real practices of United States client states, he said, "you could demonstrate the ways in which they didn't measure up."
The group's technique of highlighting Washington's hypocrisy was called "shaming." And it got results. When Human Rights Watch exposed the crimes that the U.S.-supported regime in El Salvador was committing on a routine basis, it actually forced the Reagan Administration to try to put a stop to the worst abuses. This was a direct result of pressure and lobbying by human rights groups on Capitol Hill. In 1981, Congress began imposing human rights standards that the Administration had to certify were in place in order for foreign aid to continue flowing. But given what U.S.-backed regimes were actually up to in El Salvador, such certification was nearly impossible. "In December of 1983," Neier recalled, "George Bush had to be sent to El Salvador to put a stop to the death squads. The Administration knew that otherwise Congress would never accept their certification, and they were desperate to secure the funding."
The Reaganites kept falling into the same trap. "Abrams and his colleagues made it a quarrel over the facts," Neier said. "The style of Human Rights Watch evolved directly out of this. We started producing thick, amply documented reports. That was different from what Amnesty International had done. Our emphasis was on providing the evidentiary bases for the claims we were making."
Bolstered by this combative approach, human rights groups became more and more influential. With Bill Clinton's election in 1992, the human rights movement appeared very likely to reach an even higher plateau. The new Administration presented itself as a partner, and in many ways it was. Lifelong advocates like Harold Koh, David Scheffer and John Shattuck were given posts in the Government. And rhetorically, Clinton's commitment to human rights was steadfast.
The reality, though, has been more complicated. Despite the triumph of Kosovo, the human rights movement has during the 1990's suffered an equally important defeat: the Clinton Administration's policy toward China. It was Clinton, after all, who severed the link between progress on human rights and most-favored-nation trading status. As a result, some advocates have begun to fear that in the future Western Governments may be willing to uphold principles only where economically unimportant countries like Serbia or Burma are concerned.
Kenneth Roth, the current executive director of Human Rights Watch, insists that this is not the case. "China is not illustrative," he said. "It's an anomaly." But others have drawn a different lesson. Neier seems less optimistic. "China," he argued, "has been able to play off the U.S. and the European Union. It is the first case where reverse human rights pressure has been applied. To Western Governments, the Chinese have said, in effect, 'If you criticize us, we will stop trading with you and turn to your competitor.' When the U.S. does it, the Chinese say they will stop buying from Boeing and start buying from Airbus, and vice versa." Neier thinks the best strategy is to persuade the Americans and the Europeans to take a joint position on trade, refusing to sell China goods it covets until the Beijing Government modifies its policies. He's right. Yet he admits that the trend has been almost entirely in the opposite direction, as Western Governments vie with one another for Chinese contracts.
The movement's loss over China does not invalidate its intellectual or moral assumptions. But it does suggest that the era when it was able to emerge victorious simply by exposing hypocrisy -- as it did with El Salvador -- is ending. Neier put the matter starkly: "We have more difficulty getting leverage with Clinton than we did with Reagan. Unlike in those years, today there are relatively few disputes over the facts." Having openly placed economics before human rights, the Clinton Administration can't be swayed from its current policies by yet another thick report documenting repression in Tibet. Clearly, alternative tactics need to be used.
But so far, such approaches haven't been forthcoming. By and large, the mainline organizations remain wedded to the methodologies of the Reagan era. Catherine Fitzpatrick, executive director of the International League for Human Rights, was probably exaggerating when she said, "Human Rights Watch is a report mill, the Committee to Protect Journalists is a case mill and we're an issue mill." But the human rights movement does seem unable to come up with fresh tactics for the post-cold-war world.
Human solidarity is a real fact of the world, but so is compassion fatigue, particularly in an era when press coverage of events is episodic, fickle and often trivializing. You can no longer build a political consensus for action, assuming you ever could, by showing yet another clip of disaster pornography on television. Nor can you simply issue reports, no matter how superbly researched, and demand that Governments alter their policies accordingly -- at least not where a powerful nation like China is concerned -- with any realistic expectation of success. To complain, as the 1999 Human Rights Watch annual report does, that "visits of world leaders to China were marked more by symbolism than substance," but at the same time to boast that "we used high-level visits to Asian countries as a focus for Advocacy work, with particular attention to the steady stream of state visitors to China," is emblematic of the bankruptcy of the current approach.
The Chinese example would seem to throw into question the claim by activists and their supporters that the worldwide revival of Enlightenment ideals -- with human rights at its core -- is very likely to take permanent root. Will today's post-Balkan optimism turn out to be another false dawn?
The issue is not whether the human rights movement does good. Unquestionably, it does. The question is whether it is configured, intellectually or operationally, to cope with the challenges of the 21st century.
On the practical level, the human rights movement needs to confront Holly Burkhalter's insight that "stigma is not getting the job done." Burkhalter, the advocacy director for Physicians for Human Rights, laments: "The only thing we really know how to do well is expose. We do that better than ever, and we're making galloping leaps in establishing norms. But you look at the great bloodletting of the recent past and you ask yourself, 'Are we seeing a reduction in violence against the innocent?"' When Human Rights Watch boasts that its goal is to "challenge Governments and those who hold power to end abusive practices and respect international human rights law," it is easy to sympathize and to respect the principles being upheld. But it is also hard to ignore the fact that the abusers the human rights movement are now seeking to challenge are not politically vulnerable American officials, but warlords in southern Sudan or Serb paramilitaries. Do these people care about international human rights norms? Not likely.
The human rights movement has assumed that establishing norms will lead to a better world. But can anyone be confident that developing the "right" norms will lead to effective enforcement? It sometimes appears as if it is extrapolating from the experience of civil rights legislation. You establish norms, and they're unpopular, but eventually people acquiesce. But what if the model is not civil rights law, but drug law, in which the norms have not led to obedience but to mockery of the law itself?
Other cherished assumptions need to be confronted as well. Advocates routinely claim that there can be no peace without justice. But the evidence suggests that often that isn't true. Consider the eight-year civil war in Sierra Leone, during which Revolutionary United Front guerrillas committed the most unspeakable atrocities and war crimes -- routinely mutilating children and raping and murdering civilians. When they were defeated by a Nigerian-led regional intervention force in 1998, their leader, Foday Sankoh, was tried and sentenced to death. To have executed Sankoh would have been justice. But the reality in Sierra Leone was that there could be no peace without a deal between the rebels and the Government. The guerrillas would not sign until Sankoh and other detained rebels were pardoned and set free. In the name of peace, the Government agreed not to prosecute -- rightly, in my view. In order to seize what was almost certainly Sierra Leone's only chance, justice had to be sacrificed. And as a result, a fragile peace reigns in Freetown for the first time since 1991.
But the outrage of the human rights movement knew no bounds. Mary Robinson, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, declared that the United Nations did not accept the deal. There could be no impunity for human rights violations, she insisted. And in a letter to the United Nations Security Council, Human Rights Watch denounced the agreement. Its advocacy director, Reed Brody, announced that his group would lobby to get the blanket amnesty for Sankoh and his comrades annulled.
The indignation of the human rights movement was a perfect illustration of the remark by Stephen Holmes, a political scientist at Princeton, that "justice is too often something that takes place 'out there."' Closer to home, we have different standards. At the same time Western leaders were welcoming Slobodan Milosevic's indictment for war crimes and insisting that the days of the "culture of impunity" were numbered, the Blair Government in Britain was releasing paramilitary prisoners in Northern Ireland to further the peace process there. "Justice and peace are often not the same thing," Holmes has said. "Actually, they can be contradictory."
Examples of this tension can be found around the globe. An obvious example is Algeria. In 1992, faced with the threat of Islamic fundamentalists taking power after free elections, the Algerian Government annulled that vote and imposed a state of emergency. Human rights groups were quick to respond. Amnesty International issued a special report denouncing the Government. The counterargument -- namely, that had the fundamentalists been allowed to take over this might have been the last free election to be held in Algeria -- cut no ice with them. Norms were norms, and violators were violators. In a similar display of orthodoxy, Human Rights Watch recently accused the United States Government of making drugs rather than human rights "the centerpiece of U.S. policy" in Colombia. The message was plain: it is immoral ever to fail to uphold human rights.
I would say that there is a case to be made for what the Algerian generals did -- and that it's understandable that the United States has concluded that Colombian drug interdiction is at least as important a concern, and as morally reputable a one, as human rights. This is not to say that human rights advocates are wrong to point out abuses; in the Algerian case, there was ample evidence of systematic and barbarous behavior on the part of the authorities. But there is a danger in turning human rights principles into dogma.
Imagine if Human Rights Watch were confronted not with contemporary Algeria but with Germany circa 1932. Wouldn't the world have been better off had there been a German Government with the courage to annul Hitler's victory at the polls? Seen through the tunnel vision of today's human rights leadership, such a move would have been unacceptable. A violation, after all, is a violation. It may be stacking the deck to use an analogy with Nazi Germany, but it illustrates the hard questions about the assumptions of the human rights movement that are not being asked. What if you are a secular Algerian citizen? What is the relative moral weight of the human rights imperative versus your well-founded fear of fundamentalism? At the very least, the picture becomes cloudier, and the transcendent insights of human rights suddenly seem less transcendent.
Even the Kosovo conflict points to a problem with the human rights movement's absolutist stance. Most activists, though not all, privately hoped for and initially welcomed NATO's action. But consternation and self-doubt began almost from the moment the first bomb fell. Human Rights Watch even issued a report denouncing NATO military tactics like dropping cluster bombs on civilian areas. And yet it seems that it was precisely this bombing of civilian targets in Serbia -- which may well have been illegal under international law, just as Human Rights Watch has asserted -- that eventually forced the Milosevic regime to give in. The battle-damage assessments have shown that Serb forces in Kosovo came through largely unscathed. Once again: do human rights norms provide an adequate guide to what the right thing to do is in a hard case like Kosovo?
Some human rights advocates insist that their only obligation is to document abuses, not to shape Government policy or figure out how enforcement can be implemented. They argue that only by maintaining an objective, extra-political stance can they retain their credibility. As Leonard Rubenstein, executive director of Physicians for Human Rights, put it: "Our role is to highlight violations, no matter who is doing them. Our first order of business is to do no harm. If you take a side, you're morally implicated in the consequences."
In the abstract, this may be true. But to mobilize mass constituencies and affect public opinion, activists cannot simply call for "something" to be done -- but then refuse to say what, exactly, is required. To do so will inevitably appear like moral posing.
Even those who finance human rights groups are nervous about the movement's current hermeticism. As Larry Cox, an ex-Amnesty International staff member who is at the Ford Foundation, said: "Twenty years ago, when you went to a meeting at a human rights group, you saw all kinds of people. But these days, you usually find that most of the people there are either lawyers or human rights professionals. To me, the human rights movement has not been successful in capturing the imagination of a broad group of people -- the way, whatever I may think of them, a strong civil-society group like the National Rifle Association has done."
William Schulz, executive director of the American branch of Amnesty International, has similar concerns. "For a while, human rights groups had a great deal of success by setting in motion a process in which the human rights groups would inform the media, the media would inform the Government and then the Government would do something," he said. "But that model is breaking down. We have to become more constituency-oriented."
Few of his colleagues would disagree, but this agenda still does not have the high priority it should. That is a pity. Human rights is one of the major ideas to emerge from the 20th century. But it has yet to become an integral part of the fabric of American democracy. So far, what power the human rights movement has obtained derives not from an evolution in popular sentiment -- as occurred, for example with regard to civil rights or the environment -- but from the press and the political elite.
But in an age in which gross human violations seem to require military force or, at least, the threat of it -- power that often only America can provide -- the advantages of this elite strategy are disappearing fast. Kosovo is a case in point: the war may have been fought on human rights grounds, but it was fought on human rights grounds by pilots flying 15,000 feet up in the air. This was because the Clinton Administration knew there was no widespread support for casualties in defense of these human rights ideals.
Today's human rights workers wield great clout in Washington as long as they can work on an issue to which the public is not paying much attention. But when risks are involved -- and members of Congress are getting countervailing pressure from their districts -- the weaknesses of the insider approach quickly become apparent. The Rwandan genocide of 1994 was the most tragic case in point. Anthony Lake, then the national security adviser, reportedly told a Human Rights Watch representative who had quietly come to lobby him for United States action that he would be unsuccessful in pressing for an intervention unless a great deal of popular protest began to occur. But the human rights movement was in no position to mobilize it. It could merely publish more reports, issue appeals and dispatch more wrenching videotapes to the media.
The same is true with China. Joint trade sanctions will never happen unless American and European leaders know that a failure to act will hurt them at election time (or leave their campaign war chests empty). No amount of hectoring from advocates will keep them from putting economics first. Until their ideas are put forward in a way that stirs the public's imagination, human rights activists will be busy refining their norms as vast areas of the world go up in flames.
Human rights workers sometimes talk of their movement as an emblem of grass-roots democracy. Yet it is possible to view it as an undemocratic pressure group, accountable to no one but its own members and donors, that wields enormous power and influence. For example, would there have been a war in Kosovo without the human rights movement? As a supporter of the war in Kosovo, I applaud the result. As a democrat, I worry. It was a moral decision, but it was arrived at undemocratically.
Because there were no American combat casualties in Kosovo, the issue of popular support never really arose. But future human rights crises will most likely not be as cost-free as Kosovo; they will require sacrifice and impose losses. Will people be willing to accept this? Only, I think, if the human rights movement shows more willingness to engage in straightforward political activism, to get its hands dirty. It must lobby people in churches and shopping malls in the Midwest as assiduously as it lobbies Capitol Hill or the Ford Foundation. It must take its case to the public, not just rely on its influence and its certainty that it does an enormous amount of good in the world.
If the human rights movement cannot or will not engage in this way, then there is a great chance that the human rights paradigm will backfire the way affirmative action did. The parallel is striking. Affirmative action was also well meant. It drew popular opposition not, for the most part, because it was wrong, but because it was sneaked in, with no serious effort made to win people over. Convinced that their cause was right, its advocates saw no reason to campaign for it among the public at large. Instead, they relied on the courts, the law and legislation. And eventually, the whole project came undone.
At the moment, the human rights movement seems set to go down exactly the same path. If it does, it will, in the end, encounter the same result. That would be a very great loss.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1457 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
At Lenox and 116th, Co-ops and Stores Are Rising

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IN central Harlem, 125th Street is the principal commercial thoroughfare as well as the main focus over the years of public efforts to stimulate Harlem 's economic development.
But in its own way 116th Street has been coming on strong. Stretches of this crosstown thoroughfare show the signs of longterm housing improvement, and more recently new three-story houses have made their appearance on neighboring streets near Lenox Avenue. 
 Now a $61 million mixed-use project has gone into construction on the east side of Lenox Avenue from 116th to 117th Street, the largest expression so far of the Giuliani administration's emphasis on neighborhood retail development. Under the banner of the Anchor program, the city has been trying to induce retail development in locations where houses have been built under the New York City Housing Partnership program. The acronym Anchor stands for Alliance for Neighborhood Commerce, Home Ownership and Revitalization.
The 116th Street development, called Renaissance Plaza, will provide 60,000 square feet of stores, stretching all around the base of a mixed-use building in which there will be 241 moderately priced co-op apartments and parking for 200 cars. The site is diagonally across the street from the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque, whose religious leader, Imam Izak-el M. Pasha, is the community sponsor. The site is also at the express subway stop for the 2 and 3 trains, which bring riders to midtown in 10 minutes, a notable marketing asset.
The city-designated developer is Suna Levine Inc., a partnership of Stuart Match Suna and Jeffrey E. Levine. Mr. Suna is a partner in Metro Management Development, a Queens-based management firm, and president of Silvercup Studios in Long Island City. Mr. Levine is the principal in Levine Builders of Douglaston, Queens, which is handling the construction.
The Anchor program, administered by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development in cooperation with the Housing Partnership, is a departure for a local housing agency.
Rarely do housing agencies involve themselves with store development, especially when the stores serve a wide community purpose. And among Anchor projects Renaissance Plaza is unusual because the stores are a separately financed element in a building of scale at a central urban location.
The co-op sales will test the strength of the co-op sales market in central Harlem. Although the prices will assure a largely moderate-income occupancy, the eligibility limits are high enough to accommodate many middle-income buyers.
The apartments are expected to sell for about $160 a square foot when they go on the market in about six months, once the offering plan is approved by the New York State Attorney General's office. At that price, a 900-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment with one bath would sell for about $140,000, with a down payment requirement of 5 percent, or $7,000. The monthly maintenance charge would be about $1,165 , covering operating expenses, the underlying mortgage and property taxes, which are abated in the early years. A three-bedroom, two-bath apartment, with about 1,200 square feet, would sell for $192,000, with a monthly maintenance of $1,550.
THE apartment mix is 9 one-bedrooms, 129 two-bedrooms with one bath, 13 two-bedrooms with two baths and 89 three-bedrooms. Occupancy is expected to begin in the summer of 2001. Suna Levine, at Silvercup Studios, is handling buyer applications.
The developer must sell 75 percent of the apartments to buyers earning no more than 165 percent of areawide median income, which translates to a maximum income of $88,100 a year for a family of four. The rest of the apartments can be sold to households earning up to 250 percent of median income, or $133,500 for a family of four.
"We have tried for a solid, dignified building, which the community was asking for," said Navid Maqami , head of the New York office of the Atlanta-based firm of Greenberg Farrow Architecture, who designed the building. It will rise 11 stories on Lenox Avenue, and step down to eight floors facing 116th Street and six floors facing 117th Street, with a 10,000-square-foot landscaped courtyard between these elements on the roof of the stores.
The enthusiastic collaboration of Imam Pasha has been a key element in this and other nearby development projects. Born and raised in Brooklyn in the 50's and 60's, Imam Pasha worked as a plumber on major construction jobs, including the low-income Nehemiah project in East Brooklyn, before he was named to lead the Shabazz mosque by his late predecessor, Ali Rashid, in 1993. Since then he has been an advocate of racial harmony and community development. "We're all family here in New York," he once remarked in a sermon.
In 1994 Imam Pasha cooperated with the city in relocating street vendors from 125th Street on an interim basis to the cleared 116th Street development site. Their forced ouster had incited a protest requiring police action. With redevelopment at hand, the vendors were moved again last year to another interim site, at 116th Street and Fifth Avenue, and only two months ago they moved to a long-term site in the newly built Malcolm Shabazz Harlem Market.
The market consists of 116 small stores with neat signs and awnings lined up along several narrow pathways on 22,700 square feet of city-owned land. It was built with city funds on the south side of 116th Street between Fifth Avenue and Lenox Avenue. David Danois of Manhattan was the architect.
While city officials were dealing with the vendor issue, the Suna Levine partnership was trying to line up commercial tenants. Rite Aid, the drugstore chain, had signed on for 12,300 square feet in 1997, and Petland Discounts had committed to 2,400 square feet last February. Rents are expected to average about $25 a square foot a year.
But it was necessary to prelease 50 percent of the commercial space, or 30,000 square feet, to creditworthy tenants to nail down the financing for the $14-million commercial component, Mr. Levine said. The government-backed financing package needed a co-insurance commitment from the State of New York Mortgage Agency on the first mortgage loan, and 50 percent preleasing to creditworthy borrowers was a requirement of the agency.
The crucial lease was signed in December by Pioneer Supermarkets for 20,600 square feet. Pioneer has a market a third the size in rented space on the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. The 20,000-square-foot building will become a redevelopment candidate when Pioneer moves. Since then, Ashley Stewart, a women's clothing store, has leased 12,000 square feet.
Chase Manhattan Bank is the lead construction lender for the project. The permanent financing on the commercial condominium consists of a first mortgage of $10.8 million from the New York City Employes Retirement System, plus $3 million in state and Federal money at 3 percent interest to reduce the overall debt burden.
THE residential component's first mortgage is a 35-year, 7.15 percent loan of $31.6 million from the city's Housing Development Corporation. To make carrying costs more affordable to buyers, the co-op will also have two city loans totaling $13.2 million, one of $6.9 million at 1 percent interest from the Housing Development Coporation and another of $6.3 million at zero interest from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
The Shabazz mosque is also the sponsor of for-sale housing in the neighborhood. The Bluestone Organization, of Queens, is well advanced in the construction of Shabazz Gardens, 34 three-family houses on 117th Street west of Lenox Avenue and seven more on 118th Street east of Lenox. Sales contracts have been signed for all of them -- 21 houses at $223,000, and 20 at $278,500, said Ira Lichtiger, a partner in the Bluestone Organization.
Because Federal funds were used, half of these three-family houses had to be sold to buyers earnings no more than about $40,000 a year -- 80 percent of areawide median income. Using Fannie Mae underwriting standards, the lender is allowed to count as income 60 percent of the total rent the buyer is expected to receive -- in this case an estimted $1,650 for the two apartments -- making the houses affordable.
At Renaissance Plaza, Robert Greenstone Realty of Manhattan is handling the store leasing. With more than half the space already leased, he is looking for stores that provide services that complement those already in place, he said. "I'm looking for shoes, I'm looking for hardware, I'm looking for electronics, I'm looking for music," Mr. Greenstone said. "It's nuts-and-bolts retailing going into a neighborhood with nothing to serve people's needs."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
As a Feminist, a King; as a Ballerina, a Klutz

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THE movie marquee in the Los Angeles County Museum of Art says, "Now Showing: Eleanor Antin." Beneath it are a few stills of Ms. Antin's most famous roles, plus a free-standing cutout of her in full ballerina regalia. If you can't find Eleanor Antin in your movie guide, try the deadpan dictionary, the feminist gazette, the lexicon of subversive notions or, better still, the catalogue named after her by Howard N. Fox, curator of "Eleanor Antin," the first retrospective of 30 years of this artist's work (through Aug. 23). A lot of this show stars Ms. Antin on video as the marquee promises, and even more of it is theatrical in a quirky way, fleshing out the female role in the human comedy with laughter and cultural smarts and a deep curtsy to despair.
Female roles, rather: Ms. Antin hooked up early to the idea that personality, even gender, were not unified and static but various and shifting, and at different times she has tried on fantasy autobiographies as a king, a ballerina and a nurse. In real life (whatever that is these days) she was a painter and an actress first, then, in the later 1960's, a conceptual artist. She became a feminist artist, a video artist and a performance artist in the first years of the 1970's, coming early to all three parties and helping to make them memorable. 
 Ms. Antin made a kind of still movie in 1971-73: "100 Boots," a set of 51 photographic postcards that were mailed to hundreds of people around the world. These chronicle a picaresque journey taken by a staunch corps of boots from the Pacific Ocean to the Museum of Modern Art in New York, with a number of standard-issue adventures like going to market and to church, being unemployed, doing their best, and taking a hill (a victory of sorts), before going to the big city and ending up in a seedy dump. This reverse journey, from middle-class military to scruffy bohemia, is made by the most independent articles of clothing since Gogol's overcoat or Dr. Seuss's pale green pants with nobody inside them.
Mail art was still rather new, but male art bestrode the world and always had. Ms. Antin wryly commented on society's expectations of women and on women's possibilities of redefining themselves. "Carving: A Traditional Sculpture" (1972) is a pseudo-scientific record of her weight loss on a strict 36-day diet. She had herself photographed naked every morning -- front, back, left, right -- as she "carved" her "ideal" self through abnegation. In a wall text she refers to Michelangelo, "our great predecessor," who wrote that a sculptor could not create anything that was not already in the marble.
In the early 1970's women were still tossing around the heady idea that they could do something other than diet themselves to perfection. Feminism released a number of female fantasies into the realm of artistic expression, including autobiographies as explorations of gender, pace Marcel Duchamp. Ms. Antin paraded in the costume of a king for a while, in her self-appointed kingdom of Solana Beach, Calif., documenting her transition to manhood in a video of applying a beard. (Costume loomed large in feminist and performance art: big girls dressing up.) Her subjects were puzzled when she greeted them on sidewalks, pushed a marketing cart and thumbed a ride, but this was California, so perhaps it did not seem so strange.
Ms. Antin was not a cheerleader for the feminist movement and did not think women were any more likely to have it all than men were. Her king appeared in a video leading his (or her) followers to the promised land, which turned out to be a realm of bones and ashes. Her stories tend to be quixotic comedies wrapped around an elegy.
The exploration of the naked self and the clothed fantasy was one tactic in the campaign to introduce "feminine" material into the mainstream of art. Though male artists like Pollock and Rothko had abstracted their angst, self-revelation in the 1970's was assumed to be predominantly female. When men revealed themselves, they would do so under wraps. No messy confessions on Roy Lichtenstein's canvases or Carl Andre's lines of bricks, no tears or hysteria, no leaky emotions or insecure moments hung out to dry. At least not recognizably.
Women put their inner lives, their well-kept secrets, their embarrassing imaginations on view. In Judy Chicago's "Dinner Party," the female genitalia, which nature has discreetly tucked away, came barely disguised to the dinner table. In novels like Erica Jong's "Fear of Flying," women's sexual fantasies -- at least one woman's -- were laid bare.
Around that time, narrative swung in on the art pendulum as a reaction to minimalism's insistence on the circumscribed, storyless, hard material fact of the object. Ms. Antin, a low-life playwright in a high cause, had been hooked on stories for some time. She put aside her royal male self for another fictional autobiography, this one the most feminine of fantasies, the ballerina. Millions of little girls once dreamed of being a ballerina, paragon of grace, beauty and weightlessness, soaring above baby fat and acne on delicate clouds of tulle. Ms. Antin had herself photographed on point in classic poses.
She also had the photographic session filmed for a piece called "Caught in the Act," where she is seen galumphing unsteadily off her toes or clinging to a prop to steady herself for her fabulous split second aloft. Giselle is a klutz! Deadpan, Ms. Antin deals a mortal blow to the illusion of beauty and perfection offered by photography and foisted by all the media, and hints that even dreams of twinkling toes wear running shoes by day.
The scenarios of "The Loves of a Ballerina" -- short, silent films viewed through the windows of a mock movie theater -- unfold like romance novels written by Harpo Marx. In "Love's Shadow," the ballerina's shadow is implored by a three-dimensional lover who, when she rebuffs his suit, impetuously shoots her silhouette. At once he is overcome by despair and tenderly clasps her dying shadow. In "Swan Lake," the ballerina, in a brief, black tutu, leans over and waggles her cute little behind. Et voila, there emerges from the groin of her male companion the head and long, curved neck of a plush swan. Alas, it soon droops, but the ballerina coaxes it up again, and the couple exits to applause.
Ms. Antin's most extensively pursued role was Eleanora Antinova, the only black ballerina in Diaghilev's company. In Antinova's first dance, "L'Esclave" ("The Slave"), she was chained and never moved her feet. "I was the only dancer in the world to do a stationary dance," her text says. "Luckily, the artists adored its self-referential ironies."
THE feminist movement in its early years was a white women's movement not overly concerned with race or ethnicity. Ms. Antin brought up the race issue early, and was criticized for playing a black woman. (She recently said that African-Americans didn't criticize her; only white liberals did.) The idea of a black ballerina in Diaghilev's company in the 1920's, when ballet was white to the tippy tip tips of its satin shoes and Paris was enamored of the American-born Josephine Baker, clad in bananas and dancing bogus jungle dances, is more pointed than a ballerina's big toe.
In 1981, Ms. Antinova, by then past her prime, down on her luck and subsisting on sherry, gave performances in New York and elsewhere in a salon that the Los Angeles show recreates, decorated with photographs of her great roles, her own amusing accounts of her choreography and her elegant water colors of Diaghilev and his scintillating circle. In performance she recalled her days of glory and slowly sank into her sherry. Again the fantasy does a smart jete and lands on the lip of the abyss.
Ms. Antin kept reinventing herself, proving that American fantasies had second and third acts. In an interview with Mr. Fox in the show's catalogue, she remarks that "service is the main role our culture has allotted to women, and we've been put down for it ever since." In comes Nurse Eleanor, cheerfully exploited by all manner of men and involved in soap opera adventures, some a bit too long-winded to be gripping, though she does perform an operation by herself.
Nurse Eleanor had another incarnation as Eleanor Nightingale, the heroic founder of the profession. Her all-too-properly buttoned-up family and her landmark career in the Crimean War are playacted by Ms. Antin and others in fine, fake period photographs. In a related play, Nurse Eleanor muses that bandaging a soldier meant sending him out to kill again. The war photographs include several images of the wounded and dead, subjects that Roger Fenton, the photographer who actually went to that war in 1855, never photographed because the British were not supposed to see them.
In the 1990's, Ms. Antin's references have grown wider. In "Vilna Nights" (1993), the windows of a mock-up of a bombed-out building in the Jewish ghetto in Vilna show scenes of the people who once lived there. A sobbing tailor ceaselessly mends the tattered clothes of dead children. A woman clutches letters in anguish before burning them. Two frightened, hungry children are miraculously visited by a menorah and a Hanukkah feast, only to have it all disappear when they sit down to eat. This view of the Holocaust is similar in spirit to work by Shimon Attie, who has projected pre-war photographs of residents and establishments of the former Jewish district in Berlin on the buildings that still stand there.
Ms. Antin, Jewish, a woman and an artist, considers herself an outsider through and through, so in a way a piece like "Vilna Nights" is but a more desperate comment on the identity and experience of the outsider than her comedic saunters through fantasy autobiographies. "I may be ironical, I may be funny," she says in the catalogue interview, "but I'm not kidding." She also says that even in her baby days she had her calling: causing trouble. Lucky us.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Love's Shadow" from "The Loves of a Ballerina," a silent-film series by Eleanor Antin, 1987. A set of 51 such cards chronicled the journey of a corps of boots from the Pacific Ocean to the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. They wound up in a dump.
