HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
Trenton's Focus on Small Manufacturers Yields Jobs

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER operating in Trenton for a century, Hill Refrigeration shut the doors to its 850,000-square-foot plant three years ago, among the last of a long list of big manufacturers to leave the state capital.
Hill subsequently gave its 25-acre site, on Pennington Avenue between Prospect and Calhoun Streets, to the city, which, in turn, razed part of the collection of industrial hulks that made up the old plant. The city then carved up the remaining 424,300 square feet of space into eight condominiums and over the next two years sold them for $1 each to small manufacturers, who invested $3.9 million to spruce up their space and set up shop. The city also plans to build a 70,000-square-foot building on the site as an incubator for companies to do light manufacturing, assembly and research. 
 The city, together with a local developer, is also developing a modern industrial park on a long-vacant 11-acre site, once home to a pottery manufacturing plant, that it inherited in 1972. Four buildings, totaling 45,500 square feet of space, have been or will soon be built and three more buildings with 40,000 more square feet could ultimately be built on the site, just off Route 1 and Olden Avenue.
Trenton's goal is to shore up its remaining industrial base and give it a modest boost. Last year, for the first time in decades, six new manufacturers moved into the city, increasing the number of such companies left within its borders to 91 and adding 140 manufacturing jobs, to 2,620.
To be sure, the city will never be the industrial powerhouse dotted with steel fabricating and pottery plants it was through the late 1940's, when it was home to 50,000 manufacturing jobs. But these projects are intended to show that Trenton "is an attractive place for small and mid-size industries to locate," said James T. Harveson, acting director of the city's Department of Housing and Economic Development. "We're using our resources to go after that market niche," he added.
Trenton is not alone. The state is also providing financial assistance to help businesses, especially small manufacturers, survive and grow and to attract new ones. Under its Business Incentive Program, it returns to companies, through grants for up to a decade, as much as 80 percent of the state personal income tax revenue generated by each new employee.
Blinds to Go Inc., a Canadian manufacturer of window blinds and shades, took advantage of the program to build a 150,000-square-foot manufacturing, warehouse and distribution plant on Cedarbridge Avenue in Lakewood. It is the company's first plant in the United States.
The New Jersey's Economic Development Authority also offers below-market-rate loans for expansion, renovation or the purchase of equipment. Last year, the autonomous authority gave out $94 million in loans for 37 projects, up from $50 million for 19 projects in 1994.
STILL, New Jersey continues to lose manufacturing jobs. The number of such jobs fell to 480,200 last year from 482,000 in 1997 -- and almost a million at the peak in 1969, according to state figures.
But Caren S. Franzini, executive director of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, said, "While traditional smokestack manufacturing may still be declining, we are seeing more clean industries, or high-tech manufacturers, growing in the state." They include biotech and pharmaceutical concerns, along with makers of cosmetics, computers and communications equipment, she said, adding that these clean industries are helping to stabilize the state's manufacturing base.
David T. Houston, president of Colliers Houston & Company, a commercial brokerage in Teaneck, said, referring to the new industries, "That area of the manufacturing sector is doing well, with companies leasing modern industrial buildings." There is a ripple effect to older buildings, too, he said.
The overall space market is actually tightening, due largely to the state's strong economy, the lack of new construction and the conversion of many old industrial buildings to retail or housing. Mr. Houston said that demand has also increased from tenants for light assembly as well as warehouse and distribution space, the biggest user in the market. And even small local manufacturers, like specialty food and packaging concerns as well as printing and graphic arts concerns, are looking for space, he added.
Stephen Jenco, senior research analyst at Grubb & Ellis, another commercial brokerage, added that landlords were carving up big industrial buildings for multiple tenants, which has "helped lease the larger buildings and reduce the overall vacancy rate." His company puts the industrial vacancy rate for the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market at 4.4 percent for this year's second quarter, down from 5.1 percent a year earlier. In turn, average annual rental rates rose by 23 cents, to $5.03 a square foot.
As rents rise, so does interest from tenants in more suburban areas in the state's cities, which offer lower rents and some geographical and transportation advantages. Mark Sanders, executive vice president at the Harris & Lerman brokerage in Totowa, said that in cities like Paterson and Passaic, tenants "no longer are finding the choices they once had." While relatively low rents in cities are a driving force, state programs and local initiatives like tax abatements also help, he said.
That is the strategy at play at the two Trenton projects. "We realized that while there is a need for industrial space at a more competitive price than the suburbs, there were not enough incentives to draw tenants," said Mr. Harveson, "so we provided them."
One issue, he said, is that industrial sites are often contaminated. But a 1992 study for Trenton showed that if sites were made available, the city, with its labor pool and highway access, would draw small companies, from manufacturers to technology concerns.
Mr. Harveson said the redevelopment of the Hill and Route 1 sites was helped by the easing of the state's cleanup rules for industrially polluted land. "We also indemnified from liability" the tenant-owners and developer for the two properties, he said, noting that they are also getting tax breaks from the city.
THE Janzer Corporation, which makes porcelain mailboxes and house signs, was the last of the tenants to move to the Hill site. The company relocated in February from 9,000 square feet in Hulmeville, Pa., to 29,000 square feet space at Hill and invested $500,000 in its new space, including $30,000 for equipment, said Thomas Janzer, its president.
"It was the deal of the century," he said of the price. "It's still a bad neighborhood, but the city cleaned up the site, which is gated, and Trenton has nowhere to go but up."
Other tenants at the site, all of whom have to stay for a decade, include Trenton Corrugated, which makes boxes; Genpac, which produces corrugated packaging, and C.J. Auto Parts, a distributor.
Mr. Harveson said that though the taxes on the improvements the owners made are frozen for five years, the redevelopment generates $165,900 in taxes a year, which is the same as what Hill Refrigeration would have paid for a building of the same size.
The city is redeveloping the Route 1 property, called the Route 1 Commerce Center, with Faigle Realty and Development of Trenton. Mr. Harveson said the city sells pieces of the site and charges the developer a "payment in lieu of taxes," which is lower than the normal tax rate, allowing that savings to be passed on to tenants.
Jeffrey D. Faigle, who runs the company bearing his name, said the site offered an opportunity for a modern industrial park that "would attract local and statewide businesses that want to expand." Rents range from $2 to $6 a square foot.
Of the two buildings built so far, one with 11,000 square feet houses a candle manufacturer; the other, with 10,000 square feet, is occupied by a fish distributor and processor. Another 10,000-square-foot building is under way for Tektite Industries, which makes underwater lighting devices, Mr. Faigle said, while a fourth, with 14,500 square feet, is planned.
"But if the city was not involved," he said, "I probably would not have moved ahead."
Mr. Harveson said the city, using public funds, would build the incubator building over the next two and a half years and would like to acquire more land along Route 1 to encourage additional industrial development. The hope is that eventually the activity "will have a ripple effect," he said, paving the way for private investment to take over and feed on itself.

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
Relying on the Luck of the Draw

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; E-mail address: liorder@nytimes.com

 BODY:
EVERYTHING I know about casino gambling comes from old James Bond movies. From a distance, I have admired the magnificent casino buildings at Monte Carlo and Baden-Baden, but never ventured into one. Casinos seemed to me places reserved for upper-class playboys with unlimited amounts of money to throw away, and beautiful women who are anxious to help them.
But, at the Port Jefferson ferry office, I picked up a flyer with a brazen invitation to come to the Mohegan Sun Casino in Connecticut. The fare of only $30, including the ferry and the bus, was impossible to resist. I purchased a ticket, and took my old tuxedo out of mothballs. James Bond always wore a tuxedo in the many casinos he visited. But my wife advised that, first time out, I should dress down a bit and rent a tuxedo in Connecticut if necessary. 
 My fellow players on the tour were not quite the reckless young aristocrats I had imagined. Before leaving, I thought that I might be too old for all this excitement. Now I began to worry that I might not be old enough. The majority of the group consisted of very senior citizens, and there was not a tuxedo anywhere in sight.
"Watch your step," said the driver kindly, as I climbed laboriously onto the bus at Bridgeport. Somehow, I had acquired arthritis on the ferry. After a long drive, we arrived on the casino grounds, excitement rising on the bus, and pacemakers working overtime. We were so deep in the woods that we might have been anywhere, or nowhere. Escape was obviously impossible.
The casino itself looks not unlike a prison or a mall, a huge blank building with no windows. We were greeted by Marlena, who gave us a $10 ticket to gamble on the Wheel of Fortune and another $10 voucher toward a meal thus (at least in theory), bringing the total cost of the trip down to $10. My plan was to use my voucher to win a couple of hundred dollars on the Wheel of Fortune, spend my winnings on some other games, and then retire to the bar with a martini (shaken, not stirred) until the bus came to take me away at 4:30.
Inside the entrance, most of the Long Island group vanished into the restrooms, and I continued alone into the mysterious interior. There was no Mohegan Sun, or any other kind of sun, to be seen inside the hall on this brilliant summer day, but a subdued twilight effect. The strangest thing was the noise, a continuous, penetrating tone about the key of A, which may be intended to generate a sense of tension and excitement. Nobody else seemed to notice.
The decor was meant to be evocative of American Indian themes: plastic rocks, animated wolves and abstract trees in different seasons. The visual effect was quite soothing. But this was canceled out by the overwhelming impact of 3,000 slot machines, all being played at once.
Obviously, in order to understand the casino experience, I had to play the slots. To get my stake, I took the $10 voucher to the Wheel of Fortune, placed it on number 13, and lost it immediately. This forced me to finance my own downfall, and I purchased a plastic bucket full of quarters. The machines were covered in words like "Slotopoly," "Bonus" "Wild," "Lucky," "Bonanza" and "Bar-Bar-Bar," but none of them had simple instructions. I chose one that seemed slightly less garish than the rest, and started feeding quarters into it. My bucketful vanished in what seemed like seconds. Even when I won something, I couldn't figure out why, although kindly ladies on each side took time out from their own efforts to explain about credits, bars and triple plays. After my second bucket of coins had been swallowed, I decided that these slot machines were for suckers, and I'd better get serious.
Between and around the slots were almost 200 gaming tables for poker, roulette, blackjack and more exotic games. Here the players were younger, the atmosphere more sociable, but the dedication just as intense.
My ignorance of these games was so obvious that I was quickly taken in hand by Judy, a member of the Long Island contingent, who obviously felt that I should never have been let out on my own. As we stood watching a baccarat game, the cards flashing out and vanishing like a conjuring trick, she explained the rules. As far as I could understand, this was a game of pure chance, depending on which cards happened to be dealt out. I was shocked, but somewhat encouraged. Anyone can win at a game of chance.
A man stood at the table with an impressive pile of chips. Assuming that the chips were worth 25 cents each, he was doing quite well.
"Can we join your game?" I asked.
"Sure," he said, "Do you know it's $100 a chip?"
Thank goodness the casino provided a selection of pleasant restaurants away from the racket of the floor. Taking my $10 meal ticket, I gambled on the fish of the day. It was excellent, and only about $9 above the usual price. But this is no place for people who believe in economy.
Fortified by lunch, I headed for the roulette wheels. I had always wanted to play roulette, which seems extraordinarily glamorous. In the movies, the hero always scoops up a fortune in chips, and is immediately surrounded by incredibly beautiful women in slinky dresses who want to give him financial advice. It didn't work quite like that for me. I purchased a cautious $20 worth of blue chips, and placed them on random numbers. My attention tended to drift to decor, the colorful outfits worn by the other players and reflections on the last days of Roman Empire. I was amazed when the croupier pushed a stack of chips back at me. Had I ordered these by mistake? No, it appeared that I had won them by placing one or more of my chips on the correct number. I tried to pay more attention to the game, listening for the cries of "Faites vos jeux, madames et messieurs," "Neuf a la banque" and "Rien non va plus," so familiar from a hundred movies. But the young female croupier said nothing at all, running the game in complete silence, with hand gestures. I suppose that sometimes they must get foreigners into the casino, from the remoter regions of Connecticut, or even Rhode Island, who are unable to speak French. The wheel spun, and my mind drifted off again. Next time I looked down, all my chips were gone and the croupier was giving me the old raised-eyebrow look. I gave her my best James Bond shrug and left.
I'm no economist, but I can't see how it helps the Long Island economy to send residents over to Connecticut with their pockets stuffed with money, and bring them back broke. If people are determined to throw their money away, why can't we have our own Long Island casino, down on the Shinnecock Reservation? The worst that can happen is that members of the Shinnecock tribe will get very rich, and the rest of us will get very poor. And that will be nothing but historical justice.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
A Major New Jersey Developer Gets Even Busier

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
STEVE POZYCKI certainly is busy these days. Already the designated developer of a 1.1-million-square-foot office building on the Hudson River in Hoboken, N.J., he plunged farther into the hot waterfront market last month by buying a 300,000-square-foot former toothpaste factory in Jersey City from Colgate-Palmolive for conversion to offices.
Meanwhile, his joint venture with the publicly traded Mack-Cali real estate investment trust has broken ground in Bernards Township near I-78 for a 135,000-square-foot office building to be called Liberty Corner Corporate Center. The joint venture partnership is also planning to put up a 100,000-square-foot building near the Princeton Junction train station. 
 And for a 300,000-square-foot two-building complex that was completed earlier this year in Princeton, he recently signed Merrill Lynch to a long-term lease for 232,000 square feet.
Mr. Pozycki is president of SJP Properties, one of the largest private developers and owners of commercial property in New Jersey, with 10 million square feet of Class A office properties in its portfolio. In a recent interview, he discussed his projects and his outlook for the office-property market in northern New Jersey and areas nearby.
Although SJP did a lot of building for corporate clients in the early 1990's, in the last year and a half it has completed 1.2 million square feet of speculative office space, with 70 percent of it already leased.
But Mr. Pozycki insists he is being conservative. "We do not see tremendous growth in office in most markets," he said. "It's not like the 80's when things exploded."
Instead, he said he is carefully choosing opportunities in the 17 or so submarkets in the northern part of the state. For instance, he said, Princeton was overdue for what developers like to call "new product."
"There hadn't been a new building in Princeton since the end of the 1980's," he said. "That's a significant amount of time with nothing being delivered." Merrill Lynch has said it will devote 44,000 square feet of the property to its retail brokerage operation, with the remaining space allocated to different divisions of the company.
In general, Mr. Pozycki said, the key to speculative office building is to have the right product on the market at the right time. "You have to work hard and you have to have luck," he said, adding, "having the right building at the right time helps luck."
The Jersey City development is a timing play, he said. The success of office developments there by the Lefrak Organization at Newport Office Center and Hartz Mountain Industries at 90 Hudson Street and the easy accessibility to lower Manhattan has made the Jersey City office market a desirable one.
BY purchasing an existing building and converting it, Mr. Pozycki said, he can have his development on the market before his rivals, who are building out of the ground. Indeed, for the sake of speed, he is abandoning earlier plans to add six stories to the structure.
SJP plans to strip the eight-story building back to its concrete walls, cut new elevator shafts, install new mechanical equipment and a new lobby and have it on the market by the first quarter of next year. "I'm not going to have any competition for a year and a half," he said, referring to the companies that are planning to erect new buildings, such as Lefrak's 800,000-square-foot Newport Office Center IV and Hartz's 70 Hudson Street.
He said his company had been looking at Jersey City for 10 years but did not find it attractive until the old industrial character of the city's waterfront had begun to change. Now that it clearly has, he said he expects economic development to spread down the waterfront through the rest of the city and Bayonne.
He expects corporate tenants to head north of Jersey City, as well, to Hoboken, where that city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have an agreement with SJP for the company to build an office tower directly on the Hudson River adjacent to Hoboken Terminal. The project is still awaiting the signing of an anchor tenant, but Mr. Pozycki said the deal is "on the verge" of completion.
He said many of the people who work at the big financial services companies in Manhattan already live in Hoboken, which has become increasingly gentrified in recent years. "They don't like to hear it in New York, but Hoboken is the sixth borough," he said. The building, which will sit behind a park and pier being developed by the Port Authority, will have unusually large floors of up to 95,000 square feet, which may make it attractive to financial companies that need space for trading operations.
As enthusiastic as he is about New Jersey's old industrial cities along the Hudson, Mr. Pozycki is reserved about the largest city, Newark. Despite public and private efforts to prime economic recovery there, with the new performing arts center and new minor league baseball stadium, and with other sporting arenas being proposed, he cautioned the state to be careful about how much money it spends there to avoid driving up property values too quickly.
"Corporations move to a place like that because it is cheaper," he said. "If the state puts too much in there it could hurt the city's renaissance."
ONE of the statements SJP executives like to make is that they have never turned a building back to a lender because they lost control of its finances. As a result they have willing lenders, particularly corporate pension funds managed by Prudential. Mr. Pozycki said that in today's market, a developer has to get speculative projects started with his own money and then bring in a financial partner once it is well along, retaining an equity interest. As an example, he said, the building where SJP maintains its headquarters in Morris Corporate Park in Parsippany "is owned by Chrysler and me."
Another source of funds is the joint venture with Mack-Cali, which is also based in New Jersey. The two companies control enough land to build 15 million square feet of office space in the state. Mr. Pozycki said he expects to begin the second project with Mack-Cali, near the Princeton Junction train station in West Windsor, later this year.
He said that when the Bernards Township and Princeton Junction projects are completed, the Mack-Cali REIT would have the opportunity to add the buildings to its own portfolio or offer them to other investors.
Although he said he does not expect great growth in the office market, he said the long period when almost nothing was built left some tenants stuck in older buildings and looking to trade up. This, he said, is what justified new construction.
"Office users have evolved over time, and their requirements for power, air-conditioning and slab-to-slab heights have changed," he said. "There are buildings that are functionally obsolete. There is just not a lot of Class A quality in the 150 million square feet of offices in northern New Jersey."
In addition, the older office buildings often do not have the amenities, such as a cafeteria, gym and walking trails, that SJP provides in new properties.
SJP owns or controls enough land in New Jersey to develop seven million more square feet of offices. In an indication of how he views the future of the office market in the area, he has also has acquired land for five million square feet of development across the Delaware River in the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania.
"As you go west on Routes 78 and 80 you get into areas where the road network was built for farmers," he said. Commercial development in those areas will be difficult, he said.
The Lehigh Valley is not much more than a 40-minute drive from most commercial areas in New Jersey and has ample infrastructure from its past as an industrial powerhouse.
"It's a little early for office, but there is housing going up and the regional airport has been expanded," he said. "The Lehigh Valley is a market that's coming."

HEADLINE: LIPA Beats the Heat, but Barely

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
OF all the sighs of relief heard around the Island last week when cooler, drier air moved into the area and broke a 10-day heat wave, none were louder than those at the offices of the Long Island Power Authority.
In its first sustained hot-weather challenge since becoming Long Island's electric supplier, LIPA has been scavenging for every kilowatt in a summer of record-breaking temperatures and unprecedented demand for electricity. 
 So far, the authority has managed to scrape by, with the main blemish on its record the interruption of service to 100,000 of its one million customers during the extraordinary heat wave over the long July 4 weekend.
But the LIPA system is routinely stretched to its limits in periods of hot, humid weather when customers turn on more than a million air conditioners and send demand soaring. And weeks of summer are still ahead.
Over the long term, LIPA's limits are being tested by a rise in demand caused by the Island's booming economy and, ironically, by LIPA's own success in reducing electric rates that under its predecessor, the Long Island Lighting Company, had been the highest in the country, excluding Hawaii.
But one of LIPA's more pressing problems, at least for this summer, is a transformer failure that has reduced its ability to import electricity by 300 megawatts, or about the capacity of a mid-sized generating station.
The authority chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said last week that despite the reduced capacity the authority avoided the major loss-of-service problems that some regional utilities experienced during the heat wave in early July. Though the number of people who lost power on Long Island was comparable to the number blacked out in New York City and other areas served by Consolidated Edison, LIPA did not have the extended blackouts experienced by some Con Ed customers, who went up to three days without power.
Prior to July, LIPA's record demand was 4,208 megawatts set on July 22 last year, a figure already surpassed several times this summer. Average demand on cooler summer days ranges from 3,400 to 3,600 megawatts.
But on Tuesday, July 6, after the three-day Fourth of July weekend, electric demand on Long Island hit a record of 4,590 megawatts, uncomfortably close to the authority's maximum capacity, just over 5,100 megawatts. Mr. Kessel said then that the authority was "entering uncharted territory" where rolling blackouts might have to be ordered to avoid a system-wide failure.
Mr. Kessel said that luck and cooperation from Long Island businesses that voluntary curtailed electric use saved the severely overburdened and overheated electric system on July 6, and warned that although the authority also met high demand in other periods during the hottest July on record, more challenges lay ahead.
"There is no question that the system is stressed," Mr. Kessel said. "But we have done very well considering we lost that transformer and considering that we experienced the hottest July on record. Almost every other utility in the region has gone down at one point, and we haven't so far."
But Gordian Raacke, executive director of the Citizens Advisory Panel, a court-appointed watchdog for LIPA, took a different view of the authority's performance in July.
"Obviously they had some problems and some fairly extensive outages," he said. "Before the summer they assured us they were prepared to meet any kind of weather conditions. They ran fancy television commercials and expensive, full-page newspaper ads saying they were ready, and only a few weeks later customers found out it wasn't so."
Mr. Kessel acknowledged that "three or four times" power supplies had dipped below an 18 percent reserve power requirement set by the New York Power Pool, an association of utilities that coordinates the flow of power across the state.
As recently as July 27, LIPA's peak use reached 4,237 megawatts on a day when total capacity, which fluctuates from day to day, was 4,499. That use left only 6 percent reserve power; to maintain the 18 percent margin, peak demand on that day could not have exceeded 3,689 megawatts.
Projections of power shortages were often heard from the Long Island Lighting Company during the years it was building the never-opened, 800-megawatt Shoreham nuclear plant. In the 1970's, Lilco proposed building two additional nuclear plants in Jamesport, near Riverhead, with a combined capacity of more than 1,100 megawatts.
The Jamesport proposal was rejected by the state in 1980, though Lilco was given permission to build two coal-burning plants at the more than 500-acre Jamesport property. The plants were never built. Critics of Lilco, including Mr. Kessel, said the utility neglected its power plants and electric system during the 1970's and 1980's as it concentrated on bringing the Shoreham plant on line. But in 1989, after years of intense public opposition to the plant because of safety concerns, the Shoreham project was mothballed.
The aging, fossil fuel-powered plants in the Lilco system have since been repaired and upgraded to extend their useful life. Lilco had planned to retire some of the plants after the Shoreham reactor came on line.
Any chance that the broken transformer at the East Garden City substation can be replaced or fixed in time to meet summer demand appears to have collapsed. When authority officials reported on the transformer failure at a board meeting in May marking the authority's first anniversary, officials said they anticipated that a temporary replacement transformer would be in operation by this month.
Mr. Kessel said last week that the authority learned later that the replacement could not be completed until October, when power demand will be far lower. He said the authority then decided to scrap plans for a replacement and instead would wait for the failed transformer to be rebuilt.
The transformer is owned by the New York Power Authority, which is performing the repairs. It is one of two transformers at an East Garden City substation connected to a transmission cable that can carry 600 megawatts of electricity. The cable runs under Long island Sound to a substation in Westchester County.
Mr. Kessel said that the transformer outage reduced from 1,000 to 700 megawatts the amount of power that can be imported to Nassau and Suffolk.
Another underwater cable able to carry 286 megawatts from Norwalk, Conn., to Northport is also out of service because of equipment problems on the Connecticut side.
But the authority said the actual power loss was only 50 to 80 megawatts because the line shared land-based transmission lines used by the Northport generating station, a four-unit plant owned by Keyspan Energy that generates more than 1,500 megawatts.
Keyspan, a company formed by Brooklyn Union and the former Long Island Lighting Company, also owns and operates former Lilco generation stations at Port Jefferson, Island Park, Glenwood and Far Rockaway, as well as 42 smaller "peaking units" that operate on hotter summer days.
Keyspan sells the power to LIPA, and also operates the authority's electric transmission and distribution system under a contract with the authority. A Keyspan senior vice president, David J. Manning, said last week that Keyspan plants had been operating at or near capacity and were "flat out" on July 6, the day of record demand.
In addition to the Westchester-to-East Garden City cable, the authority also imports power on a 650-megawatt underwater cable from Yonkers to a substation in Port Washington. Other imports come over land lines in Queens linking the authority with Con Edison.
The New York Power Authority also supplies the authority with power from a 136-megawatt plant in Holtsville. Other supplies are available from municipal utilities in Freeport, Rockville Centre and Greenport, and from the American Ref-Fuel plant in East Garden City.
Mr. Kessel said that even when the broken transformer was back in service, electricity supplies would remain tight during the next two summers, underscoring a need for more import capacity, new generating plants on Long Island and more ambitious conservation programs.
He said that the growth rate for electricity demand, now more than 4 percent annually, also mandated expanded supplies.
The authority trustees voted last year to allow a subsidiary of Hydro Quebec, the Canadian hydroelectric giant, to proceed with a $1.9 million study for a new power cable to be in service in 2002. If approved, the cable would carry 600 megawatts of power 26 miles under Long Island Sound from Connecticut to the site of the former Shoreham nuclear power plant.
Last week a State Supreme Court justice, citing the need for more power, allowed the study to proceed despite a challenge from a competing bidder, AEP Resources Service Company, which contended that the authority should have accepted its lower bid.
In another step toward more power, the authority issued a request for proposals last month for three 75-megawatt power plants to be built on Long Island to come on line beginning in 2001.
Mr. Kessel said that one of the plants was likely to be built in Southampton or East Hampton, where second-home construction has caused electricity demand to spike more dramatically than anywhere else on Long Island.
Bert J. Cunningham, the authority vice president for communications, said that many of the new homes had central air-conditioning and other amenities that increased electricity use. "We have seen some high numbers, quite frankly," he said.
The authority has also allocated $32 million for each of the next five years for conservation programs, an amount that conservation advocates say is insufficient.
"The authority needs to do more than just some token, environmentally friendly-sounding power program," Mr. Raacke said "But there seems to be no concerted effort. Instead, the authority is following right in Lilco's footsteps and wants to build more polluting and environmentally harmful power plants."

HEADLINE: FIRST PERSON;
Tuxedo and Martini Dreams

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; David Bouchier, who lives in Wading River, N.Y., is an essayist and a music host at WSHU, an National Public Radio station in Fairfield.

 BODY:
EVERYTHING I know about casino gambling comes from old James Bond movies. From a distance, I have admired the magnificent casino buildings at Monte Carlo and Baden-Baden, but never ventured into one. Casinos seemed to me places reserved for upper-class playboys with unlimited amounts of money to throw away, and beautiful women who are anxious to help them.
But, at the Port Jefferson ferry office, I picked up a flier with a brazen invitation to come to the Mohegan Sun Casino in Connecticut. The fare of only $30, incuding the ferry and the bus, was impossible to resist. I purchased a ticket, and took my old tuxedo out of mothballs. James Bond always wore a tuxedo in the many casinos he visited. But my wife advised that, first time out, I should dress down a bit and rent a tuxedo in Connecticut if necessary. 
 My fellow players on the tour were not quite the reckless young aristocrats I had imagined. Before leaving, I thought that I might be too old for all this excitement. Now I began to worry that I might not be old enough. The majority of the group consisted of very elderly people, and there was not a tuxedo anywhere in sight.
"Watch your step," said the driver kindly, as I climbed laboriously on to the bus at Bridgeport. Somehow, I had acquired arthritis on the ferry. After a long drive, we arrived on the casino grounds, excitement rising on the bus, and pacemakers working overtime. We were so deep in the woods that we might have been anywhere, or nowhere. Escape was obviously impossible.
The casino itself looks not unlike a prison or a mall, a huge blank building with no windows. We were greeted by Marlena, who gave us a $10 ticket to gamble on the Wheel of Fortune and another $10 voucher towards a meal thus (at least in theory) bringing the total cost of the trip down to $10.
My plan was to use my voucher to win a couple of hundred dollars on the Wheel of Fortune, spend my winnings on some other games, and then retire to the bar with a martini (shaken, not stirred) until the bus came to take me away at 4:30.
Inside the entrance, most of the Long Island group vanished into the restrooms, and I continued alone into the mysterious interior of the place. There was no Mohegan Sun, or any other kind of sun, to be seen inside the hall on this brilliant summer day, but a subdued twilight zone effect. The strangest thing was the noise, a continuous, penetrating tone about the key of A, which may be intended to generate a sense of tension and excitement. Nobody else seemed to notice.
The decor was meant to be evocative of American Indian themes: plastic rocks, animated wolves and abstract trees in different seasons. The visual effect was quite soothing. But this was canceled out by the overwhelming impact of 3,000 slot machines, all being played at once.
Obviously, in order to understand the casino experience, I had to play the slots. To get my stake, I took the $10 voucher to the Wheel of Fortune, placed it on number 13, and lost it immediately. This forced me to finance my own downfall, and I purchased a plastic bucket full of quarters. The machines were covered in words like "Slotopoly," "Bonus" "Wild," "Lucky," "Bonanza" and "Bar-Bar-Bar," but none of them had simple instructions.
I chose one that seemed slightly less garish than the rest, and started feeding quarters into it. My bucketful vanished in what seemed like seconds. Even when I won something, I couldn't figure out why, although kindly ladies on each side took time out from their own efforts to explain credits, bars and triple plays. After my second bucket of coins had been swallowed, I decided that these slot machines were for suckers, and I'd better get serious.
Between and around the slots were almost 200 gaming tables for poker, roulette, blackjack and more exotic games. Here the players were younger, the atmosphere more sociable, but the dedication just as intense.
My ignorance of these games was so obvious that I was quickly taken in hand by Judy, a member of the Long Island contingent, who obviously felt that I should never have been let out on my own. As we stood watching a baccarat game, the cards flashing out and vanishing like a conjuring rite, she explained the rules to me. As far as I could understand, this was a game of pure chance, depending on which cards happened to be dealt out. I was shocked, but somewhat encouraged. Anyone can win at a game of chance.
A man stood at the table with an impressive pile of chips. Assuming that the chips were worth 25 cents each, he was doing quite well.
"Can we join your game?" I asked.
"Sure," he said, "Do you know it's $100 a chip?"
Thank goodness the casino provided a selection of pleasant restaurants away from the racket of the floor. Taking my $10 meal ticket, I gambled on the fish of the day. It was excellent, and only about $9 above the usual price. But this is no place for people who believe in economy.
Fortified by lunch, I headed for the roulette wheels. I had always wanted to play roulette, which seems extraordinarily glamorous.
In the movies, the hero always scoops up a fortune in chips, and is immediately surrounded by incredibly beautiful girls in slinky dresses who want to give him financial advice. It didn't work quite like that for me.
I purchased a cautious $20 worth of blue chips, and placed them on random numbers. My attention tended to drift to decor, the colorful outfits worn by the other players and reflections on the last days of Roman Empire. I was amazed when the croupier pushed a whole stack of chips back at me.
Had I ordered these by mistake? No, it appeared that I had won them by placing one or more of my chips on the correct number.
I tried to pay more attention to the game, listening for the cries of "Faites vos jeux, mesdames et messieurs," "Neuf a la banque" and "Rien non va plus," so familiar from a hundred movies.
But the young female croupier said nothing at all, running the game in complete silence, with hand gestures. I suppose that sometimes they must get foreigners into the casino, from the remoter regions of Connecticut, or even Rhode Island, who are unable to speak French.
The wheel spun, and my mind drifted off again. Next time I looked down, all my chips were gone and the croupier was giving me the old raised-eyebrow look.
I gave her my best James Bond shrug and left.

HEADLINE: A Trip to Italy Without Leaving Home

BYLINE: By ALIX BOYLE

 BODY:
WHILE Italian opera pours out of a boombox, a group of 20 children paint their own interpretation of Botticelli's "Birth of Venus." Those who have finished their watercolors build a three-dimensional puzzle of a cathedral in Italy.
In the classrooms down the hall, boys and girls study Italian culture or learn to count in Italian. In North Haven this summer fourth-and fifth-grade students from across the region join each other to learn Italian language, culture and cooking in a free, two-week summer program. 
 "We want the children to feel as if they were dropped from a plane to a place called Camp Paesano," said Rita Leonardi, who is in charge of the camp, which was run this year in Chaplin as well as in North Haven.
Nana Asiedu, a 9-year-old of Orange, said he loves the program because it's so much fun he hardly notices that he's learning.
"We get to do a lot of exciting things, like taste Italian stuff like Italian ice," Nana said.
Caitlin MacDonald, 10, of New Haven, learned that ciao means hello or good-bye to friends, but that buon giorno and arrivederci should be used when speaking with adults. Caitlin also liked learning about Michaelangelo and Leonardo Da Vinci. Of the Mona Lisa, she said, "The way her eyes follow you is kind of mysterious."
Nana, however, was unimpressed with the Mona Lisa's famous smile. "It's a boring old smile," he said.
While the children are clearly enjoying the days filled with songs, games and art, all conducted in Italian, the program serves another purpose as well. It is part of a plan to bring children from the cities and the suburbs together for a multicultural experience. The program was a response to Sheff v. O'Neill, a court case in which a group of minority students and their parents sued the state for failing to provide equal educational opportunities. The ruling in 1996 came down in favor of the plaintiffs, and the state legislature passed a law to promote equal educational opportunity in its school districts.
Summer programs like Camp Paesano are just one of a number of initiatives to promote multicultural awareness and racial, social and economic balance among the state's schoolchildren.
"It's an interdistrict program open to all public school students in those towns, and it provides a chance for kids from different communities to get together and therefore break down walls of isolation," said Tom Murphy, spokesman for the State Department of Education, which supports the program.
"It uses state dollars to reach a state interest of equal educational opportunities and reducing isolation. It's a voluntary program that's locally designed."
In addition to Camp Paesano, there are about 45 state-funded summer programs on topics like marine biology, writing, and math and science. There are more children applying for the programs than the state can serve, Mr. Murphy said. For several years, Ms. Leonardi has run Camp Paesano in Chaplin, near the University of Connecticut, and this year was asked to start the program in North Haven under the auspices of Area Cooperative Educational Services or ACES.
Just two weeks before school ended, notices were sent to parents of public school students in 15 cities in New Haven and surrounding cities, including Ansonia, Bethany, Branford, Derby, Durham, East Haven, Middleford, Milford, Naugatuck, North Haven, Northford, Orange, Oxford, Shelton and Wallingford. Students were chosen by lottery for the half-day program in North Haven. Private school students and those who are home-schooled were not eligible to attend. Bus transportation is provided and there is a nurse on the premises at North Haven Middle School.
This year only a handful of minority students applied to the program, and through more extensive marketing next year, Ms. Leonardi hopes to attract more African-American and Hispanic children, she said. There are four teachers and three teacher's aides for 68 children. All the teachers speak Italian and instruct the children in the language. The children learn quickly. "What I teach here in two weeks is what I teach in high school in two months," said Susanna LaVorgna, a Camp Paesano instructor who teaches Italian and Spanish at Trumbull High School during the school year.
"In school, foreign language should start in kindergarten," said Ms. Leonardi, who was raised in Italy and teaches Italian at Brien McMahon High School in Norwalk. "Then the child will be more able to reproduce the sound like a native speaker. Why should children study a foreign language? It makes them smarter."
Basic survival in Italian is stressed. "What is your name?" "My name is" and "Where is the bathroom?" are commonly taught phrases. Children in the North Haven program also take a field trip to the Liuzzi cheese factory and there is an Italian festival at the end of camp.
A puppeteer treats the children to a show using pupi siciliani, the rod puppets that have been used in Italy for centuries. (There is a spot inside the puppet that holds wine, which spills out at the appropriate moment as blood and guts.)
"For me, teaching Italian is a passion," Ms. Leonardi said. "Finding teachers who are upbeat and enthusiastic, that's what makes the program click. We want the children to leave the program loving it."
Joedi Brown, a teacher's aide for the program, has learned about managing groups of children and has broadened her own knowledge of Italian by working at Camp Paesano. Ms. Brown, a 16-year-old senior at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven, takes Italian for her high school language requirement and studied in Italy last year in the Sister Cities program, an exchange with students from Amalfi, Italy, an area near Naples. Her 8-year-old sister, Annabelle, is a Camp Paesano participant.
Ms. Brown, who is African-American, said she believes the program can be successful in integrating children from the suburbs with children from the city and thinks that suburban children need more exposure to children of other races and ethnic backgrounds. "We separate the kids into different groups so they're not with their friends, and they're forced to make new friends," Ms. Brown said, adding, "next year I'd like to see more people from New Haven and the other towns apply."
Although Camp Paesano North Haven has already concluded for this year, parents who live in the participating communities can call ACES in Hamden at (203) 407-4400 for information on the program for next summer.
The Camp Paesano in Chaplin runs through Aug. 13. The program is full, but to inquire about cancellations, call (860) 455-0707.

HEADLINE: Q & A/Susan Bysiewicz;
'C.E.O.' of Company Worth $20 Million

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK

 BODY:
AS a candidate for the office of Secretary of the State, Susan Bysiewicz stressed her interest in the business side of the job. While certainly not all business, the office is more business-oriented than ever. Ms. Bysiewicz, a corporate lawyer, had strong opinions about where change was needed.
"We want to make that first point of contact into state government as positive and as productive as possible," she said. She takes pride in making her office accessible and efficient for Connecticut's business and legal community. 
 Ms. Bysiewicz, 37, grew up on her grandparents' Middletown farm. She proudly speaks of her Polish and Greek heritage and displays a red and white Polish flag in her office beside the American flag. "That's because I am the first Polish-American ever elected to statewide constitutional office in Connecticut," she said. She lightheartedly said that her heritage gives her great food as well as a work ethic and quickly adds "an appreciation for learning." She is a graduate of Yale University and Duke University Law School.
 She lives in Middletown with her husband, David H. Donaldson, and their three children, Ava, 7, Leyna, 5 and Tristan, 3. She credits her mother-in-law and husband with creating the support systems that make it possible for her to do the demanding work of the Secretary of the State.
"I like to say the Secretary of the State is the C.E.O. of a $20 million company because our commercial recording division generates about $20 million for the general fund," Ms. Bysiewicz said. Recently, she discussed her job as Secretary of the State and her emphasis on the business side of her responsibilities. Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Q. In what ways is the Secretary of the State's office involved with Connecticut business?
 A. There are two chief responsibilities of the Secretary's office. One is to run the elections in the State of Connecticut to make sure they run fairly and efficiently because the Secretary is the chief election official. The Secretary of the State is also the chief business registrar for the State of Connecticut. Our office registers over 100,000 corporations in the state. It's a matter of state law. We also register thousands of limited-liability companies and we register limited partnerships.
 You may not begin your business in the State of Connecticut unless you register with us first. It's a very important function. You want businesses to be legitimate and to know where they are located.
 Q. What did you do as a business lawyer with this office?
 A. I would register corporations for my clients and frequently dealt with the commercial recording division because liens on personal property are all filed in the Secretary of the State's Office. At the time that I was practicing in the late 80's there was a problem. There was a backlog. Liens were not being filed on a timely basis. I remember as a young attorney going to the Commercial Recording Division and seeing plastic tubs on the floor filled with U.C.C. statements, which are lien filings.
 We don't have a backlog now. One of our messages to the business and legal community is that we are running smoothly and efficiently.
 Q. Are there other changes in that procedure?
 A. One of the things I used to wish for when I was practicing business law was to have information available on computer. By September we will have all of the state's business information available on the Internet for free to people in the business and legal community. Now what happens is paralegals or attorneys who seek this information have to come to the office or pay a private service to get the information.
 Q. So you are increasing the use of computerized systems in your office?
 A. In this past legislative session, which ended in June, an electronic commerce bill was passed. That means businesses will be able to sign binding contracts over the Internet in Connecticut. It also means clients of our office will be able to send all of their business filings electronically. It's much more efficient. Our agency would like to be a leader in the state in making technology more accessible and easier to deal with our office.
 Trade on the Internet is becoming very widespread. The problem is our laws have not caught up with electronic commerce. We just passed a bill in the Connecticut legislature to allow binding contracts to be signed over the Internet. Until that legislation was passed, parties could sign a contract but they couldn't go to court and sue on it. Therefore people weren't willing to send us business documents electronically because our state courts didn't recognize electronic signatures. We are pleased that it was passed. This will allow the people who use our office to send us their business documents electronically.
 Q. Would you call yourself a Connecticut business booster?
 A. One of the things I was hoping to do in the Secretary of the State's Office when I came was to provide businesses with more information about business opportunities in Connecticut. That's both to businesses that are here already and also to businesses that are not located here, but might be interested in coming.
For instance, there are businesses who have part of their operation here and are registered here, and we have a new pamphlet that will let them know what the advantages of moving other factories or offices here are. We have a great location between Boston and New York, a highly educated work force and Connecticut is a beautiful place to live. Connecticut has great schools, which is one of the main reasons why they come.
 Q. Do you envision overseas trading becoming a more significant part of Connecticut economic life?
 A. Many medium and small businesses in Connecticut have not entered the international marketplace. Those are the companies creating 80 percent of the new jobs. If we are growing in the export area, it means we are expanding our job base in Connecticut. That's one of the reasons why we did a trade seminar in May to let people know about export opportunities in Eastern Europe. We had over 100 small- and medium-sized businesses that attended to listen to information about opportunities in Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. We are also planning on doing future forums and seminars. We are planning one in New Haven specifically geared toward women and minorities in early fall.
 
The Web site for the office of the Secretary of the State: www.state.ct.us/sots.

HEADLINE: For Architects, It's a Boom Town

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
FRESHLY recruited from a corporate colossus, the new president strides into a rapidly growing company in search of even higher profits, untapped markets and maybe an acquisition or two.
The description could fit many Wall Street firms. But the firm in question is Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. You can easily spot its architects, planners and interior designers. They're the ones dressed completely in black among all those navy blue and charcoal gray suits in the canyons of the financial district. 
 That Skidmore now does business from 14 Wall Street, on a crossroads it shares with the New York Stock Exchange and J. P. Morgan, is in one sense coincidental. (The firm just needed affordable space.) In another sense, it is an apt metaphor for the state of the profession at the moment. Like Wall Street, architecture is booming.
Five years ago, Skidmore had 200 employees in New York, down from a peak of 425 in 1988. The firm moved downtown last October into space designed for up to 325 employees. There are now 340.
Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, by some rankings the largest architectural firm in America, has doubled the size of its New York office since 1994, from 50 to 100 employees. So has Gensler, another national giant, whose New York office has grown from 169 to 334 employees in the past five years. The ranks at H L W International's New York office have risen from 215 to 310 in the same period.
Good fortune is also visiting small firms. Wendy Evans Joseph has watched her practice at 500 Park Avenue grow from one person in 1994 to six today. "I could have 20 people, there's so much work right now," she said. Her projects include a V-shaped, cable-stayed pedestrian bridge over East 63d Street for Rockefeller University and, in Dallas, the Women's Museum: An Institute for the Future.
Roberta Washington, too, has as much work as she can handle in her 10-person office at 271 West 125th Street. But she depends on government agencies and nonprofit institutions for jobs: a new station for the Franklin Avenue shuttle in Brooklyn, four clinics for the Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn, 27 homes in central Harlem, two schools in New Haven.
"I'm not the only black architect whose majority of work is public work," she said. "It goes back to the root of how potential clients select architects. A lot of it has to do with who you know."
"There are very few of us who can say we're benefiting from the boom," Ms. Washington said. "It would be great to participate and not just see it through the glass." Because salary levels have risen faster than fees, she cannot afford the extra staff she needs and so finds herself working longer hours.
To judge from help-wanted advertising, the demand for architects is greater than it has been in a decade. In July 1989, The New York Times ran an average of 42 ads for architectural positions in its Sunday classified section. In July 1994, with the real estate market in tatters, the average was 25 ads. Last month, it was 79.
Fueling the demand is the scarcity of experienced architects in their late 30's and early 40's. "There is a missing generation," said David M. Childs, the chairman designate of Skidmore. Despairing of their prospects earlier this decade, they either got out of architecture or never got into it.
"We were taking jobs that smaller firms would have taken," recalled A. Eugene Kohn, a founding principal of Kohn Pedersen Fox. "Smaller firms were taking jobs that new firms might have taken. And new people were saying, 'Forget it.' "
"Where did they go?" asked Walter A. Hunt Jr., a managing principal of Gensler. "Maybe they're running a bed-and-breakfast in Vermont. Maybe they're fishing." It is widely supposed that those embryonic architects wound up in other parts of the country or related fields like construction management and real estate development.
Their absence is keenly felt. "What's generally available is a zero- to 8-year experience level," said Carl W. Ordemann, the managing principal of the New York office of Perkins & Will. "Then there's a substantial gap in the 8- to 15-year level. Every office, across the board, is suffering from that gap. You can't do jobs as well without those people as part of the team."
The scarcity of experienced architects allows some of them to command salaries in the range of $60,000 to $70,000 -- a small fortune for architectural staffers.
"It's a good thing for the profession at one level," said Kenneth H. Drucker, director of design and senior principal at the New York office of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, "but at another level, the fees were lowered to remain competitive and they haven't rebounded. They've stayed low, salaries have risen and headhunters are pursuing your professional staff."
THOMAS BALSLEY, a landscape architect who designed Gantry Plaza State Park on the Queens waterfront, would not want to return to the old days. "If anyone complains about working weekends," he said, "I'll show them the help wanted ads from eight years ago."
Nonetheless, he noted that higher salaries and the cost of computer equipment and programs had pushed up operating costs. "We're not even close to being as profitable as we were in the 80's," Mr. Balsley said.
Adding to Mr. Balsley's concerns are signs that the Flatiron district, where he and many other architects have offices, may be growing too popular -- and too pricey. He would love to stay in 119 Fifth Avenue, at 19th Street, he said, but "with all the I.P.O. brats running around with million-dollar bills hanging out of their pockets, landlords won't even negotiate."
Costas Kondylis & Associates is preparing to leave 3 West 18th Street in October for new quarters at 31 West 27th Street.
Mr. Kondylis is designing Trump World Tower at the east end of 47th Street and Larry Silverstein's River Place complex at the west end of 42d Street. His office has grown from 28 to 64 people since 1994. "The rents in the Flatiron district have gone up," Mr. Kondylis said. "So the new area for architects is the West 20's."
Overall, however, the movement over time has been downtown. The highest concentration of membership in the American Institute of Architects is in ZIP code 10003 around Union Square, which takes in parts of Ladies' Mile, the Flatiron district, Greenwich Village and the East Village.
"More than 50 percent of our firms are now below Union Square," said Rolf Ohlhausen, the immediate past president of the New York chapter of the A.I.A.
Another area that architects are discovering is the financial district. Nearing the end of its lease in 600 Madison Avenue, at 58th Street, Pei Cobb Freed & Partners is scouting for new quarters and has cast its net as far downtown as Wall Street. "Many buildings that were considered Class B have been upgraded," said George H. Miller, the managing partner. "They present what we believe to be the best value in today's market for the architectural community."
Gensler, at 1 Rockefeller Plaza, has a "Wall Street studio" -- 25 people in 1 Liberty Plaza at Broadway and Liberty Street -- to serve financial institutions like J. P. Morgan and the Federal Reserve Bank.
Skidmore moved 10 months ago to the former Bankers Trust Company Building at Wall and Nassau Streets, a landmark completed in 1912 and expanded in 1933, topped by a stepped pyramid like the ancient Greek Mausoleum at Halicarnassus.
Skidmore is one of the largest firms in New York, if not the largest. And it probably has the highest public profile, with commissions that include the new Pennsylvania Station, the new International Air Terminal at Kennedy International Airport, the new New York Stock Exchange, the Columbus Centre complex at Columbus Circle that includes Time Warner headquarters, Bear Stearns headquarters on Madison Avenue and one of the new Times Square towers.
As its lease neared an end at the old Daily News Building, 220 East 42d Street, Skidmore began a search for new space. "Where we really wanted to be was the Hudson Street corridor or Ladies' Mile but there was nothing available in those two areas," said T. J. Gottesdiener, a partner.
The firm was in an awkward position. "We're not big enough to threaten the Mayor that we're going to move to New Jersey," Mr. Childs said, "but we're also not in the 3,000- to 4,000-square-foot range."
After looking as far afield as Long Island City, Queens, Mr. Gottesdiener settled on 14 Wall Street as meeting three key criteria: floors as large as possible (Skidmore has 72,000 square feet on three floors); a safe, convenient location and "rents we could sustain when the market turned" -- low $20's a square foot annually, compared with the high $20's on 42d Street.
In some ways, lower Manhattan is quite accessible. Subway lines converge there and city agencies are within walking distance. On the other hand, bulky architectural models have to be carted around much more, since clients in mid-Manhattan are less likely to visit the Skidmore office in person. "We spend more time shlepping than we did before," Mr. Childs allowed.
Those who do show up at the 24th floor of 14 Wall Street find a much different Skidmore office than the one on 42d Street, which affected a lavish corporate look, with a lobby paved in travertine and framed by colossal stainless steel columns.
Bare concrete floors run through the austere new space, with its plywood cubicles for design partners, spidery-looking Aeron chairs and a factory-like steel staircase linking display galleries that parallel the computer-filled drafting rooms.
"We wanted to create a laboratory to allow our practice to happen," said Roger F. Duffy Jr., a design partner. "We wanted our work to speak for itself."
Having settled into its new quarters, Skidmore shook itself up again in June when it named an outsider, both to the firm and the profession, as its first president.
Through a management recruiter, the partners found Kenneth C. Brown, 47, a corporate vice president of the General Electric Company and president of GE Southeast Asia, in Singapore. He holds a degree in mechanical engineering from Cornell and a degree in engineering science and economics from Oxford. He joined General Electric in 1992 after a career that included the Solar Energy Research Institute in Golden, Colo., and Price Waterhouse.
He is to manage business operations and assist the partners in strategic planning. "They still didn't feel as competent as they should be -- or even wanted to be -- in managing the business affairs of the firm," Mr. Brown said.
A limited liability partnership founded in 1936, Skidmore elected Mr. Childs its first chief executive in 1991, followed by Adrian D. Smith of Chicago and John H. Winkler of New York. Mr. Childs will assume the new position of chairman in October.
With worldwide revenues of $89 million in 1998, Skidmore ranked 10th among architects and architect-engineers in Engineering News-Record's list of top design firms. (Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum was first in the architectural field, with revenues of $295 million. It has 1,900 employees worldwide.)
"This is raw material waiting to be formed into a great new business proposition," Mr. Brown said. "I wouldn't mind being No. 1 or No. 2 in size of revenues, but my first goal is to make sure that we're No. 1 in terms of recognition, where anywhere in the world, when people think about taking on a complicated project, the first name that comes to mind is S.O.M."
"From every partner," Mr. Brown said, "I've heard three or four great ideas about new ways to leverage the influence of this firm." His goals include increasing profitability -- "It could be better but it's not dismal" -- and productivity.
"It doesn't have to be done in ax-and-saw fashion," he said. "Very clear definitions of customer requirements and diligent planning will cut out a lot of the rework and mistaken direction that sometimes occurs."
As a veteran of overseas operations, Mr. Brown would also like to see Skidmore fortify its international business, which accounted for 35 percent of revenues last year. While the firm is strong in Asia and the Middle East, it has much less of a presence in Western Europe and Latin America. "I don't see how you can call yourself global without seeing that, long term, half of your work is going to be outside the United States," he said.
To get a toehold in other markets, Skidmore might even acquire firms. "I don't think you ought to discard it as a possibility," Mr. Brown said.
Mergers and acquisitions may not exactly be sweeping the architectural profession, but there is at least one noteworthy prospective union this summer, as Alan Lapidus takes steps to ally his specialty hotel practice with Perkins & Will, which is itself under the umbrella of Dar Al-Handasah Consultants (Shair & Partners) of Cairo.
Mr. Lapidus, designer of the curvy, plum-colored Crowne Plaza in Times Square and the new Holiday Inn Wall Street District, carries on a family architectural tradition. His father, Morris, designed the swooping, jet-set-modern Fontainebleau in Miami Beach and the Americana in Manhattan, now the Sheraton New York.
The younger Mr. Lapidus said he hoped a merger would allow him to exploit his expertise in hotel planning by taking advantage of Perkins & Will's "horsepower."
"I needed a firm that does good construction documents and has a good design sense, where I could input all of my hotel knowledge," Mr. Lapidus said, "even if it meant not being glitzy, which would deprive me of my name of honor and make me a shame unto my father."
For Perkins & Will, the addition of the Lapidus team would "spread our footing" in the hotel field, Mr. Ordemann said.
Diversification is the name of the game, as firms try to devise strategies that will soften the blow when the market turns around again -- as it surely will.
"Our industry is so cyclical," said Belmont Freeman, who runs a six-architect practice at 110 West 40th Street. "On the upturns, you're able to accumulate money you use to pay off the debt that you accumulated in the bad times."
Last month, he hired an office manager and bookkeeper. "That's a significant turning point," he said. "We've gotten so busy that I ended up doing the administrative work while the other architects on my staff were doing the fun stuff."
Like principals in firms that are many times larger, Mr. Freeman is diversifying his practice. His jobs include a new seven-story apartment building on Eighth Street, east of Tompkins Square; the conversion of an East 73d Street town house into apartments; video and sound studios on lower Broadway; interior projects at three Columbia University graduate schools, and a residential compound in Langley, Va.
"I've got all the desks in my office filled for the first time," Mr. Freeman said. But that sight does not erase vivid memories of having one employee and subletting half his space. "Only as recently as last December did I take the gamble of renewing my lease for five years," he said. "My new worry is: one more job and I may have to expand."
 
A.I.A. Gets New Home, and New Goals
 Not long ago, many members of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects were scrambling to pay their own rent. Now, times are flush enough that they have raised $1.25 million among themselves to buy a large storefront space at 534 La Guardia Place, in Greenwich Village. They intend to raise $1.5 million more to turn it into a showplace headquarters that will help raise the chapter's profile.
"This is not just for architecture, this is for public engagement," said Walter A. Hunt Jr. of Gensler, the president of the chapter. The A.I.A. is a 142-year-old professional organization based in Washington. Its New York chapter represents nearly 70 percent of the registered architects in Manhattan.
 Wendy Evans Joseph, who will succeed Mr. Hunt in January, believes this is an opportune moment for architects to acknowledge their social responsibility. "Especially when times are good," she said, "we have to watch very carefully what we're doing and not just satisfy the client who pays us but the people who are not paying us; who are walking by, and under the shadows and living next door to what we're doing."
She suggested that architects could play a role in solving the public school construction crisis. "There is no excuse for bricks to be falling on kids' heads," Ms. Joseph said.
Rolf Ohlhausen, of Ohlhausen DuBois, the immediate past president, conceded that the chapter had "not always been really visible to the public or many of our members." The A.I.A. and its affiliate, the New York Foundation for Architecture, are tucked among furniture showrooms in the New York Design Center, 200 Lexington Avenue, between 32d and 33d Streets.
The 11,000-square-foot space on La Guardia Place, at street level and two floors below, will accommodate a gallery and meeting room. Mr. Hunt said there would be a design competition and that construction might begin next spring.
The move downtown was prompted in part by Mr. Ohlhausen's geographic study of A.I.A. membership, which is centered around Union Square in ZIP code 10003. The new headquarters will be immediately to the south in 10012, another architecturally populous ZIP code. "Most of us cannot afford midtown rents," Mr. Ohlhausen said. "The migration south has to do with economics and the rediscovery of older buildings." His own office is at 14 East Fourth Street, New York, N.Y. 10012.

HEADLINE: THE ARTS;
Urban Renewal With a Difference: At Last, a Cultural Oasis in Trenton

BYLINE: By BEN SISARIO

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
THE view from outside the Urban Word Cafe shows the contrasts of a city struggling to recreate itself. On one side, abandoned buildings rot, flanked by overgrown weeds and peeling billboards. But across the street, construction of a $60 million sports arena, on the site of an iron and steel plant that has been closed since 1987, is nearly complete.
Inside the Urban Word, another kind of renewal springs. Open since late March as part of a half-completed redevelopment project comprising four adjacent buildings on South Broad Street, the cafe acts as a magnet for creative types, offering a nightly schedule of music, poetry and films in a cozy space lined with paintings by local artists. 
 On a recent Friday night, patrons mingled and munched on sandwiches while listening to Ball in the House, an a cappella group of wholesome young men from Boston. (Their motto: "Six guys, six mouths, that's it.") Between sets, a gaggle of teen-age girls surrounded the singers, soliciting hugs and autographs, while the adults -- the usual Urban Word clientele -- wandered between the cafe's two red-brick rooms, checking the bulletin boards for notices of concerts and art exhibitions and studying the paintings on the wall, a series of images of boxers at a local gym.
For Roland Pott, the manager of the Urban Word and a co-founder of Trenton Makes, the development company that owns the buildings, the scene is exactly what he had hoped for when he began the project three years ago with two friends, David Henderson and John Hatch, both architects.
"We all live in Mill Hill and downtown Trenton, and we felt there was something missing," Mr. Pott said. "There was a real need for a community-oriented place for people to meet and socialize, and for artists to express themselves. A place where people could gather around the arts."
Mr. Pott, 26, grew up in New York City and moved to Trenton to become a teacher after graduating from Reed College in Portland, Ore. Soon he quit teaching. After meeting Mr. Henderson and Mr. Hatch, he threw himself into the business of building for the arts' sake.
The men spent two years canvassing for money. They hit up friends, family and people in the neighborhood -- each of whom became shareholders in Trenton Makes, named after the city's slogan, "Trenton makes, the world takes" -- before getting the $130,000 needed to purchase the four decrepit buildings near Route 129. Eventually, with help from the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority and the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, Trenton Makes secured a bank loan to begin construction. In two months, the Urban Word Cafe was open for business, along with the Mind and Soul Bookstore in the rear of the complex.
The cafe and the bookstore are just the beginning. By the time the Mercer County Arena across the street opens in October, Mr. Pott and his partners hope to complete the final phases of the project: two remaining buildings next door to the cafe are to be converted into a 150-seat theater and performance space with its own pub. There will also be studio space for artists upstairs and retail space that Mr. Pott hopes will attract "a record store or a funky clothing store or an art gallery or something like that."
Patrons at the Urban Word, fed up with a capital city that closes down at 6 P.M. and lacks even a movie theater, expressed one sentiment in common: relief.
"It's nice that Trenton is starting to blossom a little," said Michael Berry, a Trenton resident on a rare night out with his wife, who works in Manhattan. "It's been such a desolate place for decades. This is an example of Trenton's rebirth to community, which it lost decades ago."
One patron, Gay Pearson, a jazz pianist who lives down the street, just booked a gig at the cafe and sees another benefit. "I'm so grateful for a smoke-free place," she said. "And they're doing well in spite of that -- or maybe because of it."
The cafe has sparked a small artistic renaissance in Trenton by giving local artists a place to gather and perform. And there has been no shortage of talent, said Mr. Pott, who calls himself an "artist in remission" because his duties at the cafe and in Trenton Makes have caused him to shelve his poetry and filmmaking interests.
"People usually have to go to New York or Philadelphia to find this sort of thing," he said. "They're really happy there's a place right around the corner from Princeton or Hamilton or Pennington or some of the other towns, a place right just a hop, skip and a jump away and get the same quality of artistic, hip experience."
