HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Neighborhood Is Superseded By Superstore

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
TO make way for the New York region's third Ikea furniture superstore, this city has officially declared a patchwork of working-class homes and mom-and-pop factories "blighted," fit for no better fate than the crunching bulldozers of urban renewal. But go tell Ruth McGruder that her neighborhood is blighted and she'll give you a tart piece of her mind.
"We're just like family here on the street," she protested, padding barefoot on her porch. "It feels to me, if we weren't poor people, they wouldn't come here." 
 The 62-year-old, five-foot Mrs. McGruder thinks the house she rents for $600 a month with her sister Willie Mae and where she has helped raise a dozen nephews and nieces has been a fine home. Sure, it's not the princely Victorians she cleans for a living, but she has filled it with touches that have meaning and that tell of her battle to eke out some beauty in a life of two failed marriages and other harsh moments.
When she moved here 30 years ago, she painstakingly enveloped her front porch with the baby hedges she had carried with her from her mother's yard in rural Alabama. The hedges are now nine feet tall. She has added pots of zinnia, petunias and geraniums, and a maple she found as a sapling in the nearby lake where she fishes.
"I set out all these plants -- I bought 'em and set 'em out," she said with a molasses drawl impervious to the influence of the Northern gentry she works for. "I'm used to sitting out on this porch, nobody bothering nobody. I feel this is my home."
She has crowded the porch with faded chaises and charcoal grills, all handed down to her along with three refrigerators, a 1950's hi-fi set and a mahogany dresser at prices even Ikea will never beat. "My white people give me all my stuff," Mrs. McGruder, who is black, says with a laugh.
New Rochelle's Development Commissioner, Joseph Madonna, has a powerful argument that the Swedish retailer, by obtaining a 16-acre plot for assemble-it-yourself furniture in southern Westchester, will bring in $2.5 million annually in sales taxes. Less persuasive is the contention that Ikea will bring in 300 jobs. The neighborhood's factory owners say there are far more than 300 workers here already, skilled stonecutters, electricians and car mechanics, not Ikea's low-wage, often part-time clerks.
But city officials never bothered to find out very much about who exactly lives and works in the neighborhood they will soon subject to eminent domain. If they did, they would have had to acknowledge flesh-and-blood people, deeply entangled in their homes and workplaces, who are frightened at the thought of pulling up roots and relocating elsewhere, even if the city compensates them at fair market value.
Owners of the 50 businesses, like Jerry Newmark, whose factory makes cutting tools, and Stephen J. Wodraska 2d, who repairs roofs, have spent lifetimes taking risks, cultivating customers, bringing their children into the business.
"They're trading lives for dollars," Mr. Newmark said. "Why should Ikea get the use of eminent domain and not us? You read any encyclopedia description and they say eminent domain is for public use, a highway or reservoir."
In the 34 homes, there are people like Josephine Notaro, who was born in her green cottage 80 years ago when neighbors raised pigs in their yards and the corridor that now constitutes Interstate 95 was a swamp. Her parents and her husband died at this address. Now she owns it free and clear and wants to live out her days with her aged brother, Martin, reading dime-store novels on the porch.
People here look out for each other. Factory workers watch the houses when residents are off to work. The residents protect the factories from graffiti and break-ins at night. Blacks and whites who may have eyed each other suspiciously decades ago have become friendly.
Ikea's arrival, though, seems like a done deal. If he is forced to move, Mr. Wodraska says, he will worry not only about how to retain his customers but also where to find neighbors like Mrs. McGruder to sweeten the sense of community.
"Ruth watches out for the neighborhood," he said. "We'd have to take her with us."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Oakley Has to Choose: Business or Sentiment

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
After he was traded to Toronto a year ago, Charles Oakley showed up at a golf tournament in White Plains with some of his former Knick teammates. Still unhappy about becoming a Raptor, he began boasting of how he would eventually end up in Los Angeles. "I'm bringing Shaq back with me to New York, knock out everyone," Oakley said, grumbling under his breath. "Get me some rings with the Lakers."
The idea of the Lakers' acquiring Oakley seemed farfetched at the time -- the Raptors had no intention of trading him, and Shaquille O'Neal's team seemed stacked for the millennium. But a year later, the Lakers' president, Jerry West, is seriously interested in paying what his team is allowed to spend for the toughness and intangibles of a 35-year-old power forward who has never won a championship. 
 After Oakley had lunch with Kobe Bryant and O'Neal last week in Los Angeles, Magic Johnson got up at a golf outing and spoke of how important Oakley would be to the Lakers' championship hopes.
Now Oakley may have to decide which side of himself to listen to: the smart businessman, or the sentimental soul who always cared more about winning than about getting paid. He has a tough decision to make in the next couple of weeks. He can re-sign with Toronto for the final years of his career for nearly $20 million, securing his last big payday and helping the Raptors try to crack the Eastern Conference playoffs. Or he can sign with the Lakers for no more than $8 million and find solace in once again playing for a title contender.
Toronto may increase its offer and make the decision even more difficult. Or another team like Indiana, Philadelphia or Atlanta might enter the Oakley sweepstakes, if that's what you can call them at this point. Like many decent but not All-Star-caliber free agents, Oakley is finding that his leverage may decrease the longer he waits, while teams fill out their rosters and empty their coffers.
The best scenario for Oakley would be a sign-and-trade deal, in which the Lakers or another contender would send Toronto other players and agree to pay Oakley much more than their $2 million-a-year salary exception.
Oakley missed out on playing with a dynasty in Chicago, came close to a title in New York and then started at the bottom again in Toronto. Los Angeles would be a fitting place to end to his career, in Jack Nicholson's lap after hunting down a loose ball.
But it's not a no-brainer. The lockout caused him to miss a good portion of his largest payday ever last season, nearly half of $10 million. Even though he has numerous investments, and makes a nice profit from his car-wash chain, passing up more than $10 million this time around would have to be hard.
Oakley returns from the Bahamas this week after a short vacation with a genuinely tough call. Here's hoping the sentimental soul wins out over the smart businessman. After all, money can't buy you a ring.
 
Magic Makeover Continues
On the surface, Anfernee Hardaway's departure from Orlando last week did not bring the Magic much in return: Danny Manning, Pat Garrity and a couple of first-round draft picks. But it was reportedly the best offer John Gabriel, the Magic's general manager, had on the table.
The truth about Hardaway's move to Phoenix for $86 million is that the Magic had to trade him before it was forced to re-sign him.
Injury and inconsistency the last two seasons led to Hardaway's falling out of the group of upper-echelon players, plummeting far enough that other teams were not prepared to part with a perennial All-Star of their own. The Suns' owner, Jerry Colangelo, showed more faith in the disenchanted Hardaway's ability and future than any of his peers wanted to.
With Jason Kidd feeding him, Hardaway will probably lead the league in dunks on the fast break next season, and perhaps he will even recapture his form of three seasons ago. But last week, he was just another part of Orlando's makeover, in which Horace Grant and Nick Anderson had departed.
 
Richmond's Diminished Value
Whatever happened to Mitch Richmond? Once thought to be the league's second-best shooting guard behind Michael Jordan, he has turned into another malcontent who cannot find a playoff team or an exorbitant contract to suit him.
Seattle, Golden State and Sacramento, his former team, have all backed off from trying to acquire the 31-year-old shooting guard. Miami was believed to be the only team still trying to make a sign-and-trade deal with Washington, Richmond's current team. And with the Heat unwilling to part with P. J. Brown, it was looking less likely that Richmond would move on to Miami, his destination of choice.
"I still give it some hope, but all these deals are very hard to do," Richmond's agent, Mike Sharpe, told The Associated Press. "It's a tough situation, but we haven't stopped trying. The economic package has to be weighed against everything else, and Mitch has said that if he can't get the right economic package, he wants to go someplace where the team will be competitive."
Richmond was one of the league's brightest young stars a few seasons ago. Now he is just another veteran scorer who wants to be paid for his past instead of his potential, a player who may or may not be a piece to a championship puzzle.
 
Bucks Take a Step Back
Milwaukee experienced a rejuvenation under George Karl last season, but the Bucks took a major step backward in the off season. Letting go free-agent role players like Michael Curry (to Detroit) and Dell Curry (to Toronto) is the kind of decision that seems unimportant until playoff time. Michael Curry gave Milwaukee a physical presence on defense, and Dell could still knock down the 3-point bomb routinely.
You have to wonder what Boston's Rick Pitino has up his sleeve. Trading Ron Mercer, one of the five most explosive players in the league, for the bruising Denver forward Danny Fortson -- and then acquiring Calbert Cheaney through free agency -- just does not compute. Either Pitino is not done retooling, or he really wants to coach in college again.
Most impressive upgrade after the first week of free agency: Portland, which moved players who needed their egos stroked -- Isaiah Rider and Jim Jackson -- to Atlanta for the playoff-tested veterans Steve Smith and Detlef Schrempf. The Trail Blazers' blend of old and new should serve them well in the West.
Best single acquisition: Nick Anderson, Sacramento. He needed a change of pace. Where better to go than to a franchise that now is the run-and-gun capital of the league? A good friend of the Kings' show-time point guard Jason Williams, Anderson will also team with Chris Webber, Vlade Divac and Corliss Williamson. Highlights at 11.
Signing to remember: Jonathan Bender, Indiana. The Pacers took heat when they moved Antonio Davis to Toronto for the No. 5 draft pick, and then plucked the 6-foot-10-inch Bender out of a Mississippi high school. But he has range on his jump shot, can handle the ball and plays with the tenacity of a veteran.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Try to Curb Diamond Trade That Fuels Africa Wars

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Concerned that diamonds are financing and perpetuating wars in Africa, the Clinton Administration is considering actions aimed at halting the illicit diamond trade, Administration officials say.
The flow of uncut diamonds from rebel-held mines to market centers around the world -- valued at hundreds of millions of dollars a year -- is keeping rebel armies in Angola, Congo and Sierra Leone supplied with tanks and assault rifles and even uniforms and beer, American and European officials say. 
 Control of these mines has been an obstacle to peace efforts in African hot spots, and officials hope that by cutting off the gray-market diamond trade they can also choke off the flow of arms, stop the endless killing and hasten peace efforts. Diamonds are not the only way in which rebels pay for weapons, but experts in Africa and the trade say cutting it off would have a substantial impact.
The Administration is likely to propose a global marketing system, by which diamond sales must be accompanied by documents declaring the source of the precious stones and their destination.
From the fields in Africa, diamonds reach dealers in Belgium, Israel and Ukraine, where the unscrupulous turn the ready cash into weapons. The largest weapons pipeline into Africa is controlled by Russian organized crime figures who work with diamond brokers, American and European officials say.
The diamond trade, which is highly secretive and governed by informal arrangements, has been difficult to regulate.
In the last eight years, the Angolan rebel organization, known as Unita, has raised $3 billion to $4 billion from diamond sales, according to a recent report by a United Nations committee on Angolan sanctions. A peace accord collapsed late last year.
The brutal war in Sierra Leone, which left thousands maimed and mutilated, was prolonged by at least 18 months because of the ability of the rebels to quickly trade diamonds for arms, an Administration official said this week. A delicate agreement ending that war was signed in July.
In the middle levels of the State Department, the African diamonds-for-weapons trade has been under study for several years. But the problem has not penetrated more senior levels because wars in Africa are not generally seen as affecting America's strategic interests.
Now, after an intelligence study illustrated how the trade works to perpetuate rebellion in Africa, top Administration officials appear to be ready to back a plan that would try to regulate the diamond trade.
Exactly how such a marketing regime would be implemented in various African nations and European diamond centers is undecided, officials say. It could take the form of a United Nations program, a multilateral treaty or a voluntary agreement within the diamond industry.
It appears to be an idea that is gaining support outside government channels. Human rights organizations are now talking about a public education campaign to highlight the diamonds-for-weapons trade.
A spokesman for the world's largest diamond company, DeBeers Consolidated Mines Ltd., said in an interview that it would support tighter controls. DeBeers, which controls about 70 percent of the world's diamond sales, views the flow of illicit diamonds as a potential threat to its ability to influence prices.
Its support would surely be welcomed by the Administration, which had expected DeBeers to resist any move to regulate the market since the company. has done quite well under the current system.
DeBeers has repeatedly maintained that it does not buy illicit diamonds.American and European officials say, though, that while most of DeBeers' trade may be legal, its dealers also buy illicit diamonds.
"We're all for it," a DeBeers spokesman in London, Andrew Lamont, said about any proposal that the Administration might advance to strengthen controls on the trade.
"It suits our interests," he added. "The illicit trade only serves to destabilize the market."
Mr. Lamont added that he thought the countries of southern Africa whose economies are heavily dependent on diamond sales -- Botswana, Namibia and South Africa -- would also welcome more stringent controls on the trade.
And Belgium, which has resisted entreaties from the Clinton Administration to crack down on the gray-market diamond merchants, appears to be changing its attitude. In Antwerp, the diamond trading center of Europe, officials have asked for help from American law enforcement agencies to combat the growing power of Russian organized crime figures, who launder money through diamond merchants, according to American officials in Brussels.
A United Nations embargo against buying diamonds from Unita, the Angolan rebel movement, has been largely ineffective, though.
"Diamond revenues constitute the essential component of Unita's capacity to wage war," Robert R. Fowler, Canada's Ambassador to the United Nations, wrote in a recent report to the Security Council.
The Clinton Administration is reluctant to talk publicly about what steps it is considering to avoid the perception that it is imposing a regulatory regime on African states by the powerful West, said an Administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Britain is also supportive of tighter controls and is working with the Administration on proposals, American and British officials said.

HEADLINE: A Divisive Mayoral Race in Baltimore

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Aug. 6

 BODY:
After weeks of political chaos featuring 27 declared mayoral candidates, six of them with arrest records, a campaign showdown loomed noisy as summer thunder here this week in a rowdy scene outside City Hall.
"Man, you're stabbing us in the back," one black politician shouted at another as demonstrators disrupted a news conference, called to endorse a mayoral candidate, and drove their rivals across the street. 
 But the demonstrators' target, Howard P. Rawlings, the State General Assembly delegate, was determined to go forward with his role as a political kingmaker. He called on this gritty city's black majority to support the leading white mayoral contender, Martin O'Malley, a city councilman.
"O'Malley is a new generation of white political leadership," Mr. Rawlings, who is black, declared after he retreated from the hooting and hollering demonstrators, bused to City Hall on Thursday by the rival campaign of Lawrence A. Bell 3d, the City Council president and the leading black candidate.
"O'Malley has a track record of empowering black Americans," Mr. Rawlings said in front of the television cameras.
Mr. Bell, who had been increasingly upset at the rise of Mr. O'Malley from the status of also-ran to possible unity candidate, was nowhere in sight on Thursday. But his political lieutenants directed the disruptive rally and denounced the potentially decisive endorsements of Mr. O'Malley as treachery by "so-called pseudo-Negro political leaders."
News reports would describe the scene at City Hall as a dirty-tricks "ambush" by Bell forces frustrated that the formerly underrated Mr. O'Malley was gaining momentum. He had garnered endorsements from black leaders like Mr. Rawlings and State Senator Joan Carter Conway and from some well-organized, heavily black labor unions, including the city's health care workers.
"It's not a question of being the best black candidate or the best white candidate," Mr. Rawlings said in an interview. "O'Malley's the best candidate for Baltimore." He noted that he and other black leaders had tried and failed to enlist black candidates like Kweisi Mfume, the former United States Representative who is president of the N.A.A.C.P.
And so they are urging voters to wrench some order from what Mr. Rawlings described as a "frightening" and divisive campaign for the Sept. 14 primary that will determine the next mayor in this predominantly black Democratic city. The primary field had 17 Democrats, 7 Republicans and 3 independents. But only the top three Democrats were rated as having a chance of being elected. All the candidates talked of a turnout of little more than 100,000 voters in this city of 675,000 residents.
The beneficiary of the black leaders' strategy, Mr. O'Malley, seemed almost surprised to have risen to the center of attention as he warned against "the divisive politics of the past." He had used his four terms on the Council to make a show of visiting New York and other urban renaissance spots in building an image -- tinged with the sharp-edged resolve of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York -- as the leading voice against Baltimore's persistently high standing in drug and murder rates.
The rise of Mr. O'Malley, a proven vote getter in his heavily black Council district, appeared to have as much to do with a process of elimination as it did with his own dogged sense of opportunity in suddenly entering the race after black leaders failed to produce a unity candidate. Mr. Rawlings candidly admitted that after Mr. Mfume and other prominent blacks spurned a candidacy, he was going to turn to the former City Councilman Carl Stokes, a black candidate, as the next best choice.
But then Mr. Stokes became embroiled in a campaign resume controversy for having falsely claimed a college degree. That left Mr. O'Malley, who was unsullied thus far in the tragi-comical series of candidate gaffes that had provided this city with a bleak campaign sideshow.
One fringe candidate was recognized as a fugitive from a court warrant by a police officer watching television who then moved in for an arrest. Controversy had even focused on the management talents of Mr. Bell, who marshaled a formidable patronage machine in trying to appear the odds-on heir to Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke. Mr. Bell has had to deal with lawsuit disclosures of personal financial troubles highlighted by the repossession of his car.
The contenders are campaigning against a bittersweet subtext of the end of the 12-year Democratic reign of Mayor Schmoke. Hailed initially as an urban visionary, he was departing with various politicians voicing disappointment that Baltimore had failed to keep pace with other major cities during the national economic boom.
"It's sad, although everybody likes the Mayor," said Jim Knight, a Democratic committeeman from south Baltimore. He was campaigning for Mr. Stokes, faulting Mr. Bell for racial politics that Mr. Knight considered deliberately divisive in a city that sorely needed reconciliation.
Mr. Bell, vying to maintain his earlier career promise before an electorate that is more than 60 percent black, had become openly petulant about his former ally Mr. O'Malley.
"I'm tired of being a punching bag," Mr. Bell declared, pacing and frowning before the voters as the two appeared Thursday night before the 43/44 Democratic Club in the heart of the city's black wards. "I'm not going to take it anymore."
The Bell forces' commitment to an aggressive last-ditch targeting of Mr. O'Malley became clear earlier in the week when they rallied outside The Sun. They complained that negative stories had focused on black candidates, but that Mr. O'Malley had been spared criticism and should be scored as a criminal lawyer who sometimes represented drug defendants even as he campaigned against them. The Sun reported that Mr. O'Malley's mixed criminal caseload was far from lucrative and not atypical for a former criminal prosecutor. Mr. O'Malley told voters that other public figures, from Abraham Lincoln to Thurgood Marshall, pursued similar livelihoods in the law.
The crossover to Mr. O'Malley reflected growing wariness among some black leaders about Mr. Bell, as well as their own political need to play a decisive role in the city's affairs. Mr. Rawlings, appalled at being cut off as he stood for Mr. O'Malley, accused the Bell campaign of "political vandalism." "He's a child," snapped the black Statehouse leader, joining the O'Malley camp.

HEADLINE: Cisco Systems to Invest $1 Billion In the Accounting Giant KPMG

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
Cisco Systems Inc., the dominant maker of networking equipment for the Internet, said yesterday that it was making a $1 billion investment in the accounting and consulting firm KPMG L.L.P.
Under terms of an agreement to be announced on Monday, KPMG, part of KPMG International, will use the money to hire 4,000 engineers and service professionals over the next 18 months to develop and deliver Internet-based data, voice and video services to its business and consulting clients. It will also build six technology centers -- four in the United States and two abroad. In return for its investment, Cisco will own a stake of less than 20 percent in KPMG's United States unit. 
 The deal with Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., is evidence that KPMG has embraced the idea of offering professional services to its business customers via the Internet. Stephen Butler, chairman and chief executive of the United States unit, said KPMG had selectively wooed potential technology partners in recent months to complement existing relationships.
In June, the telecommunications upstart Qwest Communications International announced that it was forming a joint venture with KPMG to provide services like order processing through Qwest's Internet network. The Denver-based Qwest now owns 51 percent of the venture, called Qwest Cyber.solutions, and KPMG owns 49 percent.
Unlike the Qwest combination though, Cisco is making a direct investment. The two companies have cooperated on various initiatives for six years. But Mr. Butler said it was not until two months ago that he and his colleagues began to think about a closer alliance with Cisco.
The market for business services on the Internet is growing at a rate of more than 40 percent a year, Mr. Butler said. "It's a young market for the types of services we provide," he added.
Simply put, here is how the Cisco-KPMG alliance will work: If a corporate customer wants to transfer business functions like accounting or financial reporting to the Web, Cisco will provide the hardware and KPMG will set up and maintain the computer and software systems needed.
The strategy behind the alliance, executives from the two companies said, rests on the conviction that dominance in the Internet economy will be achieved not by being the first to notice a trend, but by being the first to exploit it effectively.
"There is the realization that you can be out of business in three years," John Chambers, Cisco's chief executive, said yesterday. "Whoever moves quickly first are those who will benefit over the next 10 years."
Carefully conceived alliances and joint ventures represent the best business model for the burgeoning Internet economy, Mr. Chambers said. And it is likely Cisco will seek alliances with other consulting firms. The company has already formed strategic relationships with many of the industry's biggest players, including the software giant Microsoft Corporation and the telecommunications equipment maker Motorola Inc.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Let's Savor Comeback Over Greed By Browns

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
SOMETHING wonderful is about to happen in Cleveland, but it should be celebrated all over North America. A community is regaining its beloved football team, which it lost through no fault of its own.
The Cleveland Browns, the real thing, are rising from the ashes of ownership greed and disloyalty. The team played its last game in December 1995, and then the material goods of the franchise were hauled to a new home in Baltimore. 
 But somehow, against all precedents, the National Football League agreed that the nickname, the colors, the uniform, the statistics, the very memories, belonged to the people alongside Lake Erie. Now that team has been resurrected.
I don't want to know how much the new stadium cost, but I am positive the burghers of Cleveland would never have raised that much money for the frayed city school system. The economists who make sense to me claim that most jobs from a football team are selling peanuts eight home games a year.
However, the gates will soon open in downtown Cleveland, and at the very least, a man named Art Modell was not allowed to expropriate the history of a franchise, and that is something to celebrate.
Tomorrow night, the real Cleveland Browns will play an exhibition game at the National Hall of Fame in Canton in the state of Ohio. On Aug. 21 the real Cleveland Browns will play their first home exhibition in the new stadium in downtown Cleveland. And on Sept. 12 the real Cleveland Browns will play their first league game at home against their old rust-belt rivals, the Pittsburgh Steelers.
These milestone games reflect the persistence of dogged, faithful people in Cleveland, but the victory is not local. It speaks to every city that ever loved and lost a team.
This victory does not mean Monte Irvin and Whitey Lockman are going to magically resume hitting baseballs in the shadow of Coogan's Bluff. (Go look it up on some search engine, kid.) But it does mean that fans everywhere now have an example of the good name of their team being left behind when the moving van chugs into the night.
Leading rusher, Baltimore Ravens, Jim Brown, 12,312 career yards. Huh? I'd like to see somebody try telling that to Brown himself. But Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the N.F.L., made sure Modell could not ransack Marion Motley and Lou Groza along with the current players.
This great triumph by the fans of Cleveland came too late to save the name Dodgers from being trundled off by the O'Malley clan. If there is any justice in the world, the team visiting Shea Stadium this afternoon should be called the Los Angeles Diggers, in honor of the team's Australian owner, rather than a hallowed Brooklyn nickname.
The great nicknames, the histories both grand and modest, await their rightful claimants, the way the Cherokee nation can be heard chanting along the Trail of Tears, if you are quiet and listen carefully.
When the hockey team in the Canadian capital of Ottawa ceased operation in 1934, no other National Hockey League team had the gall to use its nickname until an expansion team was plunked back in Ottawa in 1992, appropriately renamed the Senators.
Who is to say that heroes like Walter Johnson and noble managers like Gil Hodges and Ted Williams could not be recalled with a third Washington Senators?
The predators took a vibrant hockey franchise from Quebec City to Colorado, but maybe that lovely name Nordiques will once again be trilled on a crisp winter night in La Belle Province.
Some teams are just dead and gone, the victims of westward migration, the new demographics. St. Louis Browns. Providence Steamrollers. Hartford Whalers. The spiritual heritage of the Syracuse Nationals -- the crew cuts and tiny satin shorts and fisticuffs and the deadeye one-handed set shot of Dolph Schayes -- still belongs to the tiny Snow Belt city.
There were legal reasons they couldn't, but I am convinced the new Major League Soccer franchise in the Meadowlands would have resonated far better with fans if the team had been named the Cosmos, after that brief dynasty of Pele and Beckenbauer. Instead, they were forced to go with the clumsy name MetroStars.
Let's be realistic. The victory of the Cleveland Browns will not bring Johnny Unitas back to Baltimore or Roy Campanella back to Brooklyn.
But all of us who had our teams taken away from us can rejoice when the familiar brown-orange-and-white uniforms soon become saturated in good old-fashioned Great Lakes mud and snow. The people of Cleveland have won one for all of us.

HEADLINE: Gore Still Sees Discrimination, But Also Progress for Blacks

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, wooing blacks and liberals at a conference organized by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, said today that America had "not openly acknowledged" its legacy of discrimination, especially "the pain of slavery."
Mr. Gore, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, also lashed out repeatedly at Republicans as greedy and unfair, but did not mention his Democratic rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, who spoke at the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition conference here on Friday. 
 Mr. Bradley said the Clinton Administration was doing too little to help poor children.
"After the first two-term Democratic President since Franklin Roosevelt," Mr. Bradley said, "the number of children in poverty in America has barely blipped down."
Mr. Jackson, who made unsuccessful Presidential bids of his own in 1984 and 1988, has said that he has not decided which of the two Democratic candidates he will endorse.
Today, in introducing the Vice President, Mr. Jackson described him as "perhaps the next President."
Mr. Gore praised Mr. Jackson as a civil rights hero and recalled the work of his own late father, Al Gore Sr., in championing civil rights as a Senator from Tennessee.
Mr. Gore said that blacks in America had benefited greatly from the economic prosperity of the Clinton era. And he said the White House had promoted diversity at the highest ranks, noting that seven blacks had been appointed to Cabinet positions.
Mr. Gore won perhaps his biggest applause when he called for an end to racial profiling, the practice of singling out blacks for police questioning.
"D.W.I. is a crime -- D.W.B. is not," he said, contrasting driving while intoxicated to "driving while black."
Mr. Gore also reiterated his call for a $1 increase in the minimum wage, preschool for all American children and strong affirmative action policies.
Mr. Bradley said on Friday that he was organizing his campaign around the theme of racial unity. "I'm staking my Presidential campaign on the belief that over 50 to 60 percent of Americans, including white Americans, want to have racial unity," he said.
Mr. Bradley also voiced skepticism at Mr. Gore's vow to end the practice of racial profiling if he became President.
"I say, 'Why wait?' " Mr. Bradley said. "Why doesn't he walk down the hall, put the executive order in front of the President and ask him to sign it?"
Mr. Gore said today that the Clinton Administration could take a big share of the credit for a rosy economic picture, which included substantial gains by blacks. He said the rate of poverty among blacks was at its lowest point in the nation's history and the rate of homeownership among blacks was at its highest.
But he said some places of deep poverty and desperation in America seemed almost untouched by "these times of plenty."
"I came here today to tell you I am not satisfied and I know we can do better," Mr. Gore said.
He noted that the average family wealth of blacks was about one-tenth that of whites, a disparity he attributed to generations of discrimination. He also lamented that nearly a half-century after the Supreme Court ruling that struck down segregation in public schools, more than two-thirds of black children attended schools where minority students predominated. Children in those schools, Mr. Gore said, were some 16 times more likely to be poor than children in predominantly white schools.
The Vice President criticized what he described as the undercounting of blacks and members of other minorities by the Census Bureau. And he pledged to support stiffer penalties for attacks based on a victim's ethnicity or religion.
Mr. Gore also sprinkled his speech with references to religious faith. "I believe that God's hand has touched the United States of America on purpose and not by accident," he said.
Mr. Gore criticized a Republican plan approved by Congress this week that would cut taxes by $792 billion, saying that the top 1 percent of income earners would see as much relief as the bottom 60 percent combined.
He described the plan as a "special interest smorgasbord" that would "tear the country apart."

Tough Race to Rebuild Before Winter in Kosovo
The United Nations goal to have at least one, warm, dry room for every Albanian family in Kosovo by winter is not going to be met, officials now admit. A recent internal United Nations report said, "It is in shelter that the humanitarian community faces its greatest challenge." 1

HEADLINE: ISLAND OF FORBIDDEN FRUITS

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI; FRANK BRUNI is a reporter in the Washington Bureau of the Times.

 BODY:
IN an airport lounge in the Bahamas, waiting for my flight to Havana, I got my first glimpse of what it means to travel to Cuba today. His name was Buddy, he looked to be about 60, and he sported a belly that was decades in the making and an expectant gleam in his eye.
 
 In Havana, he felt certain, he would find not only savory cigars but also sexy, cash-strapped young women eager to make his acquaintance. That was what had drawn his father from South Florida to the island in the 1940's and 1950's, when it was a permissive playground for sybaritic Americans, and that was what friends of Buddy's who had traveled to Cuba in the last year or two had discovered, too.
 Buddy laughed. "I was just thinking," he said, "I could end up with the granddaughter of one of the women my father knew."
 A day later, ambling through Havana's Museo de la Revolucion, I got another, different view.
 The brash exhibits inside the grand building, which had served as a gilded presidential lair before Fidel Castro put an end to such ostentation in 1959, touted Cuba's liberation from European and American imperialism, from the callous dictates of capitalism and from a meek history of pliant servitude to outsiders' dreams.
 I stood before life-sized caricatures of George Bush and Ronald Reagan in a hallway dubbed El Rincon de los Cretinos, or Cretins Corner. The painted wooden effigy of Reagan depicted him in a Western sheriff's outfit, and the slogan beneath it mocked the manner in which he, like other American Presidents, had cast Castro's Cuba as a mortal enemy.
 "Thank you, cretin," it said in both Spanish and English, "for helping us to strengthen the Revolution."
 I read it with an amalgam of amusement, guilt and dismay, then walked out onto streets that seemed at once to beckon and provoke me, that unveiled stately pleasure domes from a bygone era and bold billboards of propaganda from the uprising that erased it, that did battle with - and denounced - the country's pre-revolutionary past even as Cuba's leaders sought, with luxury hotels adn an expanding infrastructure for tourism, to resurrect it in some fashion.
 To the rising number of American travelers who flock to what is still largely a forbidden destination, Cuba presents itself as a tropical storm of such contradictions, and it reminds Americans, at every turn, of their country's tortured relationship to this island, so near and yet so far.
 It held me in a kind of thrall that no other foreign country has. I was elated by the beauty of the 18th- and 19th-century architecture in Havana, where the Gran Teatro and other neo-baroque buildings around Parque Central are more evocative of Barcelona than any Caribbean outpost, but aghast at their peeling paint and crumbling edges, a decrepitude due in part to America's longstanding economic embargo of Cuba.
 I was startled by the rapid, ongoing development of Varadero, a lovely strand of beach just two hours by car east of Havana, and by the Acapulco-like phalanx of gargantuan luxury hotels along Varadero's shore. But I was troubled by the degree to which this resort was off-limits to Cubans, who are held back by checkpoints on the road, lest they be tempted to hustle wealthy. Europeans and North Americans and be corrupted by these outsiders' materially profligate ways.
 Cuba's leaders, it turns out, are deeply conflicted about their embrace of tourism, which is both an economic necessity and a social danger. Tourism brings Cuba money that is desperately needed, especially in the wake of the collapse of the Soviet Union and its formidable economic assistance, but it has other, less desired effects.
 There is, for example, an immediately evident black market of enterprising Cubans who offer to arrange for foreign tourists to stay in private houses where they can entertain Cuban guests, an option unavailable at most hotels, which post sentires at the elevators to amek sure such interactions do not take place. There is also a network of paladares, or makeshift restaurants in private apartments, and the smallest and most authentic of these are run illegally, without any notice to the Cuban Government or advertisements on their doors. They are found only with the assistance of the self-styled "tour guides" who roam Havana's sun-baked sidewalks, whispering cautiously to tourists.
When I was in Havana, in early July, the Cuban authorities were trying to crack down on all of this, and the Cubans whom I met on the street and allowed to bring me to paladares and out-of-the-way nightclubs were repeatedly stopped and grilled by the vigilant police officers who seemed to be on just about every corner. Although my new Cuban friends were allowed to continue on their way after assuring the officers that they were not conducting any shady business with me, these experiences deepened the occasionally unsettling and always adventurous feeling of being somewhere that Americans are expressly discouraged from going by their own Government.
Americans can get dispensation to visit Cuba for educational, religious or humanitarian purposes, and can thereby board charters to Cuba from the United States. But it is otherwise illegal for Americans to spend dollars on travel to or within Cuba, a stricture that effectively bans such tourism and renders direct flights from the United States off-limits.
THAT does not stop tens of thousands of Americans every year from reaching Cuba through layovers in the Bahamas or Mexico, where they pay for their trips in cash so there is no record of their whereabouts. Cuban authorities, eager for the dollars that Americans bring, facilitate this strategy by not stamping American passports.
Buddy, nervous nonetheless, had hatched an additional ploy.
In his suitcase were boxes of adhesive bandages and tubes of antibacterial cream, which he planned to take to a Red Cross office in Havana. He would have someone there snap a picture of him making this donation, so that if American authorities ever learned of his trip, he could claim he had gone to do good medical deeds.
In truth, only a tiny fraction of Americans who travel illegally to Cuba are ever caught, or punished, by the Government. Even so, going to Cuba feels like taking a dare, and I was convinced by my conversations with American tourists there that no matter what they said had attracted them -- sex or sun or simply an up-close encounter with one of the dwindling bastions of Communism in the world -- they had really come because it felt naughty and bold.
As for Cuba's Communism, it imbued the process of making flight, hotel and rental-car arrangements with an occasionally maddening vagueness and inefficiency. I quickly learned that workers guaranteed of jobs and bereft of financial incentives tend not to be exemplars of customer service.
But Cuba's Communism also means that Cubans are, at a basic level, better cared for than the residents of many other Caribbean islands; there is little outright begging on the streets, and when Cubans smile, they usually do so with all of their teeth. They are well educated, and delighted to engage Americans in candid political discussions.
Some Cubans, resentful of the luxuries available only to tourists, told me bluntly that they could not wait for Castro to die. Others praised him as a brave leader who had created a triumphantly humane system. All were kind and warm.
In Havana, I spent two nights at the Ambos Mundos, which was once a favorite haunt of Ernest Hemingway's, and one night in the famous Hotel Nacional, a former haven for gangsters and movie stars, built in the 1920's, that towers over the Malecon, Havana's scruffy oceanfront promenade. Although the Nacional has elaborate grounds and infinite amenities, it feels relatively isolated, and my room there was a cramped, dingy cell. I much preferred the cozier ambiance of the Ambos Mundos, where the lobby has a series of tall French doors that open to the lively streets of Old Havana.
The entire city is terrific for walking. The high price of cars and paucity of gasoline mean that traffic is light, and the city contains a profusion of different architectural styles -- Spanish colonial, baroque, neo-baroque, modern -- from the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries. Old Havana, with its narrow streets and artists' galleries and salsa bands in small cafes, has the aura of a less kitschy New Orleans French Quarter, and is a living museum to the city's colonial origins. It also has several lively squares, like the Plaza de la Catedral, in front of the 18th-century Catedral de La Habana, and the Plaza de Armas, teeming with vendors.
For a wholly different take on the city, there is the Plaza de la Revolucion, in central Havana, where a slim monolith similar to the Washington Monument serves as a memorial to Jose Marti and a black metal stencil of Che Guevara's face dominates the facade of a grim contemporary building containing the offices of the Minister of the Interior.
I found Havana's restaurants unremarkable, although the view from one that I visited, la Divina Pastora, was gorgeous. So I took the chance of letting Jorge, a young man I met on the street, take me to an illegal paladar in a poor neighborhood.
We walked up a narrow, unlighted flight of stone steps and around the edge of an air shaft strung with laundry to enter a Spartan apartment where, for $15 apiece, the two of us sat alone and ate generous, delicious helpings of pork, rice, beans and fried plantains, washed down by beer and followed by some of the sweetest, ripest mangoes I have ever tasted. (I paid for Jorge's meal, a gesture that seemed unavoidable and illustrated paladares' hidden cost.)
The cook, who had surrendered a meager salary of pesos at a seaside resort in order to court the mightier American dollar (the unofficial tourist currency in Cuba), prepared much of the food over an open flame on a crumbling terrace; Santeria icons festooned the walls around the dining room table.
There are many cabarets and discotheques in Havana's hotels, but I naively asked Jorge to take me to some place he and his friends would really go. We ended up in an unnamed club in Havana's Chinatown where three black Cubans performed a deafening Spanish-language rap with a chorus that sampled the melody of "London Bridge Is Falling Down."
Another night, Jorge and his friend Juan insisted I accompany them to Johnny's, also known as Club Rio, a raucous spot in the suburb of Miramar that was, for young Cubans, the place of the moment. Provocatively dressed women gyrated ecstatically to songs by the Backstreet Boys and Ricky Martin, taking breaks to thrust themselves against me in an aggressive manner that had nothing to do with my body and everything to do with my billfold.
Varadero, my next stop, was less exciting than the drive there, which I ventured tremulously in an old, sputtering Subaru -- no bigger than a golf cart, with similar acceleration and shock absorption -- that a rental agent insisted was the best he could offer for $40 a day. My beachfront hotel, the Melia Varadero, had everything from a pool the size of a reservoir to a karaoke bar. But I could have been anywhere in the Caribbean, and I wanted to be in Cuba.
So I returned to it, heading west, back through Havana, and down the highway for another two hours until I reached the turnoff to the picturesque town of Vinales. All around it rise astonishing geographical formations, called mogotes, that jut suddenly, steeply and briefly from a lush valley floor, like the humps on a camel. They are best seen from the Hotel Los Jazmines, where a comfortable room with a spacious balcony cost me less than $40 for the night.
I took a jaunt, on foot and in a small motorboat, through La Cueva del Indio, an eerie limestone cavern inside one of the mogotes. Then, with two new Cuban friends whom I had asked for directions and ended up accepting into my car (although I don't recommend giving rides to strangers), I visited nearby Puerto Esperanza, a sleepy coastal village, and treated each of us to a $9 lobster dinner at a legal paladar, Villa Sol.
In the backyard stood two noisy pigs, the larger one scheduled for consumption by the proprietor and his family this Christmas, the smaller one in line for the next. The proprietor, his brother and his son-in-law alternately sat down beside me to riddle me politely with questions: about my life in America, my reactions to Cuba and, above all, the reasons our two countries regarded each other so warily, when they were so inextricably entwined.
I had just as much that I wanted to ask them, and as the sun set and a breeze tickled the palms and the pigs squealed, I realized that despite our countries' turbulent past, tense present and uncertain future, there was really no keeping us apart.
 
If you go
Under the United States economic embargo, only certain travelers -- including journalists, Government officials and those visiting close relatives once a year for humanitarian reasons -- can go to Cuba, spending up to $100 a day for expenses. Or travelers can apply for a license to go if they have a religious or educational purpose, for example. Anybody else is banned from spending money under the Trading With the Enemy Act.
No more than $100 worth of goods (such as cigars and rum) can legally be brought back from Cuba. Because transactions are in cash (Americans cannot use credit cards issued by American banks), visitors often go over the spending limit with little risk of being caught. And Cuba enables illegal travel by waiving boating fees at marinas and not stamping passports.
Although sailing to Cuba itself is not prohibited, paying for expenses is; passengers returning by air or vessel can be investigated by the United States Customs Service, Federal officials said. Penalties for violating the travel restrictions are up to 10 years in prison and $250,000 in fines for an individual, although few Americans are prosecuted by the Government for traveling to Cuba illegally.
 
Getting There
Because of the embargo, getting to Cuba is not a simple matter of calling an airline and booking a flight. It is probably best and easiest -- though by no means easy -- to work with an agency that specializes in travel to Cuba.
Marazul Tours has a Web site, www.marazultours.com, and several offices in the United States, including one in Weehawken, N.J., (201) 840-6711. It arranges legal, Government-approved trips and can, for that reason, book direct charters from the United States.
Havanatur, a Cuban agency, has several offices outside of Cuba through which an American can arrange a trip. One is in Nassau, the Bahamas, (242) 394-7195. The agency, which books flights and hotels and therefore gives discounted package rates, requires payment in money orders, cash or traveler's checks.
Indeed, for Americans, trips to Cuba are just about all-cash endeavors; no Cuban hotel, restaurant or store will accept American credit cards. Some hotels and restaurants may honor traveler's checks, except those issued by American Express, but I never tried to use traveler's checks while I was there. Furthermore, there is essentially no way for Americans to get extra cash in Cuba.
 
Getting Around
In addition to Havanatur, Cubatur can help with excursions and guided tours within Cuba, and has an office in Havana, (53-7) 334-155, as well as desks in some of the major hotels. There are rental car representatives in most major hotels, but those unwilling to pay steep prices will find that the rental cars are old and not always reliable. Gasoline stations are few and far between, so the fuel tank should be kept at least half full. Also, be prepared to fend off hitchhikers, who seem to number 300 for every car.
 
Where to Stay
Telephone circuits to Cuba are often overloaded, so expect to make frequent attempts to get through.
HAVANA: The Ambos Mundos, at 153 Calle Obispo, Old Havana; telephone (53-7) 614-887. It has 52 rooms, a beautiful lobby piano bar, a rooftop restaurant and a good location in Old Havana. Rate: about $110 a night, with breakfast, depending on season.
The Hotel Nacional, Calle O and 21st, Vedado, (53-7) 550-294, fax (53-7) 335-171. It has 446 rooms, two pools, tennis, tropical gardens, several bars and restaurants and terrific ocean views. Rates: about $155 a night, depending on the season.
The Melia Cohiba, Paseo between First and Third, Vedado, telephone (53-7) 333-636, fax (53-7) 334-555. There are 342 rooms and 120 suites, a pool, numerous restaurants and bars and one of the hottest big-band nightclubs, the Havana Cafe. Opened in 1995, the Melia Cohiba is perhaps the most luxurious of Havana's large hotels. Rates: about $190 a night.
OUTSIDE HAVANA: The Melia Varadero, Autopista Sur, Varadero, Matanzas, telephone (53-5) 667-013, has 490 rooms, an enormous pool, restaurants, bars and private access to a beach. Rate: about $155 a night, depending on the season. Varadero is 85 miles from Havana.
The Hotel Los Jazmines, part of Cuba's Horizontes chain, Carretera Vinales, kilometer 25, Vinales; (53-7) 334 042, has 62 rooms with balconies, a swimming pool, gardens and a stunning location above a lush valley. Rates: about $50 a night, depending on the season. Vinales is a two-hour drive from Havana.
 
Where to Eat
For food that is more authentic (and, in many cases, tastier) than the fare in large restaurants, many tourists visit paladares, small dining spots in Cuban homes. Some are registered with the Cuban Government and can be recommended by hotel staff; these are more dependable but less intimate, and tourists are unlikely to find themselves the only guests. Illegal paladares involve risk; a tourist must follow the lead of one of the many self-styled tour guides on the street. But if it works out, it provides a real glimpse of Cuban life. Negotiate the price and the menu in advance. FRANK BRUNI

HEADLINE: For Architects, It's a Boom Town

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
FRESHLY recruited from a corporate colossus, the new president strides into a rapidly growing company in search of even higher profits, untapped markets and maybe an acquisition or two.
The description could fit many Wall Street firms. But the firm in question is Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. You can easily spot its architects, planners and interior designers. They're the ones dressed completely in black among all those navy blue and charcoal gray suits in the canyons of the financial district. 
 That Skidmore now does business from 14 Wall Street, on a crossroads it shares with the New York Stock Exchange and J. P. Morgan, is in one sense coincidental. (The firm just needed affordable space.) In another sense, it is an apt metaphor for the state of the profession at the moment. Like Wall Street, architecture is booming.
Five years ago, Skidmore had 200 employees in New York, down from a peak of 425 in 1988. The firm moved downtown last October into space designed for up to 325 employees. There are now 340.
Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, by some rankings the largest architectural firm in America, has doubled the size of its New York office since 1994, from 50 to 100 employees. So has Gensler, another national giant, whose New York office has grown from 169 to 334 employees in the past five years. The ranks at H L W International's New York office have risen from 215 to 310 in the same period.
Good fortune is also visiting small firms. Wendy Evans Joseph has watched her practice at 500 Park Avenue grow from one person in 1994 to six today. "I could have 20 people, there's so much work right now," she said. Her projects include a V-shaped, cable-stayed pedestrian bridge over East 63d Street for Rockefeller University and, in Dallas, the Women's Museum: An Institute for the Future.
Roberta Washington, too, has as much work as she can handle in her 10-person office at 271 West 125th Street. But she depends on government agencies and nonprofit institutions for jobs: a new station for the Franklin Avenue shuttle in Brooklyn, four clinics for the Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn, 27 homes in central Harlem, two schools in New Haven.
"I'm not the only black architect whose majority of work is public work," she said. "It goes back to the root of how potential clients select architects. A lot of it has to do with who you know."
"There are very few of us who can say we're benefiting from the boom," Ms. Washington said. "It would be great to participate and not just see it through the glass." Because salary levels have risen faster than fees, she cannot afford the extra staff she needs and so finds herself working longer hours.
To judge from help-wanted advertising, the demand for architects is greater than it has been in a decade. In July 1989, The New York Times ran an average of 42 ads for architectural positions in its Sunday classified section. In July 1994, with the real estate market in tatters, the average was 25 ads. Last month, it was 79.
Fueling the demand is the scarcity of experienced architects in their late 30's and early 40's. "There is a missing generation," said David M. Childs, the chairman designate of Skidmore. Despairing of their prospects earlier this decade, they either got out of architecture or never got into it.
"We were taking jobs that smaller firms would have taken," recalled A. Eugene Kohn, a founding principal of Kohn Pedersen Fox. "Smaller firms were taking jobs that new firms might have taken. And new people were saying, 'Forget it.' "
"Where did they go?" asked Walter A. Hunt Jr., a managing principal of Gensler. "Maybe they're running a bed-and-breakfast in Vermont. Maybe they're fishing." It is widely supposed that those embryonic architects wound up in other parts of the country or related fields like construction management and real estate development.
Their absence is keenly felt. "What's generally available is a zero- to 8-year experience level," said Carl W. Ordemann, the managing principal of the New York office of Perkins & Will. "Then there's a substantial gap in the 8- to 15-year level. Every office, across the board, is suffering from that gap. You can't do jobs as well without those people as part of the team."
The scarcity of experienced architects allows some of them to command salaries in the range of $60,000 to $70,000 -- a small fortune for architectural staffers.
"It's a good thing for the profession at one level," said Kenneth H. Drucker, director of design and senior principal at the New York office of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, "but at another level, the fees were lowered to remain competitive and they haven't rebounded. They've stayed low, salaries have risen and headhunters are pursuing your professional staff."
THOMAS BALSLEY, a landscape architect who designed Gantry Plaza State Park on the Queens waterfront, would not want to return to the old days. "If anyone complains about working weekends," he said, "I'll show them the help wanted ads from eight years ago."
Nonetheless, he noted that higher salaries and the cost of computer equipment and programs had pushed up operating costs. "We're not even close to being as profitable as we were in the 80's," Mr. Balsley said.
Adding to Mr. Balsley's concerns are signs that the Flatiron district, where he and many other architects have offices, may be growing too popular -- and too pricey. He would love to stay in 119 Fifth Avenue, at 19th Street, he said, but "with all the I.P.O. brats running around with million-dollar bills hanging out of their pockets, landlords won't even negotiate."
Costas Kondylis & Associates is preparing to leave 3 West 18th Street in October for new quarters at 31 West 27th Street.
Mr. Kondylis is designing Trump World Tower at the east end of 47th Street and Larry Silverstein's River Place complex at the west end of 42d Street. His office has grown from 28 to 64 people since 1994. "The rents in the Flatiron district have gone up," Mr. Kondylis said. "So the new area for architects is the West 20's."
Overall, however, the movement over time has been downtown. The highest concentration of membership in the American Institute of Architects is in ZIP code 10003 around Union Square, which takes in parts of Ladies' Mile, the Flatiron district, Greenwich Village and the East Village.
"More than 50 percent of our firms are now below Union Square," said Rolf Ohlhausen, the immediate past president of the New York chapter of the A.I.A.
Another area that architects are discovering is the financial district. Nearing the end of its lease in 600 Madison Avenue, at 58th Street, Pei Cobb Freed & Partners is scouting for new quarters and has cast its net as far downtown as Wall Street. "Many buildings that were considered Class B have been upgraded," said George H. Miller, the managing partner. "They present what we believe to be the best value in today's market for the architectural community."
Gensler, at 1 Rockefeller Plaza, has a "Wall Street studio" -- 25 people in 1 Liberty Plaza at Broadway and Liberty Street -- to serve financial institutions like J. P. Morgan and the Federal Reserve Bank.
Skidmore moved 10 months ago to the former Bankers Trust Company Building at Wall and Nassau Streets, a landmark completed in 1912 and expanded in 1933, topped by a stepped pyramid like the ancient Greek Mausoleum at Halicarnassus.
Skidmore is one of the largest firms in New York, if not the largest. And it probably has the highest public profile, with commissions that include the new Pennsylvania Station, the new International Air Terminal at Kennedy International Airport, the new New York Stock Exchange, the Columbus Centre complex at Columbus Circle that includes Time Warner headquarters, Bear Stearns headquarters on Madison Avenue and one of the new Times Square towers.
As its lease neared an end at the old Daily News Building, 220 East 42d Street, Skidmore began a search for new space. "Where we really wanted to be was the Hudson Street corridor or Ladies' Mile but there was nothing available in those two areas," said T. J. Gottesdiener, a partner.
The firm was in an awkward position. "We're not big enough to threaten the Mayor that we're going to move to New Jersey," Mr. Childs said, "but we're also not in the 3,000- to 4,000-square-foot range."
After looking as far afield as Long Island City, Queens, Mr. Gottesdiener settled on 14 Wall Street as meeting three key criteria: floors as large as possible (Skidmore has 72,000 square feet on three floors); a safe, convenient location and "rents we could sustain when the market turned" -- low $20's a square foot annually, compared with the high $20's on 42d Street.
In some ways, lower Manhattan is quite accessible. Subway lines converge there and city agencies are within walking distance. On the other hand, bulky architectural models have to be carted around much more, since clients in mid-Manhattan are less likely to visit the Skidmore office in person. "We spend more time shlepping than we did before," Mr. Childs allowed.
Those who do show up at the 24th floor of 14 Wall Street find a much different Skidmore office than the one on 42d Street, which affected a lavish corporate look, with a lobby paved in travertine and framed by colossal stainless steel columns.
Bare concrete floors run through the austere new space, with its plywood cubicles for design partners, spidery-looking Aeron chairs and a factory-like steel staircase linking display galleries that parallel the computer-filled drafting rooms.
"We wanted to create a laboratory to allow our practice to happen," said Roger F. Duffy Jr., a design partner. "We wanted our work to speak for itself."
Having settled into its new quarters, Skidmore shook itself up again in June when it named an outsider, both to the firm and the profession, as its first president.
Through a management recruiter, the partners found Kenneth C. Brown, 47, a corporate vice president of the General Electric Company and president of GE Southeast Asia, in Singapore. He holds a degree in mechanical engineering from Cornell and a degree in engineering science and economics from Oxford. He joined General Electric in 1992 after a career that included the Solar Energy Research Institute in Golden, Colo., and Price Waterhouse.
He is to manage business operations and assist the partners in strategic planning. "They still didn't feel as competent as they should be -- or even wanted to be -- in managing the business affairs of the firm," Mr. Brown said.
A limited liability partnership founded in 1936, Skidmore elected Mr. Childs its first chief executive in 1991, followed by Adrian D. Smith of Chicago and John H. Winkler of New York. Mr. Childs will assume the new position of chairman in October.
With worldwide revenues of $89 million in 1998, Skidmore ranked 10th among architects and architect-engineers in Engineering News-Record's list of top design firms. (Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum was first in the architectural field, with revenues of $295 million. It has 1,900 employees worldwide.)
"This is raw material waiting to be formed into a great new business proposition," Mr. Brown said. "I wouldn't mind being No. 1 or No. 2 in size of revenues, but my first goal is to make sure that we're No. 1 in terms of recognition, where anywhere in the world, when people think about taking on a complicated project, the first name that comes to mind is S.O.M."
"From every partner," Mr. Brown said, "I've heard three or four great ideas about new ways to leverage the influence of this firm." His goals include increasing profitability -- "It could be better but it's not dismal" -- and productivity.
"It doesn't have to be done in ax-and-saw fashion," he said. "Very clear definitions of customer requirements and diligent planning will cut out a lot of the rework and mistaken direction that sometimes occurs."
As a veteran of overseas operations, Mr. Brown would also like to see Skidmore fortify its international business, which accounted for 35 percent of revenues last year. While the firm is strong in Asia and the Middle East, it has much less of a presence in Western Europe and Latin America. "I don't see how you can call yourself global without seeing that, long term, half of your work is going to be outside the United States," he said.
To get a toehold in other markets, Skidmore might even acquire firms. "I don't think you ought to discard it as a possibility," Mr. Brown said.
Mergers and acquisitions may not exactly be sweeping the architectural profession, but there is at least one noteworthy prospective union this summer, as Alan Lapidus takes steps to ally his specialty hotel practice with Perkins & Will, which is itself under the umbrella of Dar Al-Handasah Consultants (Shair & Partners) of Cairo.
Mr. Lapidus, designer of the curvy, plum-colored Crowne Plaza in Times Square and the new Holiday Inn Wall Street District, carries on a family architectural tradition. His father, Morris, designed the swooping, jet-set-modern Fontainebleau in Miami Beach and the Americana in Manhattan, now the Sheraton New York.
The younger Mr. Lapidus said he hoped a merger would allow him to exploit his expertise in hotel planning by taking advantage of Perkins & Will's "horsepower."
"I needed a firm that does good construction documents and has a good design sense, where I could input all of my hotel knowledge," Mr. Lapidus said, "even if it meant not being glitzy, which would deprive me of my name of honor and make me a shame unto my father."
For Perkins & Will, the addition of the Lapidus team would "spread our footing" in the hotel field, Mr. Ordemann said.
Diversification is the name of the game, as firms try to devise strategies that will soften the blow when the market turns around again -- as it surely will.
"Our industry is so cyclical," said Belmont Freeman, who runs a six-architect practice at 110 West 40th Street. "On the upturns, you're able to accumulate money you use to pay off the debt that you accumulated in the bad times."
Last month, he hired an office manager and bookkeeper. "That's a significant turning point," he said. "We've gotten so busy that I ended up doing the administrative work while the other architects on my staff were doing the fun stuff."
Like principals in firms that are many times larger, Mr. Freeman is diversifying his practice. His jobs include a new seven-story apartment building on Eighth Street, east of Tompkins Square; the conversion of an East 73d Street town house into apartments; video and sound studios on lower Broadway; interior projects at three Columbia University graduate schools, and a residential compound in Langley, Va.
"I've got all the desks in my office filled for the first time," Mr. Freeman said. But that sight does not erase vivid memories of having one employee and subletting half his space. "Only as recently as last December did I take the gamble of renewing my lease for five years," he said. "My new worry is: one more job and I may have to expand."
 
A.I.A. Gets New Home, and New Goals
 Not long ago, many members of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects were scrambling to pay their own rent. Now, times are flush enough that they have raised $1.25 million among themselves to buy a large storefront space at 534 La Guardia Place, in Greenwich Village. They intend to raise $1.5 million more to turn it into a showplace headquarters that will help raise the chapter's profile.
"This is not just for architecture, this is for public engagement," said Walter A. Hunt Jr. of Gensler, the president of the chapter. The A.I.A. is a 142-year-old professional organization based in Washington. Its New York chapter represents nearly 70 percent of the registered architects in Manhattan.
 Wendy Evans Joseph, who will succeed Mr. Hunt in January, believes this is an opportune moment for architects to acknowledge their social responsibility. "Especially when times are good," she said, "we have to watch very carefully what we're doing and not just satisfy the client who pays us but the people who are not paying us; who are walking by, and under the shadows and living next door to what we're doing."
She suggested that architects could play a role in solving the public school construction crisis. "There is no excuse for bricks to be falling on kids' heads," Ms. Joseph said.
Rolf Ohlhausen, of Ohlhausen DuBois, the immediate past president, conceded that the chapter had "not always been really visible to the public or many of our members." The A.I.A. and its affiliate, the New York Foundation for Architecture, are tucked among furniture showrooms in the New York Design Center, 200 Lexington Avenue, between 32d and 33d Streets.
The 11,000-square-foot space on La Guardia Place, at street level and two floors below, will accommodate a gallery and meeting room. Mr. Hunt said there would be a design competition and that construction might begin next spring.
The move downtown was prompted in part by Mr. Ohlhausen's geographic study of A.I.A. membership, which is centered around Union Square in ZIP code 10003. The new headquarters will be immediately to the south in 10012, another architecturally populous ZIP code. "Most of us cannot afford midtown rents," Mr. Ohlhausen said. "The migration south has to do with economics and the rediscovery of older buildings." His own office is at 14 East Fourth Street, New York, N.Y. 10012.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 22, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page map on Aug. 8 showing the distribution of Manhattan members of the American Institute of Architects carried an incorrect color code for ZIP code 10029 -- roughly the area of Spanish Harlem. The area indeed houses at least one member -- Damiano G. Maruca, at 100 East 101st Street.
